PREFACE 
This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama. 
Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1982 Code, which embraced ordinances adopted through February 12, 1981 and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1982 Code, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE 	CD1:1 
CODE APPENDIX 	CDA:1 
CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES 	CCT:1 
STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE 	SLT:1 
CODE INDEX 	CDi:1 
 
Index 
The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes.

This publication was under the direct supervision of Roger D. Merriam, Senior Code Attorney, and John Welch, Code Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
The publisher is most grateful to the late Ms. Sylvia E. Garvin, Assistant City Attorney, Ms. Erin Dunagan, Assistant City Attorney, and Mr. Chuck Hagood, City Clerk-Treasurer, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs.

ADOPTING ORDINANCE 
ORDINANCE NO. 03-248 
AN ORDINANCE PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF THE 1982 CODE OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, COUNTY OF MADISON, STATE OF ALABAMA; PROVIDING FOR THE ADOPTION AND ENACTMENT OF A NEW CODE OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, COUNTY OF MADISON, STATE OF ALABAMA; PROVIDING FOR THE REPEAL OF CERTAIN ORDINANCES NOT INCLUDED THEREIN, EXCEPT AS HEREIN EXPRESSLY PROVIDED; PROVIDING FOR THE EFFECTIVE DATE OF SUCH CODE AND PENALTY FOR THE VIOLATION THEREOF; AND PROVIDING FOR THE MANNER OF AMENDING SUCH CODE; AND PROVIDING WHEN THIS ORDINANCE SHALL BECOME EFFECTIVE. 
WHEREAS, ON THE 27TH DAY OF MARCH, 2003, AT A REGULAR MEETING OF THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, ALABAMA, THE FOLLOWING RESOLUTION WAS ADOPTED: 
BE IT RESOLVED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, ALABAMA, AS FOLLOWS: 
"1.  That the City Council of the City of Huntsville proposes to repeal the 'Code of Ordinances, City of Huntsville, Alabama' adopted and approved on the 13th day of May, 1982, and to consider the adoption of a new revision and codification of its ordinances and the adoption of such Code by ordinance, as provided by Code of Alabama, 1975, Sections 11-45-7 and 11-45-8 and to adopt by reference as a part of such Code the following technical codes: Standard Unsafe Building Abatement Code, 1985 Edition; Standard Building Code, 1997 Edition; National Electrical Code, 1996 Edition; Standard Gas Code, 1997 Edition; NFPA Pamphlet Nos. 54 and 58; Standard Mechanical Code, 1997 Edition; Standard Housing Code, 1988 Edition; Standard Plumbing Code, 1997 Edition; Life Safety Code 101, 1997 Edition; Standard Fire and Prevention Code, 1994 Edition; National Fire Codes, 1998 Edition; and Alabama misdemeanor laws and Alabama traffic laws as provided in the Code of Alabama, 1975. The Council will hold a public hearing thereon at the regular meeting of the City Council to be held at the Council Chamber in the City Administration Building of Huntsville, Alabama, on the 24th day of April, 2003 at 6:00 P.M. Said Code shall be known as the 'Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama.' 
"2.  This resolution shall be published once a week for two (2) successive weeks in a newspaper of general circulation in the City of Huntsville, Alabama, as provided by the Code of Alabama, 1975, Sections 11-45-7 and 11-45-8, as amended, the first of which publications shall be made on or before the 9th day of April, 2003. A copy of this resolution and of said publications shall be carefully preserved by the City Clerk in his office as part of the public records of his office. 
"3.  Three (3) copies of said proposed Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, and of each said technical codes adopted in such Code shall be filed in the office of the City Clerk by the 28th day of March, 2003, for use and examination by the public from that date through the 24th day of April, 2003, as provided by Code of Alabama, 1975, Sections 11-45-7 and 11-45-8, as amended." 
ADOPTED this the 27th of March, 2003. 
	/s/ Sandra Moon 
      President of the City Council of 
      the City of Huntsville, Alabama 
 	 
APPROVED this the 27th day of March, 2003. 
	/s/ Loretta Spencer 
      Mayor of the City of 
      Huntsville, Alabama 
 	 
AND WHEREAS, THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, ALABAMA, NOW FINDS THAT SAID RESOLUTION HAS BEEN COMPLIED WITH. 
ACCORDINGLY, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE CITY COUNCIL OF THE CITY OF HUNTSVILLE, ALABAMA, AS FOLLOWS: 
Section 1. That the Code of Ordinances, consisting of Chapters 1 to 27, each inclusive, together with the codes mentioned in said resolution, is hereby adopted and enacted as the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama." Such Code shall be treated and considered as a new and original comprehensive ordinance which shall supersede all other general and permanent ordinances passed by the City Council on or before the 14th day of November, 2002, to the extent provided in Section 2 hereof. 
Section 2. That all provisions of such Code shall be in full force and effect from and after the 24th day of April, 2003, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before the 14th day of November, 2002, and not included in such Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein are hereby repealed from and after the 24th day of April, 2003, except as hereinafter provided. No resolution of the City, not specifically mentioned, is hereby repealed. 
Section 3. That the repeal provided for in Section 2 hereof shall not affect any of the following: 
(a)  Any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of such Code; 
(b)  Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the City or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness; 
(c)  Any contract or obligation assumed by the City; 
(d)  Any ordinance prescribing zoning or subdivision regulations, or zoning of particular property; 
(e)  Any right or franchise granted by the City; 
(f)  Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, opening, widening, paving, etc., any street or public way in the City; 
(g)  Any appropriation ordinance, or ordinance levying or imposing any tax; 
(h)  Any ordinance which, by its own terms, is effective only for a stated or limited time; 
(i)  Any ordinance providing for local improvements and assessing or appropriating taxes therefor; 
(j)  Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any subdivision plat; 
(k)  Any ordinance or resolution not in conflict with such Code regulating traffic on specific streets or portions thereof or in specific areas of the City; 
(l)  Any ordinance enacted after the 14th day of November, 2002. 
Section 4. That whenever in this Ordinance or such Code an act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in this Ordinance or such Code the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, and no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision shall be punishable by a fine of not less than one dollar ($1) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500); and in addition may be punishable by imprisonment or hard labor for the City, or a combination thereof, for a period not exceeding six (6) months, as is provided by Section 1-7 of such Code. 
Section 5. That any and all additions and amendments to such Code, when passed in such form as to indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part thereof, shall be deemed to be incorporated in such Code so that reference to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, shall be understood and intended to include such additions and amendments. 
Section 6. That in case of the amendment of any section of such Code for which a penalty is not provided, the general penalty as provided in Section 4 of this Ordinance and Section 1-7 of such Code shall apply to the section as amended; or in case such amendment contains provisions for which a penalty, other than the aforementioned general penalty, is provided in another section in the same chapter, the penalty so provided in such other section shall be held to relate to the section so amended, unless such penalty is specifically repealed therein. 
Section 7. That a copy of such Code shall be kept on file in the office of the City Clerk preserved in loose-leaf form or in such other form as the City Council may consider most expedient. It shall be the express duty of the City Clerk or someone authorized by the Clerk to insert in their designated places all amendments or ordinances which indicate the intention of the City Council to make the same a part of such Code when the same have been printed or reprinted in page form, and to extract from such Code all provisions which may be from time to time repealed by the City Council. A copy of such Code shall be available for all persons desiring to examine the same. 
Section 8. That it shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portions of the Code, or to insert or delete pages or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the City of Huntsville to be misrepresented thereby. Any person violating this section shall be punished as provided in Section 4 of this Ordinance. 
Section 9. That all ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict herewith are, to the extent of such conflict, hereby repealed. 
Section 10. This Ordinance shall become in full force and effect in accordance with the law of Alabama. 
Section 11. This Ordinance shall take effect as provided by law after passage, approval and publication. 
ADOPTED this the 24th day of April, 2003. 
	/s/ Sandra Moon 
      President of the City Council of 
      the City of Huntsville, Alabama 
 	 
APPROVED this the 24th day of April, 2003. 
	/s/ Loretta Spencer 
      Mayor of the City of 
      Huntsville, Alabama 
 	 
 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
 
Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters shall constitute and be designated the "Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama," and may be so cited. 
(Code 1982, § 1-1) 
State Law reference— Codification of ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-7.  
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
The following definitions and rules of construction shall apply to this Code and to all ordinances unless the context or the terms of the provision require otherwise: 
Generally. When provisions conflict, the specific shall prevail over the general. All provisions shall be liberally construed so that the intent of the city council may be effectuated. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words, technical phrases and words and phrases that have acquired peculiar and appropriate meanings in law shall be construed according to such meanings. Provisions shall be interpreted and applied so as to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. In the event of conflicts between provisions, the more stringent provision controls. It is intended that no provision of this Code conflict with any federal or state law intended to preempt municipal jurisdiction with respect to the subject matter contained in this Code; and the provisions of this Code shall be construed, whenever possible, to avoid such conflict. 
Acts. References to acts are to acts of the Alabama Legislature, as published in the Acts of Alabama. Acts passed after 1978 are referenced to the act number, which number includes the last two digits of the year of enactment. All other acts are referenced to act number and year of enactment. All references to acts are followed by a parenthetical reference to the page number in the Acts of Alabama upon which the act begins. The page number reference is for information purposes only. All references to acts are to such acts as amended. 
Bond. When a bond is required, an undertaking in writing shall be required. 
City. The term "city" means the City of Huntsville, Alabama. 
City council. The terms "city council" and "council" mean the City Council of the City of Huntsville, Alabama. 
Clerk and treasurer. The terms "city clerk" and "city treasurer" refer to the clerk-treasurer of the city. 
Code. The term "Code" means the Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, as designated in section 1-1. 
Code of Ala. 1975. The abbreviation "Code of Ala. 1975" means the Code of Alabama, 1975, as now or hereafter amended. Any reference to an act found in the Code of Alabama, 1975, by short title is a reference to such act as amended. 
Computation of time. In computing any period of time, the day of the act, event or default from which the designated period of time begins to run shall not be included. The last day of the period so designated shall be included, unless it is a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day that is not a Saturday, a Sunday or a legal holiday. When the period of time prescribed or allowed is less than seven days, intermediate Saturdays, Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. 
Conjunctions. In a provision involving two or more items, conditions, provisions or events, which items, conditions, provisions or events are connected by the conjunction "and," "or" or "either…or," the conjunction shall be interpreted as follows: 
(1)  "And" indicates that all the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply. 
(2)  "Or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly or in any combination. 
(3)  "Either…or" indicates that the connected terms, conditions, provisions or events apply singly but not in combination. 
Corporate limits. The term "corporate limits" means the corporate limits of the city. 
County. The term "county" means Madison County, Alabama; Limestone County, Alabama; or any other county in which the city may be located, as appropriate. 
Delegation of authority. A provision that authorizes or requires a city officer or city employee to perform an act or make a decision authorizes such officer or employee to act or make a decision through subordinates. 
Gender. Words of one gender include all other genders and also include firms, partnerships, corporations and other legal entities, as appropriate. 
Health department, board of health and health officer. References to the health department are to the county health department or any of its designees. References to the board of health are to the county board of health or any of its designees. References to the health officer are to the county health officer or any of his designees. 
Includes. The term "includes" does not limit a term to a specified example. 
Joint authority. Words giving a joint authority to three or more persons give such authority to a majority of such persons. 
May. The term "may" is to be construed as being permissive and not mandatory. 
Month. The term "month" means a calendar month. 
Number. Words in the singular include the plural. Words in the plural include the singular. 
Oath. A solemn affirmation is the equivalent to an oath, and a person shall be deemed to have sworn if such person makes such an affirmation. 
Officers, departments, etc. References to officers, departments, boards, commissions or employees are to city officers, city departments, city boards, city commissions and city employees. 
Owner. The term "owner," as applied to property, includes any part owner, joint owner, sole tenant, tenant in partnership, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or part of such property. 
Person. The term "person" means any human being, any governmental or political subdivision or public agency, any public or private corporation, any partnership, any firm, association or other organization, any receiver, trustee, assignee, agent, or other legal representative of any of the foregoing or any other legal entity. 
Personal property. The term "personal property" means any property other than real property. 
Preceding, following. The terms "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
Premises. The term "premises," as applied to real property, includes land and structures. 
Property. The term "property" includes real property, personal property and mixed property. 
Real property. The term "real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
Shall. The term "shall" is to be construed as being mandatory. 
Sidewalk. The term "sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curbline or the lateral lines of the roadway and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians. 
Signature and subscription by mark. The terms "signature" and "subscription" include a mark when the person cannot write if his name is written near the mark and witnessed by a person who writes his own name as a witness. 
State. The term "state" means the State of Alabama. 
Street. The term "street" includes any public way, road, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, bridge, viaduct, trestle and the approaches to any bridge, viaduct or trestle within the city. 
Tenant and occupant. The terms "tenant" and "occupant," as applied to premises, include any person holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part of such premises, alone or with others. 
Tenses. The present tense includes the past and future tenses. The future tense includes the present tense. 
Week. The term "week" means a period of seven consecutive days. 
Writing. The term "writing" includes any form of recorded message capable of comprehension by ordinary visual means. 
Year. The term "year" means a calendar year. 
(Code 1982, §§ 1-2, 1-9) 
State Law reference— Similar rules of statutory construction, Code of Ala. 1975, § 1-1-1 et seq.  
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections; history notes; references. 
(a)  The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and are not titles of such sections, or of any part of the section, nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any such section, including the catchline, is amended or reenacted. 
(b)  History notes, cross references and state law references that appear in this Code after sections or subsections or that otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of the Code and have no legal effect. 
(c)  Unless specified otherwise, all references to chapters or sections are to chapters or sections of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-3) 
State Law reference— Similar rules of statutory construction, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 1-1-14, 1-1-15.  
Sec. 1-4. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  Unless specifically provided otherwise, the repeal of an ordinance does not revive any previously repealed ordinance. 
(b)  The repeal or amendment of an ordinance does not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor does such repeal or amendment affect any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the amendment or repeal. 
(Code 1982, § 1-4)  
Sec. 1-5. - Amendments to Code; effect of new ordinances; amendatory language. 
(a)  All ordinances adopted subsequent to this Code that amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of the Code and printed for inclusion in the Code. Portions of this Code repealed by subsequent ordinances may be excluded from this Code by omission from affected reprinted pages. 
(b)  Amendments to provisions of this Code may be made with the following language: "Section (chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, is hereby amended to read as follows:…." The section (chapter, article, division, or subdivision) should be set out in full. 
(c)  If a new section, subdivision, division, article or chapter is to be added to the Code, the following language may be used: "Section (chapter, article, division or subdivision, as appropriate) of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, is hereby created to read as follows:…." The section (chapter, article, division, or subdivision) should be set out in full. 
(d)  All provisions desired to be repealed should be repealed specifically by section, subdivision, division, article or chapter number, as appropriate, or by setting out the repealed provisions in full in the repealing ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 1-6)  
Sec. 1-6. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  Supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city. A supplement to this Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of the supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete. The new pages shall be so prepared that when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In preparing a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code that have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by their omission from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the person authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as necessary to do so in order to embody them into a unified code. For example, the person may: 
(1)  Arrange the material into appropriate organizational units. 
(2)  Supply appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be included in the Code and make changes in any such catchlines, headings and titles or in any such catchlines, headings and titles already in the Code. 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions and sections to be added to this Code. 
(4)  Where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing numbers assigned to chapters, articles, divisions, subdivisions or sections. 
(5)  Change the words "this ordinance" or similar words to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," "this subdivision," "this section" or "sections _____ to _____" (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code that embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated in this Code). 
(6)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of the ordinances inserted in this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-7)  
Sec. 1-7. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
(a)  In this section the term "violation of this Code" means any of the following: 
(1)  Doing an act that is prohibited or made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(2)  Failure to perform an act that is required to be performed by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(3)  Failure to perform an act if the failure is prohibited or is made or declared unlawful, an offense, a violation or a misdemeanor by ordinance or by rule or regulation authorized by ordinance. 
(b)  In this section, the term "violation of this Code" does not include the failure of a city officer or city employee to perform an official duty unless it is specifically provided that the failure to perform the duty is to be punished as provided in this section. 
(c)  A person convicted of a violation of this Code shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00, or by imprisonment in the city jail or hard labor for a period not exceeding six months, or by any combination thereof, except: 
(1)  When in the enforcement of Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191 or 32-5A-191.3, such penalty shall not exceed the fines and sentences of imprisonment or hard labor as provided by state law; 
(2)  When a provision of this Code provides a particular penalty expressly applicable to certain violations, the express penalty shall be the penalty imposed upon conviction for those certain violations; or 
(3)  For violations of chapter 7, article V, pertaining to minimum housing standards; chapter 7, article VII, pertaining to the unsafe building abatement code; chapter 7, article VI, pertaining to nonresidential building maintenance standards; chapter 12, article IV, pertaining to junk, litter and inoperable vehicles; chapter 27, article III, pertaining to weeds and overgrown grass; section 17-6, pertaining to graffiti; section 22-35, pertaining to refrigerators and similar containers; section 17-5, pertaining to unattended receptacles; and chapter 7, article II, pertaining to administration and enforcement of building regulations, and article III, pertaining to building contractors, the following penalty shall be imposed: 
a.  Over a 24-month period, upon first conviction, a fine of not less than $100.00 or more than $500.00, or imprisonment for not more than ten days. 
b.  Upon a second conviction, a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
c.  Upon a third or subsequent conviction, a fine of not less than $500.00 and imprisonment in jail for a period not to exceed six months. Such sentence shall include a mandatory sentence of not less than two days in jail, which shall not be subject to suspension or probation. 
(d)  Notwithstanding the provisions of subsection (c) of this section, the penalty imposed upon a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, with respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, with respect to violations that are not continuous with respect to time, each act constitutes a separate offense. 
(f)  The imposition of a penalty does not prevent suspension or revocation of a license, permit or franchise or other administrative sanctions. 
(g)  Violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time are a public nuisance and may be abated by injunctive or other equitable relief. The imposition of a penalty does not prevent injunctive relief. 
(Code 1982, §§ 1-6, 1-7) 
State Law reference— Limitations on penalties, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Sec. 1-8. - Severability. 
The sections, subsections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code and all provisions adopted by reference in this Code are severable so that if any section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code or of any provision adopted by reference in this Code is declared unconstitutional or invalid by a valid judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, such judgment shall not affect the validity of any other section, subsection, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase of this Code or of any provision adopted by reference in this Code; for the council declares that it is its intent that it would have enacted this Code and all provisions adopted by reference in this Code without such invalid or unconstitutional provisions. 
(Code 1982, § 1-10)  
Sec. 1-9. - Provisions deemed continuation of existing ordinances. 
The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are substantially the same as legislation previously adopted by the city relating to the same subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations and not as new enactments. 
(Code 1982, § 1-8)  
Sec. 1-10. - Code does not affect prior offenses or rights. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects any offense or act committed or done, any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code does not authorize any use or the continuation of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any city ordinance on the effective date of this Code. 
(Code 1982, § 1-4)  
Sec. 1-11. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of the following ordinances or portion of ordinances. Such ordinances or portions of ordinances continue in full force and effect to the same extent as if published at length in this Code: 
(1)  That is an administrative or personnel ordinance, not mentioned in this Code or inconsistent with this Code. 
(2)  Annexing property into the city. 
(3)  Deannexing property or excluding property from the city. 
(4)  Describing the boundaries of the city. 
(5)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance, sale or security of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness. 
(6)  Authorizing or approving any contract, deed or agreement. 
(7)  Making or approving any appropriation or budget. 
(8)  Granting any right or franchise. 
(9)  Providing for salaries, benefits, or terms or conditions of employment of city officers or employees codified in this Code, or creating or amending any department, division or other agency of city government, or any employment classification or position, whether elected or appointed, not codified in this Code. 
(10)  Creating or amending the powers of an authority, board or commission not codified in this Code. 
(11)  Making appointments to positions, offices or boards. 
(12)  Calling or ordering an election. 
(13)  Adopting or amending the comprehensive plan. 
(14)  Providing for local improvements or levying or imposing any special assessment. 
(15)  Dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street. 
(16)  Establishing the grade of any street or sidewalk. 
(17)  Dedicating, accepting or vacating any plat or subdivision, or prescribing or accepting subdivision regulations. 
(18)  Levying or imposing taxes not codified in this Code. 
(19)  Providing traffic or parking regulations for specific locations or routing buses in a manner not inconsistent with this Code. 
(20)  Pertaining to zoning, including but not limited to the basic zoning ordinance and its amendments and ordinances rezoning specific property. 
(21)  That is temporary, although general in effect. 
(22)  That is special, although permanent in effect. 
(23)  The purpose of which has been accomplished.  
Sec. 1-12. - Resolutions not affected by Code. 
Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code affects the validity of any resolution not mentioned in this Code and not inconsistent with this Code.  
Sec. 1-13. - Official holidays. 
The official holidays of the city are declared as follows: 
New Year's Day. 
Martin Luther King's Birthday (as nationally observed). 
Memorial Day. 
Independence Day. 
Labor Day. 
Veterans' Day. 
Thanksgiving Day. 
Christmas Day. 
Two floating holidays granted at the discretion of the mayor. 
A third floating holiday taken at the discretion of the employee with the approval of the department head. 
(Ord. No. 86-30, § 1, 2-20-1986)  
Sec. 1-14. - Fiscal year. 
The fiscal year of the city shall begin on October 1 and end on September 30 of each year.  
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance authorizing or approving any contract, deed or agreement saved from repeal, § 1-11(6); any ordinance providing for salaries, benefits, or terms or conditions of employment of city officers or employees codified in this Code, or creating or amending any department, division or other agency of city government, or any employment classification or position, whether elected or appointed, not codified in this Code saved from repeal, § 1-11(9); any ordinance calling or ordering an election saved from repeal, § 1-11(12); administration and enforcement of buildings and building regulations, § 7-41 et seq.; administration and enforcement of minimum housing standards regulations, § 7-341 et seq.; administration and enforcement of nonresidential building maintenance standards regulations, § 7-491 et seq.; municipal court, ch. 16; taxation, ch. 24; administrative review and appeals procedures for taxation, § 24-31 et seq.; administration and enforcement for traffic and vehicles regulations, § 25-41 et seq.; utilities, ch. 26; administration and enforcement of amendments, permits and variances for zoning regulations, app. A, § 91.1 et seq. 
State Law reference— Municipalities generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-40-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 2-1. - Issuance of summons and complaints to appear in municipal court in lieu of arrest. 
(a)  Whenever an officer of the police department has made an arrest of a person without a warrant for violation of any class C misdemeanor or any violation of a city ordinance not involving violence, threat of violence, alcohol or drugs, except for traffic offenses which are otherwise provided by law, such officer may issue a summons and complaint (citation) to such person to appear in the municipal court of the city at a time and place certain to answer the charge. Each such summons and complaint shall contain a written promise to appear at the designated time and place as evidenced by the defendant's signature on the summons and complaint. If any person refuses to give a written recognizance to appear by placing his signature on the summons and complaint, the officer shall take such person into custody and bring him before any officer or official who is authorized to approve bond. 
(b)  Whenever a city magistrate or municipal judge is presented with probable cause sufficient to authorize the issuance of an arrest warrant for a violation occurring within the city of a class C misdemeanor or any violation of a city ordinance not involving violence, threat of violence, alcohol or drugs, the magistrate or judge may, in his discretion, elect to issue a summons and complaint ordering the accused to appear in the municipal court at a date and time certain to answer the charge against him. 
(c)  Any city employee who is designated a code enforcement officer by the department head of the city departments and divisions listed in this subsection, and any inspector or enforcement officer of the county health department, when acting as an enforcement officer of any health or sanitation ordinance of the city with respect to a violation occurring within the city, is authorized to issue a summons and complaint to persons found by him to be in violation of the particular ordinance, code, or codes enforced by the employee's department or division. This summons and complaint shall order such person to appear in municipal court at a date and time certain to answer the charge against him. The applicable departments or divisions are as follows: 
(1)  Animal control. 
(2)  Inspection. 
(3)  City clerk-treasurer. 
(4)  Community development. 
(5)  Engineering. 
(6)  Fire. 
(7)  Public works. 
(8)  Natural resources and environmental management. 
(9)  Madison County health department. 
(d)  Each summons shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  State the name of the court. 
(3)  State the name of the accused. 
(4)  State the address of the accused, if known. 
(5)  State a description of the offense charged, including the ordinance number. 
(6)  State the date, time and place of the offense. 
(7)  Set forth the date and time the accused is to appear in municipal court. 
(8)  Set forth the address of the municipal court. 
(9)  Be signed by the officer issuing or serving the citation. 
(10)  State an explanation to the person cited of the ways in which he may settle his case. 
(11)  Set forth a warning in bold type that willful failure to appear as directed is a misdemeanor and that a warrant for failure to appear will be issued in such an event. 
(e)  A summons delivered to or served upon a person accused of committing an offense in violation of a city ordinance shall place a duty upon such person to appear in municipal court at the time and date indicated, and it shall be unlawful for any such person to fail to appear as directed in such citation or summons. Failure to appear at the time and date directed shall be prima facie evidence of a willful failure to appear, and the court may cause a warrant to be issued for the accused on a failure to appear charge. 
(Ord. No. 93-275, §§ 1—5, 5-13-1993) 
State Law reference— Issuance of summons and citation in lieu of arrest, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.1.  
Sec. 2-2. - Powers of police officers. 
Police officers of the city shall, in addition to any other powers enumerated in this Code and in other applicable municipal or state laws, have the power to enforce, by arrest or citation, as appropriate, any violation of this Code, including but not limited to codes adopted by reference in accordance with section 11-45-8(c) of the Code of Ala. 1975. 
(Ord. No. 05-530, § 1, 6-23-2005)  
Secs. 2-3—2-30. - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - CITY COUNCIL[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Municipal councils generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-40 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-61. - Organization meeting. 
On the first Monday in November after each municipal election, the mayor, or mayor-elect, and members, and/or members-elect, of the city council shall meet in the city council chambers at the city hall at 5:00 p.m., unless another place is designated, to take and subscribe the oath of office; to elect officers of the city council; and to further organize the council. The city clerk-treasurer shall preside at the organization meeting until election of a president of the council as provided in section 2-63. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-12, 11-22-1994) 
State Law reference— Organizational meeting, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-44.  
Sec. 2-62. - Oath of office. 
When assembled as provided in section 2-61, the mayor and each member of the city council shall take and subscribe the oath of office prescribed by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-13, 11-22-1994) 
State Law reference— Oath, Code of Ala. 1975, § 36-4-6.  
Sec. 2-63. - Election of officers. 
(a)  Following the oath of office, the members of the city council shall elect, by a majority vote of the council membership, a president, a president pro tempore, and a third presiding officer from among their number. If no member receives a majority of votes for the office of president, a vote shall be taken for the office of president pro tempore. The member receiving a majority of votes for the office of president pro tempore shall preside and serve as president until such time as a president is elected. After a vote is taken for the office of president pro tempore, a vote shall be taken for the office of third presiding officer. 
(b)  Nominations for each office shall be taken by the presiding officer, with no second required. After nominations have been closed, the vote shall be taken in the same order as nominations were made until a nominee receives a majority vote of the council membership. All votes for officers shall be by roll call vote, with the yeas and nays recorded and reported by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(c)  At the first regular council meeting in October of each year (except for years in which there is a municipal election), the council shall elect new officers and reorganize the council for the coming year. The presiding officer shall declare all offices and committee assignments vacant and shall yield the chair to the city clerk-treasurer to preside until election of a president or president pro tempore. The rules of procedure for electing officers and organizing the council shall be the same as those to elect officers and organize the council after a municipal election. Officers may succeed themselves. All committee appointments and assignments shall continue and remain in effect until the first regular meeting of the council in each October, and thereafter until their respective successors are appointed or assigned. 
(d)  At any regular meeting of the city council, upon motion duly made and seconded, the city council may elect to call for a special reorganization meeting, provided such motion to reorganize is approved by a vote of two-thirds of the council membership. If the city council approves the motion to reorganize, it shall conduct a special organization meeting at the end of the meeting where such motion to reorganize is approved. At such meeting, a vote of the majority of the council shall prevail. The procedures for reorganization, shall be the same as those procedures for election of officers and reorganization provided in subsection (c) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-14, 11-22-1994) 
State Law reference— Election of council president, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-40; election of president pro tem, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-49.  
Sec. 2-64. - Number of meetings required; special meetings. 
As soon as the president, president pro tempore, and third presiding officer have been elected, the city council shall then be considered as organized for the transaction of business of the city council. After the organization meeting, the city council shall meet at least twice each month for the transaction of the business of the city and shall meet more often if required by the president of the council. Special meetings shall be called as provided in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-50 and according to the following provisions: 
(1)  The president of the city council may call for a special meeting. 
(2)  The mayor may request the president of the council to call a special meeting. Such request shall be in writing and shall state the purpose and time of the special meeting. Such request shall be signed by the mayor. 
(3)  Two members of the city council may request the president of the council to call a special meeting. Such request shall be in writing and shall state the purpose and time of the special meeting. Such request shall be signed by the councilmembers making the request. 
(4)  If the president of the council refuses to call a special meeting at the request of the mayor or two councilmembers, the president of the council shall notify the mayor or the two councilmembers of the denial of the request. After such notification, or if the president fails to notify the mayor or the two councilmembers within 24 hours of the request, the mayor or the two councilmembers making the request may then call for a special meeting. 
(5)  No special meeting shall be called less than 24 hours before the commencement time of such special meeting. Notice of such meeting will be given to the news media by electronic facsimile transmission, the city hall television channel, and any additional proper methods to notify the news media or public whenever there is a special session called. Such notice shall state the time, place, and purpose of such meeting. The 24-hour notice provision of this subsection shall not apply if a special meeting is required to address an emergency situation which might result in danger to the public health or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-15, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 99-607, 7-22-1999) 
State Law reference— Number of regular meetings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-50.  
Sec. 2-65. - Time of meetings. 
(a)  (1)  Until otherwise provided for, the city council shall meet for business on the second and fourth Thursdays in each month, and continue from day to day until the business is finished. The meeting shall commence at 6:00 p.m. in the official chambers of the city council or at any other place designated by the council from time to time. 
(2)  During the weeks when the second of fourth Thursday falls on the same night as the annual United Negro College Fund Banquet or the Chamber of Commerce Annual Meeting, the city council shall meet for business on the preceding Tuesday. 
(b)  The council shall meet for informal work sessions on the first and third Thursdays of each month. The meetings shall commence at 6:00 p.m. in the city council conference room on the seventh floor of the municipal building or at any other place and time designated and agreed to from time to time by the council. If there is a fifth Thursday in any month, no work session shall be held unless approved by a majority vote of the council membership taken no later than at the regular meeting of the council scheduled for the fourth Thursday of the month. 
(c)  In the event it becomes necessary to change the date of any regularly scheduled business meeting or work session, the council shall procure an advertisement in the Huntsville Times of a size at least two inches high by two high wide, which shall provide notice of the rescheduled meeting date. It is the intention of the of these by-laws that the advertisement be scheduled to appear in the Huntsville Times on the day preceding the date of the rescheduled council meeting. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-16, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 96-869, 11-14-1996; Ord. No. 05-251, 4-28-2005) 
State Law reference— Duty of council to determine time and place of its meetings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-49.  
Sec. 2-66. - Duties and responsibilities of council president. 
(a)  Supervisory capacity. 
(1)  The president of the council shall act as the department head to coordinate the council office staff and operations of the office; except that any personnel matter regarding the hiring of or disciplinary action involving a member of the council office staff shall be approved by a majority of the members of the city council. The administrative aide to the council shall perform the supervisory responsibilities authorized under sections 2.2(E) and 11 of the personnel policies and procedures manual which include but are not limited to assigning and directing the work of and evaluating the performance of the city council secretarial employees. 
(2)  At the appropriate time each year, the council president shall solicit from each councilmember an annual performance evaluation of the administrative aide to the council. The council president shall consider the administrative aide's performance evaluations submitted by each councilmember, including his own, in preparing the final performance evaluation of the administrative aide. A copy of each councilmember's evaluation shall be attached to the annual performance evaluation prepared by the council president. 
(b)  Representation at functions. The president of the council shall represent the council at official and civic functions as requested. If the president is not able to attend, the president pro tempore shall attend in the president's place as representative of the council. If both the president and president pro tempore are unable to attend, other councilmembers shall be contacted, in order of seniority if possible, until a replacement representative is available. 
(c)  Approval of documents. The president of the council shall sign and approve all documents and have all responsibility and authority as required of department heads of other city departments. In the case of purchase requisitions and expenditures by councilmembers, a simple majority vote of the council membership may override an approval or disapproval by the council president. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-18, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 96-693, 9-26-1996; Ord. No. 97-857, 11-20-1997)  
Sec. 2-67. - City council committee election; city council committee, board and commission appointments and assignments. 
(a)  At the first regular meeting after any city council reorganization meeting, the city council will elect members of the committees, commissions and boards as may be required by state law or properly adopted city ordinance or resolution. The standard nominating and voting procedure for election to council offices will be followed. A majority vote of the council membership shall be required for approval. Specifically, without excluding any other applicable committee, board or commission, the council shall elect the following: 
(1)  A member of the council shall be elected by the council to serve as its representative to the city planning commission. To facilitate coordination, the same member may serve as the council's representative to the metropolitan planning organization or in the alternative, another councilmember may be elected to serve as the council's representative to the metropolitan planning organization. 
(2)  A member of the council shall be elected by the council to serve as its representative to the research park board. 
(3)  A member of the council shall be elected by the council to serve as its representative to the historic preservation commission. 
(4)  The council, from time to time, shall elect other members as representatives as may be required. 
(b)  The council president shall make appointments and assignments of councilmembers and others to represent the president and council on the following boards, committees and commissions. The president of the council shall not serve on any of the committees. 
(1)  Top of Alabama Council of Governments (TARCOG), two appointments—councilmembers. 
(2)  Community Action Agency of Huntsville/Madison and Limestone Counties, Inc., one appointment—general appointment. 
(3)  Huntsville/Madison County Clean Community Systems, one appointment—councilmember. 
(4)  Advisory Commission on Accessibility, one appointment—councilmember. 
(5)  City of Huntsville Insurance Committee, two appointments—councilmembers. 
(6)  Board appointment representative, one appointment—councilmember. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-19, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 97-718, 10-9-1997; Ord. No. 16-891 , § 1, 12-1-2016) 
State Law reference— Council to prescribe powers and duties of officers it selects by ordinance, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-47.  
Sec. 2-68. - Organization and appointment of finance committee. 
At the first regular meeting of the council following the organization meeting, the president of the council shall appoint one member of the council as chairman of the finance committee and one other member of the council as vice-chairman of the finance committee. The president of the council shall not serve on the finance committee. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-20, 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-69. - Composition and duties of the finance committee. 
(a)  The chairman of the finance committee shall appoint any other members to the committee he deems necessary to fulfill the responsibilities of the committee, but the committee shall have not more than five members. The finance committee shall have the following duties: 
(1)  Supervision of revenue and income. The finance committee shall have in their charge and under their supervision all revenues and income of the city arising from all and every source whatsoever from which the city may derive any revenue whatsoever. 
(2)  Examination of accounts and transactions. The finance committee shall examine all the accounts and transactions of every officer of the city who has the power and whose duty it is to collect or receive any money coming from any and all sources of revenue. 
(3)  Duties of committee on examination of accounts and transactions; report to council. The finance committee, upon investigation of the accounts and transactions of any officer, shall examine all the receipts and vouchers for the payment of the money received by such officer; show how much he has paid; to whom paid and when paid; and the purpose of the payment, and thus show if such officer has faithfully paid over all the money received and make report to the next council meeting showing these facts. They shall ascertain from all sources of information whether or not there is any money still due to the city and uncollected and from whom and on what account due. 
(b)  Any question regarding finances shall be directed by the council to the finance committee for a recommendation or a report to the council. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-21, 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-70. - Amendment of bylaws. 
This article may be amended by a two-thirds vote of the council membership. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-22, 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-71. - Applicability of state law. 
Anything not specifically provided in this article shall be governed by Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 11, ch. 43 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-1 et seq.) or other class 3 or pertinent general legislation. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-23, 11-22-1994)  
Secs. 2-72—2-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - COUNCIL RULES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Council to determine the rules of its own proceedings, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-52. 
 
Sec. 2-91. - Scope. 
For the orderly transaction of the public business, the provisions of this division are adopted for the government of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17, 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-92. - Rule 1. Agenda. 
(a)  The president of the city council shall establish and make public an agenda prior to any meeting of the council. No item for which paperwork has not been submitted to the city council by 5:00 p.m. on Tuesday prior to the scheduled meeting thereof shall be considered by the city council at such meeting unless four council members have provided verbal or written consent to the council president for such consideration. The provisions of this subsection shall apply to work sessions as well as regular sessions of the city council. The agenda for any special meeting will be established at the time of notice of such special meeting. 
(b)  Each item submitted must be sponsored by a member of the council or the mayor. An item of administrative nature may be submitted by a department, board or agency of the city administration or by city utilities if that item relates directly to the business of the department. Department items must be submitted through the mayor. Each item submitted must be identified with the sponsor's name. The president of the city council may delete any item not properly submitted. Items not on the official agenda established by the president may be added for consideration, by a councilmember or the mayor, at the end of the established agenda only upon the approval by a two-thirds vote of the council membership, provided the president or presiding officer states the title of any non-agenda item that will be offered for consideration or action during the time of the regular council business meeting for "Announcements" as provided in section 2-97(4)d of this article. Likewise, any item on the printed agenda for which unanimous consent of all council members present is either requested or required may be considered for action by the council only if the president or presiding officer states the title of the item or items during the time of the regular council business meeting for "Announcements." Items can be offered for introduction only, at any time during a regular council business meeting. A change in the order of agenda items may be made by the president or by request of a simple majority of the council membership. 
(c)  An item established on the printed agenda may be removed or postponed by the sponsor without approval of the city council. The sponsor may remove or postpone the item when it is called at the meeting, or, if the sponsor will not be present at the meeting, he may submit a written request to remove or postpone the item to the appropriate presiding officer prior to the meeting. Otherwise, once an item is established on the printed agenda, it may be postponed only upon an affirmative vote of a majority of the council membership. This rule shall not preclude more than one councilmember from sponsoring the same item. 
(d)  The city council shall maintain a log in the city council office of all honorary citizenships extended by the city which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name of the sponsoring councilmember; 
(2)  A general statement as to the reason for the honorary citizenship; 
(3)  The date of the honorary citizenship; and 
(4)  A listing of councilmembers who signed the honorary citizenship. 
At the next regular council meeting following the date of the honorary citizenship, the names of the honorees shall be read into the minutes of the city council by the president. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 1), 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 95-768, 10-30-1995; Ord. No. 99-324, 4-8-1999; Ord. No. 01-903, 11-8-2001; Ord. No. 07-604, § 1, 6-28-2007)  
Sec. 2-93. - Rule 2. Call to order. 
At the appointed hour, the president of the city council shall take the chair, call the council to order and if a quorum is present, proceed to business. Those members present and absent will be noted in the minutes of the meeting. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 2), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-94. - Rule 3. Quorum. 
A majority of the council membership shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 3), 11-22-1994) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-48.  
Sec. 2-95. - Rule 4. President pro tempore. 
If the president shall be absent, the president pro tempore shall act as president. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 4), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-96. - Rule 5. Third presiding officer. 
If the president and the president pro tempore shall be absent, the third presiding officer shall act as president pro tempore. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 5), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-97. - Rule 6. Order of business. 
At all meetings, business shall be taken up and disposed of generally in the following order. The council president may adjust the format from time to time, as deemed necessary, to provide for the orderly conduct of council business. 
(1)  Invocation. 
(2)  Pledge of allegiance. 
(3)  Approval of the minutes of previous meetings, and if approved, or when approved by the council, they shall be signed by the president or the president pro tempore. 
(4)  Special recognition and honorary resolutions. Items submitted under this category must be presented for agenda assignment to the council president or council president pro tempore by close of business one calendar week prior to the scheduled meeting. 
a.  Special recognition resolutions for presentation at council meeting. (Presentations at council meetings shall be limited to direct city-related interest only.) 
b.  Special recognition resolutions for presentation at other than council meetings. (Presentations other than direct city-related interests—personal accomplishments, civic events, educations accomplishments, athletics, etc.) 
c.  Special recognitions other than by resolution. 
d.  Announcements the president or presiding officer deems necessary or appropriate, including an announcement of the title of any (1) non-agenda item that will be offered for consideration or action, or (2) any item for which unanimous consent is requested or required. 
(5)  Action on any matter where an outside legal representative employed by the city or city agency is present. 
(6)  a.  Public hearings to be held. 
b.  Public hearings to be set. 
(7)  Communications from the public. 
a.  1.  Anyone wishing to address the council on any matter or agenda item must sign the public communications roster prior to the meeting. 
2.  Each speaker shall state his name and address for the record, or name only, if the address was provided on the public communications roster. Each speaker may address the council for approximately three minutes. The city clerk-treasurer shall be responsible for keeping time on each speaker. This time is provided for making comments to the city council, or bringing items to the attention of the city council, relating to city business, whether or not such items are on the meeting agenda. Nonagenda items which cannot be resolved within the three-minute time limit may either be referred to the city administration or, at the request of a councilmember, be scheduled for a work session. Any extension of time beyond the three-minute limit shall require approval of a majority of the council. The council may, in its discretion, treat a communication from the public as a nonagenda item and at the end of the regular meeting, upon approval of two-thirds vote of the membership present, continue discussion beyond the three-minute limit. 
b.  Except as provided in subsection (8)a. of this section, public comments relating to business items identified on the council agenda will be accepted prior to council action only upon approval by a majority of the council membership, with the following stipulations: 
1.  The item must be approved or held for outside comment by a councilmember. 
2.  Comments will be limited to the specific business item under consideration. 
3.  Comments will be limited to two minutes on each such item, unless additional time is requested by a councilmember for each such item. 
c.  Anyone wishing to address the council on any item not listed on the agenda which has been approved for consideration by the council pursuant to the provisions of this section may address the council for approximately three minutes. The city clerk-treasurer shall be responsible for keeping time on each speaker. 
(8)  City utilities items. 
(9)  Board appointments. No board appointment may be made at the same meeting where the nomination is made unless there is unanimous consent of the membership of the council. 
(9a)  Board nominations. Nominations for city council board appointments must be made at one meeting and voted on at a subsequent meeting (except as provided in subsection (9) of this section), provided that no nominations shall be made sooner than at any regular meeting of the council in the month preceding the month during which the term of the board position for which the nomination is being made expires. 
(10)  Approval of expenditures. 
(11)  Communications from the mayor. This time will be provided to make comments to the city council or bring an item or issue to the attention of the city council relating to city business and not on the meeting agenda. There will be a five-minute time limit for this period of communication. The council may, in its discretion, treat a communication from the mayor as a nonagenda item and continue discussion beyond the five-minute limit, at the end of the meeting, upon a two-thirds vote of the membership of the council present. 
(12)  Communications from councilmembers. This time will be provided for councilmembers to make comments to the city council or to bring an item or issue to the attention of the city council relating to city business and not on the meeting agenda. There will be a five-minute time limit for each councilmember for this period of communication. The council may, in its discretion, treat a communication from a councilmember as a nonagenda item and continue discussion beyond the five-minute limit, at the end of the meeting, upon a two-thirds vote of the membership of the council present. 
(13)  Unfinished business items for action. 
(14)  New business items for introduction. 
(15)  New business items for consideration or action. 
(16)  Routine items from the city attorney's office. 
(17)  Nonroster communications from the public. Anyone wishing to address the council on any matter or agenda item during nonroster communications from the public may, upon approval by a majority of the council membership, address the council for approximately three minutes. Each speaker shall state his name and address for the record. The city clerk-treasurer shall be responsible for keeping time on each speaker. Any extension of time beyond the three-minute limit shall require approval of a majority of the council. 
(18)  Adjournment. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 6), 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 96-1023, §§ 1—5, 12-19-1996; Ord. No. 98-321, § 1, 4-23-1998; Ord. No. 00-404, 5-11-2000; Ord. No. 07-604, § 2, 6-28-2007)  
Sec. 2-98. - Rule 7. Procedural rules. 
Except as provided in this division, the council shall adhere to the procedural rules contained in the latest edition of Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 7), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-99. - Rule 8. Points of order. 
The president of the council shall preserve order and decorum in the transaction of business during each sitting of the council, and on points of order may speak in preference to any councilmember. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 8), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-100. - Rule 9. Questions of order. 
The president of the council shall decide all questions of order, but from his decision an appeal may be taken, which appeal shall be decided without debate. The question shall be, "Shall the decision of the president of the council stand?", and such question must be approved by a two-thirds vote of the council membership. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 9), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-101. - Rule 10. Calling members to order. 
If in speaking, or if in any way, a councilmember should violate any rule, the president of the council or any councilmember may call him to order. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 10), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-102. - Rule 11. Priority of speakers. 
When two or more councilmembers shall speak at the same time, the president of the council shall decide who is entitled to speak; however, a councilmember shall always have priority over any speaker not a member of the city council. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 11), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-103. - Rule 12. Public comment on claims, lawsuits. 
The council shall not hear public comment on formally filed claims or lawsuits. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 12), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-104. - Rule 13. Confidentiality. 
Whenever the city attorney advises the council that a matter presented to the council or to any councilmember, whether verbally or in writing, should, in the opinion of the city attorney, remain confidential, the council shall abide by the request of the city attorney and shall refrain from any public comment, discussion or dissemination of information with regard to the matter. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 13), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-105. - Rule 14. Motions. 
When a motion is made, it shall be stated by the president of the council if verbal; if in writing, it shall be read by the clerk-treasurer; and on the request of the president or any councilmember, all motions shall be put in writing. When so stated or read, the president of the council shall put all motions to the vote of the councilmembers. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 14), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-106. - Rule 15. Amended motions. 
In all cases where an amendment is offered and seconded, the question shall be taken on the motion, resolution or ordinance as amended. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 15), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-107. - Rule 16. Lost amendment. 
If an amendment is lost, the original motion, resolution or ordinance shall be put upon its passage. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 16), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-108. - Rule 17. Motion to adjourn. 
A motion to adjourn shall always be in order and shall be decided without second and any debate. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 17), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-109. - Rule 18. Priority of previous question. 
The previous question shall have precedence over all other motions (except a motion to adjourn and a motion to lay on the table), and shall, if sustained by a two-thirds vote of the council membership present, preclude all debate and all amendments. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 18), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-110. - Rule 19. Ordinances, resolutions in writing. 
Any ordinance or resolution presented to the council for consideration or action must be in writing. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 19), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-111. - Rule 20. Reconsideration of question. 
Any councilmember having voted with the majority on any question may move for a reconsideration of the question at that meeting or at the next regular meeting of the council. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 20), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-112. - Rule 21. Adoption of ordinance or resolution. 
No ordinance or resolution intended to be of permanent operation shall be adopted by the council at the same meeting at which it is introduced unless unanimous consent of those present is given for the immediate consideration of such ordinance or resolution, such consent to be shown by a vote taken by ayes and nays; and the names of the members voting shall be entered upon the minutes; and no ordinance or resolution intended to be of permanent operation shall become a law unless on its final passage a majority of the members elected to the council shall vote in its favor. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 21), 11-22-1994) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-2(b).  
Sec. 2-113. - Rule 22. Voting. 
(a)  A councilmember may or may not vote on any item at his option. 
(b)  Unless otherwise expressly provided by ordinance or state law, any matter presented to the council for action, regardless of whether the council is acting in its legislative capacity or otherwise, shall be approved only upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the council membership. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 22), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-114. - Rule 23. Recording of ayes and nays. 
Whenever requested by one or more councilmembers, the ayes and nays shall be taken. The clerk shall record the ayes and nays whenever taken. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 23), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-115. - Rule 24. Entering of protest on minutes. 
The president or any member of the council shall have the right to have his protest to the passage of any measure entered on the minutes if it is in respectful language, of which the president of council shall judge. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 24), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-116. - Rule 25. Riders, qualifications must be pertinent. 
Nothing shall be introduced as a rider or as a condition or qualification to any ordinance unless the same shall be pertinent to the subject of the ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 25), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-117. - Rule 26. Committee recommendations. 
A majority of any committee shall be sufficient to make a recommendation to the council. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 26), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-118. - Rule 27. Temporary abandonment of chair by president. 
The president of the council may at any meeting call the president pro tempore to the chair temporarily for a stated purpose; and if the president pro tempore is not present or declines, the designated presiding third officer may be called. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 27), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-119. - Rule 28. Censure authorized. 
If the president of the council or any councilmember shall willfully violate any of the rules promulgated in this division, he shall suffer such censure as the council may direct. Any censure must be approved by a two-thirds vote of the remaining councilmembers. Censure may include public criticism and admonition. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 28), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-120. - Rule 29. Filling of vacancies. 
If any vacancy should occur in the office of mayor or any councilmember, such vacancy shall be filled in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-43-87. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 29), 11-22-1994)  
Sec. 2-121. - Rule 30. Suspension of rules. 
Except as otherwise provided by state law, any one of the rules promulgated in this division may be suspended by the vote of two-thirds of the councilmembers present at any meeting of the council, but never by less than a majority of the council membership. 
(Ord. No. 94-788, § 2-17 (rule 30), 11-22-1994)  
Secs. 2-122—2-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - FINANCIAL POLICIES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance promising or guaranteeing the payment of money or authorizing the issuance, sale or security of bonds or other instruments of indebtedness saved from repeal, § 1-11(5); taxation, ch. 24. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-151. - Investment policy. 
(a)  Generally. It is the policy of the city to invest city funds in a manner which will ensure maximum security with sufficient liquidity to meet daily cash flow demands while providing the highest investment return on municipal funds. The investment of all city funds is the responsibility of the finance department. The director of finance and employees whom he may designate are authorized to invest city funds consistent with this policy. The city clerk-treasurer, in fulfilling the duties of his office, shall participate in the implementation of this section and in the obtaining of the objectives listed in this section. 
(b)  Scope. 
(1)  Pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, Sec. 11-81-19—11-81-21, this section applies to all municipal funds of the city. 
(2)  This section applies to all transactions involving the financial assets and related activities of all municipal funds of the city. 
(c)  Objectives. 
(1)  Safety of principal is the foremost objective of the investment policy of the city. Investment transactions shall seek to avoid capital losses, whether they be from security defaults or erosion of market value. Investments of the city shall be undertaken in a manner that seeks to ensure the preservation of capital in the overall portfolio. To attain this objective, the city shall diversify its portfolio to avoid incurring unreasonable risks inherent in overinvesting in specific instruments, individual financial institutions or investments with similar maturities. 
(2)  Another objective is that the city's investment portfolio will remain sufficiently liquid to enable the city to meet all operating requirements which might be reasonably anticipated. An additional objective is to attain a maximum investment yield on available funds taking into account the city's investment risk constraints and the cash flow characteristics of the portfolio. 
(d)  Authority, prudence and ethics. 
(1)  Management responsibility for the investment program is delegated to the director of finance, who, along with the city clerk-treasurer, shall establish written procedures for the operation of the investment program consistent with this investment policy. Such procedures shall include explicit delegation of authority to persons responsible for transactions. No person shall engage in an investment transaction except as provided under the terms of this section and the procedures established under this section.
