The director of finance shall be responsible for all transactions undertaken and shall establish a system of controls to regulate investment activities of officials with responsibilities under this section. 
(2)  Investments shall be made with judgment and care, under circumstances then prevailing, which persons of prudence, discretion and intelligence exercise in the management of their own affairs, not for speculation, but for investment, considering the probable safety of their capital as well as the probable income to be derived. The standard of prudence to be used by investment officials shall be the "prudent person" standard and shall be applied in the context of managing an overall portfolio. Investment officers acting in accordance with written procedures and exercising due diligence shall be relieved of personal responsibility for any change in an individual security's credit risk or market price, provided deviations from expectations are reported in a timely fashion and appropriate action is taken to control adverse developments. 
(3)  Officers and employees involved in the investment process shall refrain from personal business activity that could conflict with proper execution of the investment program, or which could impair their ability to make impartial investment decisions. Full disclosure shall be made by officers and employees who may have material financial interests in financial institutions that conduct business with the city, and they shall further disclose any large personal investments or financial activities that could be related to the performance of the city's portfolio. 
(e)  Internal controls and reporting requirements. The director of finance shall establish a system of internal control designated to prevent losses of public funds arising from fraud, employee error, misrepresentation by third parties, unanticipated changes in financial markets, or imprudent actions by employees and officers of the city. Annually, the director of finance and the city clerk-treasurer shall publish a comprehensive report on the investment program and investment activity. The annual report shall include a comparison of investment returns and may recommend policies and improvements that might be made in the investment program. 
(f)  Instruments, maturities and risks. 
(1)  The city may invest municipal funds in accordance with Code of Ala. 1975, Title 11. 
(2)  It is the policy of the city to diversify its investment portfolio to minimize the risk of loss resulting from over-investing funds in a specific maturity, a specific financial institution or a specific class of security instruments. With the exception of U.S. Treasury securities, no more than 50 percent of the city's investment portfolio will be invested in a single security type or with a single financial institution. Investments of the city shall be made in instruments whose maturities do not exceed five years. In order to ensure adequate liquidity without market risk, investments shall have maturity dates at or prior to the time cash is prudently projected to be required to meet disbursement needs. 
(g)  Collateralization, safekeeping and custody. 
(1)  It is the city's policy that any bank or financial institution in the State of Alabama that invest city municipal funds shall be a Qualified Public Depository certified by the Alabama State Treasurer according to the Security for Alabama Funds Enhancement Act (SAFE Act), Section 41-14A-1, et seq., Code of Alabama 1975, as amended from time to time. 
(2)  All amounts of deposit made and certificate of deposits (CDs) issued in excess of amounts insured by the FDIC and FSLIC shall be collateralized with securities of the United States government, federal agencies which represent the full faith and credit of the United States, or otherwise authorized by state law. The collateral for each deposit or certificate of deposit shall have a market value equal to at least 100 percent of the excess of amounts insured by the FDIC and FSLIC. 
(3)  It is the policy of the city to require from each authorized financial institution holding city funds a listing of securities pledged as collateral to protect the city's investment. This listing of collateral shall be provided to the city by each institution for deposits held on June 30 and December 31 of each year. All investment securities purchased by the city and all collateral on deposits of the city shall be held in a custodian account maintained by a trust department of a bank insured by the FDIC, in the Federal Reserve Bank or by the city. The trust department shall issue a safekeeping receipt to the city listing the specific instrument, rate of return, maturity date and other pertinent information. 
(h)  Authorized financial institutions. 
(1)  The city clerk-treasurer shall maintain the list of approved banks or financial institutions for investment purposes that have offices located in the city. 
(2)  Before accepting funds or engaging in investment transactions with the city, the supervising officer at each institution shall submit a certification that the officer has reviewed this section and agrees to disclose potential conflicts or risks to public funds that might arise out of business transactions between the institution and the city. All financial institutions shall agree to undertake reasonable efforts to preclude imprudent transactions involving city funds. 
(Ord. No. 07-226, 3-22-2007) 
State Law reference— Sinking fund investments, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-81-19 et seq.  
Sec. 2-152. - Budget management. 
(a)  Purpose . It is the purpose of this section to establish a comprehensive system for budgeting and financial management which furthers the capacity of the mayor and the city council to plan and finance the services which the city provides for its citizens. 
(b)  Definitions . The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Department means the department of the city under the general supervision and control of the mayor. 
(c)  Duties of the director of the finance department relative to the city budget. The director of the finance department shall: 
(1)  Assist the mayor and the city council in the preparation and explanation of the proposed budget ordinance, including the coordination and analysis of department goals and objectives, and departmental budget requests; 
(2)  Assist departments in preparing their statement of goals and objectives, budget requests and reporting of program performance; 
(3)  Administer its responsibilities under this section so that the policy decisions and budget determination of the mayor and the city council are implemented to the fullest extent possible within the concepts of proper management; and 
(4)  Provide the mayor and the city council with budget information. 
(d)  Budget data to be submitted to director of finance by departments and other parties. 
(1)  Each department, on the date and in the form and content prescribed by the department of finance, shall prepare and forward to the director of finance the following program and financial information: 
a.  If requested, the goals and objectives of the department programs, together with proposed supplements, deletions and revisions to such programs. 
b.  If requested, its proposed plans to implement the goals and objectives, including estimates of future service needs, planned methods of administration, proposed modification of existing program services and establishment of new program services, and the estimated resources needed to carry out the proposed plan. 
c.  The budget requested to carry out its proposed plans in the succeeding fiscal year. 
d.  Where applicable, a report of the estimated revenues for the succeeding fiscal year. 
(2)  The department proposals prepared under subsection (d)(1) of this section shall describe the relationships of their programs services to those of other departments. 
(3)  If any department fails to transmit the program and financial information required under subsection (d)(1) on the specified date, the department of finance may prepare such information. 
(4)  All boards, commissions, agencies and organizations seeking appropriations from the city shall have a budget classification of "city agency transfers" or "outside agency appropriations", and shall submit budget information to the department of finance on or before the date requested, budgetary plans and data, which may include a long-range plan covering a period of not less than five years, setting forth the organization's projected goals, objectives and financial needs year by year. 
(e)  Formulation and presentation of mayor's proposed budget ordinance. 
(1)  The mayor shall formulate a budget ordinance to be recommended to the city council after considering each department's proposed programs and financial plan. The budget ordinance thereby submitted shall include the following: 
a.  Recommended appropriations for the operations of the city departments; 
b.  Recommended appropriations for the city's capital improvements programs; and 
c.  Identified sources of revenues to be available to the city to finance the recommended appropriations for operations and capital improvements. 
(2)  The proposed budget ordinance shall be presented by the mayor to the city council according to the timetable established as provided in this section. The mayor's presentation shall include an explanatory report which summarizes recommended goals, plans and appropriations and shall contain the following information: 
a.  The program goals and objectives that the mayor recommends to guide the decisions on the proposed program plans and budget appropriations; 
b.  The program and budget recommendations of the mayor for the succeeding fiscal year; 
c.  A revised estimate of city revenues for the current fiscal year and an estimate for the succeeding fiscal year; 
d.  A summary of estimated expenditures for the current fiscal year and those recommended by the mayor for the succeeding fiscal year; and 
e.  Any additional information which will facilitate understanding of the mayor's proposed budget ordinance by the city council and the public. 
(f)  Responsibilities of the city council as to consideration and adoption of the budget ordinance. The city council shall: 
(1)  Consider the budget ordinance recommended by the mayor, including proposed goals and policies, tax rate and other revenue changes and long-range program plans; 
(2)  Adopt alternatives to the budget ordinance which it deems appropriate; however, in no event shall authorized expenditures exceed estimated revenues and resources. 
(g)  Timetable for adoption of budget ordinance. 
(1)  In order to provide for an orderly procedure for the adoption of the annual budget ordinance, the mayor, the president of the city council and the chairperson of the city council finance committee shall agree upon a timetable for the formulation of the mayor's proposed budget ordinance and for the city council's hearings, deliberations and adoption of the ordinance. The timetable for the budget shall be established prior to June 1 of each year. 
(2)  The budget timetable shall include adequate time for the mayor and the city council to consider the budget requests of the departments. 
(3)  The mayor shall transmit to the city council a proposed budget ordinance setting forth the mayor's financial program for the ensuing fiscal year by September 1 of each year. 
(4)  The policy of the city shall be that, by September 30 of each year, the city council shall adopt a budget ordinance making appropriations for the ensuing fiscal year. 
(h)  Six-month budget review. By May 1 of each year, the mayor and director of finance shall make a report to the city council of the revenues and expenditures of the city and its departments for the first six months of the fiscal year. After the review, the city council shall make budget adjustments that the city council deems advisable. 
(i)  Contingency reserves. 
(1)  The policy of the city shall be to maintain a portion of the fund balance of the general fund as a reserve for contingencies and unexpected financial events, which shall be referred to as a "reserve for contingencies." 
(2)  The city's goal in the adopted budget is to establish a reserve for contingencies equal to at least 11.5 percent of the general fund's estimated revenues, without regard to revenue from grants. The mayor may recommend any amount in excess of this goal as the reserve in the budget proposal, or a reserve for any other fund of the city, which is subject to approval by the city council in the adopted budget. 
(3)  The reserve amount shall be included in the mayor's budget proposal to the city council, and the adopted budget. 
(4)  If the city must utilize the general fund reserve for contingencies to balance appropriations within estimated revenues of any fiscal year, subsequent adopted budgets must include a plan to restore the reserve amount to the stated goal until such is fully restored. 
(j)  General administration of programs and appropriations. 
(1)  The finance department shall maintain financial records and account for the financial activities in compliance with best established practices and generally accepted accounting principles. The finance department will maintain a fund accounting system that includes the number and types of funds necessary to satisfy the legal requirements and operational needs of the city. 
(2)  The finance department shall establish and maintain a chart of accounts in compliance with best established practices and accounting requirements. The chart of accounts shall include revenue, expenditure and other required accounts that shall provide city officials and the public meaningful financial information about city financial activities and demonstrate compliance with city budget ordinances and legal requirements. 
(3)  The revenue and appropriation budgets of the city's funds shall be categorized as follows: revenue, personnel, operating, departmental capital, city agency transfers, outside agency appropriations, debt service, debt-related items, transfers with city funds, and capital projects spending. 
(4)  The city council shall adopt the budgets in the budget ordinance as follows, which represents the level of city council budgetary control: 
a.  For the expenditure accounts of departments, by personnel, operating and departmental capital. 
b.  For the funds accounting for the budgets of the city's long-range capital improvement plans, by budget category, except that accounts categorized as "capital project spending" shall be adopted at the subcategory level as presented in the long-range capital improvement plans. 
c.  For appropriations categorized as "city agency transfers" or "outside agency appropriations," by individual account. 
d.  For all other revenue and appropriation accounts, by budget category. 
(5)  The director of finance is authorized to adjust the estimated revenues or appropriations among the accounts within a budget category or subcategory to the extent the increases and decreases offset. An increase or decrease in the total amount of any budget category or subcategory must be authorized by the city council in advance. An increase or decrease to an appropriation categorized as "city agency transfers" or "outside agency appropriations" must be authorized by the city council in advance. In the event of an emergency or unusual situation, the director of finance is authorized to adjust an appropriation that must ordinarily be authorized by the city council pursuant to this paragraph, upon notification and approval of the city council president and city council finance committee chairperson. 
(6)  The mayor, mayor's designee or the city council is authorized to approve travel expenses of any officer or employee of the city who travels outside the city limits, which are incurred for the purpose of improving or furthering the city's goals or its business. Such approval by the mayor or mayor's designee shall be in writing stating the purpose and the object of such travel. Such approval by the city council shall be by resolution setting forth the purpose and the object of such travel. All travel and related expenses shall be administered in compliance with city personnel policies and procedures. 
(Ord. No. 90-462, §§ 1—9, 9-27-1990; Ord. No. 94-764, 11-22-1994; Ord. No. 95-659, 9-28-1995; Ord. No. 95-861, 12-28-1995; Ord. No. 15-527 , 8-13-2015)  
Sec. 2-153. - Disposal of surplus real property. 
(a)  The purpose of this section is to provide a procedure for the disposition of certain real property owned by the city, which property has been declared surplus to the needs of the city under the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-20. 
(b)  No real property owned by the city and administered by a general fund department of the city shall be advertised or offered for sale on behalf of the city, and no negotiations concerning the disposition of any such property shall occur by any officer or agent of the city until such property has been declared surplus by appropriate ordinance or resolution duly adopted by the city council. 
(c)  Upon any declaration by the city council that any real property owned by the city and described in subsection (b) of this section is surplus to the needs of the city, the council shall first proceed to make certain findings as follows: 
(1)  The council shall first determine that the property is not needed by some other department or division of the city. If the property is not needed by any general fund department of the city and not needed by any other board or division of the city, the council shall determine if an accurate survey and description is available with respect to the property. If an accurate survey and description of the property is not available, the director of finance shall be authorized to have a survey and description prepared by an engineer or land surveyor. 
(2)  If the property is suitable for subdivision or development, the director of finance shall be authorized to determine whether or not the property should be subdivided and public improvements installed prior to being offered for sale. If the council elects to subdivide and install improvements prior to sale, the mayor and director of finance shall be authorized to employ an engineer to develop a plan for the subdivision of the property and for the installation of improvements upon the property. No plan for subdivision of the property will be authorized by the council except upon approval of the plan by the planning commission of the city and subject to filing of the plat in the office of the judge of probate of the county. Division of any property owned by the city into two or more parts or parcels for the purpose of sale or development shall be considered a subdivision. 
(3)  If the property is not suitable for development, but would only be useful to an adjoining owner to use in conjunction with adjacent and adjoining property, all adjoining owners shall be requested in writing to acknowledge in writing whether or not they have an interest in purchasing the property for such use. If the owners of adjacent property are interested in purchase, the director of finance shall invite bids from all such interested persons to be opened by the director and presented to the council. 
(4)  If the property is suitable for development, the property shall be advertised as provided in this section. 
(5)  No property shall be sold by the council until an appraisal has been received by the council, either from an independent appraiser employed by the mayor or from a staff appraiser of the city, as the council may elect; however, no such appraisal shall be made public until after bids have been received by the director of finance. 
(6)  Property suitable for subdivision or development shall be sold only after a suitable notice with respect to the proposed sale has been placed by the director of finance in a newspaper having general circulation within the city, the advertisement to appear at least ten days prior to the time announced for the receipt of bids. The council may determine, prior to any advertisement, that the property will not be sold for less than an established price, in which case such minimum price shall be referred to in the advertisement. Prior to the publication of any notice to advertise any such property for sale, the director of finance shall consult with appropriate city departments to determine the need for the reservation of any rights-of-way or easements with respect to the property. Sale may be by public bid or by public auction. The council shall not be obligated to accept any bid, either at an advertised sale or auction, unless such fact is referred to in the notice. 
(d)  The director of the public works services department shall, upon completion of any street improvement project, report any remnants or surplus property to the council for disposition. 
(e)  Upon approval by the council for sale of any property declared surplus as provided in this section, the mayor shall proceed to deliver a deed to the property in accordance with the authorization by the council; and the proceeds shall be delivered to the city clerk-treasurer. 
(f)  This section shall not apply to the disposition of industrial or research park property or to the disposition of any property for which a disposition procedure has been or is otherwise determined by the council. 
(Ord. No. 85-269, §§ 1—6, 5-23-1985) 
State Law reference— Disposition of unneeded real estate, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-20 et seq.  
Sec. 2-154. - Service charge for bad checks. 
(a)  The city clerk-treasurer is authorized to charge and collect bad check charges of not more than the greater of either $30.00 or an amount equal to the actual charge by the depositary institution for return of unpaid or dishonored instruments assessed for any check, draft, negotiable order of withdrawal or like instrument drawn on a bank or other depositary institution given by any person in full or partial payment of any tax, license fee or other fee due the city, or other assessments of the city, if such instrument is dishonored or not paid for any reason by such institution. 
(b)  The bad check charge shall be a legal charge against the person who tendered the dishonored or unpaid instrument and shall not be deemed a finance charge or interest. 
(Ord. No. 91-326, §§ 2, 3, 5-23-1991; Ord. No. 05-892, § 1, 10-27-2005) 
State Law reference— Service charge for bad check, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-9-13.1.  
Sec. 2-155. - Admission fee discount to city residents. 
(a)  Any board or agency created solely by the city under its general police powers which charges a fee for admission to any facility under the operation and control of such board or agency shall offer a ten percent discount off the regular admission fee to any resident of the city. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to any other discount (including senior citizen discounts) or promotional offer by any such board or agency where the regular admission fee is discounted by ten percent or more or to the Trolley at the Huntsville Depot. In addition, this section shall not apply to any admission fee charged for a special event, or any event involving a nongovernmental individual, association or corporation, as a promoter or copromoter of the event. 
(c)  Presentation of a driver's license or other photographic identification card or badge which includes a city address as the presenter's residence address shall constitute sufficient proof of residency within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 97-428, §§ 1—3, 6-26-1997)  
Sec. 2-156. - Conference and travel policy. 
There is adopted a conference and travel policy for the city. A copy of the policy shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 93-576, 9-9-1993)  
Sec. 2-157. - Pre-approval of legal and professional services. 
Any expenditure out of the legal and professional services line item in the city council's department budget must be preapproved in writing by no less than four out of five councilmembers. Any expenditure requested to be charged against the city council's legal and professional services budget line item by an individual councilmember, without prior written approval of at least four councilmembers, shall not be honored by the finance department, and shall become the personal debt of the councilmember who requested the expenditure. 
(Ord. No. 01-761, 9-27-2001)  
Sec. 2-158. - Payment by credit card. 
(a)  Any office, department, agency, board or commission of the city is authorized to accept payment by credit card, charge card and debit card issued by any bank, foreign lender, domestic lender or credit card bank as defined in the Alabama Credit Card Act, sections 5-20-2 through 5-20-16, Code of Ala. 1975. The payment may be for, but is not limited to, taxes, license and registration fees, court fines, costs and penalties, building permits, filing fees, assessments against property, parks and recreation fees, parking fees, rental expenses, event admissions and garbage collection fees. 
(b)  A service fee will be added, at the discretion of the city, to the payment in an amount not to exceed the transaction fee charged by the credit card issuer or processor. Payment of the service fee is not refundable. The service fee may be added and collected directly by the city, or added and collected by the city's processer. 
(c)  With the approval of the city council, the mayor is authorized to enter into appropriate agreements with one or more credit card issuers or other appropriate parties as needed to facilitate the acceptance of credit card payment. Each agreement must provide that it may be cancelled without penalty at any time by the city upon reasonable notice. No agreement shall exceed three years in term. 
(d)  No person making payment by credit card shall be relieved of liability for the face amount of the payment except to the extent that the city realizes full and final payment of the underlying obligation in cash or its equivalent. If full and final payment is not made by the credit card issuer or other guarantor of payment in the credit card transaction, the underlying obligation shall survive and the city shall retain all remedies for enforcement which would have applied if the credit card transaction had not occurred. 
(e)  A city employee who accepts a credit card payment in accordance with this section and any applicable policy, rule or regulation of the city shall not thereby incur any personal liability for the final collection of such payments. 
(f)  The clerk-treasurer is authorized to establish policies, rules and regulations governing the acceptance of payment for municipal services by credit card and to disseminate them to all employees. 
( Ord. No. 13-844, 11-7-2013 )  
Sec. 2-159. - [Debt management policy.] 
(a)  Purpose. 
(1)  The city recognizes the foundation of any well-managed debt program is a comprehensive debt management policy. A debt management policy sets forth the parameters for issuing debt and managing the outstanding debt portfolio of the city, and provides guidance to decision makers regarding the purposes for which debt may be issued, types and amounts of permissible debt, timing and method of sale that may be used, and structural features that may be incorporated. Adherence to a debt management policy helps to ensure that government maintains a sound debt position and that credit quality is protected. 
(2)  This debt management policy will help: 
a.  Promote high quality debt management decisions; 
b.  Maintain order and discipline throughout the debt issuance process; 
c.  Promote consistency and continuity in the decision making process; 
d.  Demonstrate a commitment to long-term financial planning objectives; and 
e.  Ensure that debt management decisions are viewed positively by rating agencies and the investment community and by citizens of the city. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Build America Bonds or BABs means the same as the term "Build America Bonds" as defined by the Internal Revenue Code, and shall include Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds issued under Section 1400U-2 of the Internal Revenue Code. 
City clerk-treasurer means the person holding the title of city clerk-treasurer of the city or, if the city shall determine to vest primary responsibility for the enforcement of the provisions of this policy charged to the city clerk-treasurer in another officer of the city, then from such date the terms shall be interpreted to mean such other officer of the city. 
Finance director means the person holding the title of director of finance of the city or, if the city shall determine to vest primary responsibility for the enforcement of this policy in another officer of the city, then from such date the terms shall be interpreted to mean such other officer of the city. 
Internal Revenue Code means of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended, and the regulations promulgated thereunder. 
IRS means the United States Internal Revenue Service. 
Policy means the debt management policy prescribed by this section. 
Ten-year capital improvement plan means the long-range plan for expanding and maintaining the city's capital infrastructure as adopted by city council resolution from time to time. 
(c)  Implementation. The policy shall be implemented by the mayor and finance director as authorized by the city council. Comprehensive debt management guidelines shall provide for the following: 
(1)  Full and timely payment of principal and interest on all outstanding debt. 
(2)  Debt shall be incurred only for those purposes as provided by applicable state law. 
(3)  Capital improvements should be planned, approved and financed in accordance with city ordinances and (with the exception of unanticipated extraordinary capital improvements) the ten-year capital improvement plan development process and/or other long-term capital planning models of the city. 
(4)  The payment of debt shall be secured by the full faith and credit of the city, in the case of general obligation bonds or warrants, and by the pledge of specified, limited revenues in the case of revenue bonds and warrants. The city shall not pledge any city revenues to debt issued by conduit entities formed within the city. The city shall have no moral obligation to repay the holders of debt issued by conduit issuers or other public entities within the city. 
(5)  Principal and interest retirement schedules shall be structured to: 
a.  Achieve a low borrowing cost for the city; 
b.  Accommodate the debt service payments of existing debt; and 
c.  Respond to perceptions of market demand. 
Shorter maturities shall always be encouraged to demonstrate to rating agencies that debt is being retired at a sufficient pace. 
(6)  Debt issued shall generally be limited to obligations with serial and term maturities but may be sold in the form of capital appreciation obligations or other structures if circumstances warrant. 
(7)  The average life of the debt incurred should be no greater than the projected average life of the assets being financed. 
(8)  The city shall select a method of debt sale that shall maximize the financial benefit to the city. Such sales can be competitive or negotiated, depending upon the project and market conditions. All methods of sale shall be subject to council approval. 
(9)  The city shall maintain good communications with credit rating agencies to ensure complete and clear understanding of the creditworthiness of the city. 
(10)  Every financial report, official statement/offering circular, and annual information statement shall follow a policy of accurate disclosure of financial conditions and operating results. All financial reports and annual information statements shall conform to guidelines issued by the Government Finance Officers Association, the Municipal Securities Rulemaking Board ("MSRB"), and the Securities and Exchange Commission to meet the disclosure needs of rating agencies, underwriters, investors and citizens. 
(d)  Debt limitations. 
(1)  Legal limitations. All debt issuances will be accomplished in compliance with applicable federal regulations, the Alabama Constitution, applicable state statutes, city ordinances, and all other applicable legal constraints. 
(2)  Public policy limitations. 
a.  The city shall assess all financial alternatives for funding capital improvements prior to issuing debt. Pay-as-you-go financing should be considered before issuing any debt. Pay-as-you-go financing may include: intergovernmental grants from federal, state, and other sources; current revenues and financial balances; public/private partnerships; and lease payments. Once the city has determined that "pay-as-you-go" is not a feasible financing option, the city may use short-term or long-term debt to finance capital projects. 
b.  All capital improvements and financings for capital improvements (with the exception of unanticipated extraordinary capital improvement requirements) will be made in accordance with an adopted ten-year capital improvement plan and/or other long-term capital planning models of the city. 
c.  General obligation warrants will be used to finance only those capital projects or improvements that have been determined to be essential to the maintenance or development of the city. Debt may be issued to finance long-term capital improvements, economic development initiatives, other property and equipment used in the furtherance of the mission of the city and for public improvements related to the quality of life of the citizens of the city. The city will not issue debt for the purpose of funding short-term assets with useful lives of less than three years. 
d.  Capital projects financed through the issuance of debt shall be financed over a period not to exceed the expected useful life of the project financed. 
e.  Long-term debt will only be used for capital projects that feasibly cannot be financed from current revenue sources, in conjunction with the ten-year capital improvement plan and/or other long-term capital planning models of the city. 
f.  Current operations will not be funded from the proceeds of borrowed funds. 
g.  In general, the city will limit the term of its tax-supported debt to 20 years, arranging for the repayment of long-term debt on a level-payment basis, unless special circumstances dictate otherwise, in which case the special circumstances will be disclosed in the associated financing plans, and as otherwise specified herein. 
(3)  Financial limitations. 
a.  The city will strive to maintain the highest debt service coverage ratios practicable consistent with its long-term financial objectives. 
b.  The city will closely monitor the absolute amounts and year-to-year trends of key financial ratios. The city recognizes that specific ratios, in and of themselves, may or may not depict an accurate assessment of the financial health of the city and may be affected temporarily by national or local economic conditions. It also recognizes, however, that negative trends for an extended period over multiple years are signals that must not be overlooked and will become a part of the annual reporting process of the finance department to the mayor and city council. Ratios to be monitored consist of the following: 
1.  General obligation debt as a percent of actual market value of property; 
2.  Debt per capita; 
3.  Debt service as a percent of general governmental expenditures; 
4.  Percent of total debt to be retired after ten years; and 
5.  Unreserved and undesignated general fund balance as a percent of general fund revenue. 
c.  Revenue debt levels will be monitored periodically and evaluated in terms of other debt service coverage ratios, trends in those ratios, and against covenants contained within the applicable financing documents. 
d.  The city recognizes the potential contingent impact that poorly conceived or structured debt sold by conduit issuers incorporated within the city can have on the reputation of the city and the marketability of its debt. When entertaining a petition to authorize the formation of any conduit issuer the city shall undertake to impose certain minimum standards respecting debt issued by such entity including, without limitation, minimal credit ratings and/or levels of collateral securing the debt and limitations, the purposes for which such debt may be issued and requirements on the types of purchasers to which the debt may be marketed. With respect to hospital/medical authorities and boards, entities formed under Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 11, ch. 99A or ch. 99B, and certain other special purpose public entities, the name of the city shall not be used in the title of such issuer unless required by state law and no information respecting the city may be used in any debt offering materials circulated by such entity absent an express disclaimer in such materials that the information is being provided for information purposes only about the city and that the city has no obligation, legal, moral or otherwise, for the repayment of such debt. 
e.  The authorizing proceedings for any short-term obligations issued by the city shall describe the purpose of the proposed debt, the circumstances under which it is being issued, and the term and size limitations thereof. 
(e)  Use of derivatives. 
(1)  The city recognizes that, while generally not utilized by the city, in certain circumstances interest rate swaps and other derivatives can be appropriate interest rate management tools and when properly utilized can increase the city's financial flexibility and provide opportunities for interest rate savings or reduced risks. Derivatives should be addressed in the city's overall debt and investment management policies. 
(2)  Swaps and other derivatives will not be used for speculation. For purposes of this policy, speculation means taking additional risks, unrelated to the city's business, in an effort to increase returns. The city will follow rules and processes similar to those the city would follow when evaluating the suitability of any significant investment. 
(3)  Swaps and other derivatives may be used when they achieve a specific objective consistent with the city's overall debt and investment management policies. Swaps and other derivatives may be used, for example, to lock-in a current market fixed rate or, alternatively, to create advantages through creating exposure to variable rates of interest. Swaps and other derivatives may be used to produce interest rate savings, alter the pattern of debt service payments, and cap, limit, or hedge variable rate payments. The city will only enter into swaps and other derivatives in accordance with the requirements of applicable state law. 
(4)  Reasons to use interest rate swaps, swaptions and other derivatives include, but are not limited to: 
a.  Reducing interest expense; 
b.  Hedging and actively managing interest rate, basis, and other risks; 
c.  Optimizing capital structure (e.g., to achieve targeted debt allocation); and 
d.  Achieving appropriate asset/liability match. 
(5)  The city will evaluate this use of derivatives subsection at least annually based on current market practices and credit concerns. 
(f)  Debt structuring practices. 
(1)  In general, the city will limit the term of its tax-supported debt to 20 years, arranging for the repayment of long-term debt on a level-payment basis, unless special circumstances dictate otherwise, in which case the special circumstances will be disclosed in the associated financing plans, and as otherwise specified herein. 
(2)  Revenue debt, or supporting debt, likewise will not exceed the useful life of the assets being financed but may be structured for a longer term than the city's tax-supported debt. 
(3)  The city will structure repayments of debt so as to recapture as rapidly as possible the credit capacity of the city for future needs. 
(4)  The city may choose to structure debt repayment so as to wrap-around existing obligations or to achieve other financial policy goals. 
(5)  Redemption features of city debt - mandatory, special and optional - shall be incorporated into debt issued by the city based on the specific needs of the city and then-current market conditions. 
(6)  In general, the city will issue fixed-rate debt and will not utilize variable rate debt or derivatives such as swaps or swaptions as financing vehicles. Provided, however, the city may use variable rate debt for short-term financings (i.e., financings for a period of less than three years) and specific projects that would benefit from a variable rate structure or that may require optional redemption provisions that are not available through a traditional fixed rate financing. 
(7)  Other structuring practices. 
a.  Capitalized interest will not be utilized for general obligation debt. Capitalized interest may be used on a limited basis with revenue/self-supported debt during the construction process and for that period of time when revenues for the financed project are developing consistent with federal tax laws. 
b.  Principal deferrals may be utilized on a limited basis during the construction of the project for a revenue/self-supported project or during an initial period of time during which revenues, such as from the establishment of a tax increment finance district, are realized. Otherwise, other than in connection with creating a "wrap-around" debt structure, principal deferrals will be discouraged. 
c.  The city shall use such other practices as it deems necessary and appropriate to obtain the lowest overall financing costs for the city over the term of the financing. For example, credit enhancement vehicles may be utilized, such as bond insurance or letters of credit from suitably rated banks, may be used provided that a present value benefit is produced when compared to issuing the debt without such credit enhancement. In the event credit enhancement is not cost effective, the city may still utilize credit enhancement subject to a finding by the finance director that determines that such enhancement meets the city's financing goals and objectives. 
(g)  Debt issuance practices. 
(1)  Method of sale. The city may elect to sell debt through a negotiated or competitive sale, or by a process that utilizes requests for proposals from financial institutions to purchase the debt. The method selected by the city for the sale of its obligations will depend on various factors including, but not limited to, the size and complexity of the transaction, current market conditions and other factors applicable to the city at the time of sale. The determination of which method of sale to follow will be made on either an issue by issue basis, for a series of issues or for a part of a specific financing program. 
(2)  Refunding criteria. 
a.  The city may advance refund outstanding obligations when advantageous, legally permissible, and when net present value savings equal or exceed the greater of $200,000.00 or four percent. Exceptions may be made only upon the recommendation of the finance director and the approval of the mayor and city council. 
b.  The city may currently refund outstanding obligations when advantageous, legally permissible, and when net present value savings equal or exceed the greater of $200,000.00 or three percent. Exceptions may be made only upon the recommendation of the finance director and the approval of the mayor and city council. 
c.  The provisions of the foregoing subparagraphs a. and b. notwithstanding, the city may choose to refund debt, on either an advance or current basis, without regard to the net present value test, when the existing financial structure or bond covenants impinge on prudent and sound financial management. In such a case, the restructuring is subject to a finding by the finance director that the restructuring is in the overall best interests of the city. 
d.  The principal maturity schedule of refinancing debt will be structured as to generally conform to the schedule of the refinanced debt, unless special circumstances dictate otherwise, in which case the special circumstances will be disclosed in the associated refinancing plan. Savings the city may realize in such refinancing may be realized in the form of an up-front payment or through a reduction in debt service payments, or a combination of both, based on the city's best interest and requirements. 
(3)  Selection and use of financial providers. The city's finance director shall be responsible for the selection process for securing professional services that are required to develop, monitor, and implement the city's debt management program. Consultants providing advice or counsel to the city shall be independent. The financial advisor, bond counsel, and underwriter for any issuance of debt shall be separate entities having no relationship with one another. 
a.  The finance director will request the recommendation of the city attorney in selecting bond counsel which will also be approved by the mayor and city council. Bond counsel will be from a nationally recognized firm with significant experience in tax matters and legal requirements associated with the sale of governmental debt. 
b.  The financial advisor will be selected based upon the recommendation of the finance director to the mayor and city council. The financial advisor will be from a regionally or nationally recognized firm with experience in the capital planning, structuring and sale of governmental debt. Any financial advisor utilized by the city also capable of providing underwriting services shall be prohibited from participating in the underwriting of any debt for the city for a period of one year from the date of termination of its contract for financial advisory services. 
c.  Underwriters will be selected based upon the recommendation of the finance director to the mayor and city council. The underwriters shall be regionally or nationally recognized with demonstrated experience in the underwriting of governmental debt. 
d.  Other services providers, such as paying agents, escrow agents, verification agents, and trustees will also be selected based upon the recommendation of the finance director to the mayor and city council. 
(h)  Debt management practices. 
(1)  Arbitrage rebate monitoring and filing. The city shall minimize the cost of arbitrage rebate and yield restriction while strictly complying with federal and state law. 
a.  The city shall maintain investment allocations by source of funds and record pro rata interest income of the commingled bond funds monthly. 
b.  Project cash flows shall be carefully planned to insure the applicability of rebate exceptions, if feasible. 
c.  Rebate computations should be performed annually, but no less often than every five years until the obligations mature. 
d.  It is the city's policy to segregate current arbitrage earnings for future payment or credit, and to enter the amount as a liability on the books. 
e.  The city shall report to the IRS as required and shall make rebate payments as required by federal law. 
f.  The city shall structure its financings in such a way as to reduce or eliminate future arbitrage rebate liability, wherever feasible. 
(2)  Federal and state loan compliance practices—Continuing disclosure. The finance director will be responsible for providing ongoing disclosure information through Electronic Municipal Markets Access System ("EMMA") (or any such other system subsequently authorized by the MSRB or the SEC) and for maintaining compliance with disclosure standards promulgated by state and national regulatory bodies. The finance director will consult with the city's financial advisors and bond counsel in meeting the city's continuing disclosure and other compliance obligations. The city will conduct an annual review of all of the continuing disclosure requirements outlined in each financing and provide certifications and additional information as appropriate. 
(3)  Market and investor relations efforts. The finance director, in conjunction with the city's financial advisor, will maintain on-going contact with and supply information to the rating agencies and through its continuing disclosure obligations. The city will provide full and prompt disclosure of all material events through the national reporting system and will respond to inquiries and questions from the underwriting and investor communities as appropriate. 
(4)  Investment of proceeds of city debt. 
a.  The investment of all public funds is subject to certain state restrictions in addition to any restrictions contained within the warrant ordinance or other financing documents. 
b.  The city clerk-treasurer will be responsible for the investment of proceeds of all tax-exempt obligations and obligations issued as BABs. 
c.  The city clerk-treasurer will consult with the finance director, when appropriate, the city's financial advisor and other deputies of the city, to determine projected spend-down schedules in order to determine the optimum investment for the city of debt proceeds consistent with the Internal Revenue Code. 
(i)  Compliance procedure and policy for tax-exempt governmental obligations and Build America Bonds. 
(1)  Purpose and need for policy. To help ensure that the city takes all actions reasonably necessary to ensure the continuing tax-exempt status of its governmental obligations (and the continuing eligibility for the receipt of direct payments from the federal government respecting obligations issued as Build America Bonds), the city council has adopted this subsection to address conformance to applicable IRS post-issuance compliance requirements for tax-exempt governmental obligations, and obligations intended to be treated as Build America Bonds, issued by the city. 
This policy documents existing practices and describes various procedures and systems designed to identify on a timely basis facts relevant to demonstrating compliance with the requirements that must be satisfied subsequent to the issuance of tax-exempt governmental obligations in order that the interest on such obligations be, or continue to be, excludable from gross income for federal income tax purposes, and obligations issued as BABs in order that such obligations be, and continue to be, treated as "Build America Bonds" for purposes of the Internal Revenue Code. 
(2)  Policy. As a present or intended issuer of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs, the city is required by the terms of Sections 103 and 141-150 of the Internal Revenue Code, and the Treasury Regulations promulgated thereunder (the "Treasury Regulations"), to take certain actions subsequent to the issuance of such obligations to ensure the continuing tax-exempt status of such obligations and to take actions to ensure continued eligibility for interest subsidy payments in connection with BABs. Additionally, Section 6001 of the Internal Revenue Code and Section 1.6001-1(a) of the Treasury Regulations impose record retention requirements on the city with respect to its tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs. This subsection "Compliance Procedure and Policy for Tax-Exempt Governmental Obligations and Build America Bonds" is to help facilitate the efforts of the city in complying with the city's compliance obligations under applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code and the Treasury Regulations. 
a.  Responsible parties. The city clerk-treasurer shall be the party primarily responsible for implementing and monitoring the city's compliance requirements under applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations as they pertain to the investment of proceeds of tax-exempt obligations and BABs issued by the city. The finance director shall be the party primarily responsible for monitoring the city's compliance requirements with respect to all other applicable provisions of the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations. Each of the city clerk-treasurer and finance directors will be assisted by the staff of said officer and by other city staff and officials when appropriate. Such officers will also be assisted in carrying out post-issuance compliance requirements by the following: 
1.  Bond counsel (the law firm primarily responsible for providing bond counsel services for the city); 
2.  Financial advisor (the entity primarily responsible for providing financial advisor services to the city); 
3.  Paying agent (the person(s), entity (entities), or city officer(s) primarily responsible for providing paying agent services for the city); and 
4.  Rebate analyst (the entity (entities) primarily responsible for providing rebate analyst services for the city). 
With respect to the investment of proceeds of tax-exempt obligations and BABs, the city clerk-treasurer shall be responsible for assigning compliance responsibilities to members of such officer's staff, other staff of the city, the financial advisor, bond counsel, the paying agent, and the rebate analyst as the city clerk-treasurer deems appropriate. For all other purposes of this policy the finance director shall be responsible for assigning compliance responsibilities to members of such officer's staff, other staff of the city, the financial advisor, bond counsel, the paying agent, and the rebate analyst as the finance director deems appropriate. Each of the city clerk-treasurer and finance directors shall utilize such other professional service organizations as are necessary to ensure compliance by the city with this policy. 
b.  Special pre-issuance and post-issuance policies respecting BABs. In connection with the issuance and sale of each series of BABs by the city, the finance director shall: 
1.  Consult with the Financial Advisor on methods to help ensure that no maturities of any direct pay BABs are issued with more than a de minimis amount of original issue premium including, without limitation, (i) negotiating terms in the purchase contract or such other commitment or agreements between the city and the underwriter(s) or purchaser(s) that expressly prohibit any maturities from having beyond a de minimis amount of original issue premium; (ii) negotiating with the underwriter(s) or purchaser(s) of such obligations to minimize to the extent feasible and practicable the number of days between the sale date and the date such obligations are issued and delivered; (iii) obtaining from the underwriter(s) or purchaser(s) of such obligations a certificate representing the issue price thereof; and (iv) negotiating such other provisions as the financial advisor may advise in order to minimize or prevent any such original issue premium. (This action will be the primary responsibility of the financial advisor); 
2.  Determine the extent to which records of any secondary market trading activity for direct pay BABs are available through the MSRB's Electronic Municipal Markets Access System ("EMMA"), and if such information is so available shall monitor EMMA on a regular basis between the date of sale and the closing date of any issue of direct pay BABs to identify whether and to what extent secondary market trading activity involved the sale of more than a de minimum amount of premium on any of the maturities of such BABs (This action will be the primary responsibility of the financial advisor); 
3.  Monitor the use of proceeds of BABs to ensure compliance with the requirements that (i) all proceeds (other than amounts placed in a reasonably required reserve fund and used to pay costs of issuance) are used to pay capital costs; and (ii) no more than two percent of the principal amount of the obligations are used to pay costs of issuance; 
4.  Maintain records respecting the expenditure of all proceeds of such obligations to help ensure the timely and proper expenditure of all such proceeds in accordance with the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations; 
5.  Consult with the financial advisor in computing, and have the financial advisor independently compute and certify, (i) the amount of "available project proceeds" (i.e., proceeds from the sale of such BABs less no more than two percent of such proceeds to pay costs of issuance plus investment earnings on such proceeds) of such issue, (ii) such amount as may be used to fund a reasonably required reserve fund, and (iii) the overall costs of issuance of such BABs and the amount of proceeds from the sale of such BABs used to pay such costs of issuance; 
6.  Maintain detailed records of all expenditures of available project proceeds to ensure the same (less such amount as shall be used in a reasonable required reserve fund) are expended only for capital expenditures; 
7.  Consult with the financial advisor in computing, and have the purchaser(s) or underwriter(s) independently compute and certify, the amount of interest payable on each interest payment date; 
8.  Consult with the financial advisor in computing, or have an independent consultant (which such consultant may be, but is not required to be, the purchaser(s), underwriter(s) or financial advisor) compute, the proper amount of refundable credit to be reported on IRS Form 8038-CP; 
9.  File, or enter into an agreement on behalf of the city with the paying agent or such other third party as the finance director shall deem appropriate to cause to be filed, the IRS Form 8038-CP in accordance with the time requirements of the Internal Revenue Code (which, for purposes of direct pay BABs bearing interest at a fixed rate, shall be the periods described in Section 4(c) of this policy); 
10.  Ensure, or cause a consultant (which may be the paying agent or such other consultant as the finance director may identify) to ensure, that all filings with the IRS identify the city as the recipient of interest subsidies receivable and contain the correct information needed to transmit payment thereof; and 
11.  Undertake appropriate actions to ensure compliance with the Federal Davis-Bacon Act and regulations issued with respect thereto with regard to labor matters in connection with capital projects financed with proceeds of Recovery Zone Economic Development Bonds. 
c.  Post-issuance compliance actions. With respect to each issue of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs issued by the city: 
1.  The finance director shall obtain from bond counsel and store a transcript of principal documents pertaining to such transaction; 
2.  The finance director shall cause bond counsel to confirm that bond counsel has timely filed with the IRS an Information Return for Tax-Exempt Governmental Obligations, Form 8038-G and a Form 8038-B in the case of BABs (the action of filing such returns shall be the primary responsibility of bond counsel); 
3.  For each issue of BABs, the finance director shall file with the IRS, no earlier than 90 days nor later than 45 days before each interest payment date, Form 8038-CP to ensure payment of the BABs direct federal payment (the finance director may contract, on behalf of the city, with the paying agent or such other consultant as identified by the finance director to make such filings); 
4.  The city clerk-treasurer shall (i) cause bond counsel to identify proceeds of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs that must be yield-restricted; and (ii) in consultation with bond counsel monitor the investments of any yield-restricted funds to ensure that the yield on such investments does not exceed the yield to which such investments are restricted; 
5.  The finance director shall cause a rebate analyst or such other consultant engaged by the city to determine whether the rebate requirements of Section 148(f) of the Internal Revenue Code are applicable with respect to each issue of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs issued by the city, taking into account whether the city is eligible for any of the temporary periods for unrestricted investments and any of the spending exceptions to such rebate requirements. The finance director shall contact the rebate analyst (and, if appropriate, bond counsel) prior to the fifth anniversary of the date of issuance of each issue of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs of the city and each fifth anniversary thereafter to arrange for calculations of the rebate requirements with respect to such tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs. If a rebate payment is required to be made by the city, the finance director shall prepare or cause to be prepared the Arbitrage Rebate, Yield Reduction and Penalty in Lieu of Arbitrage Rebate, Form 8038-T, and submit such Form 8038-T to the IRS with the required rebate payment. If the city is entitled to recover a rebate payment previously paid, the finance director shall prepare or cause to be prepared the Request for Recovery of Overpayments Under Arbitrage Rebate Provisions, Form 8038-R, with respect to such rebate recovery, and submit such Form 8038-R to the IRS. 
d.  Procedures for monitoring, verification, and inspections. The finance director shall (i) institute such procedures as the finance director shall deem necessary and appropriate to monitor the use of the proceeds of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs issued by the city, (ii) confirm that no impermissible private activity or business use is being conducted on the financed facilities; and (iii) confirm that proceeds are spent in accordance with the expectations described in the applicable tax certificate or tax compliance agreement. The clerk-treasurer shall verify that the interest rate on investments of proceeds of such obligations does not exceed the yield on such obligations (to the extent bond counsel has advised the city that such investments are required to be yield restricted). 
e.  Record retention requirements. The finance director shall collect and retain the following records with respect to each issue of tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs of the city and with respect to the facilities financed with the proceeds of such obligations: 
1.  Audited financial statements of the city; 
2.  Appraisals, demand surveys, or feasibility studies with respect to the facilities to be financed with the proceeds of such obligations; 
3.  Publications, brochures, and newspaper articles related to the financing; 
4.  Trustee or paying agent statements; 
5.  Records of all investments and the gains (or losses) from such investments; 
6.  Paying agent or trustee statements regarding investments and investment earnings; 
7.  Reimbursement resolutions and expenditures reimbursed with the proceeds of such obligations; 
8.  Allocations of proceeds to expenditures (including costs of issuance); 
9.  Contracts entered into for the construction, renovation, or purchase of such facilities; 
10.  An asset list or schedule of all financed depreciable property and any depreciation schedules with respect to such assets or property; 
11.  Records of the purchases and sales of financed assets; 
12.  Private business uses of such facilities that arise subsequent to the date of issue through leases and subleases, licenses, management contracts, research contracts, naming rights agreements, or other arrangements that provide special legal entitlements to nongovernmental persons and copies of any such agreements or instruments; 
13.  Arbitrage rebate reports and records of rebate and yield reduction payments; 
14.  Resolutions or other actions taken by the governing body subsequent to the date of issue with respect to such obligations; 
15.  Formal elections authorized by the Internal Revenue Code or Treasury Regulations that are taken with respect to such obligations; 
16.  Documents related to guaranteed investment contracts or certificates of deposit, credit enhancement transactions, and financial derivatives entered into subsequent to the date of issue; 
17.  Copies of all Form 8038-Ts and Form 8038-Rs filed with the IRS; and 
18.  The transcript prepared with respect to such tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs. 
The records collected by the finance director shall be stored in any format deemed appropriate by the finance director and shall be retained for a period equal to the life of the tax-exempt governmental obligations and BABs with respect to which the records are collected (which shall include the life of any warrants issued to refund any portion of such tax-exempt governmental obligations or to refund any refunding warrants) plus three years. 
f.  Reissuance. The following policies relate to compliance with rules and regulations regarding the reissuance of obligations for federal law purposes. The finance director will: 
1.  Identify and consult with bond counsel regarding any post-issuance change to any terms of an issue of tax-exempt obligations or BABs which could potentially be treated as a reissuance for federal tax purposes; and 
2.  Confirm with bond counsel whether any "remedial action" in connection with a "change in use" (as such terms are defined in the Internal Revenue Code and Treasury Regulations) would be treated as a reissuance for tax purposes and, if so, confirm the filing of any new IRS Form 8038-G. 
g.  Other post-issuance actions. If, in consultation with the mayor, the city council, the financial advisor, bond counsel, the paying agent, the rebate analyst, the city clerk, the city attorney, or any other city officials or relevant advisors the finance director determines that any additional action not identified in this policy must be taken to continue the tax-exempt status of any issue of governmental obligations of the city (or the status of obligations issued as BABs), the finance director shall take such action if the finance director has the authority to do so. If, after consultation with the mayor, the city council, the financial advisor, bond counsel, the paying agent, the rebate analyst, the city clerk, the city attorney, or any other city officials or relevant advisors the finance director determines that this policy must be amended or supplemented to continue the tax-exempt status of any issue of governmental obligations of the city (or the status of obligations issued as BABs), the finance director shall recommend to the city council that this policy be so amended or supplemented. 
(3)  Responsibility. Enforcement of this subsection with respect to the investment of proceeds of tax-exempt obligations and BABs shall be the primary responsibility of the city clerk-treasurer and, with respect to all other matters, shall be the primary responsibility of the finance director, although each of the city clerk-treasurer and finance director may delegate, as such officer deems reasonable or necessary, and or all such functions to staff within the office of the finance director, or to the financial advisor, bond counsel, the paying agent or rebate analyst. 
(Ord. No. 10-646, 9-9-2010)  
Secs. 2-160—2-180. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROCUREMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Execution of contracts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-5; awarding contracts to low bidder, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-6; public contracts, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-181. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Blind trust means an independently managed trust in which the employee-beneficiary has no management rights and in which the employee-beneficiary is not given notice of alterations in, or other dispositions of, the property subject to the trust. 
Brand name or equal specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturers' names or catalogue numbers to describe the standard of quality, performance and other salient characteristics needed to meet city requirements, and which provides for the submission of equivalent products. 
Brand name specification means a specification limited to one or more items by manufacturers' names or catalogue numbers. 
Business means any corporation, partnership, proprietorship, firm, enterprise, franchise, association, organization, self-employed individual, or any other legal entity. 
Commodities means all property, including but not limited to equipment, materials, printing and lease of real property, including land or a permanent interest in land. 
Confidential information means any information which is available to an employee only because of the employee's status as an employee of the city and is not a matter of public knowledge or available to the public on request. 
Contract means all types of city agreements, regardless of what they may be called, for the procurement of commodities or services. 
Contractor means any person having a contract with the city or a using agency of the city. 
Direct or indirect participation means involvement through decision, approval, disapproval, recommendation, preparation of any part of a purchase request, influencing the content of any specification or procurement standard, rendering of advice, investigation, auditing or in any other advisory capacity. 
Employee means an individual drawing a salary or wages from the city whether elected or not; any noncompensated individual performing personal services for the city or any department, agency, commission, council, board, or any other entity established by the executive or legislative branch of the city. 
Financial interest means: 
(1)  Ownership of any interest or involvement in any relationship from which or as a result of which a person within the past year has received or is presently or in the future entitled to receive more than $1,000.00 per year, or its equivalent; 
(2)  Ownership of more than five percent of any property or business; or 
(3)  Holding a position in a business such as officer, director, trustee, partner, employee or the like, or holding any position of management. 
Gratuity means a payment, loan, subscription, advance, deposit of money, service, gift, benefit, favor or anything of more than nominal value, present or promised, unless consideration of substantially equal or greater value is received. 
Immediate family means a spouse, children, parents, brothers and sisters of the employee, or a dependent such as a person who receives 50 percent or more of his support from the employee or the employee's spouse. Also included as a dependent would be a person who resides with the employee for more than 180 days during the preceding year. 
Invitation for bids means all documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting sealed bids. 
Procurement means the buying, purchasing, renting, leasing or otherwise acquiring of any commodities or services. It also includes all functions that pertain to the obtaining of any supply or service, including description of requirements, selection and solicitation of sources, preparation and award of contract, and all phases of contract administration. 
Public agency means a public entity subject to or created by the city. 
Qualified products list means an approved list of commodities or services, described by model or catalogue numbers, which, prior to competitive solicitation, the city has determined will meet the applicable specification requirements. 
Request for proposals means all documents, whether attached or incorporated by reference, utilized for soliciting proposals. 
Resident responsive responsible bidder means a person deemed to be a responsive, responsible bidder, as defined by Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-50. 
Responsible bidder means a person who has the capability in all respects to perform fully the contract requirements, and the tenacity, perseverance, relevant experience, integrity, reliability, capacity, facilities, equipment and credit which will assure good-faith performance and other necessary essential qualities to assure financial stability and adequate personnel. 
Responsive bidder means a person who has submitted a bid which conforms in all material respects to the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids. 
Services means the furnishing of labor, time or effort by a vendor, not involving the delivery of a specific end product other than those which are merely incidental to the required performance. This term shall not include employment agreements except agreements with private temporary services. 
Specification means any description of the physical or functional characteristics or of the nature of a supply or service. It may include a description of any requirement for inspecting, testing or preparing a supply or service for delivery. 
Using agency means any city department, commission, board, authority or public agency requiring commodities or services procured pursuant to this division. 
Vendor means any corporation, partnership, individual, sole proprietorship, joint stock company, joint venture or any other private legal entity offering to provide commodities or services to the city. 
(Ord. No. 96-864, art. 7, 11-14-1996) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-182. - Purpose and application. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this division is to provide for the fair and equitable treatment of all persons involved in public procurement by the city, to maximize the purchasing value of public funds in procurement, and to provide safeguards for maintaining a procurement system of quality and integrity. 
(b)  Application. This division applies to contracts for the procurement of commodities and services entered into by the city after November 26, 1996. When the procurement involves the expenditure of federal assistance or federal contract funds, the procurement shall be conducted in accordance with any mandatory applicable federal law and regulations. Nothing in this division shall prevent any public agency from complying with the terms and conditions of any grant, gift or bequest that is otherwise consistent with law. 
(Ord. No. 96-864, art. 1, 11-14-1996)  
Sec. 2-183. - Procurement officer. 
(a)  The director of finance or his written designee shall serve as the principal public purchasing official for the city and shall be responsible for the procurement of supplies and services in accordance with this division. 
(b)  In accordance with this division, the director of finance or his written designee shall oversee the functions of procurement services for the purposes of soliciting and encouraging competition while complying with all applicable state and local laws to obtain quality commodities and services at the lowest possible cost. 
(c)  Except in cases of emergency, as described in section 2-184(g), neither the director of finance nor any written designee nor any other officer or employee of the city shall make purchases in the name of the city on the credit of the city, or create any debt or liability against the city, unless the expenditure has been previously authorized by the city council, or unless the funds for such expenditure have been appropriated by the city council, either specifically or in the annual budget of the city. In all cases where the amount involved is more than required for competitive bidding, procurement services shall proceed to issue invitations for bids and to open the bids at the time and place stated in the invitation for bids, and shall report the results of such bids to the city council, who shall accept or reject such bids and shall in all respects act as the awarding authority for all such purchases. 
(d)  The director of finance may delegate authority in writing to purchase certain commodities or services to other city officials, if such delegation is deemed necessary for the effective procurement of those items. Any such procurements made pursuant to any such delegated authority remain subject to all requirements for authorization and approval as set forth in this division. The city engineer is authorized to procure construction services for public improvement projects as defined by Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 39 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 39-1-1 et seq.) and in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(Ord. No. 96-864, art. 2, 11-14-1996)  
Sec. 2-184. - Source selection and contract formation. 
(a)  Generally. All procurements for the city shall be awarded in accordance with the applicable provisions of the Code of Ala. 1975, tits. 39 and 41 (Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 39-1-1 et seq., 41-1-1 et seq.) and in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  Invitations for bids. For those types of contracts meeting threshold requirements for competitive bids, invitations for bids shall be issued and shall include specifications and all contractual terms and conditions applicable to the procurement. 
(1)  Public notice. Public notice of the invitation for bids shall be given a reasonable time prior to the date set forth for the opening of the bids. Such notice shall include posting all bids on a suitable bulletin board outside the procurement services office of the city. Such notice may also include publication in a newspaper of general circulation and shall state the place, date and time of the bid opening. 
(2)  Bonds. Bid bonds, performance bonds, and labor and material bonds or other security may be requested for supply contracts or service contracts as procurement services deems advisable to protect the city's interests, and in conformance with the Code of Ala. 1975, tits. 39 and 41 (Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 39-1-1 et seq., 41-1-1 et seq.). Bid or performance bonds shall not be used as a substitute for a determination of a bidder or offeror's responsibility. 
(3)  Bid openings. Bids shall be opened publicly in the presence of one or more witnesses at the time and place designated in the invitation for bids. For the purpose of designating the time of opening, the clock located in the city council chambers, first floor of the municipal building, 308 Fountain Circle, Huntsville, Alabama, shall serve as the official clock of record. The amount of each bid, and such other relevant information together with the name of each bidder shall be recorded; the record and each bid shall be open to public inspection. Late bids will not be accepted nor considered. 
(4)  Bid acceptance and bid evaluation. Bids shall be unconditionally accepted without alteration or correction, except as authorized in this division. Bids shall be evaluated based on the requirements set forth in the invitation for bids, which may include criteria to determine acceptability such as inspection, testing, quality, workmanship, delivery and suitability for a particular purpose. The invitation for bids shall set forth the evaluation criteria to be used. No criteria may be used in bid evaluation that are not set forth in the invitation for bids. Any bid determined to be nonresponsive to the requirements will be rejected. 
(5)  Correction or withdrawal of bids; cancellation of awards.
