Secs. 2-189—2-220. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PERSONNEL POLICIES 
 
Sec. 2-221. - Manual adopted. 
The Personnel and Policy Procedures Manual as adopted and amended by the city is adopted by reference. A copy of the manual as amended is on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 90-152, 5-10-1990; Ord. 08-776, 8-28-2008)  
Sec. 2-222. - Cell phone policy. 
This section establishes the city's policy concerning the use of city cell phones that are provided to employees and officials for their official use, and establish the means by which the city will reimburse its employees and officials who use their personal cell phone for city business. In this section, the term "cell phone" means a mobile communication device having telephone capabilities, and the term "cell phone allowance" means the amount paid to employees to reimburse them for use of their personal cell phone for city business. The term "city phone" means a cell phone owned by the city and any related equipment used with it. 
(1)  Eligibility . 
a.  Elected officials. The city will not provide an elected official a city phone but will provide a cell phone allowance at the request of the official. 
b.  Employees . An employee may be furnished a city phone or receive a cell phone allowance only in the following situations: 
1.  Job responsibilities of the employee are such that it is in the city's best interest that the employee be able to communicate by cell phone for work-related reasons on a regular basis, and the use of other communications equipment, including a pager, is impractical; 
2.  The employee can significantly enhance work-related personal safety with a cell phone; or 
3.  The mayor or his/her designee requires the employee to be available by cell phone whenever possible. 
The city will furnish a city phone to an employee only when it is practical to share it with other employees, or as directed by the mayor or his/her designee. All other employees will receive a cell phone allowance when they qualify according to this policy. 
(2)  City phones . 
a.  Approval . The city will provide a city phone to an employee who qualifies under this policy at the discretion of the employee's department head. 
b.  Authorized uses. The use of a city phone shall be for official use, except in the case of emergencies. City phones cannot be used at any time in violation of local, state or federal laws, nor for the purpose of personal financial gain, nor in violation of any departmental work rules. 
c.  Authorized city cell phone vendors . Only vendors authorized by the city, in accordance with state law, will provide service related to city phones. 
(3)  Cell phone allowance. 
a.  Approval . Department head will submit a written or email request to the finance director for an employee to receive a cell phone allowance, to include employee's name, employee number, job title, basis for request, and monthly amount requested. 
The finance department will ensure the request is complete as required by this policy, obtain employee acknowledgement of this policy's requirements, and obtain approval of the request from the mayor or his/her designee when required. 
b.  Payment . An employee or official authorized to receive a cell phone allowance will receive a monthly payment, which will be included in his city payroll check. The payment will begin the first full month after approval, or as is consistent with finance department payroll policy. 
c.  Taxability . The cell phone allowance paid to an employee or official may be subject to or exempt from federal and state income taxes based on the regulations in effect from time to time. 
d.  Maximum amount . The amount of reimbursement must be consistent with the cost the employee is reasonably expected to incur for using his/her personal cell phone for city business, and in the best interest of the city, all communication options considered. The maximum amount is $35.00 per month, except in special high-use cases approved by the mayor or his/her designee, for which the maximum amount is $70.00 per month. These maximum amounts may be modified in the annual budget ordinance, and the amounts paid to any employee may be increased or decreased at any time at the discretion of the city. 
(4)  Responsibilities . 
a.  Department heads will establish policies to help ensure compliance with the terms of this policy and the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual by department employees. 
b.  Employees furnished a city phone will use the device in compliance with the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual, including those that pertain to city-owned information technology equipment. The city reserves the right to review all electronic records on city issued phones and to obtain relevant information from the telephone company or carrier, if the city administration considers in its sole discretion that there is a legitimate business reason to do so. Thus, employees do not have a reasonable expectation of privacy with respect to the use of city issued cell phones and by use of such devices, do consent to all city sponsored monitoring. While employees receiving cell phone allowances applicable to the business use of their personal cell phone may generally have an expectation of privacy on their personal cell phones, there may be times when the city will have the right or duty to obtain access for business purposes to the electronic records relevant to the employee's business use of that personal cell phone. Such occasions may arise with respect to the city's duty to preserve or produce evidence relevant to anticipated or ongoing litigation or otherwise obtain access for law enforcement purposes. 
c.  Employees using a city phone, or personal cell phone for city business purposes, will not use it in a manner that would jeopardize the safety of themselves or others. Specifically, employees shall comply with Alabama state law as set forth in Code of Alabama, § 32-5A-350 which prohibits a person from operating a motor vehicle on a public road, street, or highway in Alabama while using a wireless telecommunication device (as defined within the statute) to write, send, or read a text-based communication (as defined therein) except in certain specific circumstances detailed within the state statute. 
d.  Employees who receive a cell phone allowance agree to provide their cell phone number to their supervisor, to accept and make city business calls on their phone when required by their supervisor, not represent the cell phone he/she uses as the property of the city. 
e.  An employee must sign an acknowledgement of the terms of the policy that pertain to the employee prior to being issued a city phone or receiving a cell phone allowance. 
(5)  Administration . The finance department will administer this policy as directed by the mayor or his/her designee, is authorized to periodically require an employee to submit evidence that the cost of using his personal cell phone for city business is commensurate with his cell phone allowance, and is authorized to evaluate compliance with this policy. 
(Ord. No. 06-1141, 11-9-2006; Ord. No. 15-528 , 8-13-2015)  
Secs. 2-223—2-250. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - MISCELLANEOUS POLICIES 
 
Sec. 2-251. - City attorney authorized to institute lawsuits. 
The city attorney, or an assistant city attorney under the supervision of the city attorney, shall have the authority to institute, in a court of competent jurisdiction, all legal proceedings in the name of the city, except eminent domain petitions, real estate foreclosure proceedings, and actions for the breach of written contracts or other proceedings which by law specifically require city council action, upon the direction and/or approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 88-586, § 1, 11-10-1988)  
Sec. 2-252. - Defense and indemnification—Agencies, boards and members. 
(a)  Any officer or employee of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, employed in any department of the city which is under the general supervision and control of the mayor, who is sued in connection with his or her official duty, or any agency or board created or established by the City Council of the City of Huntsville, Alabama (excluding any private, not for profit corporation) which is sued in connection with an official act or decision of such agency or board, or any officer, employee or member of such agency or board who is sued in connection with his or her official duty, shall be represented in the defense of such suit by the city attorney, an assistant city attorney, or a private attorney designated by the city attorney except in the situation where the officer, employee, agency or board is represented by an attorney pursuant to a contract of insurance with regard to such suit. 
(b)  In the event the city attorney or an assistant city attorney does not provide representation to the officer, employee, agency or board, and the officer, employee, agency or board, or officer, employee or member of such agency or board, is not represented by an attorney pursuant to a contract of insurance with regard to such suit, the city attorney shall select a private attorney to represent the officer, employee, agency or board, or officer, employee or member of such agency or board. No private attorney selected by the city attorney to represent an officer or employee shall be paid an hourly rate exceeding $200.00 per hour, prior to October 1, 2015, and $225.00 per hour on or after October 2, 2015, through September 30, 2017, and $250.00 per hour on or after October 1, 2017. Such hourly rate shall be determined by the city attorney based upon the private attorney's level of experience and expertise. The private attorney shall confirm in writing the fee arrangement. 
(c)  Any officer or employee of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, or any officer, employee or member of any agency or board, which is sued in connection with his or her official duty, shall notify the city attorney of such suit as soon as possible. Failure of such officer, employee or member to notify the city attorney within ten days of service of such suit shall relieve the City of Huntsville, or the agency or board with whom such officer, employee or member is affiliated, from any duty to represent the officer, employee or member in the defense of the suit or to pay any judgment which may result there from except as otherwise may be required by law. 
(d)  If the City of Huntsville, Alabama, an officer or employee of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, or an agency or board (or an officer, employee or member thereof) is represented by a private attorney with regard to any suit filed against the City of Huntsville, any officer or employee of the City of Huntsville employed in any department of the city which is under the general supervision and control of the mayor, or any agency or board of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, the city attorney shall request a status report concerning the suit from such other attorney on a regular, monthly basis. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall interfere in any way with the right of any officer, employee or member sued in connection with his or her official duty, to provide his or her own legal counsel at his or her own expense. In such event, the City of Huntsville shall be relieved of any responsibility to represent the officer, employee or member in the defense of such suit. 
(f)  All billings paid to private attorneys from the funds of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, for the defense of lawsuits as provided herein, including interim billings, shall be reviewed by the city attorney as to reasonableness, and the payment thereof is subject to a determination of reasonableness by the city attorney. 
(g)  This section does not address payment of any judgment rendered against any officer, employee or member (except to bar payment of any judgment as provided in paragraph (c), and nothing herein shall be construed to bind or obligate the city to pay any judgment rendered against any officer, employee or member except as otherwise may be required by law. 
(h)  Section 13 of the Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual of the City of Huntsville provides for the scheduling of a disciplinary hearing in appropriate cases, before an impartial hearing officer selected from a pool of eligible persons designated by the city council. Each person named as a hearing officer under section 13 of the City of Huntsville Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual shall be paid at an hourly rate of $200.00 per hour, prior to October 1, 2015, and $225.00 per hour on or after October 2, 2015, through September 30, 2017, and $250.00 per hour on or after October 1, 2017. 
(i)  Ordinance No. 93-19A, as amended, provides for hearing officers to be appointed by the City Council of the City of Huntsville, to preside over tax disputes arising between the City of Huntsville and taxpayers. Each person named as a hearing officer under Ordinance No. 93-19A, as amended, shall be paid at an hourly rate of $200.00 per hour, prior to October 1, 2015, and $225.00 per hour on or after October 2, 2015, through September 30, 2017, and $250.00 per hour on or after October 1, 2017. 
(Ord. No. 93-335, §§ 1—7, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. 96-350, § 1, 5-23-1996; Ord. No. 06-1220, §§ 1—7, 12-21-2006; Ord. No. 15-324, §§ 1—3, 5-28-2015 )  
Sec. 2-253. - Same—City officers and employees. 
(a)  Any officer or employee of the city employed in any department of the city which is under the general supervision and control of the mayor who is sued in connection with his official duty shall be represented in the defense of such suit by the city attorney, or an assistant city attorney in the office of the city attorney designated by the city attorney except in the following situations: 
(1)  The city is a codefendant in the suit and, in the opinion of the city attorney, there is a conflict in the defenses of the city and the officer or employee. 
(2)  Two or more officers or employees are sued in connection with claims arising out of the same set of circumstances and, in the opinion of the city attorney, there is a conflict in their defenses. 
(3)  Representation by the city attorney's office is impracticable. 
(4)  The officer or employee is represented by an attorney pursuant to a contract of insurance with regard to such suit. 
(b)  If the city does not provide representation to the officer or employee for reasons set forth in subsection (a)(1)—(3) of this section, the city attorney shall select a private attorney to represent the officer or employee after consultation with such officer or employee. No private attorney selected by the city attorney to represent an officer or employee shall be paid an hourly rate exceeding $125.00 per hour. Such hourly rate shall be determined by the city attorney based upon the private attorney's level of experience and expertise. The private attorney shall confirm in writing the fee arrangement. Except in circumstances approved by the city attorney, only one attorney will be compensated by the city for the defense of an officer or employee. 
(c)  Any officer or employee who is sued in connection with his official duty shall notify the litigation manager of such suit as soon as possible. Failure of such officer or employee to notify the city attorney within ten days of service of such suit shall relieve the city from any duty to represent the officer or employee in the defense of the suit or to pay any judgment which may result from the suit except as otherwise may be required by law. 
(d)  If the city is represented by a private attorney with regard to any suit filed against the city or any officer or employee of the city employed in any department of the city which is under the general supervision and control of the mayor, the city attorney shall request a status report concerning the suit from such other attorney on a regular, monthly basis. 
(e)  Nothing in this section shall interfere in any way with the right of any officer or employee sued in connection with his official duty to provide his own legal counsel at his own expense. In such event, the city shall be relieved of any responsibility to represent the officer or employee in the defense of such suit. 
(f)  All billings paid to private attorneys from the funds of the city for the defense of lawsuits as provided in this section, including interim billings, shall be reviewed by the city attorney as to reasonableness; and the payment is subject to a determination of reasonableness by the city attorney. 
(g)  This section does not address payment of any judgment rendered against any officer or employee (except to bar payment of any judgment as provided in subsection (c) of this section), and nothing in this section shall be construed to bind or obligate the city to pay any judgment rendered against any officer or employee except as otherwise may be required by law. 
(Ord. No. 93-336, §§ 1—7, 6-24-1993; Ord. No. 96-349, § 1, 5-23-1996)  
Sec. 2-254. - Same—Attorneys for city. 
Whenever any city employee employed by the city as a legal service provider, as defined in Code of Ala. 1975, § 6-5-572(2), shall be sued for damages arising out of the performance of his official duties in the course of his employment, the city shall provide defense counsel for such legal service provider in such legal service liability action and shall indemnify such legal service provider from any judgment rendered against him in such suit. 
(Ord. No. 93-337, 6-10-1993)  
Secs. 2-255—2-290. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENTS, DEPARTMENT HEADS AND OTHER APPOINTED OFFICERS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-291. - Position of manager of planning administration established. 
The position of manager of planning administration is hereby established. The manager of planning administration shall be an officer of the city and shall have the responsibility for the day to day supervision of the planning administration division of the department of urban development. The planning administration division provides staff support for the planning commission in performance of the duties outlined in Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 11, ch. 52, with respect to planning, zoning and subdivision regulations. The manager of planning administration shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council as provided by law. The manager of planning administration shall hold office for the term of the mayor making the appointment. The manager of planning administration shall be under the direct supervision and control of the director of urban development. Generally, the manager of planning administration shall be available to councilmembers to respond to requests for information or questions related to matters under the general control of the manager of planning administration which are pertinent to the performance of a councilmember's duties. 
Ordinance No. 90-152 of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, as amended adopting the Personnel Polices and Procedures Manual for the City of Huntsville (the "personnel manual"), shall not constitute an employment contract with the manager of planning administration, and the manager of planning administration shall not be governed by the provisions of the personnel manual except (1) where otherwise provided by law and (2) when enforcing the terms of the personnel manual in his or her capacity as a supervisor. At the direction of the director of urban development, the duties and responsibilities of a department head, as stated in the personnel manual, may be performed by the manager of planning administration. The duties of the manager of planning administration shall include but not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Plans, organizes and directs the activities of the planning administration division; supervises and participates in the preparation of comprehensive reports based upon careful research and study of planning problems. 
(2)  Plans, organizes and directs the activities of professional, technical and clerical personnel engaged in the compilation, analysis and interpretation of data affecting planning administration. 
(3)  Directs the development and updating of land use zoning regulations for adoption by the city council, preparation and revision of zoning ordinances, zoning maps, and subdivision regulations; directs implementation of land use zoning regulations which include the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, adopted land use plans, and other elements and policies of the city's comprehensive plan. 
(4)  Consults with public works engineering staff, architects, contractors, and individuals regarding land development and site development. 
(5)  Serves as project supervisor for various planning administration activities, projects and plans. Manages consultant contracts. 
(6)  Serves as technical advisor to the planning commission on city planning and development matters; recommends projects and programs to be undertaken. 
(7)  Directs and coordinates the implementation of the city's master plan and the coordination of the public interests with the private sector in enforcement of land development policies; coordinates with other departments in implementing the master plan, coordinates with research park manager to develop the research park. 
(8)  Advises and cooperates with city officials in connection with new or contemplated capital improvements. 
(9)  Provides technical advice and investigative assistance for the board of zoning adjustment. 
(10)  Maintains liaison with governmental agencies and officials in the metropolitan area. 
(11)  Makes oral and written presentations of strategies and recommendations to city council, boards, commissions, public and private organizations; prepares various correspondence and reports regarding planning administration issues and policies. 
(12)  Prepares the annual budget for the division. 
(13)  Performs related work as required. 
(Ord. No. 11-714, 9-27-2011) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-714, adopted Sept. 27, 2011, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 2-291 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Manual adopted, § 2-221.  
Sec. 2-292. - [Position of manager of urban and long range planning established.] 
The position of manager of urban and long range planning is hereby established. The manager of urban and long range planning shall be an officer of the city and shall have the responsibility for the day to day supervision of the planning division of the department of urban development. The manager of urban and long range planning shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council as provided by law. The manager of urban and long range planning shall hold office for the term of the mayor making the appointment. The manager of urban and long range planning shall be under the direct supervision and control of the director of urban development. Generally, the manager of urban and long range planning shall be available to councilmembers to respond to requests for information or questions related to matters under the general control of the manager of urban and long range planning which are pertinent to the performance of a councilmember's duties. 
Ordinance No. 90-152 of the City of Huntsville, Alabama, as amended adopting the Personnel Polices and Procedures Manual for the City of Huntsville (the "personnel manual"), shall not constitute an employment contract with the manager of urban and long range planning, and the manager of urban and long range planning shall not be governed by the provisions of the personnel manual except (1) where otherwise provided by law and (2) when enforcing the terms of the personnel manual in his or her capacity as a supervisor. At the direction of the director of urban development, the duties and responsibilities of a department head, as stated in the personnel manual, may be performed by the manager of urban and long range planning. The duties of the manager of urban and long planning shall include by not be limited to the following: 
(1)  Plans, organizes and directs the activities of the urban and long range planning division; supervises and participates in the preparation of comprehensive reports based upon careful research and study of planning problems. 
(2)  Plans, organizes and directs the activities of professional, technical and clerical personnel engaged in the compilation, analysis and interpretation of data affecting urban planning and development. 
(3)  Serves as technical advisor to the planning commission on city planning and development matters; recommends projects and programs to be undertaken. 
(4)  Serves as the transportation planning coordinator for the metropolitan planning organization. 
(5)  Advises and cooperates with city officials in connection with new or contemplated capital improvements. 
(6)  Maintains liaison with governmental agencies and officials in the metropolitan area. 
(7)  Advises the public regarding long-range planning and/or land use regulations. Facilitates communication among interested individuals and groups with differing views on planning problems. 
(8)  Serves as project supervisor for various urban and long range planning activities, projects, and plans. Manages consultant contracts. 
(9)  Coordinates transportation planning activities as related to Federal Highway Administration urban area planning regulations, the 20-year highway plan, the five-year transportation improvement plan, the planning commission major street plan, and the Huntsville urban area transportation computer model; manages and administers transportation grants; Serve as staff liaison to regional metropolitan transportation planning organization. 
(10)  Directs and coordinates the implementation of the city's master plan, and the coordination of the public interests with the private sector in the development and enforcement of land development policies; coordinates with other departments in implementing the city's recreation plan and other plans, assists in the development of industrial parks and with companies seeking to relocate to the city; coordinates with research park manager to develop the research park. 
(11)  Directs the development and updating of land use zoning regulations for adoption by the city council, preparation and revision of zoning ordinances, zoning maps, and subdivision regulations; directs implementation of land use zoning regulations which include the zoning ordinance, subdivision regulations, adopted land use plans, and other elements and policies of the city's comprehensive plan. 
(12)  Consults with public works engineering staff, architects, contractors, and individuals regarding land development and site development. 
(13)  Plans, organizes, and schedules reviews, and evaluates the work of clerical, para-professionals and professionals involved in preparation of studies, regulations, designs, plans and grant applications and other urban planning, long range planning and development related activities. 
(14)  Makes oral and written presentations of strategies and recommendations to city council, boards, commissions, public and private organizations; prepares various correspondence and reports regarding urban and long range planning issues and policies. 
(15)  Prepares the annual budget for the division. 
(16)  Performs related work as required. 
(Ord. No. 11-715, 9-27-2011) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 11-715, adopted Sept. 27, 2011, did not specify manner of inclusion; hence, codification as § 2-292 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference— Manual adopted, § 2-221.  
Secs. 2-293—2-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 07-68, adopted Feb. 8, 2007, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion herein as Div. 2, §§ 2-301—2-304, was at the discretion of the editor. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Cross reference— Department of animal control, § 5-2; Duties of officers and employees of fire and rescue department, § 13-1. 
 
Sec. 2-301. - Established. 
The police, fire and rescue, and animal services departments shall be combined into a single department which shall hereafter be known as the department of public safety. The department of public safety shall be comprised of the following divisions: 
(1)  Police; 
(2)  Fire and rescue; 
(3)  Animal services. 
(Ord. No. 07-68, 2-8-2007)  
Sec. 2-302. - Director of public safety—Generally. 
The department of public safety shall be under the general supervision and control of the director of public safety, except that operational control of the division of fire and rescue shall remain vested with the fire and rescue chief. The director of public safety shall be a department head of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council as provided by law. The director of public safety shall hold office for the term of the mayor making the appointment. The director of public safety shall be under the general supervision and control of the mayor and shall administer the department in accordance with city policies and procedures. 
(Ord. No. 07-68, 2-8-2007)  
Sec. 2-303. - Director of public safety—Authority. 
The director of public safety shall have authority to allocate employees (in authorized, funded positions) and resources among the various divisions of the department of public safety as he or she deems necessary for the efficient functioning of the department. No employee transferred from one division to another by the director shall suffer any change in classification, pay, or benefits, solely as a result of such transfer. 
(Ord. No. 07-68, 2-8-2007)  
Sec. 2-304. - Director of public safety—Functions. 
The essential functions of the director of public safety shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
(1)  Plans, organizes, directs and coordinates with police chief all police services and activities including maintenance of law and order; protection of life and property; regulation of traffic; apprehension, arrest and detention of law violators, community policing; and maintenance of police records. 
(2)  Plans, organizes, directs and coordinates with chief of fire and rescue all fire and rescue services for the City of Huntsville including safety and communications programs, and the scheduling of all training programs, but excluding fire suppression, fire prevention, fire investigation, rescues, and emergency medical training, which are expressly vested in the chief of the division of fire and rescue. 
(3)  Plans, organizes, directs and coordinates with the animal services director the operation of an animal shelter, including apprehending, impounding, and disposing of stray or vicious animals, feeding, care and disposal of animals; and maintenance and cleaning of facilities, vehicles and equipment. 
(4)  Serves as the liaison between the emergency management agency director and the mayor; serves as command coordinator, either personally or through command staff, for events, incidents, or activities involving the joint participation of the department and the emergency management agency. 
(5)  Directs, facilitates, and participates in developing the department's long range strategic plans and annual work plans; assigns, monitors, reviews, and evaluates work activities, projects, and program to support annual work plans. 
(6)  Establishes goals and objectives for efficiency of services, and continually reviews and evaluates work outcomes, and methods; establishes appropriate service and staffing levels; allocates resources accordingly; ensures readiness of department and equipment. 
(7)  Ensures subordinates conduct themselves in a professional, respectful manner, exercising their authority with appropriate discretion and treating all citizens in a fair and equitable manner. 
(8)  Directs the selection, supervision, training and evaluation of departmental staff and employees; has authorization to initiate disciplinary proceedings as necessary and impose discipline, as appropriate; reviews departmental responses to grievances to ensure policy application, and provides input and direction on complaints and other sensitive personal matters. 
(9)  Oversees the development and administration of the department's budget; identifies funding opportunities and revenue sources to meet growing demands for services; make requests for additional funding for staffing, equipment, materials and supplies. 
(10)  Oversees the development of procedures, work rules and performance standards to assure the efficient and safer operation of the department in compliance with city standards, federal, state and local laws. 
(11)  Exercises purchasing and budgetary control; reviews and gives departmental approval to specifications for new equipment. 
(12)  Addresses civic, professional, community groups, and the media regarding the activities and programs of the department to promote public understanding of the department's work, and establishes positive public relations. 
(13)  Monitors critical, special, and unusual events and provides briefings to the mayor and other public officials and informs the public. 
(14)  Ensures logistical support to operations in the public safety department. 
(Ord. No. 07-68, 2-8-2007)  
Secs. 2-305—2-320. - Reserved.
