DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 2-1291. - Number of members. 
The number of members on each board, committee, commission, agency or like body of the city shall remain the same as was authorized for such board, committee, agency or like body prior to the enactment of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-40-21. 
(Ord. No. 93-452, 7-8-1993)  
Sec. 2-1292. - Removal of members for absences from meetings. 
(a)  Any member of a board, committee or agency created by the city council the authority of which is provided for by ordinance who accrues three unexcused absences within a six-month period from regularly scheduled meetings of any such board, committee or agency that holds regular meetings on a monthly or more frequent basis or two unexcused absences within a one-year period from regularly scheduled meetings of any such board, committee or agency that holds regular meetings on a less than monthly basis shall be deemed to have resigned from such board, committee or agency and shall not be eligible for appointment or reappointment to any board, committee or agency of the city for a period of one year from the date of such resignation. 
(b)  Upon termination of membership of any member of a board, committee or agency of the city pursuant to the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, the board, committee or agency shall notify the president of the city council (if the appointment was made by the city council) or the mayor (if the appointment was made by the mayor) that a vacancy exists on such board, committee or agency. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, an unexcused absence shall mean any absence other than one resulting from illness, a personal or family medical emergency, death of a family member, an act of God, or circumstances beyond the control of the member which prevents such member from being able to attend. 
(d)  If the provisions of this section are more restrictive than the bylaws of any board, committee or agency governed by this section, the provisions of this section shall control. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to any member of an authority authorized to be incorporated by the city as provided under state law. 
(Ord. No. 96-866, §§ 1—5, 11-14-1996)  
Sec. 2-1293. - Terms; reappointment. 
(a)  Members of each board or committee created by the city council shall serve in such capacity for no more than two full consecutive terms, excluding partial terms, as such terms are established in the resolution or ordinance creating the board or committee, or for a period of 12 years, whichever is less. Any member of a board or committee who is serving at the time of the adoption or approval of this section shall be permitted to serve out the remainder of such term, the provisions of this section notwithstanding. 
(b)  Subsection (a) of this section notwithstanding, any member of a board or committee created by the city council may be reappointed to such board or committee by a four-fifths vote of the council membership, regardless of the number of terms or years served on such board or committee. 
(Ord. No. 96-887, 10-24-1996)  
Secs. 2-1294—2-1300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADVISORY COMMISSION ON ACCESSIBILITY 
 
Sec. 2-1301. - Created. 
The Advisory Commission on Accessibility is created.  
Sec. 2-1302. - Membership; functions. 
(a)  The mayor and city council shall appoint ten members to the Advisory Commission on Accessibility as set out in this section. 
(b)  The following members shall represent the city: 
(1)  President of the city council or his designee. 
(2)  Director of parking and public transit or his designee. 
(3)  Parking division manager or his designee. 
(4)  Manager of the inspection division or his designee. 
(c)  The remaining six members shall be appointed by the mayor and city council in the following manner: 
(1)  Three members shall be appointed by the mayor and three members by the city council. Of the members appointed, two shall be appointed for a term of one year, two for a term of two years, two for a term of three years, and all members after initial appointments shall be appointed for terms of three years. However, the president of the city council, representatives of the department of parking and public transit, and the inspection division shall serve only during their term of office or employment. Continued absence of any member from regular meetings of the commission shall render any such member liable to removal from office at the discretion of the appointing authorities of the city. 
(2)  At least four of the six members appointed by the mayor and city council (two members appointed by the mayor and two members appointed by the city council) shall have a disability. 
(d)  The commission shall serve in an advisory capacity to the director of parking and public transit. 
(e)  Each member shall serve in his term until reappointment.  
Sec. 2-1303. - Bylaws. 
The Commission on Accessibility shall establish and adopt its own bylaws of procedures.  
Secs. 2-1304—2-1330. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AIR POLLUTION CONTROL BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1331. - Created. 
The Air Pollution Control Board is created. 
(Ord. No. 96-25, § 1(3), 3-28-1996)  
Sec. 2-1332. - Membership. 
(a)  The Air Pollution Control Board shall consist of seven members to be appointed for the following staggered terms: Of the members first appointed, five shall be appointed by the mayor as follows: one member shall serve for two years; two members shall serve for three years; two members shall serve for four years; of the members first appointed, two shall be appointed by the city council and shall serve for five years. Continued absence of any member from regular meetings of the board shall, at the discretion of the appointing authority, be grounds for removal from office. 
(b)  Immediately after March 28, 1996, the mayor and city council shall appoint members of the board pursuant to the provisions of this section. Thereafter, the terms of all members shall be five years; except that upon the expiration of the term of any board member, such member shall continue to serve until his successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 96-25, §§ 1(3), 2, 3-28-1996)  
Sec. 2-1333. - Quorum; officers; rules, regulations. 
(a)  Four members of the Air Pollution Control Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No board member shall act in any case in which he has a personal interest. Any official action of this board must be by majority vote of those present and voting. 
(b)  The Air Pollution Control Board shall elect its own officers and shall keep, or cause to be kept, a full and complete record of all its proceedings, which record shall set forth the reasons for the board's decisions. The records of the board shall be open to public inspection during business hours. 
(c)  The Air Pollution Control Board shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedure consistent with the provisions of this division and applicable laws of the state. The board shall hold regular meetings at least once each calendar quarter at any time fixed by rule or resolution of the board. The chairman, or any three members of the board or the Air Pollution Control Officer, may call a special meeting for any stated purpose on at least 24 hours' notice to each member by mail or telephone. 
(Ord. No. 96-25, § 1(3)(a)—(c), 3-28-1996)  
Sec. 2-1334. - Powers and duties. 
The Air Pollution Control Board shall have the following powers and duties, where such powers and duties are not in conflict with or duplication of any powers and duties specifically conferred on the air pollution control officer by ordinance or resolution adopted by the city council and where such powers and duties of the board are consistent with the Alabama Air Pollution Control Act of 1971 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-28-1 et seq.) and rules and regulations adopted under the authority of that act: 
(1)  To hold such hearings as are authorized or required by the air pollution control rules and regulations of the city as adopted by the city council. 
(2)  To have the authority required to carry out all of the duties and functions of the board under the terms of the air pollution control rules and regulations of the city. 
(3)  To make recommendations to the mayor and the city council concerning the passage or amendment of any ordinance of the city concerning air pollution control and concerning the air pollution control rules and regulations of the city. 
(4)  To encourage voluntary cooperation by persons and affected groups to achieve the purposes of the air pollution control regulations of the city. 
(5)  To encourage and conduct studies, investigations and research relating to air contaminations and air pollution and their causes, effects, prevention, abatement and control. 
(6)  To determine by means of field studies and sampling the degree of air contamination and air pollution in the city and their several parts. 
(7)  To make a continuing study of the effects of the emission of air contaminants from motor vehicles on the quality of the outdoor atmosphere of the city and its several parts and make recommendations to appropriate public and private bodies with respect to the methods of abatement. 
(8)  To collect and disseminate information and conduct educational and training programs relating to air contamination and air pollution. 
(9)  To advise, consult and cooperate with agencies of the state, local governments, industries, other states, interstate or interlocal agencies and the federal government, and with interested persons or groups. 
(10)  To consult, upon request, with any person proposing to construct, install or otherwise acquire any air contaminant source or device or system for its control, concerning the efficiency of such device or system, or the air pollution problems which may be related to the source, device or system. Nothing in any such consultation shall be construed to relieve any person from compliance with the act, the regulations, or any other provision of law. 
(11)  To provide for the establishment of advisory committees, appointment of the membership of such committees, scope of investigation, and other duties, of such committees. 
(12)  To require from any responsible person reports containing information as may be required by the air pollution control officer concerning location, size and height of contaminant outlets, processes employed, fuels used, the nature and time periods or duration of emissions, and such other information as is relevant to air pollution. 
(Ord. No. 96-25, § 1(3)(d), 3-28-1996)  
Secs. 2-1335—2-1350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ALABAMA CONSTITUTION VILLAGE BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1351. - Created. 
The Alabama Constitution Village Board is created. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1, 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1352. - Membership. 
The Alabama Constitution Village Board shall consist of nine members serving in numbered places to be appointed as follows: 
(1)  Of the members first appointed, three members shall serve one year, two of which shall be appointed by the mayor and one of which shall be appointed by the city council; three members shall be appointed by the council and shall serve initial terms of two years; three members shall be appointed by the council and shall serve initial terms of three years. Vacancies shall be filled for unexpired terms in the manner in which original appointments are made. The terms of all appointed members next appointed after the expiration of the original terms shall be three years. 
(2)  The members of the board shall receive no compensation whatever for their services, nor shall they receive compensation or per diem for attending meetings; however, actual and necessary expenses, in amounts no greater than those appropriated by the city council, incurred in the performance of their duties, may be paid. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(1), (5), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1353. - Quorum action by board. 
Five members of the Alabama Constitution Village Board of the city shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No member shall act in any case in which he has a personal interest. Actions by the board shall be by majority of those present. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(2), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1354. - Treasurer. 
The Alabama Constitution Village Board shall elect from its membership a treasurer and such assistant treasurers as it deems advisable, each of whom shall give bond with corporate surety in the amount of $10,000.00, payable to the city, and conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of such person. The expense or premium of such bonds shall be paid by the board. The treasurer elected by the board shall have custody of all funds of the board other than those funds appropriated by the city council, subject to the control of the board. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(4), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1355. - Operation of facilities. 
The Alabama Constitution Village Board of the city is granted custody and control of Alabama Constitution Village and adjacent property, and the old Memphis and Charleston Depot and adjacent property, and is further authorized and directed to operate those facilities as historical museums to serve the people of the city and also to operate such additional facilities as may be entrusted to it for operation by special resolution of the council. It shall adopt from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, rules and regulations governing the facilities of the city entrusted to its operation and management provided such bylaws and rules and regulations are not in conflict with this division or any laws of the state related to museum establishment and maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(3), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1356. - Powers. 
The Alabama Constitution Village Board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Do the acts and things necessary to carry out the objectives and purposes set forth in this division; 
(2)  Acquire by purchase, gift or loan any money, securities, objects of historical or artistic value, and other property, other than real property, for museum purposes and uses; 
(3)  Buy and sell, and otherwise deal, in the name of the city, in property necessary to carry out its objectives; 
(4)  Cooperate with any public or private corporation or organization; 
(5)  Do any lawful act necessary or expedient to improve such museum facilities for the people of the city; 
(6)  Provide for exhibitions, particularly to students of the public schools, and in general to the population of the city, depicting the role of the city and the county in the formation of the state, with particular emphasis on the portrayal of life during the era when the state was being formed and while the city served as the site of the first Constitutional Convention and as its first (temporary) capital; 
(7)  Encourage by appropriate means the cultivation of interest in the cultural and social value of Alabama Constitution Village, and recognition of the impact of the city upon the development and growth of the state; 
(8)  Provide for the exhibitions of the commercial, industrial and transportation aspects of the city's heritage; 
(9)  Encourage by appropriate means the cultivation of interest in the evolution of commerce, industry and transportation in North Alabama and recognition of the impact of these factors upon the development and growth of the city and its environs; and 
(10)  Provide rules and regulations for its governance and the governance of its officials, employees and personnel under contract to it, and of any premises or property which may, from time to time, be in its custody provided such rules and regulations are in accordance with and do not conflict with or otherwise violate any provision of this Code or other ordinance or resolution of the city. 
In the exercise of its power, the board shall have no power or authority to obligate the city beyond the amount appropriated by the city council for its purposes. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(6), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1357. - Management, custody, and control of objects of historical significance. 
The management, custody and control of objects of historical significance or other objects belonging to the city which the city council may by resolution place under the control and management of the Alabama Constitution Village Board shall be vested in the board; and the board shall exercise, subject to the control of the city council, all the powers of the city with respect to establishing, maintaining, and operating the facilities contemplated in this division. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(7), 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1358. - Budgets, appropriations, financial procedures. 
(a)  The Alabama Constitution Village Board shall submit to the mayor, on or before June 30 of each year, a detailed budget of estimated expenditures for the fiscal year commencing October 1 of that year. The city council may set aside and appropriate for the use of the board, for the maintenance of the Alabama Constitution Village or the Depot Museum, and for the other authorized purposes of the board, either all or such part of such estimated budget as may be available or is deemed proper by the city council. 
(b)  The amount of the appropriation made from time to time by the city council for the support and maintenance of the Alabama Constitution Village and the Huntsville Depot Museum shall be held by the city clerk-treasurer and shall be paid out by him only on vouchers formally approved by the board, or by one of the following officers: the chairman of the board, the vice-chairman of the board, or the chairman of the finance committee of the board. In all cases where such vouchers are approved by one of such officers, their action shall be reviewed by the board at its next regular meeting. Such vouchers shall be retained in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(c)  Funds, other than those appropriated by the city council, shall be administered by the board and expended by it for authorized purposes only, for the operation of Alabama Constitution Village or the Huntsville Depot Museum, including the carrying out of any of the objectives or purposes set forth in this division, and all pertinent books and records shall at all times be subject to inspection and audit by the city clerk-treasurer, or other person designated by the mayor or the city council. 
(d)  For the purpose of coordinating the accounting with that used in the department of finance of the city, the director of finance is authorized to determine the method of accounting for all receipts and expenditures of the board, including the form of vouchers and general accounting records. 
(Ord. No. 95-535, § 1(8), 8-10-1995)  
Secs. 2-1359—2-1380. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ANIMAL SERVICES ADVISORY COMMITTEE[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference— Animals, ch. 5. 
 
Sec. 2-1381. - Created. 
The Animal Services Advisory Committee is created.  
Sec. 2-1382. - Membership. 
(a)  The Animal Services Advisory Committee shall be composed of seven members appointed as provided in this division; and each member shall be a resident of the city who has a recognized interest in the preservation and quality of animal life, as follows: 
(1)  Place one shall be a practicing veterinarian licensed in the city and a member of the county veterinarian association, and shall be appointed to the committee by the city council. 
(2)  Places two, three, four, and five shall be members from the community at large and shall be nominated and appointed by the city council. 
(3)  Places six and seven shall be members from the community at large and shall be appointed by the mayor. 
(b)  The Director of the Animal Services Center and the Director of the Huntsville/Madison County Health Department, or his designee, shall serve as ex officio (nonvoting) members of the committee. The ex officio members shall serve throughout the length of the respective terms of the directors. 
(c)  Initially, places one and two shall be appointed for three-year terms; places three and four shall be appointed for two-year terms; and places five, six and seven shall be appointed for one-year terms. After the initial terms, each place shall be appointed for three-year terms. 
(d)  An appointee shall cease to be a member of the committee upon the appointee's death or resignation or upon the appointee's ceasing to reside in the city. Appointments to fill any vacancies on the committee shall be made only for the unexpired portion of the term so vacated. 
(e)  Committee members shall serve without compensation, except that committee members may be reimbursed for reasonable and necessary expenses which are incurred in the performance of their duties provided that sufficient funds have been appropriated for that purpose by the city council.  
Sec. 2-1383. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The Animal Services Advisory Committee shall meet and organize as soon as possible after appointments. The committee shall annually elect from among its members a chairman, vice-chairman and a secretary. The committee, after election of its own officers, shall keep or cause to be kept a full and complete record of all of its proceedings. Such records shall set forth the reasons for the committee's decisions. The records of the committee shall be open for public inspection at the office of the director of the animal control center during normal business hours. 
(b)  The Animal Services Advisory Committee shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedures consistent with the provisions of this section. The committee shall hold regular meetings at least once every calendar month at any time fixed by rule or resolution of the committee. The chairman or any three members of the committee may call a special meeting for any stated purpose on at least 24 hours' notice to each member by mail or telephone. Four members of the Animal Services Advisory Committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No committee member shall act in any case in which he has a personal interest. Any official action of this committee must be by majority vote of those present and voting.  
Sec. 2-1384. - Assistance. 
The Director of the Animal Services Center shall furnish services from his staff to assist the Animal Services Advisory Committee on its functions.  
Sec. 2-1385. - Authority and duties generally. 
The Animal Services Advisory Committee shall have the following duties and authority: 
(1)  As a principal function, to advise and give recommendations to the Director of the Animal Services Center on the management of the city's Animal Services Center and program. 
(2)  To hold public hearings and conduct public meetings at which citizens of the city are invited to comment on any aspect of the animal control program. 
(3)  To make recommendations to the Director of the Animal Services Center concerning the organization, administration, financing and/or regulations of the Animal Services Department of the city. 
(4)  To assist the Director of the Animal Services Center in collecting and disseminating information and conducting educational programs relating to the activities and programs that are being carried out by the animal control program. 
(5)  To encourage voluntary cooperation of interested citizens and affected groups to achieve the goals and objectives of the animal control program. 
(6)  To form subcommittees to assist in carrying out its functions. 
(7)  To submit periodic reports to the mayor, city council and Director of the Animal Services Center concerning activities of the committee.  
Secs. 2-1386—2-1400. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - BEAUTIFICATION BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1401. - Created. 
The Beautification Board is created.  
Sec. 2-1402. - Membership. 
(a)  The Beautification Board shall be composed of 21 members, 18 of which shall be appointed by the city council and four of which shall serve as provided in this section. 
(b)  Members of the board shall be appointed and shall serve as follows: 
(1)  The city council shall appoint 18 members to serve for a term of three years, and until their successor shall be appointed and qualified. 
(2)  The Operation Green Team director, during his or her term as such. 
(3)  The chair of the Botanical Garden Society, during his or her term as such. 
(4)  A member of the county legislative delegation who represents any portion of the city selected by the entire county delegation, for a term designated by the delegation, but such term not to exceed the term of the designee in such legislative office. 
(c)  No person shall be eligible to serve on the board who is not a bona fide resident citizen of the City of Huntsville or Madison County. 
(d)  Vacancies on the board shall be filled by appointment in the same manner and on the same conditions provided for initial members. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term. An appointee shall cease to be a member upon resignation to the city council, upon ceasing to be a resident of Madison County or the City of Huntsville, or upon two-thirds vote of the board for failure to attend meetings. 
(e)  The members of the board shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for the reasonable and necessary expenses actually incurred in the performance of their duty, provided, however, such expenses shall be limited to such amounts as may be appropriated by the city council. 
(Ord. No. 10-65, 2-11-2010; Ord. No. 11-259, § 1, 5-12-2011)  
Sec. 2-1403. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The Beautification Board shall hold regular meetings at such time and place within the city as it may determine; provided, however, that the board shall hold at least one meeting every 90 days. 
(b)  At the first meeting of the board, the members shall elect one of its number as the chairman and one of its number as secretary. The board shall have the discretion to split the duties of secretary between a recording secretary and a corresponding secretary. Thereafter, the board shall annually elect from among its number a chairman and secretary or secretaries and such other officers as it may from time to time determine necessary and appropriate for the conduct of board proceedings. The ex officio members of the board shall not be eligible to be officers. 
(c)  Vacancies in the office of chairman and secretary and in other offices as herein provided shall be filled by the board from among the membership of the board for the unexpired term. 
(d)  The chairman of the board or any six members of the board may call a meeting at any time. 
(e)  The chairman and any nine members of the board shall constitute a quorum for the conduct of business at all regular or special meetings. 
(f)  A thorough record of all meetings of the board shall be kept by the secretary. On the call of any member, the vote upon any pending question shall be taken by ayes and nays and the same shall be entered on the record. A record of the proceedings of the board shall be open to the mayor and to any member of the city council and to the public at all reasonable times. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public. 
(Ord. No. 11-259, § 2, 5-12-2011)  
Sec. 2-1404. - Appropriations. 
The city council shall appropriate such funds from the general fund which it may deem necessary for the reasonable and necessary expenses of the Beautification Board.  
Sec. 2-1405. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The Beautification Board shall have the following powers and duties: In exercising its powers and duties, the board is authorized to create committees and subcommittees composed entirely of members of the board, or composed of members of the board along with nonmember citizens selected by the board. The board and any committee of the board is authorized to consider and make recommendations with respect to appropriate uses and improvements planned or proposed for any public ground or open space pursuant to any immediate or long-range plan. The mayor, the city council, and the planning commission of the city are authorized to request consultation from the board, or from any committee, with respect to the proposed improvement of any public ground or open space. Provided further that: 
(1)  All requests received by city administration and departments from individuals, organizations, businesses, other cities and/or foreign countries to donate, place or have placed special, one-of-a-kind monuments, memorials, commemorative markers, plantings or structures in any city park or other municipally owned open space is required to be forwarded to the Beautification Board for its recommendation on the appropriateness of the request as regards both the object to be placed and the location specified; 
(2)  Any addition, deletion or alteration of any type, whether originating from a city agency or an outside group or individual, contemplated for Big Spring International Park, should be forwarded to the Beautification Board for its review and comments; and 
(3)  Review by the Beautification Board is not required for requests to place or donate objects at any municipal site already supervised by its own board of directors. 
(b)  The Beautification Board will send the requests to a committee of the board composed of board members and such nonmembers and consultants as the board may choose to appoint or invite. 
(c)  A recommendation on appropriateness will be submitted by the Beautification Board, in writing, stating the reason for modification or denial if any, to all concerned city departments and to the planning commission, if the latter body must review the request for location, character and extent. 
(d)  The decision or recommendation by the Beautification Board will be returned by the board within a reasonable time. Departments and agencies of the city submitting such requests to the Beautification Board are required to consider all recommendations before proceeding with any actual work or construction to the end that a comprehensive, coordinated program for beautification of public spaces will result to the extent practicable. 
(Ord. No. 86-136, 3-27-1986)  
Secs. 2-1406—2-1420. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - BURRITT MEMORIAL COMMITTEE[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
Editor's note— The purposes, structure, and composition of the Burritt Memorial Committee are dictated by the last will and testament of the late Dr. William Henry Burritt. 
Cross reference— Cemeteries, ch. 9. 
 
Sec. 2-1421. - Created. 
The Burritt Memorial Committee is created.  
Sec. 2-1422. - Membership. 
(a)  The Burritt Memorial Committee shall consist of ten members. 
(b)  A majority of the membership of the committee shall be composed of members of the female sex, each of whom shall be a person who is interested in garden clubs and/or the beautification of the city and none of whom may be officers or employees of the city. The members of the female sex who may be appointed to the committee shall, upon acceptance of appointment, signify in writing by certificate filed with the city clerk-treasurer their interest in garden clubs and/or the beautification of the city. The failure of any members of the female sex to file such certificate within 30 days after notification of appointment to the committee shall be deemed an automatic rejection of the appointment. 
(c)  The members of the committee shall be appointed by the city council to serve as follows: two members to serve until October 1, 1956, and until their successors are elected and qualified; two members to serve until October 1, 1957, and until their successors are elected and qualified; two members to serve until October 1, 1958, and until their successors are elected and qualified; two members to serve until October 1, 1959, and until their successors are elected and qualified; two members to serve until October 1, 1960, and until their successors are elected and qualified. At the first regular meeting of the city council in the month of September of each year, the council shall select successors of the members of the committee whose terms expires on October 1 following, and the persons so selected shall become members of the committee on October 1 following and shall hold such position for a period of five years and until their successors are elected and qualified. Should the city council fail to elect such members at its first meeting in September of each year, it shall do so at any succeeding regular meeting. A member of the committee may succeed himself if the city council desires to reelect him. Whenever a vacancy occurs in the membership of the committee by resignation, death or any other cause, the city council shall immediately fill such vacancy by electing another person to membership on the committee, who shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term of the member he succeeds and until his successor is elected and qualified. 
(d)  No member of the committee shall receive any compensation for his services.  
Sec. 2-1423. - Officers, rules of order. 
Within ten days after the Burritt Memorial Committee has been appointed and qualified as provided in this division, the committee shall meet and elect its own officers and prescribe its own rules of order. Thereafter, the committee shall meet monthly. The committee shall keep accurate minutes of each meeting, and they shall be available for inspection by the mayor or any member of the city council.  
Sec. 2-1424. - Duties. 
(a)  The Burritt Memorial Committee shall be vested with the management, control and supervision of the Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park. 
(b)  The overall duties of the committee shall be to supervise and govern the maintenance and operation of the park and museum. The committee shall have full authority to employ and discharge employees in carrying out their duties. The committee shall, within 30 days following its appointment, after being constituted as provided in this division, and yearly thereafter on or before September 1, adopt a detailed budget of estimated expenditures for the coming year, which shall be transmitted in a formal communication to the city council. Upon its receipt, the city council shall make suitable provisions for the appropriation from the Dr. William Henry Burritt Memorial Fund as provided for in this section for the use of the committee for the performance of its duties as set out in this division. The committee may, in its discretion, make a small charge for those viewing the museum, which amount shall be transmitted daily to the city clerk-treasurer for deposit by the city clerk-treasurer in the Burritt Memorial Fund.  
Secs. 2-1425—2-1450. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - CITY TREE COMMISSION[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 27. 
 
Sec. 2-1451. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adopted standards means those standards of tree maintenance, trimming clearances, and methods of protecting trees during construction, adapted from recognized national standards (such as the National Arborist Association, International Society of Arboriculture, etc.) recommended for local adoption by the tree commission and ratified by the city council. 
Owner means the possessor of title to the land on which particular trees stand, or his agent; in the case of a tree on public rights-of-way, utility easements or land on which another public interest has been granted, ownership rights and responsibilities are as defined in section 27-52 in the absence of other specific provisions by deed or other binding agreement. 
Public land means any land belonging to the city. For the purposes of this definition, federal, state and county land is excluded from this category unless the city has specifically assumed responsibility for its maintenance. 
Shrub. See Trees and shrubs. 
Trees and shrubs means all woody vegetation, whether naturally occurring or planted. Rights, responsibilities and standards applying to trees shall, from a legal standpoint, apply to shrubs as well. 
Tree bank means a noncommercial nursery where trees and shrubs are maintained for transplanting to school grounds or to other public lands or public rights-of-way, utility easements, or land on which another public interest has been granted. 
Tree commission means the city forestry horticulture supervisor, any member of the tree commission, or any individual assigned or contracted by the tree commission, acting in pursuit of the objectives of this division within its scope and within the bounds of law. 
Tree removal, commercial, means commercial practices, including pruning of trees, and removal of trees in the following situations: trees on property approved for occupancy by the inspection department, trees being removed under contract in the course of utility or right-of-way maintenance, or trees being removed by any person who receives compensation commercially. This shall not be construed to include bona fide loggers, individuals personally removing or working on trees on their own land, or heavy equipment operators whose work may include whole tree removal as a normal element of site preparation. 
Tree service, commercial, means commercial practices, including pruning, cavity filling, wound treatment, bracing, cabling, and other repairs; the feeding of trees; protection of trees from lightning, insects and disease. For the purposes of this definition, any licensed commercial tree service operator shall be authorized to provide tree removal services as defined in this section. 
Utility, private, means a commercial service distributed by use of the public streets, alleys and easements of the city by use of the facilities and fixtures located in such places but not regulated by the state public service commission. 
Utility, public, means a service distributed by wire, pipe or airwaves to customers and either regulated by the state public service commission (as in the case of telephone service) or not regulated by the state public service commission but established as a municipal utility (as in the case of water, electric, and gas service). 
(Ord. No. 96-952, §§ 1—4, 11-25-1996) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 2-1452. - Created. 
The Tree Commission is created.  
Sec. 2-1453. - Membership. 
(a)  The Tree Commission shall consist of eight voting members and nonvoting ex officio members as follows: 
(1)  One employee of the city's utility company having knowledge of both engineering problems and tree maintenance problems; 
(2)  One professional forester, botanist or horticulturist employed by an agency of government or an educational institution having knowledge of urban forestry problems and licensed as required in the state for the conduct of his profession; 
(3)  Two professional members such as licensed tree service operators, licensed architects or landscape architects, licensed landscaping contractors or others as appropriate; 
(4)  Four other voting members selected at large from the residents of diverse parts of the city and chosen for their knowledge of, concern about and participation in issues affecting the city's tree population; and 
(5)  As nonvoting ex officio members, representatives of the departments of community development, recreation and landscape management, public works services, parking and public transit, the inspection division and the forestry horticulture supervisor. 
(b)  The utilities employees shall be appointed by the general manager of the utility company; the forester, botanist or horticulturist shall be appointed by the city council; one professional member and two at-large members shall be appointed by the mayor and like numbers by the city council. 
(c)  All terms of office of voting members shall be two years, except that the initial terms of the professional and at-large members shall be staggered according to the direction of the appointing authorities. Vacancies caused by death, resignation or otherwise shall be filled for the unexpired term in the same manner as the original appointments were made. Members will continue to serve after the expiration of their appointed terms until replacements are made and installed. 
(d)  Any member who fails to attend more than three regular meetings within a 12-month period, without justification satisfactory to the remaining members of the commission, will be considered to have resigned his appointment and will be replaced for the balance of his term by the appointing authority. 
(e)  All appointed members will serve without pay though the city may choose to reimburse members for out-of-town travel in the line of duty and other expenses incurred with prior consent of the mayor's office.  
Sec. 2-1454. - Meetings; officers. 
The Tree Commission shall conduct regular meetings and other called meetings as needed. It shall make its own rules of order, keep records of its proceedings, and annually elect from its voting members a chairman, vice-chairman, and such other officers as it may deem necessary; the forestry horticulture supervisor shall act as its secretary-treasurer. A majority of its voting members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business.  
Sec. 2-1455. - Duties. 
(a)  The Tree Commission shall: 
(1)  Study problems involving the city's tree population, determine needs, compose and annually review a city tree plan, and seek ways to implement needed work; 
(2)  Develop standards of tree maintenance and other specifications such as to foster the city's tree population, protect persons and property against injury, provide for safe and efficient passage of persons, vehicles and utilities through recognized rights-of-way; 
(3)  Act as the board of appeals, to review contested decisions and actions of the forestry horticulture supervisor; 
(4)  Assist the community and its officials in disseminating information about protection, maintenance and improvement of the city's tree population; 
(5)  Propose such legislation as may be needed and practicable to pursue the end for which the Tree Commission was created; 
(6)  Plan and coordinate an annual Arbor Week observance each year in cooperation with schools, conservation organizations, and other interested parties; and 
(7)  Monitor the licensure of tree service companies practicing in the city and initiate action toward enforcement of this division and chapter 27, article II. 
(b)  The Tree Commission may undertake and participate in cooperative projects, including but not limited to the following: 
(1)  Recycling of leaves, chips, firewood, logs and other byproducts of tree maintenance; 
(2)  Development of tree planting systems in conjunction with other public and/or private agencies; 
(3)  Development and use of a tree bank in cooperation with other public and/or private agencies; 
(4)  Development of a botanical garden for the city; 
(5)  Education of the public concerning tree maintenance; 
(6)  Providing technical advice and assistance to developers, builders, contractors, etc., in the selection and protection of naturally occurring trees during the development of wooded areas; and 
(7)  Communication with such professional and technical services as it may see fit within the scope of this division. 
(c)  The Tree Commission shall compose annually and present to the mayor's office during the month of July a city tree plan; and upon its acceptance and approval, it shall constitute the official comprehensive plan for the management of the city's tree population.  
Sec. 2-1456. - Priorities. 
(a)  The Tree Commission, with the assistance of the forestry horticulture supervisor, shall develop an orderly process for identifying public tree needs, including, but not limited to, maintenance, removals, planting, replacement and public education, and shall be empowered to purchase or contract for needed products and services within the city's normal fiscal limitations. 
(b)  The Tree Commission shall establish priorities for reports made by the forestry horticulture supervisor.  
Sec. 2-1457. - Budget. 
The budget for all technical and administrative activities planned for the Tree Commission shall be developed by the forestry horticultural supervisor. The city council will appropriate funds for the same as items in the natural resources and environmental management department budget.  
Sec. 2-1458. - Authorization to conduct financial transactions. 
The Tree Commission is empowered to accept and use donations to obligate authorized public funds and to conduct other financial business in conformity with established procedures of the city in the proper conduct of its assigned work.  
Secs. 2-1459—2-1480. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT CITIZENS ADVISORY COUNCIL[14] 

Footnotes: 
--- (14) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 03-642, adopted Aug. 14, 2003, amended provisions set out as div. 9 of this article in their entirety to read as herein set out. Prior to amendment, div. 9, §§ 2-1481—2-1484, pertained to similar subject matter and derived unamended from the original Code. 
 
Sec. 2-1481. - Established. 
There is hereby established within the city a committee to be known as the "Community Development Citizens Advisory Council of the City of Huntsville, Alabama," hereinafter referred to as the "advisory council." 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Sec. 2-1482. - Membership, terms; vacancies. 
The advisory council shall be composed of 13 members appointed by the city council. Nine members shall reside within the areas defined by the department of housing and urban development as consisting predominately of low and moderate income families. Four members shall reside in the remaining areas of the city. Four members shall initially be appointed for a term of one year, four shall be appointed for two years, and five will be appointed for three years. Thereafter, all appointments shall be for a term of three years. Appointments to fill vacancies shall be for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Sec. 2-1483. - Cessation of membership. 
An appointee shall cease to be a member upon resignation, upon ceasing to be or becoming a resident of a low and moderate income area as defined by the department of housing and urban development during the period of appointment, or for failure to attend three consecutive meetings. 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Sec. 2-1484. - Compensation. 
The members of the advisory council shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Sec. 2-1485. - Organization, meetings; quorum. 
(a)  The advisory council shall hold regular meetings at such time and place within the city as it may from time to time determine, provided, however, that regular meetings shall be scheduled during the months of September, October, November, December, January, February and May of each year. 
(b)  Vacancies in the offices of chairman or vice-chairman, shall be filled by the advisory council if and when the same may occur. 
(c)  Special meetings may be called by the chairman, or by the vice chairman in absence of the chairman, at any time he/she considers that business at hand demands that a meeting be held. A majority of the current members of the advisory council shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Sec. 2-1486. - Authority and duties generally. 
The advisory council shall serve as an advisory group for the purpose of recommending how community development funds should be spent within the city. It shall represent, generally, all areas of the city, and shall serve as the focal point for all citizens' requests for disbursement of community development funds. 
(Ord. No. 03-642, 8-14-2003)  
Secs. 2-1487—2-1500. - Reserved.
