DIVISION 12. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION COMMISSION[17] 

Footnotes: 
--- (17) --- 
Cross reference— Cultural facilities and historical preservation, ch. 10. 
State Law reference— Historic preservation commissions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-68-1 et seq.; application of statutes to existing commissions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-68-14. 
 
Sec. 2-1541. - Established. 
There is established in the city an historic preservation commission which is designated and shall be known as "The Huntsville Historic Preservation Commission." 
(Code 1982, § 10-41)  
Sec. 2-1542. - Members; terms; vacancies. 
(a)  The Historic Preservation Commission created in this division shall be composed of nine members, including one member of the city council designated by it, the manager of planning and the manager of inspection. The members of the commission first appointed, except the manager of planning, the manager of inspection and the member of the city council, who shall all serve by virtue of and whose terms shall correspond with the respective terms of their offices, shall serve for terms of one, two, three, four, five and six years respectively, as shall be specified by the mayor at the time of their appointment. Thereafter, the members of the commission, except the ex officio members, shall serve for terms of six years. 
(b)  At the expiration of the term or the death or resignation of any member, the resulting vacancy shall be filled for the unexpired term of such member in the same manner as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  No distinction shall be made between the ex officio members and other members of the commission. 
(d)  At least three of the members appointed by the mayor shall reside in and own homes in an historic preservation district within the city at the time of their appointment. At any time that there are fewer than three members of the commission appointed by the mayor who are resident owners, the next subsequent appointments shall be limited to such persons until there are three such appointed members. 
(Code 1982, § 10-42)  
Sec. 2-1543. - Duties, powers. 
The Historic Preservation Commission is vested with all of the duties and powers authorized to be delegated to such a commission under the terms of Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-68-4—11-68-12, and under the terms of Act No. 1307 of 1971 and enumerated in such statutes and act. To the extent there are any conflicts between such statutes and such act, such statutes shall control; however, no action shall be taken by the commission concerning any property within any historic preservation district without prior notice to the owner of the property, according to the rules of the commission; and no owner may be required to open his property to any tour of any kind for public viewing. 
(Code 1982, § 10-43; Ord. No. 91-597, § 1, 10-24-1991; Ord. No. 95-210, § 1, 4-1-1995)  
Secs. 2-1544—2-1560. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 13. - HUNTSVILLE ICE SKATING COMPLEX BOARD OF CONTROL 
 
Sec. 2-1561. - Created. 
The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control is created.  
Sec. 2-1562. - Membership. 
(a)  The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall consist of seven members. 
(b)  The terms of the members of the initial board shall be and are made by the city council as follows: 
Position 
No. 	Term 
(years) 
1 	5 
2 	3 
3 	1 
4 	5 
5 	5 
6 	3 
7 	1 
 
(c)  Thereafter, at the end of the stated term of each member of the initial board, all appointments to positions 1, 3, 5 and 7 of the board shall be appointed by the city council; and all appointments to positions 2, 4 and 6 of the board shall be appointed by the mayor. Each appointment shall be for a term of three years. Vacancies in any position shall be filled for any unexpired term by the governing authority who originally made the appointment to that position. 
(d)  In addition, the mayor shall have the authority with the approval by a majority of the city council to appoint two ex officio directors who shall have the authority to attend all meetings of the board and be recognized and enter into all discussions on matters before the board. These ex officio members shall have the same rights as other directors to vote on matters coming before the board, but such ex officio members shall not serve as officers. The ex officio directors shall serve for such term as may be determined by the mayor, but not to exceed the mayor's term. Any regular or ex officio directors may be reappointed for one or more successive terms.  
Sec. 2-1563. - Officers. 
The members of the Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall, in accordance with the bylaws of the board of control, elect one of their number as chairman, one of their number as vice-chairman, one of their number as secretary, and one of their number as treasurer. One person may serve as secretary and treasurer. Officers shall be entitled to succeed themselves. Vacancies shall be filled by the board for the unexpired terms.  
Sec. 2-1564. - Quorum; conflicts, action by board. 
Four members of the Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No member shall act in any case in which he has a personal financial interest. Actions of the board of control shall be by majority of those present.  
Sec. 2-1565. - Policies. 
The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall have the authority to adopt written policies and guidelines for usage of the ice skating and related facilities, including rates, a copy of which shall be furnished to the mayor and the city council. These policies may provide for the manager or director to negotiate agreements for use of the facilities, but all such agreements shall be subject to the approval of the board of control. The policies and guidelines may be amended, from time to time, at the discretion of the board of control, provided that copies of all such amendments are furnished to the mayor and council.  
Sec. 2-1566. - Expenses of members; salaries of employees. 
The members of the Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall receive no compensation whatever for their services, nor shall they receive compensation or per diem for attending meetings; however, actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties may be paid. The board of control shall not be required to adhere to the general salary structure of the city general fund in connection with the hiring of employees; however at the annual budget review meeting with the council, the board of control and the council will review the employees' salary structure of the board of control.  
Sec. 2-1567. - Treasurer; bond; duties; assistants. 
The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall elect from its members a treasurer and such assistant treasurers as it deems advisable, each of whom shall give bond with corporate surety in the amount of $10,000.00, payable to the board of control and to the city, with condition to discharge faithfully all the duties of their respective offices. The expenses or premiums of such bond shall be paid by the board of control out of its revenues. The treasurer elected by the board of control shall have custody and, subject to the direction of the board of control, control of all operating revenues and funds of the board of control. The treasurer shall have the right, subject to direction of the board of control, to invest and reinvest all operating revenues and funds of the board of control in such deposits and investments that are, at such time, approved deposits or investments for city funds.  
Sec. 2-1568. - Powers. 
(a)  The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control is granted custody of and authorized to maintain, control, operate and manage for and on behalf of the city the present Huntsville ice skating complex or any new complex to be constructed and owned by the city (collectively, the "facility"). They shall adopt from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, rules and regulations governing the facility provided such bylaws and rules and regulations are not in conflict with this division or any laws of the state. They shall have the power to arrange, sponsor, contract for and conduct programs, tournaments, shows, exhibitions, contests, skating leagues, performances, meetings, skating lessons and other recreational activities in the facility for the advancement of the cultural and civic interest and welfare of the citizens of the city. 
(b)  Subject to the requirements of this division or any laws of the state, the additional powers which the board of control may exercise in order to effectuate the purposes delineated in subsection (a) of this section shall include but are not necessarily limited to the following: 
(1)  Charge, establish and revise fees for admission, parking and other events conducted at the facility; 
(2)  Rent, lease or otherwise provide all or any part of the facility for tournaments, shows, leagues, programs, lessons, exhibitions, contests, performances, skating leagues and other recreational activities; 
(3)  Acquire, hold, sell and otherwise dispose of any personal property, subject, in the case of any acquisition of personal property, to a budget approved by the council or the available excess funds of the board not needed for any current year's expenditures; 
(4)  Subject to the provisions of section 2-1570, make, enter into and execute such contracts, agreements, and other instruments and take such other actions as may be necessary or convenient to accomplish any purpose of the board or to exercise any power that is either expressly granted to the board or must, by necessary implication, be exercisable by it in order to accomplish any purpose in this division; 
(5)  Receive and accept, in the name of the city, from any source, aid, contributions, bequests and devises, whether in the form of money, property, labor or other things of value, to be held, used and applied by the board to carry out the purposes expressed in this division, subject to any lawful condition upon which they may be given or made; 
(6)  Subject to the limitations set forth in section 2-1570, appoint, employ and contract with such employees and agents, including, without limitation, managers, teachers, professional skating instructors, attorneys, accountants, financial experts, fiscal agents and such other advisors, consultants and agents as may be in the judgment of the board necessary or desirable, and to fix their compensation; 
(7)  Enter into such management and other contracts as may in the judgment of the board be necessary or desirable in order to delegate and perform more effectively, efficiently or economically the day-to-day operations of the facility as well as various clerical, accounting and administrative functions for which the board may become responsible in the exercise of the powers conferred upon it in this division; 
(8)  If not otherwise provided by the city, and subject to the limitations set forth in section 2-1570, procure or agree to procure from any insurance company, insurance protecting any member of the board of control, the board or the facility from liabilities under broad form coverages and errors and omission coverages; 
(9)  Accumulate all income, operating revenues and other funds of the board not required for immediate use and apply all such accumulated funds to the cost of extensions, renovations, repairs and improvements to the facility, as may be determined by the board; however, no such extensions, renovations, improvements or repairs shall obligate the city beyond the amounts, if any, appropriated by the city to the board for such purposes; 
(10)  Arrange, contract for, conduct, lease or sponsor a skate or pro shop for the repair, rental and sale of skates and related items and to arrange, contract for, conduct, lease and sponsor a snack bar and any other related activities necessary or useful for the enjoyment of the facility; 
(11)  In general, and subject to the limitations and conditions as provided, exercise such other powers necessary or incidental to the powers conferred in this division, or conducive to the attainment of the purposes of the board; and 
(12)  Establish and maintain deposit and investment accounts in the name of the board with banks, savings and loans and other institutions, including but not limited to money market funds, and make all deposits and withdrawals as the board of control may authorize.  
Sec. 2-1569. - Advertising authorized. 
The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control may advertise its facility, programs, tournaments, shows, exhibitions, performances, events and other recreational activities on behalf of the city and may expend such funds as may be appropriated to it for that purpose or such additional funds as may be in the possession of the board in excess of the amounts necessary to meet any expenditures required to be paid by the board of control. No material for the advertising and promotion carried on by the board shall directly promote any privately owned business or entity.  
Sec. 2-1570. - Purchases and contracts. 
(a)  The board shall have the power to make contracts in the name of the board for the purposes set forth in section 2-1568 and for acquisition of personal property or services to be used in furtherance of the purposes for which the board has been created, and to execute all contracts necessary or convenient for such purposes; however, the board shall have no power or authority to obligate the city beyond the amount appropriated by the council for its purposes. 
(b)  In making expenditures for personal property or services authorized in this division, the board of control shall, in all respects, comply with Code of Ala. 1975 tit. 41, ch. 16 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-1 et seq.); however, as to property that is stocked or purchased in quantity by the purchasing agent of the city, the board may requisition such property from the inventory of the city at cost; and where tangible personal property is to be acquired by the board which is the same or substantially similar to like property acquired by the purchasing agent of the city, the board of control may request that the needs of the city and the board be acquired by joint bid and purchase, in which case the property shall be acquired by the purchasing agent of the city and transferred to the board of control at the unit or pro rata price. 
(c)  The board of control shall designate a person employed by the board or the city to act as the board's purchasing agent and may provide, by resolution or bylaw entered upon the minutes of the board, that the purchasing agent so designated shall have the authority to act as awarding authority for and on behalf of the board in all or any specified class of purchases; however, if a bid is received for an item of personal property to be purchased or contracted for from a person who has continuously maintained a place of business within the city for which a business license has been paid to the city during the current and immediately preceding license year, deemed to be a responsible bidder, which such bid is no more than three percent greater than the bid of the lowest responsible bidder, and where such personal property is either manufactured within the city or regularly warehoused and stored for distribution at a place within the city, the awarding authority shall award the contract to such resident responsible bidder. 
(Ord. No. 97-887, § 2, 11-20-1997; Ord. No. 98-29, § 1, 1-22-1998; Ord. No. 02-52, 2-14-2002)  
Sec. 2-1571. - Budget. 
In accordance with the terms of section 2-152, the Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall submit a detailed budget of estimated expenditures for the fiscal year commencing October 1 of each year and a five-year capital plan. The council shall set aside and appropriate for the use of the board, for the maintenance and operation of the facility, and for the other authorized purposes of the board, either all or such part of such estimated budget as may be available or is by the council deemed proper. Notwithstanding an approved budget, the board of control shall not be prevented from expending its excess funds not needed to meet its anticipated yearly expenses for such purchases, improvements, renovations, repairs and extensions as the board may deem best advisable, so long as the city does not become obligated beyond the amount appropriated in such budget.  
Sec. 2-1572. - Officers and employees. 
The Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall have the power to appoint a manager and such other officers and employees as it may deem necessary and desirable, and to fix its duties, authorities and compensation. The manager of the facility appointed by the board shall be responsible to the board of control for the day-to-day administration of the facility and for the supervision and control of the other officers and employees of the board.  
Sec. 2-1573. - Audit. 
At least once each year, the Huntsville Ice Skating Complex Board of Control shall appoint an independent public accountant to conduct an examination or review in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards of all books and accounts of the board of control since the preceding examination, and to make a full report in writing, under oath, which shall be submitted by the board to the council, the city clerk-treasurer and the mayor at its first meeting after the completion of such report.  
Secs. 2-1574—2-1590. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 14. - HUNTSVILLE-MADISON COUNTY CONVENTION AND VISITORS BUREAU BOARD OF DIRECTORS 
 
Sec. 2-1591. - Created. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Control is created.  
Sec. 2-1592. - Membership. 
(a)  The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall consist of seven members whose appointments and terms shall be as follows: 
(1)  Of the members first appointed, three members from the current board of the Huntsville Convention & Visitors Bureau shall be appointed, one by the mayor for a term of three years and two by the city council for a term of one and two years respectively. 
(2)  Two members from the current advisory committee of the Madison County Tourism Board and one member at-large shall be appointed by the county commission for terms of one year, two years and three years respectively. 
(3)  One member from the Von Braun Center Board of Control shall be appointed by that board for a term of four years. 
(4)  Following the initial terms, the term of all appointed members shall be for four years. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term by the appointing agencies in the same manner in which original appointments were made. 
(5)  The city council and the county commission may each, at their discretion, appoint one ex officio, nonvoting member to the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors. 
(b)  The members of the board of directors shall receive no compensation for their services, nor shall they receive compensation or per diem for attending meetings; however, actual and necessary expenses, in amounts no greater than those appropriated by the city council, incurred in the performance of their duties, may be paid.  
Sec. 2-1593. - Quorum. 
Four members of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No member shall act in any case in which he has a personal financial interest. Actions of the board shall be by a majority of those present. The time and place of meetings shall be posted, and legal notice shall be given as required by state law.  
Sec. 2-1594. - Officers. 
The members of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall, in accordance with the bylaws of the board, elect one of their members as chairman, one of their members as vice-chairman, one of their members as secretary, and one of their members as treasurer. Officers shall be entitled to succeed themselves. Vacancies shall be filled by the board by election for any unexpired terms.  
Sec. 2-1595. - Staff. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall have the power to appoint a director and such other officers and employees as it may deem necessary and desirable and to fix its duties, authorities and compensation. The director of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau appointed by the board shall be responsible to the board for the day-to-day administration of the bureau and for the supervision and control of the other officers and employees of the board.  
Sec. 2-1596. - Powers. 
(a)  The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors is granted custody of and authorized to maintain, control, operate and manage for and on behalf of the city and the county the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau. This agency shall be a full-service public organization responsible for marketing the city-county as a convention site and tourist destination; to increase lodging tax and sales tax receipts, thus increasing the economic base for the city and the county. The board of directors shall adopt from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, rules and regulations governing the operations of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau provided such bylaws and rules and regulations are not in conflict with this division or any laws of the state. 
(b)  The board of directors shall have the power to: 
(1)  Appoint officers, hire employees and fix their compensation; 
(2)  Make contracts; 
(3)  Set policy and oversee programs necessary to bring convention delegates and visitors into the community in an effort to increase visitor spending and thereby boost the economic base in the city and the county; and 
(4)  Execute all instruments necessary or convenient to promote the city and the county as a convention site and visitor destination. 
(c)  The board of directors shall be a municipal board of the city, a municipal corporation of the state, subject to the terms of that certain "Agreement Between the City and the Madison County Commission for the Creation of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention and Visitors Bureau" as manifested by city Resolution No. 91-122, adopted and approved on March 26, 1991, and as the agreement shall be from time to time amended between the city and the county. Any provision of this section to the contrary notwithstanding, the lawful contracts of the board shall be the contracts of the city to the extent authorized in this division, all property of the board shall be the property of the city subject to management and control of the board, and all employees of the board shall be employees of the city but shall be entitled to the benefits and subject to the terms of the bylaws and the personnel policies and procedures as may be approved by the board, and not the benefits or general personnel policies and procedures of the city pertaining to the city's general fund employees who serve under the general administration of the mayor.  
Sec. 2-1597. - Custody of funds. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall elect from its members a treasurer and such assistant treasurers as it deems advisable, each of whom shall give bond with corporate surety in the amount of $10,000.00, payable to the board and to the city and the county commission jointly, condition to discharge faithfully all the duties of their respective offices. The expenses or premiums of such bond shall be paid by the board. The treasurer elected by the board shall have custody of all funds of the board.  
Sec. 2-1598. - Budget. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall submit to the mayor and county commission chairman a detailed budget of estimated expenditures for the fiscal year commencing October 1 of that year. The city council shall set aside and appropriate for the use of the board not less than half of the lodging tax receipts generated by the five percent city lodging tax. An agreement with the county will be signed outlining the appropriation of funds from the county to the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau. The county funds will be comprised of the lodging tax receipts generated by the one-half percent regional lodging tax. It is the intent of both the city and the county commission that the respective appropriations shall be not less than $605,000.00, and $200,000.00 annually.  
Sec. 2-1599. - Audit. 
At least once each year, the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau Board of Directors shall appoint an independent public accountant to conduct an examination in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards of all books and accounts of the board since the preceding examination, and to make a full report in writing, under oath, which shall be submitted by the board to the council and mayor and the county commission at its first meeting after the completion of such report.  
Sec. 2-1600. - Advertising. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau is authorized by the board of directors to advertise and promote city- and county-owned and operated facilities, including but not limited to the Von Braun Center, Huntsville Museum of Art, Huntsville Depot Museum, Constitution Hall Village, Burritt Museum and Park and other cultural and recreational facilities of the city and county. In addition, the bureau may include in its advertising and promotional efforts, material directly advertising and promoting the use of tourist or visitors attractions operated by the state, the county, the city or any public corporation operating within the county, including the U.S. Space & Rocket Center, the Huntsville-Madison County Marina & Port Authority, Monte Sano State Park, and the various parks and recreational facilities of the city and the county. In addition, the bureau may advertise, as part of its general advertising and promotional efforts, the existence of publicly owned and operated landmarks and structures and also the publicly designated historical preservation districts and historical structures of the city and county. No material for the advertising and promotion carried on by the bureau shall directly promote any privately owned business or facility; however, informational material and maps may designate the geographical location, within the city and the county of shopping centers, hotels, restaurants, golf courses, etc., and particular businesses by name where all such businesses in a particular class are identified on a nondiscriminatory basis. The bureau shall also make published promotional material available to the public on a nondiscriminatory basis.  
Sec. 2-1601. - Advisory committee. 
(a)  In order to assist the staff of the Huntsville-Madison County Convention & Visitors Bureau in formulating and carrying out its tourism and convention advertising and promotional programs, there is created a convention and tourism advisory committee composed of seven members to be appointed by the mayor (two appointments), city council (two appointments), and county commission (three appointments). 
(b)  The advisory committee shall be comprised of persons from the hospitality industry, including representatives from hotels and motels, restaurants, attractions and museums, transportation agencies (airlines, car rental agencies), although appointments would not be limited to persons in these categories. 
(c)  Each member of the advisory committee shall serve for a term of two years. 
(d)  Expenses of the advisory committee incurred in the performance of its duties shall be paid by the board; however, no member shall receive compensation for his services.  
Secs. 2-1602—2-1620. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 15. - HUNTSVILLE-MADISON COUNTY EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT BOARD[18] 

Footnotes: 
--- (18) --- 
State Law reference— Emergency management, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-1 et seq.; local emergency management, Code of Ala. 1975, § 31-9-10 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-1621. - Created. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board is created.  
Sec. 2-1622. - Created; membership. 
(a)  The Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board shall consist of five members who shall be designated as serving in places 1, 2, 3, 4, and 5, all of whom must be resident citizens of Madison County, and who shall be appointed as follows: 
(1)  Two members to be appointed by the city council to serve in places 1 and 3. 
(2)  Two members to be appointed by the Madison County Commission to serve in places 2 and 4. 
(3)  One member to be appointed by the City Council of the City of Madison. 
(b)  Each person who is elected to serve as a member of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board shall, before entering upon his duties, take an oath in writing, which oath shall be substantially as follows: 
I, ___________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Alabama, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I will bear true faith and allegiance to the same; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservation or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I a member of any political party or organization that advocates, the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am a member of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the government of the United States or of this state by force or violence. 
(c)  Members of the board shall be selected as follows: 
(1)  The member for place No. 1 selected by the city council. 
(2)  The member for place No. 2 selected by the Madison County Commission. 
(3)  The member for place No. 3 selected by the city council. 
(4)  The member for place No. 4 selected by the Madison County Commission. 
(5)  The member for place No. 5 selected by the City Council of the City of Madison. 
(d)  At the first regular meeting of the city council in the month of June of each year, at which an appointment of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Board shall be made by the city council, the council shall elect a successor of the member of the board whose term expires on July 1, following, and the person so elected shall become a member of the board on July 1 following and shall hold such position for a period of five years and until his or her successor is elected and qualified. Should the city council fail to elect a successor as set forth in this section at the meeting in June, it may do so at any succeeding regular meeting of such body. A member of the board may succeed himself if reelected. 
(e)  The members of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board shall serve without compensation but may be reimbursed for their reasonable and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(f)  Members of the board may be removed from office in the same manner and on the same grounds provided by the general law of this state for the impeachment and removal of other officers, as set out in Section 175 of the 1901 Constitution of Alabama. The director may be removed by impeachment in the same manner, or by a two-thirds vote of the board, subject to the approval of the city council, the Madison County Commission and the City Council of the City of Madison. 
(g)  Whenever a vacancy occurs in the membership of the board by resignation, inaction, death or other cause, if the member is an appointee of the city, the city council shall immediately fill the vacancy by electing another person to membership on the board, who shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term of the member he succeeds and until his successor is elected and qualified. The appointment to the board of any member shall set forth the designated place to be occupied by the member. 
(Ord. No. 13-655, § 1, 9-26-2013)  
Sec. 2-1623. - Organization. 
At the first meeting of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board, the members shall elect one of the members as chairman and one of the members as secretary; thereafter, the board shall annually elect from its members a chairman and a secretary. Vacancies in the office of the chairman and secretary shall be filled by the board if and when such vacancies shall occur.  
Sec. 2-1624. - Meetings. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board shall hold regular meetings at least once each month, at such time and place as may be determined by the board, and other meetings at such times and places as its members may elect. The chairman of the board, or any three members of the board, may call a meeting at any time he or they consider that the business demands that a meeting be held. The chairman and two members, or any three members of the board in the absence of the chairman, shall constitute a quorum. A true record of all the proceedings of all meetings of the board shall be kept by the secretary. At the call of any member, the vote of any pending question shall be taken by ayes and nays. The meeting shall be open to any member of the governing body and to the public at all times; and a copy of the record, certified by the secretary, shall be competent evidence in all courts.  
Sec. 2-1625. - Powers and duties. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board is vested, subject to the control of the city council, with all the powers of the City of Huntsville with respect to establishing, maintaining and operating an emergency management agency, and in addition, to such powers as shall be vested in said board by the Madison County Commission and the City Council of the City of Madison. The board shall not have the have the power to sue or to be sued, nor shall any title to any property be vested in said board; but any property or interest in property accruing to it shall be jointly vested in the City of Huntsville, Alabama, Madison County, Alabama, and the City of Madison, Alabama and shall be held by the Board for the City of Huntsville, Madison County and the City of Madison. 
(Ord. No. 13-655, § 2, 9-26-2013)  
Sec. 2-1626. - Annual reports. 
The Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board shall make an annual report to the city council, the Madison County Commission and the City Council of the City of Madison, showing in detail the operations and accomplishments of the board for its preceding fiscal year, the physical condition of the property under the care of the board and any other matters of public interest connected with the board. 
(Ord. No. 13-655, § 3, 9-26-2013)  
Sec. 2-1627. - Appropriations to board. 
The board will prepare and submit an annual budget to each participating member entity (City of Huntsville, Madison County and City of Madison). The city council shall appropriate such sum from the general fund as it may deem necessary for the operation of the Huntsville-Madison County Emergency Management Board based upon population of the participating member entities and other criteria. 
(Ord. No. 13-655, § 4, 9-26-2013)  
Secs. 2-1628—2-1650. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 16. - LIBRARY BOARD[19] 

Footnotes: 
--- (19) --- 
State Law reference— Library boards, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-90-2 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-1651. - Created. 
The library board is created. In addition to five board members appointed pursuant to Section 11-90-2 of the Code of Alabama, by the City Council of the City of Huntsville, two additional board members, one appointed by the city council of the City of Madison and one appointed by the Madison County Commission are hereby authorized, each of which shall be appointed for four-year terms, with the initial term of each additional board member commencing on the date specified in the appointing resolution adopted by the respective governing body. 
(Ord. No. 09-245, 3-26-2009)  
Sec. 2-1652. - Officers; bylaws. 
The library board shall elect its officers and adopt its bylaws.  
Sec. 2-1653. - Minutes of meetings. 
The library board shall keep accurate minutes of each meeting of the board. Such minutes shall be available at the library building for inspection by the mayor or any member of the city council at all times such building is open.  
Sec. 2-1654. - Governing and supervisory capacity. 
The government and supervision of the Huntsville Public Library shall be vested in the library board.  
Sec. 2-1655. - Powers and duties. 
The library board shall be vested with the following powers and perform the following duties: 
(1)  Expenditures. It shall have full power and authority to control the expenditures of all funds received or appropriated for the Huntsville Public Library. 
(2)  Erection of buildings. It shall have power to erect or rent buildings, with the approval of the city council, to cost not in excess of the funds available to it. 
(3)  Purchase of books and equipment. It shall be authorized to purchase books and equipment. 
(4)  Providing for library service. It shall have full power and authority to provide a system of library service to be made easily available to all citizens of the city through the central library, branches, stations, book truck service or other appropriate means. 
(5)  Election of librarian and other employees. It shall be authorized to elect a librarian and other employees. Such librarian shall be a professionally trained librarian. 
(6)  Receipt of gifts and trusts. It shall be authorized to receive gifts and administer trusts. 
(7)  Borrowing and lending books to other libraries. It shall be authorized to borrow books from and lend books to other libraries. 
(8)  Authority to make contracts. It shall be authorized to make contracts with other agencies for the providing of library service outside of the city subject to the approval of the city council.  
Sec. 2-1656. - Annual appropriation. 
The city council shall make an annual appropriation of funds to be available for the operation of the library.  
Sec. 2-1657. - Annual report. 
The library board shall prepare a written financial and administrative report at the end of each fiscal year of the city, and the report shall be presented to the city council immediately thereafter.  
Sec. 2-1658. - Gifts. 
Any property donated to the library board shall immediately become property of the city and by the city council or the library board kept for the benefit of the library.  
Sec. 2-1659. - Location. 
The Huntsville Public Library shall be located at such place as the city council shall designate.  
Secs. 2-1660—2-1680. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 17. - LOCAL LAW ENFORCEMENT BLOCK GRANTS PROGRAM ADVISORY BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1681. - Establishment. 
The local law enforcement block grants program advisory board is created. 
(Ord. No. 96-919, § I, 11-14-1996)  
Sec. 2-1682. - Membership. 
(a)  The local law enforcement block grants program advisory board shall be composed of five members appointed by the city council, and the board members shall consist of one representative from: 
(1)  The local police department; 
(2)  The local prosecutor's office; 
(3)  The local court system; 
(4)  The local public school system; and 
(5)  A local nonprofit, educational, religious or community group active in crime prevention or drug use prevention or treatment. 
(b)  The board shall be an ad hoc advisory board and shall serve only for such period of time as is required to complete the administration and expenditure of the grant funds. 
(Ord. No. 96-919, § II, 11-14-1996)  
Sec. 2-1683. - Authority and duties generally. 
The local law enforcement block grants program advisory board shall review the application for funding under the local law enforcement block grants program and it shall be authorized to make nonbinding recommendations to the city council for the use of funds received under the program. 
(Ord. No. 96-919, § IV, 11-14-1996)  
Secs. 2-1684—2-1700. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 18. - METRO-KIWANIS SPORTSPLEX ADVISORY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-1701. - Created. 
The Metro-Kiwanis Sportsplex advisory committee is created. 
(Ord. No. 95-538, § 1, 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1702. - Membership. 
(a)  The Metro-Kiwanis Sportsplex advisory committee shall be composed of a total of five members appointed from residents of the city who have a recognized interest in the activities which take place at the Metro-Kiwanis Sportsplex. Initial members of the committee shall be appointed as follows: one for a term of one year, two for a term of two years, and two for a term of three years. 
(b)  Two of the members of the committee shall be members in good standing of the Kiwanis Club of Metropolitan Huntsville. One shall be an initial two-year member, and the other shall be an initial three-year member. The Kiwanis Club of Metropolitan Huntsville, by duly adopted resolution, shall propose a list of nominees (not less than three in number) for each of these two member positions to the mayor. The mayor shall appoint from each of these two lists of nominees a member to serve on the committee. In the case of a vacancy resulting from the expiration of the stated term of membership on the committee, the Kiwanis Club shall, not more than 90 or less than ten days prior to the expiration of such term, by duly adopted resolution, propose a list of nominees (not less than three in number) for each member position which is to become vacant. In the case of a death or resignation, such list shall be proposed within 30 days following the occurrence of the vacancy. 
(c)  Of the other members of the committee, the member initially serving a term of one year shall be appointed by the mayor. The other two committee members, one serving an initial term of two years and the other serving an initial term of three years, shall be appointed by the city council. Each of these three members shall be a participant in the activities conducted at the facility. 
(d)  As the terms of all the members expire, their successors shall be appointed for terms of three years by the appointing authority. A vacancy occurring during the term of an appointment shall be filled by the appropriate appointing authority for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
(e)  An appointee shall cease to be a member upon resignation, upon ceasing to be a resident of the city, or as otherwise provided by ordinance or law. 
(f)  The committee members shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. 95-538, §§ 2, 5, 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1703. - Organization and meetings. 
(a)  The Metro-Kiwanis Sportsplex advisory committee shall meet and organize as soon as possible after appointments. The committee shall elect annually from among its members a chairman and a secretary. The committee, after election of its own officers, shall keep or cause to be kept a full and complete record of all of its proceedings. Such records shall set forth the reasons for the committee's decisions. The records of the committee shall be open for public inspection at the office of the manager of recreation services during normal business hours. 
(b)  The sportsplex advisory committee shall establish rules and regulations for its own procedures consistent with the provisions of this division. The committee shall hold regular meetings at least once every other calendar month from March through September at any time fixed by rule or resolution of the committee. During the period from October through February, meetings shall be held as determined necessary by a majority of the committee. The chairman or any three members of the committee may call a special meeting for any stated purpose on at least 24 hours' notice to each member by mail or telephone. Three members of the sportsplex advisory committee shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No committee member shall act in any case in which he has a personal interest. Any official action of this committee must be by majority vote of those present and voting. 
(Ord. No. 95-538, § 3, 8-10-1995)  
Sec. 2-1704. - Authority and duties generally. 
(a)  The Metro-Kiwanis Sportsplex advisory committee shall have the following duties and authority: 
(1)  The principal function of the sportsplex advisory committee is to advise and give recommendations to the manager of recreation services on the long range planning, coordination of tournaments, and promotion of the sportsplex facility. 
(2)  To encourage, provide for and coordinate the cooperation and assistance of citizens with programs and tournament activities at the sportsplex facility. 
(b)  No action of the committee shall be binding upon the city or any of its officers or employees. The authority of the committee is advisory only. 
(Ord. No. 95-538, § 4, 8-10-1995)  
Secs. 2-1705—2-1730. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 19. - MUSEUM BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1731. - Created. 
The Museum Board is created.  
Sec. 2-1732. - Membership. 
(a)  The Museum Board shall consist of 11 members to be appointed by the city council for a term of six years. Vacancies shall be filled for unexpired terms in the manner in which original appointments are made. All members who are presently serving shall be permitted to serve out the term for which they have been appointed. 
(b)  The members of the Museum Board shall receive no compensation whatever for their services, nor shall they receive compensation or per diem for attending meetings; however, actual and necessary expenses, in amounts no greater than those appropriated by the city council, incurred in the performance of their duties, may be paid.  
Sec. 2-1733. - Quorum; conflicts; actions by board. 
Six members of the Museum Board shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No member shall act in any case in which he has a personal interest. Actions of the board shall be by majority of those present.  
Sec. 2-1734. - Officers; bonds required. 
The Museum Board shall elect from its membership a treasurer and such assistant treasurers as it deems advisable, each of whom shall give bond with corporate surety in the amount of $10,000.00, payable to the city, and conditioned upon the faithful discharge of the duties of such person. The expense or premium of such bonds shall be paid by the Museum Board. The treasurer elected by the Museum Board shall have custody of all funds of the board, subject to the control of the Museum Board.  
Sec. 2-1735. - Powers. 
(a)  The Museum Board is authorized and directed to operate the Huntsville Museum. Such board shall adopt from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, rules and regulations governing the facilities of the city entrusted to its operation and management provided such bylaws and rules and regulations are not in conflict with this section or any laws of the state related to museum establishment and maintenance. 
(b)  The Museum Board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Do the acts and things necessary to carry out the objectives and the purposes set forth in this division; 
(2)  Acquire by purchase, gift or loan any money, securities, objects of art, and other property, other than real property, for museum purposes and uses; 
(3)  Buy and sell, and otherwise deal, in the name of the city, in property necessary to carry out its objectives; 
(4)  Cooperate with any public or private corporation or organization; 
(5)  Do any lawful act necessary or expedient to improve museum facilities for the people of the city; 
(6)  Provide for the exhibition, particularly to students of the public schools and in general to the population of the city, of statuary and all forms of the graphic and decorative arts and other fine arts; 
(7)  Encourage by appropriate means the cultivation of artistic talents and recognition of artistic achievements; 
(8)  Provide rules and regulations for its governance and the governance of its officials, employees and personnel under contract to it, and of any premises or property which may, from time to time, be in its custody; 
provided such rules and regulations are in accordance with and do not conflict with or otherwise violate any provision of this Code or other ordinance or resolution of the city. In the exercise of its power, the Museum Board shall have no power or authority to obligate the city beyond the amount appropriated by the city council for its purposes.  
Sec. 2-1736. - Management, custody and control of objects of art; no right to sue or be sued. 
The management, custody and control of any sculptures, paintings and other objects of art belonging to the city which the city council may by resolution place under the control and management of the Museum Board shall be vested in the Museum Board, and the board shall exercise, subject to the control of the city council, all the powers of the city with respect to establishing, maintaining and operating a museum of fine arts, which shall bear the name of Huntsville Museum of Art; however, the board shall coordinate museum policy with the Burritt Museum of the city, to the end that the last will and testament of Dr. William Henry Burritt will at all times be observed, and to the end that the policies of the two boards shall not conflict. Any conflicting policy of the two Museum Boards, certified to the council by either body, shall be resolved by resolution of the city council.  
Sec. 2-1737. - Budget, appropriations; financial procedures. 
(a)  The Museum Board shall submit to the mayor, on or before June 30 of each year, a detailed budget of estimate expenditures for the fiscal year commencing October 1 of that year. The city council may set aside and appropriate for the use of the board, for the maintenance of the museum, and for the other authorized purposes of the board, either all or such part of such estimated budget as may be available, or as may be deemed proper. 
(b)  The amounts appropriated from time to time by the city council for the support and maintenance of the museum shall be held by the treasurer of the board, and shall be paid out only for approved expenditures, upon vouchers approved by the board, or upon vouchers approved by the chairman or vice-chairman of the board. In all cases of payments made upon the approval of vouchers by the chairman or vice-chairman, such approval and payment shall be submitted to and reviewed by the board at its next regular meeting. All such vouchers shall be retained in the office of the board as part of the permanent records of the board. 
(c)  Funds, other than those appropriated by the city council, shall be administered by the Museum Board and expended by it for authorized purposes only, for the operation of the Huntsville Museum of Art, including the carrying out of any of the objectives or purposes set forth in this section, and all pertinent books and records shall at all times be subject to inspection and audit by the city clerk-treasurer of the city, or other person designated by the mayor or the city council. 
(d)  For the purpose of coordinating the accounting with that used in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, the city clerk-treasurer is authorized to determine the method of accounting for all receipts and expenditures of the Museum Board, including the form of vouchers and general accounting records.  
Sec. 2-1738. - Yearly audit required. 
At least once each year, the Museum Board shall appoint independent public accountants to conduct an examination in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards of all books and accounts of the board not kept by the city clerk-treasurer since the preceding examination and to make a full report in writing, under oath, which shall be submitted by the board to the council and mayor at its first meeting after the completion of such report.  
Sec. 2-1739. - Purchases; contracts. 
Subject to the limitations provided in this division, the Museum Board shall have the power to make contracts in the name of the board for the acquisition of property or services to be used in furtherance of the purposes for which the board has been created, and to execute all contracts necessary or convenient for such purposes; however, the board shall have no power or authority to obligate the city beyond the amount appropriated by the council for its purposes. In making expenditures for personal property or services authorized in this division, the board shall, in all respects, comply with the competitive bid law of the state, Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-1 et seq.; however, as to property that is stocked or purchased in quantity by the purchasing agent of the city, the board may requisition such property from the inventory of the city at cost; and where tangible personal property is to be acquired by the board which is the same or substantially similar to like property acquired by the purchasing agent of the city, the board may request that the needs of the city and the board be acquired by joint bid and purchase, in which case such property shall be acquired by the purchasing agent of the city and transferred to the board at the unit or pro rata price. The board shall designate a person employed by the board to act as the board's purchasing agent, and may provide, by resolution or bylaw entered upon the minutes of the board, that the purchasing agent so designated shall have the authority to act as awarding authority for and on behalf of the board in all or any specified class of purchases; however, if a bid is received for an item of personal property to be purchased or contracted for from a person who has continuously maintained a place of business within the city for which a business license has been paid to the city during the current and immediately preceding license year, deemed to be a responsible bidder, which such bid is no more than three percent greater than the bid of the lowest responsible bidder, and where such personal property is either manufactured within the city or regularly warehoused and stored for distribution at a place within the city, the awarding authority shall award the contract to such resident responsible bidder.  
Secs. 2-1740—2-1760. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 20. - PLANNING COMMISSION[20] 

Footnotes: 
--- (20) --- 
Cross reference— Zoning, app. A. 
State Law reference— Planning, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 2-1761. - Created. 
The Planning Commission is created. 
State Law reference— Authority to create planning commission, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-2.  
Sec. 2-1762. - Membership. 
The Planning Commission shall consist of 12 members as follows: 
(1)  The mayor, or, at the discretion of the mayor, an administrative assistant to the mayor or any administrative officer of the city under the supervision of the mayor; 
(2)  One administrative official of the city selected by the mayor; 
(3)  One member of the city council selected by it as member ex officio; and 
(4)  Nine members appointed by the mayor. 
State Law reference— Planning commission membership, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-3.  
Sec. 2-1763. - Powers and authority. 
The Planning Commission shall have all powers and authority provided under state law. 
State Law reference— Planning commission powers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-52-6 et seq.

DIVISION 21. - RESEARCH PARK BOARD 
 
Sec. 2-1781. - Created. 
The Research Park Board is created.  
Sec. 2-1782. - Membership. 
The Research Park Board shall be composed of seven members appointed by the mayor, after formal consultation with the council, and subject to council approval, for staggered seven-year terms. Of the members first appointed, one member shall be appointed for one year, one member for two years, one member for three years, one member for four years, one member for five years, one member for six years, and one member for seven years. Thereafter, appointments shall be for seven years. The mayor, one member of the council elected by the council, one member of the Planning Commission elected by the Planning Commission, a representative of Marshall Space Flight Center National Aeronautics and Space Administration appointed by the director, a representative of J.F. Drake State Technical College appointed by the president, a member of the house of representatives with a constituency within the county appointed by the chairman of the county legislative delegation, and a representative of the Army Missile Command appointed by the commanding general, and the chairman of the Research Park Advisory Committee shall be members ex officio; however, any member of the Board may designate, in writing, an alternate who may attend meetings and vote in the absence of the member; and further, that of the ex officio members, the mayor, the member of the council elected by the council, and one member of the Planning Commission elected by the Planning Commission shall be voting members.  
Sec. 2-1783. - Duties; responsibilities. 
The duties and responsibilities of the Research Park Board shall be as follows: 
(1)  To assist the mayor and city council in formulating goals and objectives the accomplishment of which will enhance the Cummings Research Park with respect to research and development and new technology or high-technology industries. 
(2)  To recommend to the mayor, the city council, and the county commission an overall development plan, including streets, transportation, utilities and other amenities for the expanded areas of Cummings Research Park. 
(3)  To formulate and recommend to the commission, the mayor and the council such changes and amendments to the zoning ordinances of the city with respect to the research park district regulations as the board may find desirable. 
(4)  To recommend to the mayor and council such land acquisition as in their judgment are necessary and desirable to enhance the city's ability to attract and expand research and development and new technology industries. 
(5)  To assist public and private agencies in the city and county in establishing, developing and promoting sites and services necessary to improve the communities prospects for attracting and expanding new technology industries. 
(6)  To keep minutes of board meetings, which shall also be tape recorded, the tape recordings being preserved by the board until after the minutes have been approved by the board.  
Secs. 2-1784—2-1800. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 22. - TRUCK STUDY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 2-1801. - Created. 
The Truck Study Committee is created.  
Sec. 2-1802. - Membership. 
(a)  The Truck Study Committee shall consist of the following officials of the city: 
(1)  Chief of police; 
(2)  Manager of inspection division; 
(3)  Manager of natural resources and environmental management division; 
(4)  Director of parking and public transit department; and 
(5)  Director of public works service department. 
(b)  In addition to the officials named in subsection (a) of this section, the committee shall appoint two members from the trucking community and may appoint to its membership any supporting personnel of the city who may be necessary to carry out the intent and purpose of the committee.  
Sec. 2-1803. - Appointment of chairperson. 
The chairperson of the Truck Study Committee shall be appointed by the committee.  
Sec. 2-1804. - Duties and responsibilities. 
(a)  The Truck Study Committee shall act in an advisory capacity to the mayor and the city council on all truck-related issues, including without being limited to the following: 
(1)  Truck routes within the city; 
(2)  Truck inspections; 
(3)  Truck weights; and 
(4)  Enforcement of other truck-related ordinances and regulations and truck safety. 
(b)  The committee shall meet on a regular schedule to be established by the committee and report to the mayor and the city council on a quarterly basis as to its activities, findings and recommendations.  
Sec. 2-1805. - Duration of the committee. 
The Truck Study Committee shall be and remain in existence for the purposes stated in this division and for all other legal and proper purposes as it may be directed from time to time by the mayor and the city council.  
Secs. 2-1806—2-1830. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 23. - VON BRAUN CENTER BOARD OF CONTROL 
 
Sec. 2-1831. - Created. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control is created. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 1, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1832. - Membership. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control shall consist of seven members, whose appointments and terms shall be as follows: Of the members first appointed, one member shall be appointed by the mayor for a term of one year, two members shall be appointed by the city council for a term of two years, two members shall be appointed by the city council for a term of three years, and two members shall be appointed by the city council for a term of four years. Thereafter, the term of all appointed members shall be four years. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term by the same agency and in the manner in which original appointments were made. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 1, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1833. - Quorum; actions of the board. 
Four members of the Von Braun Center Board of Control shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business. No member shall act in any case in which he has a personal financial interest. Actions of the board shall be by majority of those present. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 2, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1834. - Powers. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control is granted custody of and authorized to maintain, control, operate and manage for and on behalf of the city, the Von Braun Center heretofore established. The board shall adopt from time to time, amend and repeal bylaws, rules and regulations governing the facilities of the Von Braun Center provided such bylaws, rules and regulations are not in conflict with this section or any laws of the state. The board shall have the power to: 
(1)  Arrange, sponsor and conduct programs and exhibits in the center for the advancement of the cultural, civic and scientific interest and welfare of the citizens of the city, and for the advancement of the humanities; 
(2)  Promote, sponsor and operate in the center exhibitions and recreational activities; 
(3)  Charge fees for admission; 
(4)  Rent or lease all or part of the center for exhibitions, shows, performances or meetings; 
(5)  Accept or receive in the name of the city gifts, bequests and devises; and 
(6)  Do all things necessary or convenient to carry out the powers explicitly given in this section. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 3, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1835. - Advertising. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control may advertise its facilities, programs and events on behalf of the city and may expend such funds as may be appropriated to it for that purpose. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 4, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1836. - Purchases; contracts. 
Subject to the limitations provided in this division, the Von Braun Center Board of Control shall have the power to make contracts in the name of the board for the acquisition of personal property or services to be used in furtherance of the purposes for which the board has been created, and to execute all contracts necessary or convenient for such purposes; however, the board shall have no power or authority to obligate the city beyond the amount appropriated by the council for its purposes. In making expenditures for personal property or services authorized in this division, the board shall, in all respects, comply with Code of Ala. 1975, tit. 41, ch. 16 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 41-16-1 et seq.); however, as to property that is stocked or purchased in quantity by the city, the board may requisition the property from the inventory of the city at cost; and where tangible personal property is to be acquired by the board which is the same or substantially similar to like property acquired by the city, the board may request that the needs of the city and the board be acquired by joint bid and purchase, in which case the property shall be acquired by the city and transferred to the board at the unit or pro rata price. The board shall designate a person employed by the board to act as the board's purchasing agent, and may provide, by resolution or bylaw entered upon the minutes of the board, that the purchasing agent so designated shall have the authority to act as awarding authority for and on behalf of the board in all or any specified class of purchases; however, if a bid is received for an item of personal property to be purchased or contracted for from a person who has continuously maintained a place of business within the city for which a business license has been paid to the city during the current and immediately preceding license year, deemed to be a responsible bidder, which such bid is no more than three percent greater than the bid of the lowest responsible bidder, and where such personal property is either manufactured within the city or regularly warehoused and stored for distribution at a place within the city, the awarding authority shall award the contract to such resident responsible bidder. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 5, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1837. - Officers. 
The members of the Von Braun Center Board of Control shall, in accordance with the bylaws of the board, elect one of their number as chairman, one of their number as vice-chairman, one of their number as secretary, and one of their number as treasurer. Officers shall be entitled to succeed themselves. Vacancies shall be filled by the board for the unexpired term. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 6, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1838. - Manager, officers, and employees. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control shall have the power to appoint a manager and such other officers and employees as it may deem necessary and desirable, and to fix their duties, authorities and compensation. The manager of the Von Braun Center appointed by the board shall be responsible to the board for the day-to-day administration of the center and for the supervision and control of the other officers and employees of the board. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 7, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1839. - Bonds required. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control shall elect from its members a treasurer and such assistant treasurers as it deems advisable, each of whom shall give bond with corporate surety in the amount of $10,000.00, payable to the board and to the city, with condition to discharge faithfully all the duties of their respective offices. The expenses or premiums of such bond shall be paid by the board. The treasurer elected by the board shall have the custody of all funds of the board. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 8, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1840. - Compensation. 
The members of the Von Braun Center Board of Control shall receive no compensation whatever for their services, nor shall they receive compensation or per diem for attending meetings; however, actual and necessary expenses, in amounts no greater than those appropriated by the city council, incurred in the performance of their duties, may be paid. Employees' salaries shall adhere to the general salary structure of the city's general fund, as far as practical, and at the annual budget review meeting with the council, the Von Braun Center Board of Control and the city council will review the employees salary structure of the board. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 9, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1841. - Budget required. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control shall submit to the mayor, on or before June 30 of each year, a detailed budget of estimated expenditures for the fiscal year commencing October 1 of that year. The city council shall set aside and appropriate for the use of the board, for the maintenance and operation of the Von Braun Center, and for the other authorized purposes of the board, either all or such part of such estimated budget as may be available or is, by the city council, deemed proper. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 10, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1842. - Yearly audit required. 
At least once each year, the art museum shall appoint independent public accountants to conduct an examination in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards of all books and accounts of the Von Braun Center Board of Control not kept by the city clerk-treasurer since the preceding examination and to make a full report in writing, under oath, which shall be submitted by the board to the council and mayor at its first meeting after the completion of such report. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 12, 1-23-1997)  
Sec. 2-1843. - Policies of the board. 
The Von Braun Center Board of Control shall, as soon as possible, generate a set of written policies and guidelines for usage of the facilities and rates to be charged for usage, whereupon the policy, and all revisions to the policy, will be delivered to the city council and mayor. The policy shall not be changed or amended unless the proposed change is first presented in writing to the mayor and city council at least ten days prior to its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 97-55, § 13, 1-23-1997)  
Secs. 2-1844—2-1860. - Reserved.
