(3)  Sales of all agricultural produce and livestock arising from the labor of the seller or other labor under his control on or belonging to his real or personal estate and not purchased or sold for speculation. 
(4)  All sales under legal process. 
(5)  Sales by a licensed pawnbroker or loan company which is selling or offering for sale unredeemed pledges of chattels as provided by law. 
(6)  Sales made on properties acquired by, or under contract to be acquired by the United States of America, the State of Alabama, Madison County, the City of Huntsville, and/or any of their respective agencies, subsidiaries or authorities, pursuant to the power of eminent domain, or under threat of acquisition by eminent domain. 
(7)  Sales of automobiles by an auctioneer licensed under the laws of the State of Alabama. 
(8)  Sales of fire, smoke, or water damaged merchandise by a licensed business establishment continuing in business. Such sales shall be limited to 12 regular business days. 
(9)  Sales of perishable merchandise by a licensed business establishment continuing in business. Such sales shall be limited to seven regular business days. 
( Ord. No. 16-890 , § 1, 11-17-2016)  
Sec. 8-422. - Sunset date. 
Unless extended by act of the city council, this article shall expire on December 31, 2017. 
( Ord. No. 16-890 , § 1, 11-17-2016)  
Secs. 8-423—8-450. - Reserved.  
Chapter 9 - CEMETERIES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Burritt Memorial committee, § 2-1421 et seq.; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23. 
State Law reference— General authority relative to cemeteries, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-40; cemeteries generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-60 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, adopted June 23, 2016, amended Ch. 9 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Ch. 9, §§ 9-1—9-52, pertained to similar subject matter. For prior history, see Code Comparative Table. 
 
Sec. 9-1. - Compliance with zoning ordinance. 
Both the location of a cemetery and the extension of the boundaries of an existing cemetery, whether public or private, are subject to the terms and requirements of the zoning ordinance of the city and must comply with that ordinance before such location or extension of the cemetery shall be approved by the mayor and council. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Secs. 9-2—9-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CITY CEMETERIES 
 
Sec. 9-31. - Director of cemeteries. 
(a)  There shall be a director of cemeteries who shall be appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council as provided by law. He shall hold office for such period of time as the mayor and city council shall deem necessary and desirable, or until the expiration of the term of the mayor making the appointment. 
(b)  The director of cemeteries shall: 
(1)  Exercise general supervision over the cemetery department and its employees under the direction and control of the mayor. 
(2)  Have all the grounds, walks, drives, fences and gates of the city cemeteries kept in good order and repair. 
(3)  Maintain and care for all shrubbery, flowers and ornamentals. 
(4)  Protect all the graves, tombs, tombstones, monuments, fixtures. 
(5)  Attend to the opening of all graves, depositing the dead and closing the graves. 
(6)  Attend to the opening of all tombs and vaults, depositing the dead and closing tombs and vaults. 
(7)  Keep a register of all burials, giving the name, place of death, place of burial or disposal and the name and address of the funeral director of each, and shall require in each case a burial permit or receipt for burial before interment and shall furnish the city clerk-treasurer, once a month, a copy of such register. 
(8)  Establish rules and regulations regarding anything that affects the orderly operation and maintenance of city cemeteries including, but not limited to, the size, type and method of placement of tombstones, markers and monuments, placement of flowers and personal items on gravesites. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-32. - Designation of city cemeteries. 
The grounds, lots, parcels of land, fences, walls and gates surrounding the properties known and designated as Maple Hill Cemetery, Northside Cemetery, Brandontown Cemetery, Nickels-Martin Cemetery (Brandontown #2), Sivley Cemetery, Merrimack Cemetery, Dallas Mill Cemetery, Glenwood Cemetery, and #4 Hall Cemetery are designated and officially named city cemeteries. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-33. - Lots to be under control and regulation of city. 
The city shall, at all times, regulate and control the lots, as well as other properties in the city cemeteries, in order that all properties in such cemeteries shall be properly maintained as such. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-34. - Reserved.  
Sec. 9-35. - Lots set aside for memorial; provision of funds. 
Lots 7, 8, 9, 23 and 24 of block 36 of Maple Hill Cemetery according to the map on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer are set aside and reserved for the erection of a suitable memorial to the memory of county veterans who have made or will make the supreme sacrifice overseas, the funds for such memorial to be provided for by the organization of American Legion and Veterans of Foreign Wars, together with public subscriptions to be raised and distributed by such organizations. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-36. - Lots set aside for veterans. 
(a)  Lots 1—6, 10—21, 25—28, 35—52, 69—76, 78, 79, 80—82, 99, 100—112, 129—142, and 159—165 in block 36 of Maple Hill Cemetery and lots 4—14 in block 9 in Northside Cemetery are set aside and reserved for the interment of the remains of Huntsville veterans who gave their lives on foreign soil while serving in the United States Armed Forces and who will be returned to the city for interment, with two spaces being set aside and reserved for the remains of each such veteran. 
(b)  After the interment of the remains of any veteran in any of the spaces described in this section, the immediate family of such veteran shall have and is given the right to use the remaining space for the interment of members of the veteran's family. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sell or use any of the lots in block 36 of Maple Hill Cemetery or block 9 in Northside Cemetery except in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-37. - Authorization for final disposition. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bury or permit to be buried within the city any body without first presenting to the director of cemeteries an authorization for final disposition. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016) 
State Law reference— Authorization for disposition of dead body, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-9A-16.  
Sec. 9-38. - Authorization for final disposition and application for interment. 
It shall be unlawful for any person acting in the capacity of undertaker to conduct a funeral or attempt to bury a body within the city without first obtaining an authorization for final disposition and filing with the cemetery department an application for interment (burial). It shall be the duty of any relative or friend of the deceased person who is in possession of any facts or information required by the state to furnish the authorization upon request, to the undertaker. It shall be the duty of every physician or professional adviser, who has been present at the death of any person, or has attended any person at last illness, to, upon request of the undertaker, write in the death certificate such statements regarding the deceased as are required or prescribed by state law. If no physician was in attendance, the appropriate officer under state law shall make out a certificate of death based on the data obtainable unless he has reason to suspect foul play. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016) 
State Law reference— Authorization for disposition of dead body, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-9A-16.  
Sec. 9-39. - Time for burials. 
No interment of human bodies shall be made in the cemeteries of the city after sundown or before sunrise without the written application for permission duly submitted to and approved by the mayor. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-40. - Depth of graves. 
No grave for the interment of human bodies in the cemeteries of the city shall be less than four feet deep. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-41. - Monument guidelines. 
(a)  No monument shall be erected in any city cemetery without the prior approval of the director of cemeteries. The following guidelines shall apply to all monuments: 
• Ledgers and coping will not be allowed. 
• Wording/icons on monuments shall be at the discretion of the director. 
(b)  Monuments in blocks 41 through 46 of Maple Hill Cemetery shall be subject to the following restrictions in addition to those set forth in section 9-50 of this chapter: 
Flat monument guidelines/restrictions: 
• Foot markers—shall be flat and shall not exceed 24" length, 12" width, 4" height. 
• Single flat monuments—shall not exceed 36" length, 16" wide, 4" height. 
• Double flat monuments—shall not exceed 48" length, 16" wide, 4" height. 
NOTE: All flat monuments will run with the slope of the ground and no foundation will be required. Flat monuments will be placed on a dry mixture of sand and rock mixture. Flat bronze monuments will be required to be placed on a piece of granite. 
Upright monument guidelines/restrictions: 
• Foot markers—shall be flat and shall not exceed 24" length, 12" width, 4" height. 
• Single upright markers—shall not exceed 36" length, 16" wide, 36" height, including base. 
• Double upright markers—shall not exceed 72" length x 16" width x 36" height, including base. 
• Family monuments shall not exceed 72" length x 16" width x 36" height, including base and shall be placed at the head of the grave/graves. 
• No benches are allowed. 
Corner markers: 
Corner markers are not allowed. 
(c)  Columbariums are allowed; however, they are restricted to two cremains per columbarium. The size of the columbarium is subject to the approval of the director of cemeteries. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-42. - Construction of monument foundation by city. 
The service charge for the construction of a monument foundation by the cemetery department is fixed and established at $0.50 per square inch computed on the size of the monument base, and such service charge shall be payable at the office of the director of cemeteries. The director shall, upon such payment, receipt the payment and perform the services. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-43. - Curbing. 
No curbing shall be permitted to be placed in any city cemetery. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-44. - Cemetery service fees. 
The fees for cemetery services shall be as follows: 
(1)  Interment of a casket (weekdays prior to 3:00 p.m.) ..... $750.00 
(2)  Interment of a casket (arriving at cemetery after 3:00 p.m. weekdays) ..... 850.00 
(3)  Interment of a casket (Saturdays) ..... 850.00 
(4)  Interment of a casket (Sundays) ..... 1,000.00 
(5)  Interment of cremains (weekdays arriving at the cemetery prior to 3:00 p.m.) ..... 450.00 
(6)  Interment of cremains (Saturdays and weekdays arriving at the cemetery after 3:00 p.m.) ..... 550.00 
(7)  Interment of cremains (Sundays) ..... 650.00 
(8)  Disinterment of a casket (non-lawn crypt) (allowable on weekdays only) ..... 1,800.00 * 
(9)  Disinterment of a bottom lawn crypt ..... 3,600.00 
(10)  Disinterment of a top lawn crypt ..... 1,800.00 
(11)  Disinterment of cremains ..... 500.00 
(12)  Installation of a corner marker (per marker) ..... 5.00 
(13)  Marker foundation fee (per square inch) (minimum charge $100.00) ..... 0.50 
(14)  Sounding fee $10.00 for first space, $5.00 for each additional space (no charge if in connection with burial) 
(15)  Property transfer fee 50.00 for the first space and $25.00 per each additional space 
(16)  Excavation to determine vacancy of a burial space ..... $200.00 
(17)  Mail fees $20.00 overnight and $6.00 for certified 
*All disinterments are subject to the approval of the cemetery director. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-45. - Payment of charges for opening graves; erection of monuments. 
The charges for lots or services in city cemeteries shall be payable at the office of the director of cemeteries in advance; and he shall, upon such payment, receipt for payment and shall open the grave. No grave shall be opened without such payment. No monument shall be erected on a lot until full payment has been made. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-46. - Entrance and exit at gates only. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to climb over or go through or under any wall, fence, hedge or similar barrier enclosing any city cemetery, or to enter or leave the cemetery at any place, except at a regularly established gateway or entrance. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-47. - Selling of merchandise and commodities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to borrow, sell, offer to sell, trade or offer trade or solicit orders for any merchandise or commodity on the grounds or within the enclosure of the grounds of any city cemetery during any period of the day or night. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-48. - Loitering at night. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to be on the grounds or within the enclosure of the grounds of the premises of any city cemetery during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise without first having obtained the express permission of the director of cemeteries. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-49. - Animals. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit or allow any animal, other than service animals, to be on the grounds of any city cemetery. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-50. - Price of spaces in Maple Hill Cemetery. 
(a)  The price of a single burial space (approximate size 40? × 10') available for sale by the city in Maple Hill Cemetery shall be $3,000.00 except for the following spaces, the price of which shall be $2,500.00:

(b)  The price of a single space for an infant burial or interment of cremains (approximate size 40? × 4') available for sale by the city in Maple Hill Cemetery shall be $1,250.00. The maximum size of a casket/vault for an infant burial is 18? × 36?. 
(c)  All burial spaces and cremation spaces available for sale in Maple Hill Cemetery shall be sold on a first come basis. Payment must be made in full at the time of purchase. 
( Ord. No. 16-412 , § 1, 6-23-2016)  
Sec. 9-51. - Purchase of spaces—Form of agreement. 
(a)  Any person desiring to purchase a burial space in Maple Hill Cemetery shall execute an agreement with the city in the following form: 
"AGREEMENT" between City of Huntsville, herein referred to as "the city," and ____________/____________/____________, herein referred to as "the Purchaser." 
WITNESSETH:

The said space is sold subject to the following conditions which are agreed to by the parties hereto: 
(1)  The said space shall be used for burial of a human body and such use shall at all times be subject to the rules, regulations, and laws of the city now or hereafter in force. 
(2)  In the event Purchaser pays the purchase price by check or bank draft and said draft is not paid due to insufficient funds then City may, at its option, declare this contract terminated in which all of the rights of the Purchaser shall cease and the city may, and is hereby authorized to, disinter and remove from the said space any human body or remains thereof then buried in said space and bury the same at such other place or places as it may select. 
(3)  In the event the Purchaser pays the purchase price contemporaneously with the execution of this Agreement, and complies with all rules, regulations, and laws of the city relating to the aforementioned burial space, the city will thereupon convey the same to Purchaser, such conveyance to contain a provision that the said space shall be used only for burial of a human body, and use thereof shall at all times be subject to the rules, regulations, and laws of the city then or thereafter in force. 
(4)  No person, organization, corporation, or other entity who purchases a space in Maple Hill Cemetery following the date of adoption of this ordinance, shall sell, transfer, or convey such space to another person, organization, corporation, or other entity, for a sum greater than the original purchase price, as established under this Article, without first having offered such space to the City of Huntsville for re-purchase at the original purchase price. If the City of Huntsville fails to exercise its "right of first refusal" within sixty days (60) of receipt of a space owner's written "Intent to sell, transfer or convey for a price greater than the original purchase price," then the "right of first refusal" shall be deemed "waived" by the city and the space owner shall be allowed to sell, transfer, or convey, the space without any price limitation.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 10-1—10-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BURRITT MEMORIAL MUSEUM AND PARK 
 
Sec. 10-31. - Construction of article. 
This article shall be liberally construed. 
(Code 1982, § 10-16)  
Sec. 10-32. - Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park and Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park fund created. 
(a)  There is created and established the Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park and Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park fund. 
(b)  The Dr. William Henry Burritt Museum and Park consists of the home of the late Dr. William Henry Burritt, located on Roundtop Mountain in the county and approximately 160 acres of land surrounding the home, together with all furnishings, including books, pictures, furniture and furnishings used in and about the home of the late Dr. William Henry Burritt.  
Sec. 10-33. - Burritt Memorial fund. 
(a)  The city clerk-treasurer is designated as the depository with whom the trustee under the last will and testament of Dr. William Henry Burritt, deceased, shall deposit the $10,000.00 per year as provided in the will for the purposes designated in this article; and the First National Bank of Huntsville, Alabama, is designated as the depository in which the city clerk-treasurer shall deposit the funds to the account of the Burritt Memorial fund. All expenditures from the fund shall be made upon warrants signed by the city clerk-treasurer, upon substantiation by appropriate vouchers as submitted by the committee created in chapter 2, article VIII, division 7 of this Code, and upon approval of the expenditures by the city council; however, $3,000.00 per year shall be used from the Burritt Memorial fund for the maintenance of the Dr. William Henry Burritt house, including the present yard and sufficient area that may be added to the present yard to further develop the yard from time to time as may be appropriate; and the remaining $7,000.00 from the $10,000.00 annuity shall be used each year to maintain and develop the park on the remainder of the land. 
(b)  The city clerk-treasurer is made responsible for the maintenance of complete financial records showing income and disbursement from the fund and the making of an annual audit of the fund and the submission of the records to the city council, and the trustee as appointed under the last will and testament of Dr. William Henry Burritt, deceased. 
(Code 1982, § 10-19)  
Secs. 10-34—10-60. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION DISTRICT[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Historic preservation, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-68-1 et seq.; 1971 Ala. Acts 1307. 
 
Sec. 10-61. - Requested. 
The city council finds and determines that more than 60 percent of the property owners within the historic preservation district designated in this article have requested in writing to the council the establishment of such district. 
(Code 1982, § 10-51)  
Sec. 10-62. - Designation of district. 
There is designated within the city an historic preservation district to be known and identified as "The Huntsville Historic Preservation District." The city council finds and determines that: 
(1)  The district as described in this article possesses such historic significance by reason of antiquity, architecture, historic importance of persons or events identified with the district, including numerous historic structures and sites, as to give such district as a whole a character of historic significance worthy of preservation for the protection of the historic character of the city, and in the interest of the general welfare of the inhabitants of the city, county and state; 
(2)  The promotion and preservation of its educational, cultural and economic interest, opportunities and advantages through the preservation and protection of historic buildings, structures, places and areas of historic interest located in the district are desirable; 
(3)  The preservation, protection and maintenance of the buildings, structures, places and landmarks in the history of the territory and the state and of the city is necessary and desirable as being commemorative of the events, circumstances, persons and architecture associated with the district; 
(4)  Such buildings, structures and places are tangible reminders of such events, circumstances, persons and architecture; and 
(5)  The preservation and protection of appropriate settings and environment for such buildings, structures, places and areas are necessary for the promotion, development and preservation of the economy, commerce and industry of the state and the city by the preservation and protection of such buildings, structures, places and areas and of appropriate settings and environments, and the preservation of the economic value of property within the district is necessary and desirable and in the public interest. 
(Code 1982, § 10-52)  
Sec. 10-63. - Subdivisions of district; construction. 
The area described in this section shall comprise "The Huntsville Historic Preservation District"; however, the district is further subdivided into four parts, which are designated as "The Twickenham Historic Preservation District," "The Old Town Historic Preservation District," "The Alabama A & M University Historic Preservation District," and "The Five Points Historic Preservation District," respectively. No building or structure shall be erected, constructed or reconstructed, altered, restored or renovated within the district unless a certificate of appropriateness shall have been issued by the historic preservation commission, in accordance with the procedures, powers and duties of the commission and in accordance with the rules, regulations and requirements of the commission adopted pursuant to law, the district being more specifically described as follows:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - AMBULANCES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Ambulances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-18-1 et seq.; local ambulance regulation, Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-18-7. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 11-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Ambulance means any privately owned motor vehicle used for the transporting of persons who are wounded, ill, injured or sick, and includes but is not restricted to emergency vehicles used for such purpose. The term "ambulance" is expressly distinguished from governmentally operated vehicles serving the same purpose as described in this definition. The term "ambulance" shall not be construed to include vehicles operated by organizations approved by or affiliated with the Huntsville-Madison County emergency management board while such vehicles are being used by members of approved organizations to respond to an emergency officially declared according to the rule of the board. 
Owner means every person having use or control of any passenger-carrying or motor-propelled ambulance, whether as owner, operator, lessee or otherwise. 
(Code 1982, § 4-1) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 11-32. - Prerequisites for operation of ambulance. 
No person shall engage in the business of operating an ambulance on the public streets of the city unless he shall have acquired in the following order an appropriate license from the health care authority and a certificate of convenience and necessity as required in this article, and unless he shall have paid all privilege licenses and privilege taxes as required by the ordinances of the city and shall have filed with the city clerk-treasurer a policy of insurance executed and delivered by a company licensed by the state department of insurance under the terms of which the insurance company provides coverage for injuries to persons or property for which the insured may become legally liable to pay as a result of the operation of the ambulances in the following amounts and under the following conditions: 
(1)  For each ambulance, such insurance policy shall provide insurance coverage in the amount of $1,000,000.00 for personal injury or death arising from any one accident and $50,000.00 for property damage liability and uninsured motorist's liability coverage in the sum of $20,000.00 per person for bodily injury liability and $40,000.00 per accident for bodily injury liability or $500,000.00 combined single limit liability with $1,000,000.00 excess liability coverage whether the operation of any such vehicle is by such person, his agent, servant or employee, or by any person in possession of such vehicle. 
(2)  The insurance coverages required by this section shall at all times be maintained for the full amount. The policy of insurance required by this section to be filed with the city clerk-treasurer shall contain a clause obligating the company issuing the policy to give not less than 30 days' written notice to the city clerk-treasurer before its cancellation. Notice of cancellation shall not relieve the company issuing such policy of liability for any injury or claim arising before the cancellation becomes effective. The cancellation of any such policy shall have the effect of suspending the permit of such person to operate the ambulances covered by the permit until a new policy complying with the provision of this section is filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(3)  Every insurance policy required under this section shall contain a provision for a continuing liability under the policy to the full amount, notwithstanding any recovery, that the liability of the insurer shall not be affected by the insolvency or the bankruptcy of the insured, and that until the policy is canceled the insurance company will not be relieved from liability on account of nonpayment of premium, or any act or omission by the named assured. Such policy of insurance shall be further conditioned for the payment of any and all judgments, up to the limits of such policy, recovered against any person other than the owner, his agent or employee, who may operate the policy with the consent or acquiescence of the owner. 
(4)  In order to meet the policy filing requirements in this section, as an alternative, the insured may file a binder of liability and property damage insurance as required in this section and a letter from the insuring agent which shall state that the coverage is bound, the name of the company, the effective date of coverage, the limits of liability and a list of all vehicles covered and proof that the agent has the ability to bind the issuing company. The policy of insurance so bound shall be filed with the city clerk-treasurer within 60 days of the effective date of coverage. 
(Code 1982, § 4-2)  
Secs. 11-33—11-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CERTIFICATE OF CONVENIENCE AND NECESSITY 
 
Sec. 11-51. - Number of applications by each person. 
No person shall apply for a certificate of convenience and necessity in any case where an application has been disapproved on behalf of such person within six months next preceding the date of its filing. 
(Code 1982, § 4-3)  
Sec. 11-52. - Application for certificate. 
All persons applying to the city council for a certificate of convenience and necessity for the operation of one or more ambulances shall first obtain and have an appropriate license from the health care authority and then file with the city clerk-treasurer a sworn application containing the following information or documentation: 
(1)  The name of the applicant and trade name, if any, under which he intends to conduct his business; and if the applicant is a partnership, the name of each member, whether a limited or general partner and the name under which the partnership business is to be conducted; and if the applicant is a corporation, the name of the corporation and the name of each one of its officers. 
(2)  The business address and resident address of the applicant; and if the applicant is a partnership, the business address of the partnership and the resident address of each partner, whether he is a limited or general partner; and if the applicant is a corporation, the address of the corporation and the resident address of each one of its officers. 
(3)  The number of ambulances actually owned and/or leased and the number of ambulances actually operated by such applicants on the day of application, if any. 
(4)  A description of each such ambulance, including the make, model, year of manufacture and state license number. 
(5)  The location or station address of each such ambulance. 
(6)  A description of the proposed color scheme, insignia, trade style and/or any other distinguishing characteristics of the proposed ambulance design. 
(7)  A copy of the applicant's license from the health care authority. 
(8)  Any other documentation requested by the city clerk-treasurer for purposes of investigation. 
(Code 1982, § 4-4)  
Sec. 11-53. - Investigation. 
Before any application is acted upon, the city clerk-treasurer shall cause an investigation to be made and shall report his findings in writing to the council on the following: 
(1)  The demand of the public for additional ambulance service. 
(2)  The adequacy of the existing ambulance service. 
(3)  The financial responsibility and experience of the applicant. 
(4)  The applicant's ability to provide ambulance service at a level equal to the current community standard for prehospital care. 
(5)  Such other relevant facts as the council may deem necessary or advisable. 
(Code 1982, § 4-5)  
Sec. 11-54. - Resolution by council; public hearing. 
(a)  No certificate shall be granted until the city council shall determine by resolution that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed ambulance service. 
(b)  In determining whether the public convenience and necessity require the operation of an ambulance or ambulances for which an application is made, the council shall hold such public hearing as it may deem necessary and advisable to determine that fact. 
(Code 1982, § 4-6)  
Sec. 11-55. - Grounds for denial of certificate. 
The following shall be prima facie grounds for denial of a certificate: 
(1)  The applicant or one of the partners, if the applicant is a partnership, or one or more of the officers of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation, if the policy of such corporation will be directed, controlled or managed by such partner or officer, has been convicted of a felony or crime involving moral turpitude unless five years shall have elapsed since his discharge from a penal institution, or having been discharged from probation, during which period of time there is no evidence of the probable commission of other felonies or crimes involving moral turpitude. 
(2)  The applicant or one or more of the partners, if the applicant is a partnership, or one or more of the officers of the corporation, if the applicant is a corporation, if the policy of the corporation will be directed, controlled and managed by such persons who have ever been convicted of doing business in violation of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 4-7)  
Sec. 11-56. - Certificate not transferable. 
Each certificate issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be separate and distinct and shall not be transferable from the person to whom issued to another person. 
(Code 1982, § 4-8)  
Sec. 11-57. - Annual report. 
Every certificate holder shall file annually with the city clerk-treasurer a report of equipment and capabilities, which shall include, among other things, any change in equipment, and any change in the information required by section 11-52, and a certified audit of financial operations. 
(Code 1982, § 4-9)  
Sec. 11-58. - Destruction of ambulance. 
Any certificate holder whose ambulance has been destroyed involuntarily, or who voluntarily destroys any ambulance, shall, as a matter of right, upon written application to the city clerk-treasurer within 30 days after such destruction, and upon satisfactory evidence presented to the city clerk-treasurer of such destruction, be issued a new certificate for the operation of no greater number of ambulances than those so destroyed, provided the certificate holder has complied with all the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 4-10)  
Sec. 11-59. - Sale or transfer of title to ambulance. 
Whenever a certificate holder sells or transfers title to, assigns a lease to or subleases an ambulance, and within 30 days after such sale, transfer, assignment or sublease, purchases or leases another ambulance or a like number of other ambulances, the certificate holder shall, as a matter of right, upon written application to the city clerk-treasurer within 30 days of such purchase or lease, be issued a new certificate for the operation of no greater number of ambulances than those operated prior to the sale, transfer, assignment or sublease, and provided the certificate holder has complied with all the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 4-11)  
Sec. 11-60. - Grounds for suspension and revocation. 
The city council may suspend and revoke any certificate issued under the provisions of this article in the following cases: 
(1)  If council finds the certificate holder is not providing adequate service. 
(2)  The certificate holder fails to operate the ambulance in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(3)  The certificate holder shall cease to operate any ambulance for a period of 60 consecutive days without having obtained permission for cessation of such operation from the council. 
(4)  The certificate holder fails to file any report required by section 11-57. 
(Code 1982, § 4-12)  
Sec. 11-61. - Surrender of certificate. 
Certificates issued under this article which have been suspended or revoked by the council shall, forthwith, be surrendered to the city clerk-treasurer; and the operation of any ambulance or ambulances covered by such certificates shall cease. 
(Code 1982, § 4-13)  
Chapter 12 - ENVIRONMENTAL MANAGEMENT[1]
