(a)  It shall be the obligation of the presiding judge to see that the court docket is kept as current as is reasonably possible; and to such end the presiding judge shall establish a court calendar of cases and shall have the authority to set dockets and assign cases for trial and disposition before such municipal judges as shall be appointed. The presiding judge shall also prescribe and publish reasonable rules and regulations for the dispatch of the business of the court. 
(b)  The presiding judge, in order to maintain a current docket, shall have the authority to hold, or direct to be held, such sessions of court as shall be necessary. All sessions of court shall be presided over by the presiding judge or by a judge assigned by the presiding judge. This subsection will be construed in pari materia with section 16-6(d). 
(c)  The presiding municipal judge shall designate any other municipal officers who shall be authorized to approve appearance and appeal bonds. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, §§ 15-2(g), (h), 15-7(a), 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-2. - Benefits for judges. 
(a)  Each full-time municipal judge shall be entitled to employee benefits on the same basis as from time to time is provided for other employees of the city. 
(b)  Each part-time municipal judge who is an employee of the city shall be entitled to two weeks' leave (four sessions for night court) annually in lieu of all other leave benefits and shall also be subject to any health insurance program of the city provided for other part-time employees of the city. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-3(c), (d), 6-23-1994) 
State Law reference— Designation of presiding judge required, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-30(c); powers of judges, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-31 et seq.  
Sec. 16-3. - Probation. 
(a)  The grant of probation by the municipal court will consist of one of three aspects: unsupervised probation, supervised or monitored probation, or intensive supervised probation. 
(b)  Unsupervised probation will be probation granted by the municipal court wherein the probationer will not have to adhere to a reporting schedule. A probation officer will follow up on specified reports of violations or possible violations of probation conditions. 
(c)  Supervised or monitored probation will be granted by the municipal court wherein the probationer will have a reporting schedule and will require continuous contact and followup by a probation officer or other designated officer of the court. Any person who is placed on supervised probation by the municipal court and who has an income shall be required to contribute between a maximum of $20.00 and a minimum of one hour gross wage, at the discretion of the court, per scheduled contact visit with their assigned probation officer toward the cost of his supervision and rehabilitation beginning 30 days from the date he has an income. The responsibility of assuring such contribution is that of the probationer. Exemptions from payment required by this section may be granted for undue hardship on a case-by-case basis by the sentencing court. In the event of over two months' arrearage or delinquency in making such contribution, such arrearage or delinquency shall constitute sufficient ground for revocation of the probation of the person in arrears. Payment shall be deposited in a timely manner with the clerk of municipal court and maintained in a separate account with the city clerk-treasurer's office and used only to defray the cost of the service performed. 
(d)  Intensive supervised or monitored probation will be granted by the municipal court wherein all the specifications of supervised probation are applicable and will be enhanced by the use of remote electronic monitoring. This particular program will be utilized only upon the convicted misdemeanant's voluntary participation and the affirmative discretion of the court. Any convicted misdemeanant participating in the remote electronic monitoring system who receives a wage from gainful employment shall be required to pay one hour of the gross wage, per day of utilization, for maintenance of the system, to be deposited with the clerk of municipal court and maintained in a separate account with the city clerk-treasurer's office and used only to defray the cost of the service performed. 
(e)  The sentencing court shall, at the time probation is granted, make specification as to unsupervised probation, supervised or monitored probation or intensive supervised probation and in the specification of the latter two alternatives will order the frequency of the interview, counseling and contact visits along with the specified contribution per contact visit required by the probationer. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-4(f)(5), 6-23-1994) 
State Law reference— Probation, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-13.  
Sec. 16-4. - Court costs. 
(a)  Upon each conviction in the municipal court for violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city, there shall be taxed against the defendant as court costs the sum of $10.00. In each case where the defendant has posted cash bond and such bond is forfeited, there shall be taxed against the defendant as court costs the sum of $10.00. These costs shall be in addition to other costs provided by law. In all cases which are nolle prosequi, the court may, at the discretion of the judge, tax costs to the defendant or to the complainant. 
(b)  In addition to the court costs assessed in accordance with the provisions of subsection (a) of this section, there shall be assessed and collected on each case filed in the municipal court, and accounted for within a special account of the general fund, additional court costs and fees up to an amount not to exceed the court costs and fees in the district court of the county for a similar case. These funds are to be used exclusively for the operation and maintenance of a municipal correctional facility, other correctional facilities, any juvenile detention center, or any court complex. The court cost shall not be waived by any court unless all other costs, fees, assessments, fines or charges associated with the case are waived. 
(c)  No part of the court costs shall be taxed against or paid by the city. 
(d)  Whenever a person is tried on the complaint of another and acquitted, the municipal judge may, in his discretion, tax the party making the complaint with all or any of the costs. 
(e)  Court costs will not apply to parking violation adjudications. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-6, 6-23-1994; Ord. No. 95-268, § 1, 4-11-1995; Ord. No. 95-592, 9-14-1995; Ord. No. 03-558, § 1, 7-10-2003) 
State Law reference— Court costs, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-14.  
Sec. 16-5. - Costs for copies and certification of court records. 
(a)  A fee of $0.25 per page shall be charged for copies of court records made by the clerk; however, at the discretion of the clerk, copies of court records may be made at no charge for governmental agencies whether federal, state, county or municipal. A fee of $1.00 shall be charged by the clerk for each certification made to copies of court records. These costs are to defray the expense of the service performed. Such fees collected shall be distributed by the clerk to the city clerk-treasurer's office. 
(b)  Fees collected by the clerk for copies of court records shall be disbursed to the city general fund. 
(c)  As used in this section, the term "copies" shall mean any reproduction of a document of file in the office of the clerk, whether produced by photograph or photostat machine, by computer, by microfilm equipment, or by any other means. 
(d)  No case file shall be removed from the control of the clerk except by order of the court and only upon good cause shown. 
(e)  The provisions of this section shall not alter the provision that court files shall be open to inspection free of charge. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-9, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-6. - Municipal court administrative agency. 
(a)  The municipal court shall have under its supervision a municipal court administrative agency empowered to provide expeditious service in connection with administrative adjudication of ordinance violations; the handling of uniform traffic tickets and complaints; the issuance and accounting of arrest warrants; the issuance and accounting of search warrants issued by nonfull-time magistrates authorized to practice law in the state and whose remuneration shall be on a contract basis with payment for services verified and authenticated by the chief of police prior to disbursement of moneys; the acceptance of guilty pleas in accordance with the fine schedule as established in rule 20 of the state rules of judicial administration, including the supreme court's extended schedule of fines appearing as appendix B to rule 20, as now existing or hereafter amended by the state supreme court, and the fine schedule included under subsection (g) of this section; the summary disposition of parking offenses and the administrative adjudication of parking offenses wherein a dispute arises with appeals lying to the circuit court for a trial de novo; and other powers and duties provided by law. 
(b)  There is created the office of clerk of the municipal court. The clerk of the municipal court shall be appointed by the presiding judge of the municipal court, subject to approval by the council in the same manner as provided by law for the appointment of department heads in Act No. 738 of the 1971 legislature. The clerk of the municipal court shall hold office for the term of the mayor of the city, and may be removed or demoted for cause by the presiding judge of the municipal court, subject to review by the city council as provided for department heads in Act No. 738 of the 1971 legislature. The clerk of the municipal court shall serve as the chief administrative officer of the municipal court administrative agency and shall answer to the presiding judge of the municipal court. The clerk of the municipal court shall assist the presiding judge in connection with his duties as the administrative head of the municipal court, which shall include the presiding judge's responsibility to ensure that the business of the court is attended with proper dispatch, the court dockets are not permitted to become congested, and trials of cases are not unreasonably delayed. The clerk of the municipal court, or in his absence, the assistant municipal court clerk, or other such person as directed by the presiding judge, shall be responsible for the general custody and control of the records of the municipal court, and shall perform all duties of the court clerk as defined by the laws and supreme court rules of the state, and by the ordinances of the city; provided, however, that before performing the duties of magistrate, any such person must be duly appointed as a municipal court magistrate. In connection with the administration of justice within the municipal court, the clerk of the municipal court shall coordinate the functions and duties of administrative personnel and court-support persons and agencies, including magistrates, probation officers, court referral officers, victim advocates, and research personnel, so that the overall administration of justice may function with efficiency and cooperation. The clerk of the municipal court shall disburse funds collected by the court to the proper agencies, with such disbursements to be made not less than monthly, as provided by state law for municipal court clerks. The clerk of the municipal court shall be under the supervision of the presiding judge, and shall represent the municipal court on administrative matters before the mayor and council and at other times as deemed appropriate. The clerk of the municipal court shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by the presiding judge. The clerk of the municipal court shall not be considered to be a department head or division manager and shall not be eligible for appointed employee pay as set forth in Ordinance No. 97-90. 
(c)  All officials, officers and employees of the municipal court, excluding the clerk of the municipal court, shall be classified employees within the city's then current salary classification plan, and shall be appointed by the clerk of the municipal court, subject to the approval of the presiding judge, and shall be subject to the provisions of the city's Personnel Policies and Procedures Manual, except to the extent that this ordinance is in conflict with the provisions of such provisions. 
(d)  The presiding judge shall request the appointment of employees, subject to authorization by the city council, or the filling of vacancies (in accordance with the then current policy for filling vacancies) as needed for the efficient conduct of the business of the municipal court. Personnel action requests made by the municipal court shall be submitted by the presiding judge to the mayor and the city council. The presiding judge is authorized to direct the expenditure of funds budgeted for and appropriated to the municipal court. On behalf of the municipal court, the presiding judge, with the assistance of the clerk of the municipal court, shall report once every six months to the mayor on the state of the court. This report shall include, at a minimum, activities of the court that have fostered the maintenance or improvement in the five performance areas established by the trial court performance standards: 
(1)  Access to justice; 
(2)  Expedition and timeliness; 
(3)  Equality, fairness and integrity; 
(4)  Independence and accountability; and 
(5)  Public trust and confidence. 
This report shall also include the court's compliance with the time standards for case management established by the American Bar Association, as the same may have been modified by the presiding judge of the municipal court. 
(e)  All magistrates of the municipal court shall maintain in the office of the court clerk a log showing the names of each person applying to the magistrate for a search or arrest warrant, together with a notation as to whether or not a warrant was issued as a result of such application. 
(f)  Municipal court shall be open at all times for the transaction of business. Each full-time judge shall hold regular morning and afternoon sessions of court on each Monday through Friday of each week, excepting holidays, or at such times as deemed necessary by the presiding judge of the municipal court. Each part-time municipal judge shall hold regular sessions of court and special settings at such times as may be set by ordinance, by court rule, or by the presiding judge, excepting holidays, and shall be available to issue all search warrants required by the police department, except for search warrants required during regular sessions of court. If there are no part-time municipal judges, the presiding judge shall designate one or more of the full-time judges to be available to issue search warrants required by the police department, except for search warrants required during regular sessions of court. 
(g)  Municipal court magistrates, in addition to those powers and duties specified in subsection (a) of this section, may accept a plea of guilty and impose the stated fine for any of the following offenses: 
Driving on Barricaded/Closed Road ..... $ 20.00 
Failure To Signal ..... 20.00 
Improper Seating ..... 20.00 
Improper Towing ..... 20.00 
Wrong Way on One-Way Street ..... 30.00 
Disobeying Traffic Control Device ..... 20.00 
Improper Lane Change ..... 25.00 
Off Truck Route ..... 25.00 
Improper Lane Usage ..... 30.00 
Cutting Corner To Avoid Intersection ..... 20.00 
Headlights Required During Wiper Use ..... 20.00 
No Helmet/Shoes on Motorcycle ..... 10.00 
Operating Steel Disc on Highway ..... 20.00 
Highway Littering (on extended schedule) ..... 100.00 
Motorcycle Handlebar Violation ..... 10.00 
Motorcycle—Improper Riding ..... 30.00 
Pedestrian—Improper Crossing ..... 10.00 
No Horn/Improper Horn ..... 20.00 
Failure To Restrain or Confine Dog or Cat ..... 20.00 
Failure To Register/Obtain License/Permit for Animal ..... 15.00 
Failure To Confine a Female Dog or Cat in Estrus (Season/Heat) ..... 25.00 
Failure To Attach Current License Tag to Animal ..... 15.00 
Failure To Attach Current Rabies Tag to Animal ..... 15.00 
Confining Animal or Animals in Pen Less Than Minimum Area or Improper Distance from Occupied Dwelling ..... 15.00 
Allowing an Animal Other Than a Dog or Cat To Run At Large ..... 25.00 
Misuse of Animal Trap ..... 25.00 
Violation of chapter 12, article V (noise control ordinance) ..... 50.00 
Violation of section 8-3 (Vehicles displayed or offered for sale) ..... 200.00 
Violation of section 25-7 (Private property impoundment and repossession notification) ..... 50.00 
Any person convicted of two or more traffic violations in the past 12 months must appear in court. Failure to appear is not a traffic violation. Any person convicted of one or more violations of section 8-3 listed in this subsection must appear in court. Any person convicted of two or more violations of chapter 5 or section 25-7 listed in his subsection must appear in court. The fines listed above are in addition to all applicable court costs. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-10, 6-23-1994; Ord. No. 95-268, § 2, 4-11-1995; Ord. No. 96-566, 7-11-1996; Ord. No. 96-659, § 1, 9-12-1996; Ord. No. 00-190, § 1, 2-24-2000; Ord. No. 00-444, § 1, 6-6-2000; Ord. No. 01-902, 11-8-2001) 
State Law reference— Municipal court administrative agency, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-50 et seq.  
Sec. 16-7. - Time and manner of beginning prosecutions. 
Prosecutions for violations of the provisions of this Code and other city ordinances must be commenced within 12 months after the commission of the act or offense complained of, and may be begun by summons, by warrant of arrest, or by arrest without warrant. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-12, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-8. - Person arrested to be brought before municipal judge unless bailed. 
(a)  When any person is arrested, with or without a warrant, for the violation of any ordinance of the city, it shall be the duty of the officer making the arrest to bring such person before the municipal judge, or to detain him in custody until he can be brought before the judge, unless such person shall give bond, in the sum of not more than $1,000.00, as the court shall prescribe, conditioned for his appearance before the judge on the day named, not more than three days after the arrest, to answer the charge preferred against him. Upon giving such bond, such person shall be discharged from custody. 
(b)  In case of an arrest without a warrant, the arresting officer shall have the probation officer's written statement provided under Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-13(i). 
(Ord. No. 94-413, §§ 15-4(f)(4), 15-13, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-9. - Subpoenas for witnesses. 
Subpoenas for witnesses for the city or the defendant may be issued by the municipal judge or the municipal court clerk. It is the duty of the chief of police or any police officer, to whom they are delivered, to execute and return them to the court clerk. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-21, 6-23-1994) 
State Law reference— Execution of process, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-4.  
Sec. 16-10. - Judgment nisi on failure of witness to appear; notice and judgment final. 
(a)  If witnesses, after being summoned, fail to appear and testify, a conditional judgment may be rendered against them and in favor of the summoning party; and in such cases, the proceedings, in all material respects as to notice, final judgment and other matters may be made to conform to those provided in the case of forfeited bail bonds. 
(b)  The penalty for the nonattendance of witnesses shall be $100.00; and the judgment nisi must be entered for that amount, to be made absolute for the whole or any part, as the municipal judge shall determine. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-22, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-11. - Statement of offense contents. 
No statement of the offense need be made other than that contained in the summons or complaint and warrant of arrest. It shall be a sufficient statement of the offense in the complaint, warrant or entry on the court docket to designate the offense or act by name, or by some other phrase which in common parlance designates it. It shall be no objection to the proceedings that they are imperfect or inaccurate, and all amendable errors shall be regarded as amended, so as to present only the substantial inquiry of the guilt or innocence of the defendant in accordance with all applicable federal, state and local laws. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-23, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-12. - Establishment of comprehensive traffic safety programs. 
(a)  There is established an alcohol abuse educational program to be known as the highway intoxication seminar, which shall be under the supervision of the clerk of municipal court. Each person attending the seminar shall be charged no more than $300.00 for evaluation and/or registration. Such fees are to be assessed by the judge of municipal court as appropriate unless waived by the municipal judge or by the clerk of municipal court in such cases where the individual is being referred by an outside agency. 
(b)  There is established a traffic safety educational program which shall be under the supervision of the clerk of municipal court. Each person attending the seminar shall be charged no more than $150.00 for registration. Such fees are to be assessed by the judge of municipal court as appropriate unless waived by the municipal judge or by the clerk of municipal court in such cases where the individual is being referred by an outside agency. 
(c)  There is established an advisory committee consisting of the presiding municipal judge or his designee, the chief of police or his designee, and the city attorney or his designee. 
(d)  The clerk of municipal court shall be responsible for scheduling of classes, instructors and facilitators and setting reasonable fees for the payment of the instructors and facilitators. The clerk of municipal court shall adopt rules and regulations for the operation of the established educational programs, criteria for acceptance and completion and established fees for the appropriate program. These rules and regulations, policy and procedures, and fee list shall be readily available for public inspection. 
(e)  All moneys collected as a result of this article in the form of registration fees, evaluation fees and/or tuition fees shall be maintained in a separate account with the city clerk-treasurer's office to be used only to defray the cost of services provided by the previously mentioned educational programs and for the purpose of providing various other traffic safety education and awareness programs to the city through the highway safety office of municipal court. The collection and use of these moneys shall be under the supervision of the clerk of municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-24, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-13. - Work release programs. 
(a)  There is established a work release program to be under the supervision of the presiding judge of the municipal court. The judges of the municipal court shall have the authority to sentence defendants, upon petition to the court by the defendant or upon application through a duly appointed officer of the court, to any one of the established programs. 
(b)  Municipal court work release will consist of three distinct types of programs applicable at the discretion of the court. 
(1)  Private industry work furlough involves the qualifying individual's being allowed to go to his jobsite during working hours on the judge's authorization. The individual must return to confinement at the end of his specified workday and can go nowhere else without the approval of the court. An inmate who is released from custody under this program is required to pay costs incident to confinement equal to one hour gross wage for each day of work release as a minimum and no more than 20 percent of the gross wage per day of work release as a maximum, as ordered by the court. These costs will be deposited with the clerk of municipal court and maintained in a separate account with the city clerk-treasurer's office and used only for the purposes as are established by the presiding judge and available for public inspection. 
(2)  Inmate community service involves the qualifying individual's being assigned to supervised work crews which are detailed to different city departments for community service projects. This program does not involve furlough and is based on supervised/custody work within the community. Appropriate rules, regulations and policies will be established by the presiding judge and available for public inspection. 
(3)  Alternative service involves the qualifying individual's being assigned community service work as opposed to incarceration. The program is based on intensive supervision and requires the court's authorization for placement. The individual must report to the court for community service work each day at a specified time unless otherwise authorized by the court. Appropriate rules, regulations and policies will be established by the presiding judge and available for public inspection. 
(c)  Municipal court work release programs may utilize extended limits of confinement to facilitate its purpose and is authorized to adopt rules, regulations and policies with specification and definition as to those extended limits of confinement. 
(d)  Municipal court work release programs designated as private industry work furlough and alternative service may utilize remote electronic monitoring with the convicted misdemeanant's voluntary participation and the affirmative discretion of the court. Any convicted misdemeanant participating in the remote electronic monitoring system who receives a wage from gainful employment shall be required to pay one hour of the gross wage, per day of utilization, for maintenance of the system, to be deposited with the clerk of municipal court and maintained in a separate account with the city clerk-treasurer's office and used only to defray the cost of the service performed. 
(e)  Indigent convicted misdemeanants will be subject to and governed by all laws presently in effect and hereinafter enacted. 
(f)  Convicted misdemeanants that are involved in municipal court work release programs will be responsible for their own medical costs pursuant to law. 
(g)  The municipal court shall adopt pertinent, reasonable and across-the-board rules, regulations, policies, procedures and guidelines, available for public inspection, regarding the availability, implementation, evaluation, utilization and maintenance of work release programs under the direction of the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-25, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-14. - Indigent defense system. 
(a)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to: 
(1)  Establish the indigent defense system to be used in the municipal court; 
(2)  Provide for the collection, accounting and disbursement of moneys used in the indigent defense system; and 
(3)  Provide legal counsel for any person found to be indigent by the court. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Appointed counsel means any attorney licensed to practice law in the state who is appointed by the court to represent one or more indigent defendants. 
Indigent defendant means any person charged in a criminal proceeding in the municipal court for which proceeding representation by counsel is constitutionally required and who under oath or affirmation states that he is unable to pay for his defense and who is found by the court to be financially unable to pay for the defense. 
Indigent defense system means any method or mixture of methods for providing legal representation to indigent defendants, including use of appointed counsel or any alternative method meeting constitutional requirements. 
(c)  Provision of indigent defense services. 
(1)  Pursuant to the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975 tit. 15, ch. 12 (Code of Ala. 1975, § 15-12-1 et seq.), §§ 12-14-9, 12-19-250, 12-19-250.1, and 12-19-251.1, the municipal court (clerk) administrator shall collect the appropriate fair trial tax on all applicable cases and deposit the moneys in the general fund of the city. Upon using and expending so much of the moneys as is necessary to defray the costs of providing representation for indigent defendants in the municipal court and after payment of such costs, the city shall pay into the state treasury any funds not used for that purpose with an accounting of the moneys expended. Attorney's fees to be paid by the city from this fund must be claimed on the proper fee declaration form duly authenticated and authorized by the signature of the municipal judge. 
(2)  The municipal court (clerk) administrator shall maintain a roster of six attorneys licensed to practice law in the state. One such attorney will attend each session of municipal court, as necessary, and shall be appointed by the court to assist indigent defendants at initial appearances, plea negotiations, guilty pleas and sentence impositions from previous appearances. 
(3)  The municipal court (clerk) administrator shall maintain a roster of all interested attorneys licensed to practice law in the state. Any rostered attorney may be appointed at any time to represent an indigent defendant as private counsel for trial arrangements, trials, appeals or any other circumstance when the appointed attorney as provided in subsection (c)(3) of this section cannot provide prompt and adequate representation or when a conflict of interest is evident. 
(Ord. No. 94-212, §§ 1—3, 4-14-1994) 
State Law reference— Indigent defense, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-9.  
Sec. 16-15. - Establishing a pretrial diversion program. 
(a)  Pursuant to authority granted by the state legislature, a pretrial diversion program is hereby established whereby certain offenses may be dismissed upon a defendant's successful completion of the program requirements including, but not limited to, payment of applicable fees and costs, treatment, and community service work. Eligibility for the program shall be determined by the municipal court and shall be subject to the City of Huntsville Pretrial Diversion Guidelines and Procedures as approved by the city's governing body. Eligibility further requires an admission of guilt and a waiver of the right to appeal by defendants entering the program. Any defendant who fails to comply with the requirements of the pretrial diversion program may face sanctions (including incarceration, extension of time of supervision, or further orders of the court), or termination from the program. 
(b)  The presiding municipal court judge, acting in consultation with the municipal prosecutor(s) of the office of the city attorney, is hereby authorized to establish guidelines regarding eligibility for participation in the pretrial diversion program pursuant to enabling legislation enacted by the Legislature of the State of Alabama and as approved by the city's governing body. The presiding municipal court judge's guidelines are attached hereto and the presiding municipal court judge, after consultation with the municipal prosecutor(s) shall have the authority to modify the guidelines as needed. 
(c)  The following application fees assessed for admittance and evaluation for the pretrial diversion program shall be based on the underlying criminal offense charged and shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  DUI: $507.00; 
(2)  Theft of property in the third degree: $307.00; 
(3)  Domestic violence offenses (excludes offense involving a minor child as victim): $507.00; 
(4)  Other misdemeanor offenses: $307.00; and 
(5)  Other violations: $307.00. 
The application fee shall be nonrefundable upon approval for participation in the pretrial diversion program. The application fee shall be collected by the city municipal court clerk and allocated to the city's general fund, except that a minimum of 25 percent shall be directed to the City of Huntsville's Advanced Technical Data Fund and a minimum of 25 percent shall be directed to the City of Huntsville Indigent Treatment Fund as established by the city. 
(d)  The following monitoring, supervision and testing fees for participation in the pretrial diversion program shall be assessed as follows: 
(1)  Compliance monitoring fee: $30.00, per appointment; 
(2)  Drug/alcohol testing fee: $25.00, per test; and 
(3)  Rescheduling fee: $15.00, per reschedule. 
Each offender shall also be responsible for payment of the cost of any treatment program made a part the offender's pretrial diversion program. Such programs may include: drug and alcohol treatment programs, other addiction treatment programs, behavior modification treatment programs or other therapy programs as may be required on a case by case basis. 
In addition to all fees required for participation in the pretrial diversion program, an offender shall also be liable for all court costs and fees, restitution, victims' compensation fund assessment, and any and all other fees and assessments, in the same manner as if the offender had not applied for entry into the program and has been found guilty of the offense or offenses involved. No costs, fees, restitution, or assessments shall be waived or remitted, absent an express agreement to that effect between the city judge and the offender, without a finding by the city judge that the offender does not have the reasonable ability to pay the same within the reasonably foreseeable future. 
With the exception of the evaluation fee, as previously provided, all other pretrial diversion program fees, assessments and treatment program costs, as well as, all court costs, court fees and court assessments shall be collected by the city municipal court clerk and shall be distributed as provided by state law. The municipal court clerk shall also collect fees as required by Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-17-226.17, as that section may be amended. 
(e)  The City of Huntsville Office of Probation shall be charged with reporting information to the office of prosecution services as required by Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-17-226.17, as that section may be amended. 
( Ord. No. 13-845, § 1, 11-7-2013 ; Ord. No. 18-670 , § 1, 9-13-2018)  
Secs. 16-16—16-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BAIL BONDS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Bail, Code of Ala. 1975, § 12-14-5. 
 
Sec. 16-51. - Cash bail bonds. 
(a)  The clerk of municipal court, or designee as provided by law, shall be authorized to accept cash bonds on criminal charges for violation of any section of this Code or other ordinance of the city within the city. Such bond shall be approved by the municipal judge or magistrate. 
(b)  The municipal judge of the city may forfeit such cash bonds placed with the clerk of municipal court, or designee as provided by law, by persons arrested for violation of any provision of this Code or other ordinance of the city for their appearance in the municipal court upon the failure of the person arrested to appear in accordance with the terms of such bail. 
(c)  All cash bonds heretofore accepted by the clerk of municipal court, or designee as provided by law, and heretofore forfeited by the person charged with violation of any provision of this Code or other city ordinance by their failure to appear in the municipal court and upon which the municipal judge has entered a forfeiture shall be and are forfeited to the city. 
(d)  All such cash bonds forfeited to the city shall be transferred in a timely manner, by the clerk of municipal court, to the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-14, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-52. - Liability on bail bond. 
The bail bond provided for in this article binds all and each of the obligors for the appearance of the defendant on the day named, and on each subsequent day to which the case may be adjourned or continued, until discharged by law. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-15, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-53. - Judgment nisi on default of appearance. 
If the defendant fails to appear, as required by his bail bond, the municipal judge shall enter up a conditional judgment against him and his sureties. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-16, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-54. - Notice of judgment nisi. 
(a)  If the defendant fails to appear, the municipal court clerk shall issue a notice to each defendant of the rendition of judgment nisi. 
(b)  The notice provided for in this section may be executed by the chief of police or any police officer and must be returned by the officer executing it, with the proper return, on or before the day appointed for the parties to show cause. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, §§ 15-17, 15-18, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-55. - Alias notice. 
If the notice mentioned in section 16-54 is not served on any of the parties, such other notices as are necessary may, from time to time, be issued, or the court may proceed against the parties on whom notice has been served. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-19, 6-23-1994)  
Sec. 16-56. - When judgment set aside, reduced or made absolute. 
If the defendants appear and show sufficient cause for the default, the conditional judgment shall be set aside without costs; but if they fail to appear, or appearing fail to show sufficient excuse for the default, the judgment must be made absolute for the entire penalty of the bond, or any part of the bond, according to circumstances, as the municipal judge shall deem proper. 
(Ord. No. 94-413, § 15-20, 6-23-1994)  
Chapter 17 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 17-1. - State misdemeanors, violations and offenses. 
(a)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city that is declared by a law of the state to be a misdemeanor shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(b)  Any person committing an offense within the corporate limits of the city, or that is declared by a law of the state to be a violation shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(c)  Any person committing within the corporate limits of the city an offense as defined by section 13A-1-2 of the Alabama Criminal Code, which offense is not declared by a law of the state to be a felony, misdemeanor or violation shall be guilty of an offense against the city. 
(d)  Except as described below, a person convicted of a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $500.00 or by imprisonment in the city jail or hard labor for a period not exceeding six months, or by any combination thereof: 
(1)  In the enforcement of a Class A misdemeanor, including a domestic violence offense, the fine may not exceed $5,000.00 and the sentence of imprisonment may not exceed one year; 
(2)  In the enforcement of penalties prescribed in Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-191, the fine shall not exceed $5,000.00 and the sentence of imprisonment or hard labor shall not exceed one year; 
(3)  The maximum fine for a person either convicted for violating any of the misdemeanor offenses described in Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9(d) or adjudicated as a youthful offender thereof shall be $1,000.00; 
(4)  When a provision of this Code provides a particular penalty expressly applicable to certain violations, the express penalty shall be the penalty imposed upon the conviction for those certain violations; 
(5)  The penalty imposed upon a corporation shall consist of the fine only, plus costs of court. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided by law or ordinance, with respect to violations of this Code that are continuous with respect to time, each day that the violation continues is a separate offense. 
(Code 1982, § 18-4; Ord. No. 83-448, § 1, 10-13-1983; Ord. No. 96-290, 4-11-1996; Ord. No. 18-249, 4-26-2018 ) 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Sec. 17-2. - Posting bills, similar materials. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to post any bill or advertisement, sign or notice by attaching it to or placing it around or against any telegraph, telephone or electric light pole or street lighting post in the city. It shall be unlawful for any person to post any bill or advertisement by attaching it to or placing it around or against any tree within the right-of-way of a dedicated street or highway within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18-26)  
Sec. 17-3. - Swimming in drainage system facilities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to swim in any creek, stream, ditch, pipe or similar facility maintained by the city as part of its public drainage system. 
(Code 1982, § 18-19)  
Sec. 17-4. - Fishing in drainage system facilities. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to fish in any creek, stream, ditch or similar facility maintained by the city as part of the city's drainage system without the permission of the owner, the owner's agent or person in possession of the property upon which the easement or right-of-way for the maintenance of the facility is located. 
(Code 1982, § 18-20)  
Sec. 17-5. - Unattended receptacles. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or allow to be placed, left or kept upon any lot or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the city any remote and unattended receptacle, bin, box, container, portable building or structure for the purpose of collecting, holding or storing discarded clothing, furniture, household hardware, appliances, household items or any other tangible items. 
(b)  Exceptions. Excepted from the requirements of this section are: 
(1)  Any accessory structure, portable building or other secondary structure which is located on the same property on which a primary structure is located and which is incidental to the occupation and use of any residential or commercial structure provided the structure is maintained and located in accordance with the ordinances and regulations of the city. 
(2)  Any dumpster, trash receptacle or other container for the collection and storage of trash, garbage or debris provided the dumpster, trash receptacle or container is maintained and located in accordance with the laws of the city. 
(3)  Any receptacle, box, bin, container, portable building or structure that is located on the premises where the daily business operations of a charitable organization are conducted provided such receptacle, box, container, portable building or structure is maintained in accordance with the zoning ordinance and other ordinances of the city. 
(c)  Enforcement. The manager of community development or his authorized representative shall be responsible for and possess the authority to enforce the provisions of this section. If any person shall fail or refuse to comply with the requirements of this section, the manager of community development or any code enforcement officer of community development may cause to be served upon such person, in person or by first class mail, a written official notice apprising the person of the violation of this section and requiring such person to comply with this section within a time stated in the notice, which shall be a period of not less than 15 calendar days. If a person fails to comply with the notice which has been served upon him in accordance with this section the manager of community development or any code enforcement officer working under his supervision may appear before the municipal court magistrate and make oath as to the facts constituting a violation of this section and apply for a summons or warrant with respect to any alleged offense. Any person found guilty of a violation of this section shall be subject to the same penalties as provided for violations of city ordinances in section 1-7. 
(d)  Removal. In addition to or in lieu of the enforcement procedures outlined in this section, the manager of community development or his authorized representative may cause the receptacle, bin, box, container, portable building or structure and its contents which are in violation of this section to be removed from its location and impounded at a depository designated by the manager of community development for such purpose. The receptacle, bin, box, container, portable building or structure and its contents shall be held at the depository for a period of 30 days, during which time it may be retrieved by the owner provided the owner reimburses the city for the reasonable costs of transportation to and storage in the depository. In no event shall the owner be required to reimburse the city more than $100.00. After 30 days, the receptacle, bin, box, container, portable building or structure and its contents if any shall be disposed of in the most suitable manner as determined by the manager of community development. 
(Ord. No. 95-469, §§ 1, 2, 7-13-1995) 
State Law reference— Citations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.1.  
Sec. 17-6. - Graffiti. 
(a)  Intent. Graffiti on private or public property is a blighting factor which deteriorates property and depreciates the value of the property and of adjacent and surrounding properties. The city council finds that graffiti or related inscribed material is a public nuisance and recognizes that it is done without the permission of the property owner and constitutes an act of vandalism, and is criminal activity under state law. It is the city council's further intent to provide for the prohibition of the placement of graffiti on public or private property as set forth in this section. Graffiti is inconsistent with the city's aesthetic standards and is injurious to the comfort, welfare and safety of the community. The existence of graffiti tends to breed community discontent and further criminal activity. The prompt removal of graffiti is necessary to prevent its proliferation, and failure to promptly remove or obscure graffiti increases the likelihood and probability that more graffiti will occur on the same site and on other nearby property. While a property and its owner or possessor are usually victims of the graffiti, it is always the duty of the owner or possessor of the property to remove graffiti immediately. To assist in preventing and controlling the spread of graffiti, the city council authorizes the use of city funds to remove graffiti on public and private property as set forth in this section. The council does not intend for this section to conflict with any existing state law. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Code officer means an officer or employee of the code enforcement section of the community development division of the city. 
Community development means the community development division of the city. 
Graffiti means any writing, drawing, inscription, figure, letter, number, symbol, word, marking, or combination, or other defacement with paint, ink, chalk, dye or other similar substances, or which are etched on public or private buildings, structures or places which are not authorized in advance by the property owner, or which are not permitted under the city's codes and ordinances, or despite authorization by the property owner or responsible party, is otherwise deemed a public nuisance by the city. Graffiti includes but is not limited to any form of writing, drawing, doodling, inscription, figure, letter, number, word, symbol, marking or etching, initials, slogans, aphorisms, threats or insults, expressions of profanity, or that which is deemed obscene, vulgar or otherwise offensive, or other defacements, regardless of the content or nature of the materials used in the commission of the act. 
Graffiti nuisance means any graffiti that has not been immediately removed or otherwise abated by the owner or responsible party of the property. 
Manager means the manager of the community development division of the city or his designee or representative. 
Owner means the recorded legal titleholder, or any person, group, firm, company, association or corporation having a legal or equitable interest in real or personal property, including but not limited to the interest of a lessee, tenant or occupant, or possessor of property. 
Property means any real or personal property, including but not limited to any building, structure, wall, sign or fence, or that which is affixed, incidental or appurtenant to real property. 
Public nuisance means any public nuisance known at common law, or that which may be detrimental to the health, safety or welfare of the public. Property defaced by graffiti is declared a public nuisance. 
Responsible party means an owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or person acting as an agent or manager for an owner, a lessee, tenant, occupant or any person having possession, charge or control of a property. Regardless of any arrangement or agreement to the contrary with any other party, each owner shall be a responsible party for the purposes of this section. There may be more than one responsible party for a property. 
(c)  Graffiti prohibited. 
(1)  Application of graffiti. It shall be unlawful for any person to write, paint, scratch, inscribe, scrawl, spray, place, draw or otherwise apply graffiti to any public or private building, structure or any other property within the city. Any person convicted of an offense under this subsection (c)(1) shall be fined not less than $200.00 and shall be ordered to perform a minimum of ten hours of community service for each offense. 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9. 
(2)  Duty of owner and responsible party. It shall be the duty of the owner or responsible party of a property to maintain that property free from graffiti. It shall be unlawful for an owner or responsible party to allow graffiti to remain on his property or to fail, neglect or refuse to immediately remove or abate any graffiti from his property. Any owner or responsible party whose property is vandalized by the application of graffiti is encouraged to notify community development. Upon notification by an owner or responsible party, community development shall notify the gang task force, or other appropriate contact, within the criminal investigation division of the police department, which shall record all reports of graffiti for investigation and reference purposes. If the owner or responsible party notifies community development as provided in this subsection, such owner or responsible party shall be allowed 14 days from the date of such notification to abate the graffiti nuisance, using whatever resources may be available for graffiti abatement through community development. Should the owner or responsible party fail, neglect or refuse to remove or abate the graffiti from the property within the 14 days provided in this subsection, the owner or responsible party shall be issued a notice from community development to abate the graffiti as provided in subsection (d)(2) of this section. 
(d)  Enforcement. 
(1)  Inspections. The community development manager or any code officer is authorized to make inspections of properties within the city to enforce the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Notice. If the owner or responsible party of any real property within the corporate limits of the city shall fail, neglect or refuse to comply with the provisions of this section, the community development manager or any code officer may cause to be served upon the owner or responsible party, in person or by first class mail, a written notice apprising the owner or responsible party of the violation of this section and requiring such owner or responsible party to comply with this section by removing or abating graffiti within 14 days of the date the notice is issued. This notice shall contain the street address or location of the property, a statement that the property is a graffiti nuisance, a concise description of the conditions that render the property a graffiti nuisance, and a statement that the graffiti nuisance must be abated by removal within a time as specified in the notice. The notice shall advise the owner or responsible party that if the graffiti nuisance is not abated within the allowed time, the city may enter the property and abate the graffiti nuisance and assess the costs of abatement to the property owner or responsible party and cause a citation to the municipal court to be issued for a violation of this section. The notice shall also advise that the owner or responsible party may request an appeal hearing as set forth in subsection (d)(3) of this section, and shall name the date, time and place for the hearing. 
(3)  Appeal hearing. An owner or responsible party receiving a notice may request an administrative hearing before the community development manager, or other hearing officer as designated by the community development manager, to determine whether the owner or responsible party is in violation of this section. The community development manager and the owner or responsible party shall have the right to compel attendance of witnesses on their behalf at such hearing. If after the hearing the community development manager determines that this section has been violated, the owner or responsible party shall have five days from the date of notification of the determination to comply with this section. If the owner or responsible party fails, neglects or refuses to comply after such notification, the community development manager may institute the following enforcement procedures: 
a.  The community development manager may cause the abatement of the graffiti nuisance by removing or obscuring the graffiti. An account of the costs of the abatement shall be kept by the community development manager. Costs may include but are not limited to costs incurred in inspecting the property, in documenting the nuisance, in preparation of notices, work orders, and abatement contracts, and in inspection of the abatement work, in legal expenses, and other expenses. A billing notice of the expenses incurred by the city for the graffiti abatement may be served upon the owner or responsible party by certified mail or by personal delivery. The billing notice shall include the street address or location of the property where the abatement occurred and a statement of the expenses incurred by the city for abating the nuisance on the subject property and requiring that the expenses be paid to the city within 30 days from the date of the billing notice, or an assessment may be placed against the subject property. If the expenses are not paid within the allotted time, the community development manager may render an itemized report in writing to the city council setting forth the costs for abating the graffiti nuisance and requesting that an assessment be placed against the subject property. The community development manager shall notify the owner or responsible party at least five days in advance of the time fixed for the council to receive the report, and the owner or responsible party may appear at that time and present any objections to the report. At the time fixed for receiving and considering the report, the council shall hear the report, along with any objections which may be raised by the owner or responsible party whose property is liable to be assessed for the abatement. The council may make such modifications to the report as they deem necessary, after which by motion or resolution the report shall be confirmed. The amounts set forth in the report shall constitute special assessments against the subject property and shall constitute a lien on the property for the amount of the assessments. After confirmation of the report, a copy shall be given to the city clerk-treasurer, who is charged with the collection of assessments, whereupon it shall be the duty of the city clerk-treasurer to charge the assessments against the respective property; and thereafter the amounts shall be collected at the same time and in the same manner as ordinary municipal assessments are collected and shall be subject to the same penalties and the same procedures under foreclosure and sale in case of delinquency as provided for ordinary municipal assessments. 
b.  The community development manager, or any code officer, may cause a citation to be issued to any owner or responsible party who, after written notice has been issued, fails, neglects or refuses to comply with the provisions of this section. Such citation shall name the party charged, the address or location of the property where the graffiti nuisance is located, and the nature of the offense or violation. It shall also apprise the responsible party of the date, time and place at which to appear for court. Such citation shall be returnable to the municipal court. 
c.  The community development manager may institute both enforcement procedures set forth in subsections (d)(3)a. and b. of this section. 
(e)  Emergency removal. If the community development manager or any code officer determines that any graffiti is an immediate danger to the health, safety or welfare of the public, then 48 hours after the notice is posted on a conspicuous place on the property, the city may remove or cause the graffiti to be removed. 
(f)  Right of entry. The community development manager, or any code officer, is authorized to enter upon any property within the city for the purpose of enforcing this section, or for the purpose of abating a graffiti nuisance. 
(g)  Materials. In no case shall the city be required to paint or repair any more extensive an area than that where graffiti is located, or is necessary to remove or abate the graffiti, as determined by community development. The city shall not be required to restore the property to its original condition with regards to color, texture or type material used for abatement. 
(h)  Penalty. Any owner or responsible party of a graffiti nuisance property who violates this section by allowing graffiti to remain upon the property shall upon conviction be punished by a fine of not less than $100.00 upon conviction in the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 96-918, §§ 1—8, 11-25-1996) 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Sec. 17-7. - Global positioning system monuments. 
The city, to aid in more accurate surveying, has placed global positioning system (GPS) monuments at various locations. Global positioning system monuments are concrete cylinders four feet in length, eight inches in diameter with numeric characters engraved on a three-inch diameter brass disc implanted in the cylinder and placed in the ground with the brass disc exposed or just below grade. The alteration, removal, disfiguration or destruction of a global positioning system monument without the specific permission of the public works services department is an act of destruction of city property and is unlawful. 
(Ord. No. 87-244, 6-23-1987)  
Sec. 17-8. - Discontinuance of CATV service. 
(a)  No franchised cable TV provider of the city shall disconnect or discontinue basic subscriber service to any subscriber, solely on the basis that the subscriber has refused the provider entry into the living area of the residential subscriber; however, such service may be discontinued after notification by the franchise holder to both the subscriber and to the city clerk-treasurer and after a hearing by the city council if the provider shows that there is reasonable grounds for such entry and that entry has been denied. 
(b)  Reasonable grounds shall include but are not limited to: 
(1)  Reasonable suspicion that the operation of a subscriber's equipment and attached to the franchise holder's cable is causing interference which places the franchise holder in potential violation of FCC regulations. 
(2)  Reasonable grounds to believe that illegal or unauthorized connections or attachments are attached to the franchise holder's cable. 
This provision shall not apply where there is an immediate danger to public safety because of the connection. 
(Ord. No. 83-444, 12-8-1983)  
Secs. 17-9—17-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY RIGHTS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference— Offenses against property rights, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-7-1 et seq., 13A-8-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 17-41. - Failure to return library books. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person who has been issued a membership card by the Huntsville Public Library, the government and supervision of which is vested in the library board, after receiving written notice as provided in this section, to fail or refuse to return or cause to be returned any book, periodical, recording or other material borrowed or withdrawn from the library or any branch or bookmobile of the library on such card to the public library, together with all overdue assessments or late charges, in compliance with the rules of the board. 
(b)  The failure of any person borrowing or withdrawing any book, periodical, recording or other material from the library or any branch or bookmobile on any membership card issued by the library to return the material within the time required by the rules of the board shall be prima facie evidence of intent not to return the book, periodical, recording or other material to the library by the holder of the membership card to which the material is charged. 
(c)  Any person who is shown to be the holder of a membership card upon the records of the library shall be chargeable with all loans or withdrawals made upon such membership card unless such person shall have prior to such loan or withdrawal surrendered his card to the library or given written notification to the library of the loss or theft of the card. 
(d)  Before any holder of a membership card of the public library shall be charged with any violation of this section, such holder shall first be given not less than ten days' written notice that borrowed or withdrawn library material is overdue. Such notice shall be conclusively presumed to have been given when the notice is deposited with the United States Postal Service and addressed to such holder at the address shown upon the membership records of the library. 
(e)  This section shall apply only to offenses where the borrowing or withdrawal of the book, periodical, recording or other material actually occurred entirely within the city, it not being within the authority of the city council to create an offense for an act occurring entirely outside the city. 
(f)  Any person violating any provision of this section shall upon conviction be punished by a fine not in excess of $100.00, or may be sentenced to the city jail for a term not exceeding 30 days, either or both, at the discretion of the municipal judge. 
(Ord. No. 82-367, §§ 1—6, 9-23-1982) 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Secs. 17-42—17-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC SAFETY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Offenses involving public order and safety, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-1 et seq. 
 
Sec. 17-71. - Emergency calls; interference. 
(a)  For purposes of this section, the following terms will be defined, as follows: 
(1)  Emergency response officer means any city employee, including but not limited to police and fire personnel, and other emergency response personnel, whether employed by the city or otherwise. The term shall not include the public information officer of the police department or the fire and rescue department. 
(2)  Emergency call means any call for assistance, whether emergency or otherwise, which is being or recently has been transmitted over city, police, fire or emergency radio systems. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person, after hearing or receiving information regarding an emergency call, to contact emergency response officers, including those at the police department, fire and rescue department, or any participating emergency response agency, including the E 911 center, in an attempt to obtain information about an emergency call. It shall also be unlawful for any person to interfere in any way with an emergency response officer in answering an emergency call. 
(c)  The provisions of subsection (b) of this section shall not preclude a person from contacting emergency response officers at the scene of an emergency so long as such conduct does not interfere with an emergency response officer in responding to the emergency call or otherwise in performing his duties.  
Sec. 17-72. - Discharging firearms. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or fire a gun or other firearm within the city except as follows: 
(1)  In the execution of the law. 
(2)  At a military parade by order of a proper officer. 
(3)  If the person holds a license, which license may be issued by the chief of police upon the application of an individual or organized gun or skeet club to discharge shotguns only upon specifically described premises within the city. Each application for such authority shall be submitted to the chief of police at least five days in advance of any requested shooting date and must be accompanied by a map or plat showing all roads and development within 300 yards of the property upon which the shooting is to be allowed. Any license issued by the chief of police to any individual or club under this subsection shall be limited as to the premises and shall be limited to such times as the chief of police may determine, not exceeding one year. The chief of police shall take into consideration, in granting or refusing such permits, the proximity of such premises to inhabited dwellings, businesses, streets or highways, and also the likelihood that persons or domestic animals will be endangered by such shooting. 
(4)  At a range, shooting gallery, or test site, for the discharge of specific types of firearms and ammunition, approved by the inspection division as meeting the design, operational and other requirements set forth as follows: 
a.  Location. Location shall be as set forth in the zoning ordinances for the city. 
b.  Codes. Building and construction shall comply with the following codes as adopted and amended by the city: 
1.  Standard Building Code. 
2.  National Electrical Code. 
3.  Standard Plumbing Code. 
4.  Standard Gas and Mechanical Codes. 
5.  Other ordinances as they may apply. 
c.  Miscellaneous building requirements. Notwithstanding all other provisions of this section: 
1.  Other uses within an indoor firing range building shall be separated from the firing range as required by the Standard Building Code. 
2.  Buildings classified as type V or VI construction by the Standard Building Code shall not be considered for use as an indoor firing range. 
3.  Walls, floors and ceilings of the firing range itself must be bulletproof for the type of firearms, bullet weight, velocity and bullet construction to be permitted. Bulletproof means the ability of the wall, floor and ceiling material to contain three maximum power projectiles fired into any point from behind the firing line, and as certified by an architect or engineer registered under the laws of the state. 
4.  Ricochet control within the firing range shall be by absorption and/or deflection and shall be explained by plans and specifications. 
d.  Plans and specifications. The permittee shall submit to the inspection division the following: 
1.  A complete set of building plans and specifications and other engineering reports as may be required as sealed by an architect or engineer legally registered under the laws of the state, the plan to include plat, building specifications, parking availability, landscaping, outdoor advertisement signs, and types of firearms, bullet weight, velocity and bullet construction to be allowed. 
2.  A standard operating procedures manual, for file purposes only, which shall include, but not be limited to, the following: 
i.  Posting of warning or precautionary signs. 
ii.  Availability of hearing and eye protection. 
iii.  Firing range cleaning procedures and methods of disposing of waste. 
iv.  Procedures for removing lead from bullet trap. 
v.  Disposal of lead recovered from bullet trap. 
vi.  Disposal procedures for spent bullet trap material. 
vii.  Ventilation system testing procedures and schedules. 
viii.  Specifications of and maintenance schedules for air cleaning system (recirculation type only). 
3.  Proof of a public liability insurance policy with a minimum limit amount of $500,000.00 for the purpose of payment of all damages to persons or property which may arise from or be caused by the conduct of any act on the property, authorized by the city, upon which any legal judgment results. 
e.  Environmental. 
1.  Noise. All noises emanating from the property shall comply with chapter 12, article V, except that the sound of firearm discharge and the sound of bullet impact shall not exceed 65 percent of the levels established in those sections; and where a firing range property adjoins residentially zoned property, the sound of firearm discharge and the sound of bullet impact shall not be audible at or beyond the property line. Compliance with noise requirements shall be determined by personnel of the natural resources and environmental management divisions and reported to the manager of the inspection division for appropriate action. These noise restrictions apply only to adjoining property lines exterior to any building which houses a firing range. 
2.  Ventilation system. 
i.  Fresh air system. The exhaust system shall be so designed that the air entering the range is from above and behind the firing line, is evenly distributed across all firing stations, and will result in an air velocity of between 65 and 85 feet per minute (fpm) past the firing line. At least 75 percent of the air volume shall be exhausted at the target/backstop area. The velocity shall be tested and certified every six months and results reported to the inspection division. Prior approval of the methodology for testing and certification must be given by the inspection division. 
ii.  Recirculation system. If a recirculation type ventilation system is utilized, the requirements stated in subsection (a)(4)e.2.i. of this section shall apply, and in addition, an air cleaning system (with pressure drop indicator) which will remove 99.97 percent of all particles greater than or equal to 0.3 micron in diameter must be installed and operated. 
3.  Wastewater. If the range area is to be cleaned by flushing with water, the floor drain shall be equipped with a grit trap and other control devices as required and approved by the natural resources and environmental management division. 
4.  Inspection. The range shall be subject to periodic inspection by the natural resources and environmental management division to determine compliance with noise and ventilation requirements. Results of such inspections shall be reported to the inspection division for appropriate action. 
5.  Testing. Before a certificate of occupancy is issued, the range shall be tested for the requirements contained within this section. This testing shall be accomplished by an agency approved by the inspection division. All costs associated with such testing shall be paid by the owner. Results of a test completed within the previous six months to validate compliance of the bulletproof and ventilation requirements shall accompany the application for an annual business license. 
(b)  Nothing contained in this section shall exempt compliance with all other applicable laws, ordinances or regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 18-49; Ord. No. 84-835, 12-13-1984; Ord. No. 88-208, 5-26-1988; Ord. No. 89-109, 3-9-1989) 
State Law reference— Firearms and weapons, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-50 et seq.; preemption of handgun ordinances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-1.1.  
Sec. 17-73. - Discharging air rifles, airguns, air pistols, BB guns, paintball guns. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to shoot or discharge an air rifle, airgun, air pistol or BB gun within the city except as provided in subsection (b) of this section. 
(b)  The chief of police may upon application permit an individual or organization to discharge BB guns within an indoor facility approved for such use by the chief of police subject to the provisions of the city's zoning ordinance and the following provisions: 
(1)  Each application for a permit shall be submitted to the chief of police at least 14 calendar days in advance of any requested shooting event date. 
(2)  Permits, if approved, shall be issued on an event basis only. 
(3)  In reviewing applications for BB gun permits, the chief of police shall take into consideration the: 
a.  Suitability of the indoor facility for such use; 
b.  Safety procedures to be implemented by the individual or organization responsible for such use; 
c.  The proximity of the indoor facility to inhabited dwellings, businesses, streets or highways; and 
d.  Likelihood that persons will be endangered by such use. 
The chief of police is authorized to deny or revoke any permit if in his opinion use of the facility as proposed by the individual or organization presents a danger to persons or damage to property. 
(c)  Notwithstanding anything contained in this section 17-73 to the contrary, it shall be lawful to shoot or discharge a paintball gun within the city limits at a site which has been granted a special exception by the board of zoning adjustment of the city, in accordance with the city's zoning ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 18-50; Ord. No. 97-171, § 18-50, 3-13-1997; Ord. No. 05-310, § 1, 5-12-2005)  
Secs. 17-74—17-100. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC PEACE AND ORDER[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Offenses against public order and decency, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-1 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 17-101. - Sleeping in parked vehicles, public places or on private lot of another. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep in, or use for sleeping quarters, any automobile, truck or any other vehicle, while the vehicle is parked on any street or other public roadway or public land, except this provision shall not prohibit sleeping in recreational vehicles on public land officially established as a trailer camp, tent camp or tourist camp and designed for overnight sleeping. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep in, or use as sleeping quarters, any public place, public house, building or structure within the city unless such building or structure is one which has been provided with beds or sleeping quarters. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to sleep in or upon, or use as sleeping quarters, any private lot or ground, whether such sleeping, or use for sleeping, is had or done in an automobile, truck or other vehicle located upon such private lot or land without the written consent of the person owning such private lot or land; except that nothing in this subsection shall be construed as prohibiting the right of any person to sleep in or upon, or use for sleeping quarters, any such private lot or land which is owned by the person so using the vehicle for such sleeping purpose; nor shall the vehicle be construed as prohibiting the use for sleeping or sleeping quarters of the area embraced in any regularly licensed trailer camp, tent camp or tourist camp. 
(Code 1982, § 18-23) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23; traffic and vehicles, ch. 25.  
Sec. 17-102. - Disturbing the peace. 
It shall be unlawful for any person willfully to disturb the peace of others by violence, offensive, boisterous or tumultuous conduct or carriage or by language calculated to provoke a breach of the peace, or to create or aid in a rout or riot within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 18-48) 
State Law reference— Disorderly conduct, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-7.  
Sec. 17-103. - Trespassing, prowling, loitering, etc. on private property. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to enter, remain, loiter, prowl or wander about, whether in a motor vehicle or on foot, upon or around any private premises, or in any enclosed lot, or in and around any dwelling, without the permission, consent or knowledge of the owner or lessee of the premises, lot or dwelling. 
(Code 1982, § 18-17; Ord. No. 05-1033, § 1, 11-22-2005)  
Sec. 17-104. - Police department firing range. 
It shall be unlawful and shall constitute a trespass for any person, not authorized by the chief of police or his designee, to enter, remain, loiter or prowl about any section or part of the police department firing range, located on or about 325 Wall-Triana Highway S.W. in the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-337 , § 1, 5-25-2017)  
Sec. 17-105. - Police department evidence and impound storage lot and/or facility. 
It shall be unlawful and shall constitute a trespass for any person, not authorized by the chief of police or his designee, to enter, remain, loiter or prowl about any section or part of any police department evidence and impound storage lot and/or facility owned by the city. 
(Ord. No. 17-337 , § 1, 5-25-2017)  
Secs. 17-106—17-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLIES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Unlawful assembly, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-5. 
 
Sec. 17-121. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Missile means a weapon or object thrown or projected or intended to be projected. 
Police officer means any member of the police department or any member of the fire department engaged in assisting police officers in police work, or any other person who, at the request of an officer of the city or of police officers, is engaged in assisting police officers in police work. 
Public place means any public park, public building or other public place of the city. 
Street means any public street, public avenue, public road or public alley or sidewalk of the city. 
Unlawful assembly means an assembly which is unlawful according to Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-11-5, or any other state act or statute. 
(Code 1982, § 18-69) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 17-122. - Authority to prohibit use of public places when disorder threatened. 
(a)  Whenever the chief of police has good reason to believe that an unlawful assembly on a street or in a public place within the city is in progress or is planned to be held, the chief of police, if he has good reason to believe that it is necessary to prevent a breach of the peace, a disorder or a riot, may prohibit, for the time being, persons from occupying or passing on any street or public place where such breach of the peace, disorder or riot is threatened or is believed by the chief of police likely to occur, and to otherwise regulate passage or occupancy upon such street and place. 
(b)  The chief of police or, in his absence, the officer mentioned in section 17-123, may deputize any member of the police department to impose the prohibitions or regulations upon occupying or passing on streets or public places provided for in this section. 
(Code 1982, § 18-70)
