(a)  Definitions . For purposes of this section 18-36, the following words, terms, and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (a), unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Central city area means the area described in section 18-31. 
Central city core area means the following described area located within the central city area: 
Beginning at the intersection of Church Street and the Norfolk Southern Railroad; thence Southeast along the centerline of Church Street to the intersection with Monroe Street; thence Southwest along the centerline of Monroe Street to the intersection with Holmes Avenue; thence East along the centerline of Holmes Avenue to the intersection with Church Street; thence Southeast along the centerline of Church Street to the intersection with Williams Avenue; thence Northeast along the centerline of Williams Avenue to the intersection with Franklin Street; thence Northwest along the centerline of Franklin Street and to the intersection with Eustis Avenue; thence Northeast along the centerline of Eustis Avenue to the intersection with Greene Street; thence Northwest along the centerline of Greene Street to the intersection with Monroe Street and Meridian Street; thence North along the centerline of Meridian Street to the intersection with Pratt Avenue; thence West along the centerline of Pratt Avenue to the intersection with I-565; thence Southwest along the centerline of I-565 to the intersection with Church Street; thence Southeast along the centerline of Church Street to the intersection with the Norfolk Southern Railroad and the point of beginning. 
Central city review committee or committee means a committee comprised of the police chief, the city-clerk treasurer, and the manager of planning administration, or their respective designees. 
Business license shall have the same meaning ascribed to it in section 15-31 of this Code. 
Permit means a sidewalk cafe permit, a vendor's permit, or a mobile food vendor's permit issued under the authority of this section. 
Permitted activity means the sidewalks cafes, vendors, or mobile food vendors permitted under this section. 
Permitted premises means that portion of the public streets, sidewalks, or parks that is allowed by the permit to be occupied for the permitted activity. 
Public works activity means any public works project; public building project; infrastructure construction, maintenance, or repair; or other public improvement activity of the state or city. 
(b)  General conditions . Each of the following conditions shall apply to the activity or persons permitted or regulated under this section: 
(1)  The permit shall be in addition to the required business license and the permit holder shall obtain and maintain a business license from the city and, failing to so obtain or maintain the business license, the permit issued under this section shall be automatically revoked without the need for any action from the city or any right of appeal by the permit holder. 
(2)  The permit holder shall comply with all applicable laws, rules, and regulations that pertain to the permitted activity and use of the permitted premises, including city and state health laws and the obtaining of the required health department permitting. 
(3)  The free passage of pedestrians along the sidewalk shall not be prevented or substantially impaired and there shall be at least a minimum sidewalk width of five feet of unencumbered sidewalk that is open for pedestrian use maintained adjacent to the permitted premises. 
(4)  No signs shall be allowed to be placed on any portion of the public sidewalks, streets, or parks, including the permitted premises, except that a mobile food vendor may affix signage to its mobile food vending unit and a vendor may affix signage to its cart or other equipment. 
(5)  Access to adjacent buildings or uses shall not be impeded. 
(6)  At any time and from time to time the city clerk-treasurer may, in the case of a vendor's permit or mobile food vendor's permit, re-assign a permit holder's assigned space to another appropriate location and, in the case of a sidewalk cafe permit or a mobile food vendor's permit, temporarily suspend the permit, in order to accommodate: 
a.  A special event, including lease events and sponsor events, permitted under chapter 23, article VI of this Code; 
b.  Another permitted activity authorized under this section; or 
c.  A state or city project, activity, or event, including a public works activity. 
(7)  A permit holder shall keep the permitted premises and adjacent public property clean and free from all trash, litter, debris, or waste generated from the operation of its business. The permit holder's installations, equipment, carts, and other items shall be maintained and kept in good and presentable condition and repair and free from graffiti. 
(8)  The permit holder shall not erect or construct any permanent structure or modify or affix anything to any existing structure or any public property or otherwise damage or deface public property. 
(9)  A vendor or mobile food vendor must use its permitted premises for its permitted activity on a routine basis during the appropriate seasons for outdoor use, unless prevented from doing so by circumstances beyond the permit holder's control. 
(10)  The city clerk-treasurer may, at any time and from time to time, attach additional conditions to the use of the permitted premises in order to protect the public health, safety, or general welfare. 
(11)  Upon the termination, whether by revocation or otherwise, of the permit, the permit holder shall restore the permitted premises to the satisfaction of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(c)  Permits. 
(1)  Permit requirement . 
a.  Every person who shall desire to use public space in the central city core area or, where allowed under this section, the central city area, to conduct an activity authorized under this section shall make application with the city clerk-treasurer on forms provided by the city, which application shall include the applicants complete name and address and, where applicable, its trade name, the address of any location used for storage of carts, supplies, equipment, or inventory, installation plans, indemnification of the city, and proof of insurance. 
b.  Permits required by this section shall be renewed annually by filing, at business license renewal time, a permit renewal application with the city clerk-treasurer on forms provided by the city. Permits are not transferrable. 
c.  Permit holders shall notify the city clerk-treasurer within ten days of a change in the permit holder's address. 
d.  The city-clerk treasurer is hereby authorized to administer the provisions of this section and to issue a permit authorized under this section in accordance with this section. 
(2)  Use fee . At the time of the filing its application or renewal application, as the case may be, the applicant for a permit shall pay to the city a non-refundable, annual use fee for the right to use the permitted premises as follows: 
a.  The applicant for a vendor's permit shall pay $100.00. 
b.  The applicant for a sidewalk cafe permit shall pay $100.00. 
c.  The applicant for a mobile vendor's permit shall pay $100.00 per mobile food vending unit located on public vending space. 
(3)  Revocation, suspension, or non-renewal of permit; no vested right . 
a.  The city clerk-treasurer is authorized to revoke or suspend or not renew a permit for a violation of this section; provided that the permit holder shall first be given a reasonable period of time, not to exceed 20 days, to cure the violation, unless the clerk-treasurer determines that the violation is not reasonably capable of being cured, the permit holder refuses to cure the violation, or the permit holder has on multiple occasions within a given calendar year committed the same violation. 
b.  The permit holder may appeal the action taken against the permit to the two remaining members of the central city review committee by filing, within 20 days of the date of the action taken, a written request with the city clerk-treasurer. The hearing on the appeal shall be held by the two remaining members of the committee within a reasonable period of time and the permit holder shall be provided advance written notice of the date and time of the hearing of the appeal and shall have the opportunity to be heard at the hearing. The decision of the city clerk-treasurer shall be upheld unless the two remaining members of the committee determine that a reversal is justified under the circumstances. 
c.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this subsection (3), while an appeal is pending the permit holder may continue to operate under the permit unless the city clerk-treasurer determines that the permit should be suspended pending the outcome of the appeal in order to protect the public's health or safety or prevent damage to or destruction of public property. 
d.  Action taken against a permit shall not constitute action being taken against the business license. 
e.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section: (i) a permit holder shall acquire no vested right to a permit or use of the permitted premises and the provisions of this section and any rights granted hereunder, in whole or part, are subject to repeal or amendment, at any time or from time to time; and (ii) there is no right of appeal from a temporary suspension of a permit under subsection (b)(6) of this section. 
f.  Nothing in this subsection (3) shall be construed to prevent the enforcement, by arrest or citation, of applicable laws, including a violation of this section. 
(d)  Sidewalk cafes . 
(1)  Sidewalk cafe permit . Subject to the provisions of this section, any person engaged in the business of operating a restaurant, cafe, cafeteria, or other public place where meals, food, or refreshments are prepared and furnished upon premises licensed for such use that are within the central city core area may apply for a sidewalk cafe permit from the city in order to use the public sidewalk adjacent to such premises as a sidewalk cafe for its patrons. 
(2)  General conditions . Sidewalk cafes shall be subject to each of the following conditions: 
a.  No alcoholic beverages are to be served or consumed upon the permitted premises unless the provisions of subsection (3) of this subsection (d) are met. 
b.  The city may require that the permitted premises be delineated by a railing or other method of delineation that is not affixed to any portion of the sidewalk or other public property. 
c.  During hours when the establishment is closed for business chairs shall either be removed from the sidewalk or otherwise secured so as to prevent their use while the business is closed; provided that, notwithstanding the foregoing, the city clerk-treasurer may, at any time and from time to time, require that all or any portion of the installations on the permitted premises be removed when the establishment is closed for business for public safety or convenience. At all times the permitted premises and the installations thereon shall be maintained in a neat and presentable manner, without clutter, and chairs shall be neatly stacked or placed when not in use. 
d.  All proposed installations upon or over the permitted premises, including location, materials used, appearance, style, extent, and method of installation, shall be subject to review and approval of the central city review committee. Detailed plans and specifications of the installation suitable in form and content to the committee shall be submitted to the office of the city clerk-treasurer together with any other information that may be required by the committee in order to approve the installation. Such installations may include customer tables and seating, railings or other methods of delineating the space, awnings to be installed over the permitted premises, table umbrellas, and containers of plants. At any time and from time to time the committee may require installations to be modified or removed for the public health, safety, or general welfare. All installations shall be installed at the sole costs and expense of the permit holder and under proper building and other technical code permitting as may be required. 
e.  A permit holder shall make its indoor bathroom facilities available to its sidewalk cafe customers, and in no event shall the permit holder be allowed to install any outdoor bathroom facilities. 
f.  Should the committee determine that lighting is required for the public safety and convenience, then the permit holder shall, at its sole expense and cost, provide such required lighting; provided said lighting shall not be affixed so as to damage or deface public property, and further provided, the permit holder shall obtain and maintain any applicable permits for installation and operation of the lighting, including but not limited to electrical permits. 
g.  There shall be no outside live music or entertainment. Music may be played outside over a public address system, provided that it shall cease at 10:00 p.m. 
(3)  Sidewalk cafes serving alcoholic beverages . Alcoholic beverages may be served to patrons seated at tables and chairs on the permitted premises, subject to each of the following conditions: 
a.  The permit holder shall be duly licensed by the state and city to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption and such licensing shall include as a portion of the licensed premises the permitted premises. 
b.  The permit holder shall not be an establishment that provides live entertainment or dancing inside its licensed premises unless it qualifies as a restaurant (as defined by the zoning laws of the city). 
c.  The establishment shall comply with applicable state and city alcoholic beverage laws, which includes the regulations of the Alabama Alcoholic Beverage Control Board governing the display of alcoholic beverages and their service on patios adjacent to the licensed premises. 
d.  The permit holder shall be responsible for the provision of security within the permitted premises during the period of the permit; provided, however, nothing herein shall prevent any law enforcement officer or other official from entering upon the permitted premises to perform any law enforcement function or otherwise administer or enforce any federal, state, or local law. 
e.  The permit holder shall obtain and maintain throughout the permitted period bodily injury and property damage liability insurance, on an occurrence basis, naming the city, its officials, officers, employees, and agents as an additional insureds, covering the permitted premises in a minimum amount of $100,000.00 for the injury to or death of any one person and $300,000.00 for the injury to or death of any number of persons in one occurrence, and property damage liability insurance in the amount of $100,000.00. Such insurance shall specifically insure the permit holder against all liability assumed by the permit holder hereunder as well as liability imposed by law, and shall insure both the city and permit holder, but shall be so endorsed as to create the same liability on the part of the insurer as though a separate policy had been written for the city and permit holder. Such policy of insurance shall be issued by a company authorized to engage in the insurance business in the State of Alabama, maintaining a Best rating of not less than "A," and shall be approved by the city attorney or his designee prior to the issuance of a permit. The city clerk-treasurer may, at any time and from time to time, require the permit holder to provide a certificate of insurance or other proof of insurance. 
f.  The applicant for a permit shall, at the time of making application for a permit and on forms provided by the city, agree to indemnify and hold harmless the city, its officials, officers, employees, agents, contractors, and volunteers performing authorized city functions, from and against any and all claims, costs, losses, expenses through appeal (including reasonable attorneys' fees, and costs or expenses incidental to the investigation of claims and lawsuits), demands, payments, suits, actions, recoveries, penalties, fines, liabilities, and judgments, of any nature and description, resulting from or arising out of the acts or omissions of the permit holder, its officers, servants, agents, contractors, employees, or customers, in connection with the conduct of the permitted activity or the use of the permitted premises. This provision shall survive the termination, whether by revocation or otherwise, of the permit. 
(e)  Vendor's permit . 
(1)  Definitions . For purposes of this subsection (e), the following words, terms, and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (1), unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Public vendor space means the public sidewalks and parks located in the central city core area, and the routes of public parades which are located within the central city area, but only during the hours of such parades. 
Vendor activity means: 
a.  Demonstration or sale of the following products: 
1.  Sandwiches, hot dogs, hot tamales, hamburgers, pizzas and drinks (other than alcoholic beverages); 
2.  Candies, nuts, popcorn and confections; 
3.  Ice cream, ice cream bars and related confections; 
4.  Fruits and vegetables; 
5.  Novelties and homemade artifacts which are handmade by the permit holder or his employees, and specifically excluding finished or unfinished products bought for resale; and 
6.  Fresh cut and dried flowers. 
b.  To take and sell photographs where the parties photographed willingly pose for the pictures and the picture is developed on the spot where taken and there delivered to the parties photographed. 
c.  Painting, sketching, drawing; exhibiting original paintings, sketches or drawings of the permit holder; or the sale of the permit holder's original (including prints or other reproductions) paintings, sketches, or drawings. 
d.  The sale of new or used books. 
e.  Exhibitions or performances by a single performer, educational or otherwise, when admission or fee is charged. The term shall not include exhibitions or performances that are a part of the conduct of an organized event regulated by chapter 23, article VI of this Code. 
(2)  Vendor's permit . Subject to the provisions of this section, any person engaged in the business of operating a vendor activity may apply for a vendor's permit from the city in order to use public vendor space to conduct its vendor activity. 
(3)  Assignment of space . Each vendor's permit shall designate that portion of the public vendor space assigned to the permit holder by the city clerk-treasurer. Assignments shall be made by the city clerk-treasurer based on the preference of the applicant, the availability of the space, and any other factor deemed appropriate by the city clerk-treasurer based on the public's health, safety, and general welfare. Where more than one applicant for a permit expresses a preference for the same location, the space shall be assigned to the applicant first filing a completed application for the space; provided, that, where a permit is being renewed from the prior year, then the renewal applicant may be given preference. 
(4)  Sponsor's events . Where there are multiple vendors of vendor activities organized under a single sponsor, the sponsor shall make application for a special event permit under chapter 23, article VI of this Code, and shall be regulated by that article. A vendor operating under a sponsor's special event permit shall not be required to obtain a vendor's permit under this subsection (e). 
(5)  Condition . No permit holder shall operate or locate in any residential district or adjacent to any building used exclusively for residential use. 
(f)  Mobile food vendors . 
(1)  Definitions . For purposes of this subsection (f), the following words, terms, and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (1), unless the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Mobile food vending unit means a trailer or motorized vehicle designed to be portable and not permanently attached to the ground from which only prepared food or beverages, excluding alcoholic beverages, are peddled, vended, sold, displayed, offered for sale, or given away. 
Public mobile food vendor space means space on public property located within the central city core area, which is approved for a mobile food vending unit by the city's manager of planning administration. 
(2)  Mobile food vendor's permit . Subject to the provisions of this section, any person engaged in the business of operating a mobile food vending unit may apply for a mobile food vendor's permit from the city in order to use public mobile food vendor space to operate its mobile food vending unit. 
(3)  Assignment of space; number of units . 
a.  Each permit shall designate that portion of the public mobile food vendor space assigned to the permit holder by the city clerk-treasurer. Assignments shall be made by the city clerk-treasurer based on the preference of the applicant, the availability of the space, and any other factor deemed appropriate by the city clerk-treasurer based on the public's health, safety, and general welfare. Where more than one applicant for a permit expresses a preference for the same location, the public mobile food vendor space shall be assigned to the applicant first filing a completed application for the space; provided, that, where a permit is being renewed from the prior year, then the renewal applicant may be given preference. 
b.  A mobile food vendor may apply for more than one public mobile food vendor space. However, in order to accommodate other mobile food vendors, the city clerk-treasurer may limit or equitably apportion the number of public mobile food vendor spaces used by a mobile food vendor or a person associated with the vendor, such as a relative, family member, or, in the case of a vendor that is an entity, its officers, members, managers, or partners. 
(4)  Conditions . 
a.  For mobile vending units that are located on or adjacent to a street, food service shall be solely from that side of the unit that opens away from the street. 
b.  Hours of operation for mobile food vending units, not including set-up or take-down, shall be from 9:00 p.m. Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday until 2:00 a.m. Friday, Saturday, and Sunday; and from 6:00 a.m. until 11:00 a.m. Saturdays and holidays recognized by the city. Vendors may set-up one hour before opening and take-down 30 minutes after closing. Mobile food vending units shall be removed from public property at times other than the hours of operation and the set-up and take-down periods. 
c.  Mobile vending units shall not be placed or operated so as to impede vehicular traffic's use of the streets. 
d.  No outdoor loudspeaker, public address system, music, or other form of entertainment shall be audible from mobile food vending units. 
(Ord. No. 97-173, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 03-1063, 12-18-2003; Ord. No. 10-430, § 1, 6-10-2010; Ord. No. 13-434, § 1, 6-27-2013; Ord. No. 16-739 , § 1, 10-13-2016) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23.  
Chapter 19 - RECREATION SERVICES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Environmental management, ch. 12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23; vegetation, ch. 27. 
State Law reference— Municipal parks, playgrounds and other recreational and athletic areas and facilities, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-210. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 19-1. - Wheeled recreational vehicles. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Wheeled recreational vehicle means any vehicle used for recreational purposes, whether motorized or nonmotorized, which has one or more wheels affixed to the vehicle, and which shall include but is not limited to motorcycles, scooters, skateboards, in-line skates, and roller blades. Specifically excluded from this definition are baby strollers, wheeled vehicles required to assist the disabled, and nonmotorized bicycles and tricycles. 
(b)  Use in park prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any person to use, operate or allow to be used or operated within any public park in the city limits any wheeled recreational vehicle unless otherwise posted. 
(Ord. No. 95-568, §§ 1, 2, 8-24-1995; Ord. No. 05-711, § 1, 9-8-2005) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25.  
Sec. 19-2. - Vehicles in parks to be driven on roadways. 
No person shall ride or drive any vehicle in any public park within the city limits unless it is upon a road or driveway set apart for such use. 
(Code 1982, § 19-1) 
Cross reference— Traffic and vehicles, ch. 25.  
Sec. 19-3. - Persons in parks at night. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be upon the grounds of any public park under the supervision of the director of parks and recreation, except Big Spring Park, during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise unless such person is at the time a participant or spectator of an activity officially scheduled by the parks and recreation department. 
(b)  This section shall be effective as to each such park from and after such time as appropriate signs are erected in such park informing the public of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1982, § 19-2)  
Sec. 19-4. - Bathing in public springs, streams. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to bathe in the Big Spring Branch between its head and Lehmans Ferry Road. It shall also be unlawful for any person to bathe or wash in an indecent manner in any of the streams within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 19-4) 
State Law reference— Indecent exposure, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-6-68; public lewdness, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-12-130.  
Sec. 19-5. - Fishing in Big Spring and Big Spring Lake. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to catch or take or attempt to catch or take fish, minnows or bait from or out of Big Spring from its head through and including Big Spring Park Lake; however, the director of recreation and landscape management, upon application or by his own initiative, may permit the removal of fish or minnows for relocation purposes, upon such terms and conditions as he may impose, taking into consideration the biological results in granting or refusing such permit. 
(Code 1982, § 19-5)  
Sec. 19-6. - Trespassing upon Big Spring Park dam. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon the dam at Big Spring Park or climb upon or in any manner interfere with the chains stretched across the branch below the dam. 
(Code 1982, § 19-6)  
Sec. 19-7. - Trespassing upon public parks and athletic fields which are closed for repair. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to trespass upon any public park or city operated or maintained athletic field when signs have been posted by the city which shall give notice that the park or athletic field has been closed for repair. 
Any such trespass shall constitute a misdemeanor. Upon conviction of a violation under this section, the guilty party shall be subject to a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Ord. No. 05-252, § 1, 4-28-2005)  
Secs. 19-8—19-40. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SWIMMING POOLS 
 
Sec. 19-41. - Supervision and regulation. 
A swimming activities coordinator shall supervise city-owned swimming pools subject to the overall supervision of the director of recreation and landscape management and shall have the power and authority to promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and regulations for the efficient operation, use and management of the aquatic facilities; and when posted in a conspicuous place at city-owned swimming pools such rules and regulations shall be effective. Failure to adhere to such rules and regulations may result in a loss of facility use. 
(Code 1982, § 19-22)  
Sec. 19-42. - Accounting of funds. 
Swimming activities coordinators shall make an accounting daily to the city clerk-treasurer of all moneys received by them belonging to the city, and shall pay over such money daily to the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1982, § 19-23)  
Sec. 19-43. - Fees. 
The following schedule of fees is hereby set and established for all city-owned and -operated swimming pools: 
(1)  Brahan Spring Park Natatorium (located at Brahan Spring Park), James A. Williams Aquatic Center (located on Monroe Street), and Dr. Richard Showers, Sr. Pool (located on Blue Spring Road). 
a.  Nonrestricted public swimming (during nonscheduled hours). 
1.  The sum of $2.00 per person for all ages, in advance, for general admission to swim during public hours. On October 1, 2008, this rate will change to $3.00. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $4.00. 
2.  The sum of $50.00 for tickets issued to swimmers 19 years of age and over for swimming any day during public hours for any three-month period. On October 1, 2008, this rate will change to $60.00. On October 2, 2010, this rate will change to $70.00. 
3.  The sum of $100.00 for tickets issued to families for swimming any day during public hours for any three-month period. On October 1, 2008, this rate will change to $120.00. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $140.00. 
4.  Persons who are eligible to receive food stamps under the federal food stamp program operated pursuant to the provisions of 7 USC 2011 et seq., are eligible for a special rate of $1.00 per person, in advance, for general admission to swim during public hours. Proof of eligibility, together with a valid driver's license or other identification containing a photograph of the applicant, shall be furnished when a special rate under this subsection is claimed. Application for the special rate shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city. The city may designate the manager of recreation services or any other person to determine eligibility for the special rate. The decision of such person designated by the city shall be final. Any person who qualifies for the special rate shall be required to reapply for the special rate on an annual basis. The form for reapplication shall be the same as for initial application. The reapplication period shall be between October 1 and December 1 of each calendar year. 
5.  The sum of $90.00 for a 30-visit, nonrefundable, punch card which is valid for a period of one year from the date of purchase. 
b.  Restricted public swimming (scheduled by pool manager). 
1.  The sum of $75.00 per person in advance per course for all basic swimming and aquatic safety programs, except that those persons who meet the eligibility requirements of paragraph (1)a.4. of this section shall pay the sum of $20.00 per person in advance for such programs. 
2.  The sum of $75.00 per person in advance per course for any advanced Red Cross program (lifeguarding, lifeguard instructor, and water safety instructor). On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $100.00. 
3.  Refunds will be issued according to departmental policy. 
4.  The sum of $10.00 per person per month for all ages participating with a year-round competitive swim group. On October 1, 2008, this rate will change to $15.00. On October 2, 2010, this rate will change to $20.00. 
5.  The sum of $10.00 per person per month for all ages participating with a year-round competitive dive group. On October 2, 2008, this rate will change to $15.00. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $20.00. 
c.  Group rates. 
1.  Nonoperating hours. 
i.  Organized group(s) i.e. scuba, kayaking, etc, wishing to use any facility after normal operating hours shall be a minimum rate of $75.00 per hour, or $3.00 per person per hour, whichever is greater. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $100.00 per hour, or $4.00 per person per hour, whichever is greater. In addition to facility charges these organized groups shall pay any overtime wage accrued by supervisory personnel during the scheduled activity. 
(2)  Swim meets. 
The following schedule of fees is hereby set and established for swim and dive meets to be held at the Brahan Spring Park Natatorium and Dr. Richard Showers, Sr. Pool: 
a.  Swimming pool rental. 
1.  The sum of $300.00 per day during the months of September through April. On October 2, 2010, this rate will change to $400.00. 
2.  The sum of $400.00 per day during the months of May through August. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $500.00. 
b.  Timing system rental and operation. 
1.  The sum of $200.00 per system per day for use of the timing system(s). 
2.  In addition to the usage charge for the timing system(s), the swimming organization shall be charged in order to compensate for any overtime accrued by any city employee(s) while operating the timing system during a swim meet. 
3.  There will be an additional charge of $50.00 for setup on a one-day meet. This fee is waived if the event runs for more than one day. On October 1, 2010, this rate will change to $75.00. 
(3)  Special account. 
The proceeds collected from subsections (2)a. and b. of this section, pertaining to swimming and diving meet fees shall be placed in special numbered account, 01-0000-2268-0000, of the city and shall be used only for the purpose of repairing, replacing or upgrading equipment used by the swimming and diving organizations, or the costs which may result from hosting a championship meet, subject to the approval of the recreation services manager. 
(Ord. No. 96-308, § 1, 5-9-1996; Ord. No. 96-783, §§ 1, 2, 9-26-1996; Ord. No. 08-129, § 1, 2-28-2008; Ord. No. 11-258, §§ 1, 2, 5-12-2011)  
Secs. 19-44—19-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - HUNTSVILLE TENNIS CENTER 
 
Sec. 19-71. - Accounting of funds. 
The tennis activities supervisor shall make an accounting daily to the city clerk-treasurer of all moneys received by him belonging to the city, and shall pay over such money daily to the city clerk-treasurer.  
Sec. 19-72. - Supervision and regulation. 
A tennis activities supervisor shall supervise the Huntsville Tennis Center, subject to the overall supervision of the director of recreation and landscape management and shall have the power and authority to promulgate and enforce reasonable rules and regulations for the efficient operation, use and management of the facility; and when posted in a conspicuous place at the Huntsville Tennis Center, such rules and regulations shall be effective. Failure to adhere to such rules and regulations may result in a loss of facility use.  
Sec. 19-73. - Fees. 
(a)  The following schedules of fees are set and established for the Huntsville Tennis Center (located in Brahan Spring Park) for play when courts are available: 
(1)  The sum of $2.00 per person in advance for two hours; play on hard courts only. (Courts 11—16.) 
(2)  The sum of $2.50 per person in advance for two hours; play on soft courts only. (Courts 1—10.) 
(3)  The sum of $175.00 annually for seasonal tickets issued to a family of three, plus $25.00 for each additional family member. 
(4)  The sum of $60.00 annually for season tickets issued to persons 65 years of age and over. This pass is restricted to Monday through Friday only and shall not be valid on weekends and holidays. 
(5)  The sum of $100.00 annually for season tickets issued to persons under 65 years of age. 
(6)  Persons playing in tennis tournaments at the Huntsville Tennis Center shall be required to pay a fee of $8.00 per tournament. This fee may be paid as part of a tournament entry fee or directly to the tennis center personnel (in addition to the regular tournament entry fee). 
(7)  The superintendent of special facilities shall have the authority, subject to the approval of the director of parks and recreation, to negotiate and set fees for special events that may be held at the Huntsville Tennis Center. 
(b)  All fees must be paid prior to obtaining a court. Seasonal tickets, unless otherwise indicated, shall mean a 12-month period from the time of purchase. 
(Ord. No. 88-635, 12-8-1988)  
Chapter 20 - SECONDHAND GOODS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Businesses, ch. 8. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 20-1—20-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 
 
Sec. 20-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Garage sale means the display and offer for sale of any goods, wares or merchandise, on the premises of any residential lot within the city limits of the city, which goods, wares or merchandise are household furnishings or personal possessions of persons residing in the household upon which they are displayed and offered for sale, under circumstances where many such items are displayed upon the premises at the same time, and persons are invited to come upon the premises to view such items for the purpose of sale. 
(Code 1982, § 18-333) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 20-32. - General restrictions. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hold a garage sale upon any residential premises at which items are not the household furnishings or personal possessions of persons residing in the household upon which they are displayed. The offer for sale by means of a garage sale of property which has been specifically acquired for resale, or the consignment of which has been accepted for display and offered for sale at a garage sale, is specifically prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 18-334)  
Sec. 20-33. - Place, duration. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hold a garage sale except upon premises to which he has the right to possession and of which he is a member of the household. It shall be unlawful to hold a garage sale of longer duration than three consecutive days. 
(Code 1982, § 18-335)  
Sec. 20-34. - Frequency. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to hold any garage sale at any time within 60 days subsequent to the holding of any such previous sale by him or any member of his household upon the same premises. 
(Code 1982, § 18-336)  
Chapter 21 - SEWERS, SEWAGE DISPOSAL AND OTHER WASTEWATER DISPOSAL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; stormwater management, § 12-331 et seq.; utilities, ch. 26; disposal-storage district regulations, app. A, art. 61. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 21-1. - System standards. 
(a)  No sewage collection, treatment and disposal system shall be permitted within the city unless the system shall be: 
(1)  Connected to the public sewer system of the city; or 
(2)  Permitted according to the terms and procedures set forth in this section. 
This section specifically excludes septic tanks installed according to state health department standards and permits. 
(b)  As used in this section, the following words and terms shall have the following meanings: 
Developer means any person, individual, corporation, firm, company or other legal entity. The term "developer" may be used synonymously with the term "person." 
Private package wastewater treatment plant (PWTP) means any system, excluding septic tanks, for collecting, piping, conveying, storing, treating or disposing of sewage where the system is not connected to a public sewer system, together with all appurtenances. The term "PWTP" includes all mains, laterals, disposal and treatment plants and all property used in connection with the system. 
Sewage means the human, animal or vegetable waste from residences, buildings, institutions, food service and industrial establishments, and other facilities. 
Subdivision means the division of a lot, tract or parcel of land into two or more lots, plats, sites or other divisions of land for the purpose, whether immediate or future, of sale or building development. 
(c)  The engineering division is authorized and directed to develop standards and criteria for the design and construction of PWTPs covered under this section, and to promulgate and enforce the standards and criteria as set forth in this section, all as the public health, safety and general welfare shall require. 
(d)  Before the construction or operation of a PWTP for the disposition of sewage, the developer of the PWTP shall obtain a permit from the engineering division as follows: 
(1)  a.  The developer shall submit a preliminary site application to the director and obtain a certificate of preliminary site approval before any further application shall be accepted. 
b.  The preliminary site application must show the wastewater treatment facility in relation to other elements of the PWTP. Sufficient topographical features must also be included to indicate the PWTP's location with relation to streams, existing and proposed wells, and the effluent disposal system. 
c.  The preliminary site approval shall be granted only if: 
1.  No public sewer system of the city is available; 
2.  The design and capacity of the proposed private sewer treatment facility is compatible with any master sewer plan adopted for the proposed site by the appropriate public authority; and 
3.  The developer has been previously granted an NPDES discharge permit by the state department of environmental management. 
(2)  After receipt of a certificate of preliminary site approval, the developer shall submit to the engineering division an application for a package wastewater treatment plant, on the form provided by the engineering division. The engineering division shall review the application, the plans and specifications submitted with the application, and any other pertinent information brought to his attention affecting the proposed PWTP and determine whether the proposed system meets the design and construction criteria for PWTPs adopted and promulgated by the engineering division. 
(3)  If the proposed system meets the design and construction criteria, then prior to construction and final approval by the engineering division, the developer and the city shall enter into a private wastewater treatment plant (PWTP) agreement, which agreement shall contain the following provisions: 
For PWTPs located within the corporate limits of the city or serving property located within the corporate limits of the city. 
a.  The developer will agree to pay for the costs of construction and to construct the PWTP in accordance with the approved plans and the standards and criteria promulgated by the engineering division. 
b.  Upon completion of the construction of the PWTP, the developer shall dedicate and transfer full title and ownership of the PWTP to the city, free and clear of liens, without cost to the city. 
c.  The city shall assume ownership, operation and maintenance of the PWTP only after the final consummation of the transaction set forth in subsection (d)(3)b of this section. 
d.  The city shall assess and collect any sewer fees assessed for users of the PWTP. 
e.  The city shall control all connections to the PWTP after its acquisition by the city provided in this section. 
(e)  As a part of its approval of any PWTP, the engineering division may require the proposed PWTP to be constructed with a capacity in excess of that capacity required to serve the developer's project. In such event, the city and the developer will agree that the city will share with the developer the expense of the construction, maintenance and operation of the PWTP on a pro rata share basis. 
(f)  The engineering division shall cause to be conducted regular and periodic inspections of the proposed PWTP system during its construction. The developer shall construct and install the PWTP according to all plans, specifications and regulations promulgated by the department. 
(g)  Upon completion of construction of the PWTP according to engineering division standards and criteria, the engineering division shall issue a final approval of the PWTP. The PWTP will then be dedicated to the city. 
(h)  The developer shall, at the time of the transfer of ownership of any PWTP to the city, dedicate to the city such easements for egress and ingress as are necessary for the maintenance and operation of the PWTP. 
(Ord. No. 87-354, §§ I—VIII, 8-27-1987)  
Secs. 21-2—21-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SEWERS AND SEWAGE DISPOSAL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Requirements for improvements and design of sanitary sewer facilities in subdivisions, app. B, § 4. 
State Law reference— Exercise of police jurisdiction over sanitary or stormwater sewers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-22; municipal sewers and sewer systems generally, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-50 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 21-31. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, wherever used in this article, shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section unless the context plainly indicates otherwise or that a more restricted or extended meaning is intended: 
Authority means the city. 
AWIC means the Alabama Water Improvement Commission. 
BOD (denoting biochemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at 20 degrees Celsius, expressed in parts per million by weight. BOD shall be determined by Standard Methods. 
Building (house) sewer means the extension from the building drain to the sewer lateral at the property line or other lawful place of disposal. 
COD (denoting chemical oxygen demand) means the quantity of dissolved oxygen required for the chemical oxidation of decomposable matter under aerobic conditions. 
Composite sample means a sample consisting of several effluent portions collected during a 24-hour period in which the portions of sample are taken at even intervals and combined to form a representative sample. 
Consistent removal means the reduction in the amount or alteration of the nature of a pollutant by the POTW to a less toxic or harmless state in the effluent which is achieved by the system in 95 percent of the samples taken when measured according to the procedures set forth in 40 CFR 403.7(c) "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution." 
Constituents means the combination of particles, chemicals or conditions which exist in the industrial wastes. 
Control manhole means an appropriately located manhole from which a given user's effluent can be effectively sampled by the city. 
Cooling water means the water discharged from any use to which the only pollutant added is heat. 
Director means the director of water pollution control or his duly authorized deputy, agency or representative. 
Effluent means the discharge of flow of a treatment facility. 
Flammable means existing fire regulations covering the city. 
Grab sample means a sample taken on a one-time basis which is not a function of flow or time. 
Grease trap means a fixture through which all of the discharge of a connection flows and which provides a minimum detention period of ten minutes between influent and effluent baffles with 20 percent of the total volume as allowance for a sludge pocket. 
Grit chamber means a device to remove sand and gritty material from sewage. 
Illicit discharge means any discharge to the municipal separate storm sewer that is not composed entirely of stormwater, except discharges pursuant to a National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit (other than the NPDES permit for discharges from the municipal separate storm sewer) and discharges resulting from firefighting activities. 
Industrial plant means any plant producing liquid waste, with or without bearing suspended solids, required to be discharged either with or without pretreatment, into the city sanitary sewer system. 
Industrial plant site means a parcel of land occupied by a facility which discharges industrial wastes. Each separate industrial plant connected to a city sewer will be considered and assessed for each connection individually even though an owner may operate one or more industrial plants on the same site. A single- or multi-building industrial plant with more than one connection located on a single site shall not arbitrarily combine waste qualities by computations for the purpose of obtaining a dilution benefits. 
Industrial user or contributor means an industry which discharges wastewaters having the characteristics of industrial wastes, as distinct from commercial wastes or domestic wastes and having a BOD of 250 ppm or greater and/or total suspended solids of 250 ppm or greater or other chemical constituents above or different from normal domestic and/or commercial waste. 
Industrial waste surcharge means the additional service charge assessed against industries in the city service area of which waste characteristics exceed those of normal wastewater. 
Influent means the wastewater arriving at the wastewater treatment plant for treatment and those structures associated with its initial treatment. 
Metered water means the amount of water consumed by the sewer customer as measured by the city water meter. 
Mg/l (milligrams per liter) means ratio by weight, to volume, interchanged with ppm. 
Municipal separate storm sewer means a conveyance or system of conveyances (including roads with drainage systems, municipal streets, catch-basins, curbs, gutters, ditches, manmade channels, or storm drains): 
(1)  Owned by the city having jurisdiction over disposal of sewage, industrial wastes, stormwater or other wastes; 
(2)  Designed or used for collecting or conveying stormwater; 
(3)  Which is not a combined sewer; and 
(4)  Which is not part of a publicly owned treatment works (POTW). 
Natural outlet means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body of surface water or groundwater. 
Normal means those values taken as standards in the measurement of this article; these limits are defined in context. 
Owner means any individual, firm, company, association, society, corporation or group. 
pH means the logarithm of the reciprocal of the weight of hydrogen ions in grams per liter of solution; pH shall be determined by Standard Methods. 
POTW means publicly owned treatment works, i.e., the city's wastewater treatment facilities. 
ppm (parts per million) means ratio by weight. 
Pretreatment means that biological, physical or chemical treatment given to waste or those processes utilized for this purpose before discharge into the sanitary sewer system. 
Public sewer means a sewer in which all owners of abutting properties have certain rights and includes all fixtures and appurtenances connected and used in the wastewater collection system, and is controlled by public authority. 
Receiving waters means those waters into which wastes are discharged. 
Residential or domestic user means premises or a person that discharges wastewaters to the city sewers, which closely match normal wastewater as to their volume and strength, and further, for billing purposes, is defined as a dwelling place or place of residence. 
Sampling means the collection of a sample of two effluent discharges by a given connection to the system. 
Sanitary sewer means a sewer which carries wastewater and to which stormwaters, surface waters and groundwaters are excluded. 
Septic tank waste means that waste which results from the emptying of domestic septic tanks. 
Sewer means a pipe or conduit for carrying wastewater. 
SIC means Standard Industrial Classification, pursuant to the manual issued by the Executive Office of the President, Office of Management and Budget 1972, as amended. 
Significant industrial user means a user who has a discharge flow of 25,000 gallons or more per average workday, or a flow greater than five percent of the POTW, or has in its discharge toxic pollutants, or is found to have a significant impact, either singly or in combination with other industrial users on the POTW system. 
Standard Methods means those procedures or methods established by the latest edition of the "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," 20th edition, as prepared, approved and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association and the Water Environment Federation. 
Standard strength means wastes of any origin having a content of 250 mg/l or less of five-day, 20 degrees Celsius BOD and/or containing 200 mg/l or less of suspended solids, and having no prohibited qualities for sanitary sewer system admission. 
Storm sewer and storm drain mean a sewer which carries stormwaters and surface waters and drainage, but excludes wastewater and polluted industrial wastes. 
Stormwater means stormwater runoff, snow melt runoff, and surface runoff and drainage. 
Suspended solids means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, wastewater or liquid and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
Total solids means total weight ppm of all solids, dissolved, undissolved, organic or inorganic. 
Toxic means constituents of wastes which adversely affect the organism involved in wastewater treatment or aquatic life in receiving statements. 
Wastewater and wastes mean a combination of the water-carried wastes from residences, business buildings, institutions and industrial establishments; treatable wastes. 
Wastewater treatment plant means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating wastewater. 
Watercourse means a channel in which an open flow of water occurs either continuously or intermittently. 
(Code 1982, § 20-101; Ord. No. 82-192, 6-15-1981; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987; Ord. No. 93-270, § 1, 5-13-1993; Ord. No. 00-129, § 1, 3-9-2000) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 21-32. - Application of article. 
The rules and regulations incorporated in this article shall govern the installation, alteration and maintenance of all storm and sanitary drainage within the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-102)  
Sec. 21-33. - Compliance with article. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to do or cause to be done any of the acts prohibited by this article or to fail, refuse or neglect to do any of the acts required to be done or performed by this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-104)  
Sec. 21-34. - Sewer mains under exclusive control of city. 
(a)  All sewer mains established in or under the streets, avenues, easements or public ways of the city are now declared to be under the exclusive control of the city, to be maintained and kept in repair by the city, without interference by any person. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to undertake to exercise control over such sewer mains, or to aid in or grant the right to make connections without obtaining a permit from the city. 
(c)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the service lines established and connected with such sewer mains. Such service (building sewer) lines are to be maintained and kept in repair by the person owning or controlling the property serviced by such service lines except that repair and maintenance of service lines used in connection with individual sewer systems requiring grinder pumps shall be made by employees or agents of the city or other qualified factory trained servicemen with the cost for all labor and materials to be paid by the property owner. 
(Code 1982, § 20-105; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987)  
Sec. 21-35. - Right of entry of inspectors. 
(a)  The director and other duly authorized employees of the city are authorized to receive and investigate complaints of violations of this article, including but not limited to investigation of possible illicit discharges to the municipal separate storm sewer system and possible violations of the city's National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (NPDES) permit. 
(b)  The director and other duly authorized employees of the city bearing proper credentials and identification shall be permitted to enter all properties for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing in connection with enforcement of the provisions of this article. The director or such duly authorized representative shall have no authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil, refining, ceramic, paper or other industries, beyond that point having direct bearing on the kind and source of discharge to the sewers, facilities for waste treatment, or the municipal separate storm sewer system. 
(c)  While performing the necessary work on private properties referred to in subsection (b) of this section, the director or duly authorized employees of the city shall observe all safety rules applicable to the premises established by the company. The company shall be held harmless for injury or death to the city's employees caused by the negligence of the city's employees; and the city shall indemnify the company against loss or damage to its property by the city's employees and against liability claims and demands for personal injury or property damage asserted against the company and growing out of the negligence of any city employee in the measurement, sampling and testing operation, except as such may be caused by the negligence of the company or its officers, agents or employees or failure of the company to maintain safe conditions. 
(Code 1982, § 20-106; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987; Ord. No. 93-270, § 2, 5-13-1993)  
Sec. 21-36. - Indemnification. 
In any and all instances where the city has reasonable cause to believe that any of the rules, regulations or provisions set forth in this article or that have otherwise been adopted by the city have been, may be or are being violated by any person discharging waste into the sanitary sewer system, the city may require such person to give bond or enter into an indemnity agreement in a form acceptable to the city with sufficient surety to be approved by the approving authority to protect, indemnify and hold harmless the city from any loss, damage or expense that may suffer or incur as a result of such noncompliance or violation by such person; and, in the event of the failure to do so after ten days' notice by registered U.S. mail that the bond will be required, the use of the sanitary sewer system by such person shall be denied or discontinued. 
(Code 1982, § 20-107)  
Sec. 21-37. - Special agreements. 
No statement contained in this article shall be construed as preventing any special agreement or arrangement between the city and any industrial concern by the city for treatment, subject to payment, by the industrial concern. 
(Code 1982, § 20-108)  
Sec. 21-38. - Appeals procedure. 
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the director or by any determination of the sewer rules and regulations shall have the right to appeal to the council or to a committee which may be established by the council for the purpose of hearing such appeals. The appellant must file with the city clerk-treasurer a request in writing for such a hearing and also cite the sections of the rules and regulations that he is aggrieved by. Upon receipt of such request, it shall be the duty of the city clerk-treasurer to present the request to the council at the next regular scheduled meeting. The council may elect to hear the appeal or may refer the request to a committee the council will establish. The appellant will be given the time, date and place of the hearing and may present the objection in his behalf at the hearing. 
(Code 1982, § 20-109)  
Sec. 21-39. - Discontinuance of connections discharging injurious substances into sewers. 
The director shall have power to prevent or discontinue any connection with the public sewer which discharges any substance liable to injure the sewers or obstruct the flow of the sewerage. 
(Code 1982, § 20-110)  
Sec. 21-40. - New sewer lines. 
(a)  No person shall construct or lay sewer lines in any subdivision of the city, or in any easements or public rights-of-way of the city, where public sewers are not existing or located, without first presenting plans and specifications for the laying of such sewers to the city council or its duly designated agent and obtaining the consent for the laying of such sewer lines. A copy of such plans and specifications shall be left on file with the engineering division. 
(b)  The engineering division is designated the lawful agent of the city to receive and approve such plans and specifications. 
(c)  Physical location for grinder pumps shall be forward of the rear wall of the main building but shall in no case be obstructed by shrubbery, fences or any other object which would prevent clear access or visibility from the public street. 
(d)  The installation and use of individual sewer systems requiring grinder pumps shall be permitted provided that all provisions set forth in this article are complied with. 
(e)  The developer or person in control of any subdivision of the city who is permitted to install any sewer system utilizing grinder pumps shall be required to provide at no cost to the city, and before the actual installation begins, an inventory of replacement parts in an amount equal to ten percent of the total number of grinder pump units to be installed and shall consist of the following: complete simplex grinder pumps, pump O-rings, pump seals, pump gaskets, grinder pump impellers, pump shredding rings, complete float assemblies, float brackets, complete junction boxes, complete simplex control panels, control panel circuit breakers, control panel overloads, control panel run caps, control panel start relay, control panel start caps, control panel contractors, control panel run lights, and any other parts as recommended by the equipment manufacturer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-111; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987)  
Sec. 21-41. - Shows and carnivals to be provided with approved toilets, sanitary and water connections. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to conduct and operate a show or carnival on any lands upon which there is located no good and sufficient toilets, sanitary and water connections, the sufficiency of which is to be approved by the health officer. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning or controlling lands within the city to rent, lease or permit the occupancy of such lands by any person for the purpose of conducting a show or carnival unless such lands are provided with a toilet, sanitary and water connections which have been or are approved by the health officer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-112)  
Sec. 21-42. - Design and acceptance manual for sanitary sewers. 
The Design and Acceptance Manual for Sanitary Sewers, 2005 Edition, city engineering department, is adopted. 
(Ord. No. 00-862, § 1, 11-9-00; Ord. No. 05-1016, § 1, 12-15-05)  
Sec. 21-43. - Design and acceptance manual for wastewater pump stations. 
The Design and Acceptance manual for wastewater pump stations, dated October 2000, city engineering department, is adopted. 
(Ord. No. 00-864, § 1, 11-9-2000)  
Secs. 21-44—21-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 21-61. - Criminal enforcement. 
(a)  Any person who shall violate any provision of this article or fails to comply with any of its requirements or who shall fail to comply with any order made under the provision of this article shall, upon conviction, be punished as provided in section 1-7. Each person shall be deemed guilty of a separate offense for each and every day or portion during which any violation of any of the provisions of this article is committed or continued. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to falsely tamper with or knowingly render inaccurate any monitoring device or method required to be maintained under this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-121; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981) 
State Law reference— False statements, Code of Ala. 1975, § 13A-10-109.  
Sec. 21-62. - Termination of service. 
The city may terminate water and wastewater disposal service and disconnect an industrial customer from the system when: 
(1)  A government agency informs the city that the effluent from the wastewater treatment plant is no longer of quality permitted for discharge to a watercourse, and it is found that the customer is delivering wastewater to the city's system that cannot be sufficiently treated or requires treatment that is not provided by the city as normal domestic treatment. 
(2)  The industrial customer: 
a.  Discharges industrial waste or wastewater that is in violation of the permit issued by the city. 
b.  Discharges waters or wastes having a deleterious effect upon the city's sewer system. 
c.  Discharges wastewater at an uncontrolled, variable rate in sufficient quantity to cause an imbalance in the wastewater treatment system. 
d.  Fails to pay monthly bills for water and sanitary sewer services when due. 
e.  Repeats a discharge of prohibited wastes to a public sewer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-122)  
Sec. 21-63. - Disconnection. 
If service is disconnected pursuant to this division, the city shall: 
(1)  Disconnect the customer. 
(2)  Supply the customer with the governmental agency's report and provide the customer with all pertinent information. 
(3)  Continue disconnection until such time as the industrial customer provides additional pretreatment or other facilities designed to remove the objectionable characteristics from its industrial wastes. 
(Code 1982, § 20-123)  
Sec. 21-64. - Other legal sanctions. 
In addition to sanctions provided for by this article, the city is entitled to exercise sanctions provided for by the other ordinances of the city for failure to pay the bill for water and sanitary sewer service when due. 
(Code 1982, § 20-125)  
Secs. 21-65—21-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - USE OF PUBLIC SEWERS 
 
Sec. 21-91. - Requirement of sewer use. 
(a)  The owner of all houses, buildings or properties used for human occupancy, employment, recreation or other purposes, situated within the service area located or may in the future be located, a public sanitary sewer of the city, is hereby required at his expense to install suitable toilet facilities therein, and to connect such facilities directly with the proper public sewer in accordance with the provisions of this article within 360 days after the date of official notice to do so, provided that said public sewer is within 300 feet of the property line. 
(b)  The disposal of wastewater by means other than the use of the available sanitary wastewater system shall be in accordance with local county and state law. The disposal of wastewater by private disposal systems shall be as specified in sections 21-241—21-244. 
(Code 1982, § 20-136; Ord. No. 02-333, 4-25-2002) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to require premises to be connected to sewer system, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-50-53, 11-50-54; regulation of septic tanks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-55.  
Sec. 21-92. - Sewer connections. 
No permit shall be issued where a connection to the sanitary sewer is required unless the building contractor or plumber involved has located by actual excavation the sewer which will serve his building, and has so planned the flow elevation and building sewer elevation to provide a proper slope in the sewer connection to the sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1982, § 7-145)  
Sec. 21-93. - When connections made by city. 
If any owner shall fail to have a sewer connection made as provided by section 21-91(a), without sufficient legal excuse for such failure, the engineering division shall cause such sewer connection to be made or the property ditched or drained or water closets put in and connected with the city sewer system, as the case may be, at the cost and expense of the property owner. The engineering division shall report to the city council the costs and expenses of such work and materials, or either, which report shall be entered upon the minutes of the city council; and such costs shall constitute and be a lien on such property prior to all other liens, except for taxes, which lien may be enforced by sale of the property, in all respects as in cases of assessments for street improvements and also in the courts of the state in equity. 
(Code 1982, § 20-137) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-54; authority of city to require property owners to ditch and drain premises, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-53.  
Sec. 21-94. - Statement of cost of work done by city to be filed with county probate judge. 
Whenever any water closet is installed or connections made by the city under the provisions of this division, the mayor shall prepare a statement in writing setting forth the name of the owner and a description of the property on which such improvements have been made together with the costs of such sanitary connections and installing of closets, or either, which must be signed by the mayor in his official capacity and filed with the probate judge of the county for record in the mortgage records of the county. The filing of such statement shall operate as notice of the existence of such lien from the date of its filing. 
(Code 1982, § 20-138)  
Sec. 21-95. - Service of notice required by section 21-91. 
The notice required by section 21-91, where the property owner is a resident of the city, shall be given either by personal delivery to him or by mail addressed to him with postage fully prepaid. Where such property owner is a nonresident of the city, such notice may be given to his agent, if any, in the city who has charge of such property or its rental. If the owner has no resident agent, such notice must be given by advertisement once a week for three successive weeks in some newspaper published in the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-139) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-56.  
Sec. 21-96. - Discharge to municipal separate storm sewer system or natural outlet. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to place, discharge or cause to be placed or discharged any illicit discharge into the municipal separate storm sewer system or any natural outlet. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to discharge any sanitary sewage or wastewater into the municipal separate storm sewer system or any natural outlet. 
(Code 1982, § 20-140; Ord. No. 93-270, § 3, 5-13-1993)  
Sec. 21-97. - Unsanitary methods of discharge. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place, or permit to be deposited in any unsanitary manner on public or private property within the service area, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any human or animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. 
(Code 1982, § 20-141)  
Sec. 21-98. - Septic tanks. 
Septic tanks will be prohibited except as provided in this article and the Standard Plumbing Code (chapter 7, article IV, division 6) as adopted and amended by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-142)  
Sec. 21-99. - Reporting of illicit discharge. 
(a)  Any person who places, discharges or causes to be placed or discharged any illicit discharge into the municipal separate storm sewer system or any lake, stream or other body of water located within the corporate limits shall report all information relevant to the discharge, including but not limited to the date, location, nature and volume or quantity discharged, if known, to the division of natural resources and environmental management within 24 hours of such discharge. 
(b)  Failure to report an illicit discharge as provided in this section shall constitute a misdemeanor. Each day any violation of this section shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 93-270, § 3, 5-13-1993)  
Secs. 21-100—21-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BUILDING SEWERS AND CONNECTIONS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 7. 
 
Sec. 21-121. - Duties of owner generally. 
(a)  All costs and expenses incident to the installation and connection of the building sewer shall be borne by the owner. The owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may directly or indirectly be occasioned by the installation, maintenance or mechanical failure of the building sewer. 
(b)  All industries, commercial organizations or other producers of liquid waste of any form, including domestic waste, as at apartments, hotels, motels, hospitals, universities, schools or homes served by the city sewer system, must obtain a permit from the director prior to making a connection to the city sanitary sewer system. 
(c)  Service charge for repair and maintenance of grinder pumps during normal working hours shall be $15.00 per hour for technician and $7.50 per hour for laborer/helper. Service charge for after-hours call-out shall be computed on the greater of: 
(1)  Four times the hourly rate of this subsection; or 
(2)  Actual number of hours worked times the overtime rate (time and one-half). 
Property owner shall be responsible for invoice cost (replacement parts, including freight, factory service, etc.) plus ten percent, and billing shall be in accordance with section 21-276. Rates will be reviewed on an annual basis and changed as necessary by the engineering division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-151; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987)  
Sec. 21-122. - Fee when connection was at no cost to the owner. 
In all cases where the sewer main to which the connection is to be made has been installed at no cost to the property involved, the applicant shall, before obtaining a permit from the inspection division, pay to the city clerk-treasurer the sum of $1,000.00. This provision shall not apply to a connection made to serve approved subdivisions where the sewer mains in the subdivision have been installed at the expense of the property served in the subdivision and a connection made to a developed lot served, at the time of the connection, by a septic tank system of wastewater removal. 
(Code 1982, § 20-152; Ord. No. 94-809, § 1, 12-20-1994)  
Sec. 21-123. - Connections outside city. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect with or maintain a connection with the city sewer system any premises located outside the corporate limits of the city; however, this section shall not prevent any person from maintaining any connection heretofore made with such system, or from connecting and maintaining any premises to such system in accordance with approval of the city council heretofore rendered; and the owners of any tract in close proximity to the existing corporate boundaries who are not legally entitled to become annexed to the city because of lack of contiguity may, with the approval of the council, be specifically authorized to connect specifically described premises to the city sewer system under the following conditions: 
(1)  The applicant must file an application with the council describing the premises to be served and listing the proposed use of the facilities and the type and volume of effluent to be discharged. 
(2)  The applicant must agree to pay all connection and service fees. 
(3)  The applicant must irrevocably agree to annexation into the city limits at the discretion of the city council at such time as contiguity with the present city boundary and compliance with applicable law can be met. 
(4)  The applicant must agree, prior to annexation, to make an annual payment in lieu of city ad valorem taxes, such payment to be based upon the city tax rate applied against the value as assessed for state and county ad valorem taxes, the first such payment to be due for the tax year beginning next after such connection is actually made and terminating with the tax year ending prior to the year such property is annexed, or if such property is disconnected from the system, terminating with the year ending prior to the year of termination. 
(5)  The applicant must file such agreement in the office of the judge of probate of the county. Such agreement must, by its terms, bind the successors in interest to the property. 
(Code 1982, § 20-153(b); Ord. No. 94-297, 5-12-1994; Ord. No. 95-511, 8-10-1995) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to make sewer improvements outside corporate limits, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-48-80 et seq.  
Sec. 21-124. - Prohibited connections. 
No person shall make connection of roof downspouts, exterior foundation drains, areaway drains or other sources of surface runoff or groundwater to a building sewer or building drain which in turn is connected directly or indirectly to a public sanitary sewer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-154)  
Sec. 21-125. - Method of connection. 
The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall all conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing code or other applicable rules and regulations of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-155)  
Sec. 21-126. - Elevation of connection. 
Whenever possible, the building sewer shall be brought to the building at an elevation below the basement floor. In all buildings in which any building drain is too low to permit gravity flow to be the public sewer, sanitary wastewater carried by such building drain shall be lifted by an approved means and discharged to the building sewer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-156)  
Sec. 21-127. - Engineering standards. 
The connection of the building sewer into the public sewer shall conform to the requirements of the building and plumbing codes or other applicable rules and regulations of the city, or the procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the ASTM (American Society for Testing Materials) and the WPCF (Water Pollution Control Federation) Manual of Practice No. 9. All such connections shall be made gastight and watertight. Any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials must be approved by the director before installation. 
(Code 1982, § 20-157)  
Sec. 21-128. - Separate connections. 
Every building in which plumbing fixtures are installed shall have a connection to a public or private sewer, except where a public sewer is not available, an individual sewage disposal system shall be of a type that is acceptable and approved by the director or other governing authority having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 20-158)  
Sec. 21-129. - Public hazard. 
All excavations for building sewer installation shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-159)  
Sec. 21-130. - Grease and solid removal. 
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be provided when, in the opinion of the director, they are necessary for the proper handling of liquid wastes containing grease in excessive amounts or any flammable wastes, sand or other harmful ingredients; except that such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwelling units. All interceptors shall be of a type and capacity approved by the engineering division and shall be located as to be readily and easily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Code 1982, § 20-160)  
Sec. 21-131. - Preliminary treatment devices.
