Where preliminary treatment of flow-equalizing facilities is provided for any waters or wastes, it shall be maintained continuously in satisfactory and effective operation by the owner at his expense. 
(Code 1982, § 20-161)  
Sec. 21-132. - Control manhole. 
The owner of any property serviced by a building sewer carrying industrial wastes shall install a suitable control manhole together with such necessary meters and other appurtenances in the building sewer to facilitate observation, sampling and measurement of the wastes. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessibly and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the director. The manhole shall be installed by the owner at his expense and shall be maintained by him so as to be safe and accessible at all times. The manhole must be located on the industrial waste service connection with all sanitary wastes excluded. 
(Code 1982, § 20-162)  
Sec. 21-133. - Cross connections. 
Any cross connection between potable water supply and sanitary sewer shall be prohibited, except as specified by the Standard Plumbing Code (chapter 7, article IV, division 6) as adopted and amended by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-163)  
Secs. 21-134—21-150. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 21-151. - Connection to sewer mains generally. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to connect with or maintain a connection with any sewer main within the corporate limits of the city without first having secured a permit for such connection from the engineering division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-171)  
Sec. 21-152. - Industrial permits. 
(a)  Any person owning or operating an industrial plant producing a liquid industrial waste of any quantity or strength or other qualities requiring special consideration, as relevant conditions are defined in this division, or who desires to make connection for the industrial waste-producing facilities of any such establishment, to the sanitary sewer system of the city, shall make application on the supplied forms to the engineering division for a permit authorizing such connection. A sample of the required form is attached. (See subsection (c) of this section.) 
(b)  The engineering division shall not issue a plumbing permit for any industrial plant until the applicant presents a completed and approved industrial sewer connection application. 
(c)  Application for a permit under this section shall be in essentially the following form: 
APPLICATION FOR PERMIT 
TO 
DISCHARGE INDUSTRIAL WASTE 
TO: 	Engineering Division 
City of Huntsville 
Post Office Box 308 
Huntsville, Alabama 25804 	DATE:

ADDRESS: _____ 
_____

The applicant further agrees to report to the engineering division immediately in writing any change in the process which causes any measurable change in composition of waste discharge and any change in volumetric discharge of more than ten percent in GPD. 
It is understood that the permit, if issued, will authorize only the discharge of waste listed in this application, and none other, and that a new application will be made and permit requested if the composition of waste discharge and/or volume, or both, listed in this application are exceeded.

If the total water supply for the firm is furnished by the City of Huntsville, water used for purposes other than for treatment of industrial waste will not be reported under the industrial waste discharge. If the source of water supply for processing industrial waste is obtained from a source other than from the city water department, this volumetric discharge will be considered as a supplement to water furnished by the city, will be metered, and will be reported in industrial waste discharge. 
(Code 1982, § 20-172)  
Sec. 21-153. - Permit where no pretreatment required. 
For those applicants for which no pretreatment is required for the waste to be discharged into the city sewer from the premises desiring service, if the engineering division determines that the capacity of the available existing city mains and treatment plant facilities are sufficient to accommodate the applicant's waste, upon the applicant's providing a proper connection from his plant or premises to the city sewer, the engineering division will issue the applicant a permit to discharge waste connection and permit the applicant to discharge waste from such premises into the city sewer at the rate and in the quantities stated. Upon receipt of such permit, the applicant will thereafter be charged by the city at the rates established by ordinance for the taking and disposing of such waste. 
(Code 1982, § 20-173)  
Sec. 21-154. - Chemical analysis required. 
Any person now discharging or desiring to discharge industrial waste into the sanitary sewer system shall submit with his application to the approving authority a complete chemical analysis of the waste being discharged or proposed to be discharged, including concentrations of BOD and suspended solids contained in such discharges. Such person shall also submit pertinent flow data, including rates and duration, and description of his operation. Should the waste from such person's operations be deemed to be inadmissible into the sanitary sewer system because of objectionable character as defined by this division, because of concentrations of elements or substances in excess of the limits established by the approving authority, or because of flow characteristics incompatible with the best use of the receiving sewer, the approving authority will not approve the discharge of such waste into the sanitary sewer system until such person has employed, at his own expense, methods and processes for pretreatment as will render the waste admissible to the sanitary sewer system in accordance with this division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-174; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-155. - Approval of discharge. 
The approving authority will not specify, suggest or recommend equipment, structures or arrangements comprising the pretreatment processes. Approval of discharge of industrial waste by any person will be given only on the basis of performance of pretreatment processes, if pretreatment should be required. Approval given to any person for discharge of industrial waste, whether pretreated or not, into the sanitary sewer system shall in no way relieve such person of the responsibility for full compliance with this division at all times. 
(Code 1982, § 20-175; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-156. - Acid or alkaline range. 
No wastewater which for any sustained period shows an acid or alkaline reaction outside of the recommended pH range (i.e., less than six or more than nine) shall be placed in the sanitary sewer system. Wastewater outside of these limits may be chemically adjusted, and the process used shall be at the option of the producer. It shall also be the responsibility of the producer to design, operate and maintain the pretreatment plant and demonstrate its effective use to the satisfaction of the engineering division. The continuous operation and maintenance of the plant with consistent results will be the responsibility of the producer, even though the pretreatment plans have been approved by the director. Dilution, in no way, will be accepted as a form of pretreatment except and only then when duly authorized by the engineering division, AWIC and/or the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). 
(Code 1982, § 20-176; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-157. - Connection charge determination. 
After issuance of the required permit under this division, the industrial waste disposal connection charge will be made as provided for completion connection charge and billing with water service. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-158. - Effect of approvals. 
Any approval by the engineering division of a type, kind or capacity of an installation shall not relieve a person of the responsibility of revamping, enlarging or otherwise modifying such installation to accomplish an intended purpose; nor shall any fixed or oral agreement as to limits of constituents or volumes of waters or wastes be considered as final approval for continuing operation. These limits will be subject to constant study and change as considered necessary to serve their intended purpose. 
(Code 1982, § 20-177)  
Sec. 21-159. - Property rights. 
The issuance of a permit by the engineering division does not convey any property rights in either real or personal property, or any exclusive privileges, nor does it authorize any injury to private property or any invasion of personal rights, nor any infringement of federal, state or local laws or regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 20-178)  
Sec. 21-160. - Ownership changes. 
If a property or plant authorized to make a connection to the city sewer for industrial waste disposal under the provisions of this article is sold, leased or its operation is assumed or taken over by a person other than that named in the permit, a new application or permit will be made by the new owner, lessee or operator. No permit issued under the provisions of this division shall be assignable to any other persons to exercise the privileges and receive the benefits of such permit, and a violation of the provisions of this article shall be grounds for summary cancellation of such permit by the director. 
(Code 1982, § 20-179)  
Sec. 21-161. - Due date; amount of fees. 
(a)  Industrial waste permits shall be due on January 1 in three-year intervals and shall be delinquent on the following February 1. 
(b)  Applicants shall pay a fee of $15.00 for the first permit issued and a renewal fee of $15.00. If the permit fee becomes delinquent, there shall be added a penalty of $15.00. If a permit is canceled for cause under the provisions of this division by the engineering division, a fee of $45.00 shall be payable for a subsequent initial permit issued to such applicant on completion by the applicant of forms provided and their approval. 
(Code 1982, § 20-180; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-162. - Permit cancellation. 
The engineering division is authorized to cancel any permit issued under the provisions of this division and terminate such service at any time that an applicant violates any of the provisions of this article or other ordinances of the city pertaining to wastewater disposal into city sewers by such plant; or should the applicant fail or refuse to pay, when due, charges made by the city for such sewer service; or should the applicant discharge waste at a rate, or in a quantity or strength or other quality in excess of that provided for by the permit or of a quality violating the permit or prohibited by this article or other related city ordinance. Such cancellation shall be subject to review as provided for. 
(Code 1982, § 20-181)  
Sec. 21-163. - Conflicts with state and federal laws. 
(a)  Where conflicts exist between city and state or federal regulations, the more stringent requirement shall apply. In all cases where limits have not been specifically determined in this article, the more stringent of state or federal regulations shall apply. 
(b)  Within nine months of the promulgation of a National Categorical Pretreatment Standard, the industrial waste permit of users subject to such standards shall be revised to require compliance with such standard within the timeframe prescribed by the standard, except when the state and/or city pretreatment standards are more stringent than the National Categorical Pretreatment Standard. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 9, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-164. - Monthly reports. 
Any user subject to pretreatment standards and requirements shall submit to the engineering division a monthly report indicating the nature and concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated wastestream and the average daily flow rate of the discharge. This monthly self-monitoring report shall be signed by an authorized representative of the industrial user. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 10, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-165. - Confidential information. 
Information and data on a user obtained from reports, questionnaires, permit applications and monitoring shall be available to the public or governmental agency without restriction unless the user requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the engineering division that the release would divulge processes or methods entitled to protection as trade secrets of the user. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 11, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-166. - Treatment credits. 
Where the POTW achieves consistent removal of pollutants limited by federal pretreatment standards, the city or an industrial user may apply to the AWIC for modification of specific limits in the standards. After sufficient analytical proof of consistent removal is obtained (the cost of which can, at the option of the city, be borne by the industrial user), the city may then modify that pollutant discharge limits if the requirements contained in 40 CFR 403.7 are fulfilled and with prior AWIC approval obtained. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 12, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-167. - FDF variances. 
FDF (fundamentally different factors) variances, referred to in section 307(b) of the Clean Water Act of 1977, are allowances in which an industrial user can present information and data to the EPA and the AWIC which verify that the user's particular process is different, fundamentally, from others in his pretreatment category and thus different from those factors which were used to develop the categorical pretreatment standards for that group. These are case-by-case adjustments which can make the standards more or less stringent and approval for such requests is reserved for the EPA. The written submission, however, is handled by the AWIC and should have certain content and be in acceptable form. This information as well as essential qualifications for approval and other aspects of the FDF variance are available from the AWIC upon request. The city reserves the right to comment on FDF variance applications submitted by its industrial users. 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 13, 6-25-1981)  
Secs. 21-168—21-190. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - INDUSTRIAL SURCHARGES 
 
Sec. 21-191. - Definition; amount of charges. 
Industrial waste is considered any effluent with pollutant loadings in excess of the following maxima during a 24-hour average for a billing period. Industrial surcharges shall apply as follows: 
(1)  BOD 5 —In excess of 250 ppm, $0.17 per pound. 
(2)  SS—In excess of 250 ppm, $0.12 per pound. 
(Code 1982, § 20-191; Ord. No. 00-129, § 2, 3-9-2000)  
Sec. 21-192. - Computation of pounds. 
(a)  Pounds shall be computed by 8.34 (the weight of one gallon of water), times the volume of the wastewater in million gallons, times the parts per million in excess of normal strength. (P = 8.34 × MGD × PPM) 
(b)  Alternatively, pounds shall be computed by 0.00624 pound, the conversion factor to determine the weight in pounds of one mg/l for a volume in hundreds of cubic feet, times the volume of wastewater in hundreds of cubic feet, times the parts per million in excess of normal strength. 
(Code 1982, § 20-192)  
Sec. 21-193. - High concentrations of pollutants. 
At the discretion of the director, on a case-by-case basis, high concentrations of specific pollutants will warrant a surcharge based upon the higher cost of treatment of the discharge. 
(Code 1982, § 20-193)  
Secs. 21-194—21-210. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - PROHIBITED DISCHARGES 
 
Sec. 21-211. - Generally. 
(a)  No person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any stormwater, surface water, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage, uncontaminated cooling water, or unpolluted industrial process waters to any sanitary sewer. 
(b)  In no case shall a slug load have a flow rate concentration or qualities of pollutants that exceed for any time period longer than 15 minutes or more than five times the average 24-hour concentration, quantities or flow during normal operation that will interfere with the operation of the POTW. 
(Code 1982, § 20-201; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-212. - Substances prohibited in public sewers. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall discharge or cause to be discharged any of the following waters or wastes into any public sewers: 
(1)  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature higher than 150 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(2)  a.  Any water or waste which may contain more than 100 ppm, by weight, of fats, oil or grease, or any water or waste containing oil, grease, or other substance that will solidify or become viscous at temperatures between 32 and 90 degrees Fahrenheit. 
b.  As set forth in sections 21-154—21-156, minimal pretreatment of wastes containing concentrations of grease (i.e., animal and vegetable fats and oils) in excess of 75 ppm is required. 
c.  Such minimal pretreatment requires passage through a grease trap meeting the city's engineering standards and providing a minimum retention time of ten minutes between influent and effluent battles with 20 percent of the total volume as allowance for a sludge pocket. This sludge pocket should be kept reasonably free of inorganic solids, and all grease and other floating materials shall be skimmed from the tank at sufficiently frequent intervals to avoid reduction of efficiency of the trap. 
d.  Upon written notification by the director that a grease trap is required for a given discharge, the user will have a period of 90 days for compliance. Such compliance consists of the complete installation and operability of a grease trap approved by the director. Failure to comply will result in the implementation of the enforcement procedures of division 2 of this article. Grease traps shall be available for inspection by the director or his staff at all reasonable times. 
(3)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, mineral spirits, commercial solvent, motor oil or other flammable or explosive liquid, or any other petroleum derivative. 
(4)  Any waters or wastes that contain more than ten ppm by weight of hydrogen sulfide, sulfur dioxide or nitrous oxide. 
(5)  Any ashes, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, offal, plastics, wood, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, lime residues, beer or distillery slops, chemical residues, fiberglass, paint or ink residues, cannery waste, bulk solids or any other solid or viscous substance capable of causing obstruction to the flow in sewers, or other interference with the proper operation of the wastewater works without proper pretreatment and written approval of the director. 
(6)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than six or higher than nine at any time, or having any other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment or personnel of the wastewater works, or the treatment process. 
(7)  a.  Any waters or wastes containing toxic or poisonous substances in such concentration as to constitute a hazard to humans or animals, or to interfere with any wastewater treatment process, or to create any hazard in the receiving waters of the wastewater treatment plant without proper pretreatment and written approval of the director. 
b.  These limits may be used as a guide in design and plant control, but may be altered by the director as required or authorized by state or federal law in the event of a cumulative overload on a particular drainage basin or wastewater treatment plant. 
(8)  Any waters containing suspended solids of such character and quantity that unusual provision, attention or expense is required to handle such materials at the wastewater treatment plant. 
(9)  Any noxious or malodorous gas or substance, capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or preventing entry into sewers for their maintenance, inspection and repair. 
(10)  Any waters containing quantities of radium, naturally occurring, or artificially produced radioisotopes in excess of presently existing or subsequently accepted limits for drinking water as established by the National Committee on Radiation Protection and Measuring. 
(11)  Any concentrated dye wastes, spent tanning solutions or other wastes which are highly colored, or wastes which are of unusual volume, concentration of solids or composition that may create obstruction to the flow in sewers or other interference with the proper operation and treatment of influent of the wastewater works without proper pretreatment and written approval of the director. 
(12)  Any waters or wastes containing substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment processes employed, or are amenable to treatment to only such degree that the wastewater treatment plant effluent cannot meet the requirements of other agencies having jurisdiction over discharge to the receiving waters. 
(13)  Any water or waste containing more than 2,000 ppm total solids. 
(14)  Any wastes at a flow rate and/or pollutant discharge rate which is excessive over a short period of time so that there is a treatment process overload and subsequent loss of treatment efficiency. 
(15)  Any wastewater containing phenols or other taste-producing substances in such concentrations as to produce odor in the effluent as to affect the taste or odor of the receiving water. Quantities of such substances will be determined by the director on a case-by-case basis. 
(b)  No person may discharge into grinder pumps or operate grinder pumps in any manner which is not recommended by the equipment manufacturer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-202; Ord. No. 87-167, § 1, 5-14-1987)  
Sec. 21-213. - Concentrations. 
Fixed upper limits for constituents (ppm, by weight) are as follows:

Sec. 21-214. - Dilution. 
The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes in volumes, or with constituents, such that existing dilution conditions in the sewers or at the treatment plant would be affected to the detriment of the city, shall be subject to review and approval of the director. Where necessary, in the opinion of the director, pretreatment or equalizing units may be required to bring constituents or volume of flow within the limits previously prescribed or to an otherwise acceptable level, and to hold or equalize flows such that no peak flow conditions may hamper the operation of any unit of the sewer system. This equalization or holding unit shall have a capacity suitable to serve its intended purpose, and be equipped with acceptable outlet control facilities to provide flexibility in operation and accommodate changing conditions in the waste flow. 
(Code 1982, § 20-204)  
Sec. 21-215. - Suspended solids. 
The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having a suspended solids content in excess of 500 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis or having a suspended solids content for any grab sample greater than five times the average influent value recorded at the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year, will be subject to review by the director. Where necessary, in the opinion of the director, pretreatment may be required as stated in this division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-205)  
Sec. 21-216. - Chemical oxygen demand (COD). 
The admission into the public sewers of any water or waste having a chemical oxygen demand (COD) in excess of 850 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis or for any grab sample having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand in excess of five times the average influent value for the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year, will be subject to review by the director. Where necessary, in the opinion of the director, pretreatment may be required as stated in this division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-206)  
Sec. 21-217. - Biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) limit. 
The admission into the public sewers of any waters or wastes having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand in excess of 500 ppm, by weight, on a 24-hour composite basis, or for any grab sample having a five-day biochemical oxygen demand in excess of five times the average influent value for the affected wastewater treatment plant during the previous calendar year, will be subject to review by the director. Where necessary, in the opinion of the director, the owner shall provide and operate, at his own expense, such pretreatment as may be required to reduce the biochemical oxygen demand to meet these requirements. 
(Code 1982, § 20-207)  
Sec. 21-218. - Action by director. 
If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the public sewers, which waters or wastes contain the substances or possess the characteristics enumerated in this article and which in the judgment of the director, and/or the local, state and federal agencies having jurisdiction, may have a deleterious effect upon the wastewater works, processes, equipment, or receiving waters, or which otherwise create a hazard to life or constitute a public nuisance, the director may: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment to an acceptable condition for discharge to the public sewers; 
(3)  Require control over the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Require payment to cover the added cost of handling and treating the wastes not covered by existing taxes or sewer charges. Such payments shall be as specified in this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-208; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-219. - Approval of facilities. 
(a)  If the director permits the pretreatment or equalization of waste flows, the design and installation of the plants and equipment shall be subject to the review and approval of the director and the local, state and federal agencies having jurisdiction and subject to the requirements of all applicable codes, resolutions and laws. 
(b)  Facilities to prevent accidental discharge of prohibitive material shall be provided and maintained at the owner's cost and expense. Detailed plans showing facilities and operating procedures to provide this protection shall be submitted to the director for review and shall be approved by the director before construction of the facility. 
(c)  In the event of an accidental spill of unavoidable loss to the sanitary sewer system of any deleterious materials, the owner concerned shall promptly notify the director of the nature of the spill, the quantity, and the time of occurrence. Within five working days following an accidental discharge, the user will submit a written report describing the cause and measures to be taken to prevent any further occurrence. 
(Code 1982, § 20-209; Ord. No. 81-192, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-220. - Manifest requirements. 
A manifest is required of all users having a hazardous waste that is not acceptable at the POTW and requiring disposal at an approved hazardous materials disposal facility. The user shall submit to the director a quarterly report denoting the materials hauler, date, time, quantity and place of disposal (reference PL 94-540 subtitle C). 
(Ord. No. 81-192, § 9, 6-25-1981)  
Sec. 21-221. - Discharge to storm sewers. 
Stormwater and all other unpolluted drainage shall be discharged to such sewers as are specifically designated as storm sewers, or to a natural outlet approved by the local, state and federal agencies having jurisdiction. Industrial cooling water or unpolluted process waters may be discharged on approval of the local, state and federal agencies having jurisdiction. 
(Code 1982, § 20-210)  
Secs. 21-222—21-240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - WATER QUALITY AND QUANTITY DETERMINATIONS 
 
Sec. 21-241. - Rate of delivery of effluent and waste. 
The delivery of all effluent and waste from a producer to the city's sanitary sewer shall be at a reasonable uniform rate, as produced without storage by the producer, except that storage which is necessary in the pretreatment plant of the producer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-218)  
Sec. 21-242. - Prohibitions. 
(a)  No person who is engaged in the process of collecting, storing or holding wastewaters, oils, grease, portable toilet waste, grease trap contents or sand trap contents shall deposit any of these wastes, oils or greases into the wastewater collection system of the city. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump or place any semiliquid waste material whatsoever, including but not limited to waste cleaned from septic tanks and portable sources into the city sanitary sewer system except through a duly authorized permanent connection, or if dumped from a portable source then in conformity with the following: 
(1)  No such material will be placed or dumped into the system except under the immediate supervision of employees designated for that purpose on duty at the city sewer treatment plant No. 1. 
(2)  Each person dumping or placing waste in the city sanitary sewer system from portable sources shall pay to the city a service fee of $10.00 per month for each month during which any such material is dumped or placed, plus an additional amount of $23.00 per each 1,000 gallons of waste dumped into the sanitary sewer system. 
(Code 1982, § 20-219; Ord. No. 00-129, § 3, 3-9-2000)  
Sec. 21-243. - Requirements as to permits. 
(a)  No permit for the disposal of industrial waste will be approved by the director which will permit the acceptance of waste which will damage either the sewers, plants or appurtenances of the sewer system or produce results detrimental to the treatment process, including sludge disposal, or producing plant effluent contrary to the rules and standards set out by the local, state and federal agencies having jurisdiction. 
(b)  No waste shall be placed in the sanitary sewer system and no permit will be approved for acceptance of any waste which will produce damage or stoppage to the sewers of the city system. No waste shall be placed in the sanitary sewer system except by appropriate permit from the director, and no industrial waste shall be placed in any city sewer system or sanitary sewer system without an industrial waste disposal permit issued by the director. 
(Code 1982, § 20-220)  
Sec. 21-244. - Acceptance of waste. 
(a)  Wastes will be accepted which have been placed in satisfactory conditions or quality after pretreatment by the producer in a plant or by a process which has been approved by the director, and which is continuously maintained and operated by the producer at no cost to the city and which is continuously subject to inspection by the director or his designated representative. The construction plans for such pretreatment plants shall, after their approval, be placed on file in permanent reproducible form with the director without cost to the city. 
(b)  Septic tank waste will be received by the city only at the disposal site located at treatment plant No. 1, on Vermont Road. 
(Code 1982, § 20-221)  
Sec. 21-245. - Quality determination. 
(a)  Determination of the average concentration or strength of the waste delivered shall be the obligation of the city. Tests made on representative average samples collected by the city shall be made at intervals as the city may desire so long as at least annual samples are taken. 
(b)  Samples may be taken and tests made at the city's option without notice to the owner and test results made and approved by the city shall be final in fixing the applicable rate. However, the owner may request in writing that parallel sampling and tests at all times be made by the owner and the city, in which case consideration may be given to using the average of comparable values obtained by the owner and the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-222)  
Sec. 21-246. - Testing wastes. 
It is specifically agreed by the producer that the city may at any time test any of the waste being discharged by the company for quality or quantity, and a duly authorized city representative may enter a plant at any time by appropriate application at the plant office during business or operational hours for this purpose or for checking company operation to estimate the quantity and quality of waste. 
(Code 1982, § 20-223)  
Sec. 21-247. - Effluent sampling. 
(a)  All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with the latest edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater," 20th edition, published by the American Public Health Association, the American Water Works Association, and the Water Environment Federation, and/or "Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes," U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Washington, D.C. 20460, which publications shall be on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer and be available for use and examination by the public in that office at all reasonable times; and all such measurements, tests and analyses shall be determined at the control manhole provided, or upon suitable samples taken at the control manhole. If no special manhole has been installed, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole in the public sewer to the point at which the building sewer is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the wastewater works and to determine the existence of hazards of life, limb and property. 
(b)  The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of the premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample should be taken. Normally, but not always, BOD and suspended solids analyses are obtained from 24-hour composites of all outfalls whereas pHs are determined from periodic grab samples. 
(c)  The increased charge or surcharge, as specified in division 6 of this article for sewer and industrial waste which exceeds the standard quality set out in this division, is used to provide for the increased costs, which costs vary with both quality and quantity when waste is treated. The variations in cost with strengths are admittedly difficult to exactly determine, and the method is to be effective without reference to other possible methods of computation. This provision shall not alter any of the terms and provisions of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-224)  
Sec. 21-248. - Quality changes. 
The director shall have made from time to time tests to determine the quality of waste being discharged into the city sewer from users or connectors, including the premises or industrial waste disposal permit holders under the provisions of this article. If at any time such waste becomes or the industrial process changes to a quality that requires pretreatment according to the city standards, the director shall have the authority to require that proper permits be obtained and proper pretreatment facilities be installed by the permit holder. Should any user or connector, or a permit holder, fail or refuse to install such facilities or initiate the installation to the satisfaction and approval of the director within 30 days after receipt of written notice from the director, the director (subject to review as provided in this article) shall have the authority to revoke such permit and to terminate sewer service to such premises until such time as there has been compliance with the requirements of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 20-225)  
Sec. 21-249. - Quantity determination. 
(a)  Unless otherwise provided, the quantity of waste delivered to city sewers will be used as the same as the water delivered to the producer by the city water system; if well water is to be used, it must be known to the city and metered at the user's expense, using a metering device which meets the city's engineering standards. The user shall pay the city the cost incurred in meter reading and billing. Such metering devices will be accessible to authorized city representatives at all reasonable times. 
(b)  Should the producer evaporate or dispose of water delivered by the city water system, it shall be the obligation of the producer to install such meters or other devices to determine the portion of quantity delivered to the sewer system. 
(c)  The director will consider establishing a constant ratio, factor or percentage to be applied to the metered water quantity delivered by the city in order to determine the waste delivered by the industry. Determination of this factor will be the responsibility of the waste producer as also will be the demonstration to obtain the director's approval of the factor. The value of this factor will be periodically reviewed for accuracy. 
(Code 1982, § 20-226)  
Secs. 21-250—21-270. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - RATES 
 
Sec. 21-271. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bill means water and sewer charges. 
Billing period means the period intervening between monthly readings of meters forming a part of the water system or installed pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
Establishment means any premises used for residential, commercial, industrial, religious, charitable or any other purposes of whatsoever kind or character. 
Major industrial means users discharging 100,000,000 gallons or more of effluent per year. 
Other means hotels, motels, multifamily, general commercial, some industrial users, and, for the purpose of establishing sewer service charges under section 21-275, any single-family residence served by more than a single water meter. 
Sanitary sewer system means the sanitary sewer system of the city. 
Single-family residence means the space provided for the occupancy of a single-family, i.e., including separate living quarters and kitchen, and which is served by a single water meter. For the purpose of establishing sewer service charges under section 21-278, this definition shall not include a premise served by more than a single water meter. 
(Code 1982, § 20-236; Ord. No. 05-50, § 1, 2-24-2005) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 21-272. - Determination of quantity of discharge/consumption. 
In the case of each establishment that obtains from the water system all water that is discharged into the sanitary sewer system by or from such establishment, the quantity of water consumed during a billing period shall be deemed to be the quantity shown by the water bill rendered on the same statement. In the case of any establishment that discharges into the sanitary sewer system water obtained from any source other than the water system, the occupant of such establishment shall install a meter of a type approved by the city at the occupant's expense for the purpose of measuring the quantity of water consumed or discharged at such establishment. 
(Code 1982, § 20-237; Ord. No. 94-809, § 2, 12-20-1994)  
Sec. 21-273. - Sewer service charges. 
There are hereby established monthly charges for sanitary sewer service to each establishment which is served by a water meter which discharges into the sanitary sewer system of the city, said charges being based upon the monthly consumption of water by each establishment, or where discharge is made into said system from a source other than the city water system, then the combination of the two, subject to the charges hereinafter established, as follows:
