It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in home composting operations in such a manner so as to create a nuisance or danger to public health, sanitation or welfare. 
(Ord. No. 97-817, § 6, 12-11-1997)  
Secs. 22-44—22-70. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STORAGE AND COLLECTION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for solid waste collection, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-135, 22-27-3. 
 
Sec. 22-71. - Containers. 
(a)  Required. 
(1)  Every person in possession, charge or control of any premises within the city where any solid waste is created or accumulated, except as provided in subsections (a)(2), (3) and (4) of this section, shall cause all such material to be placed in one of the following: 
a.  Watertight standard garbage cans having a capacity of not exceeding 32 gallons, having handles or other suitable lifting devices or features and being of a type manufactured for residential solid waste, with tapered sides for easy emptying; 
b.  Watertight plastic or paper containers manufactured for garbage disposal and constructed of material suitably durable to maintain their watertight quality until collection; 
c.  Approved receptacles, in the case of owners or persons in possession, charge or control of industrial or commercial premises, including but not limited to premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy, whose waste is collected by the city; or 
d.  The collection container furnished by the city in areas where automated garbage collection is provided. 
(2)  Persons disposing of their own solid waste pursuant to Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-3(g) shall cause all such materials to be placed in approved receptacles. 
(3)  Every owner and property management company (or their agent) in possession, charge or control of any premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy where any solid waste is created or accumulated, and which contracts or permits contracting with licensed private haulers shall cause all such material to be placed in approved receptacles. 
(4)  Every person in possession, charge or control of any premises within the city where any solid waste is created or accumulated and who contracts with licensed private haulers shall cause all such material to be placed in approved receptacles. 
(b)  Customer furnished containers. 
(1)  All customer furnished containers used for deposit and collection of solid waste shall be: 
a.  Leakproof, waterproof and flytight; 
b.  Kept in good condition, closed, covered and free of ragged or sharp edges or other defects so that waste will not leak or spill and so as to reduce the risk of injury to persons collecting such containers; 
c.  Of such construction quality as to maintain its original shape when placed at an outdoor location and to be reasonably resistant to rust, corrosion and the loosening of hardware; and 
d.  Serviced with sufficient frequency so as to prevent overflow, spillage and the emanation of offensive odors. 
If a customer furnished container which does not meet the requirements of the preceding sentence is used by a person receiving waste collection service from the city, sanitation personnel shall place a notice of such defect on the container; and if not replaced within ten days of such notice, any such container then may be removed and disposed of as waste. Acceptable container materials are galvanized metal, aluminum, rubber, fiberglass and plastic. The weight of any individual container and its contents shall not exceed 50 pounds. 
(2)  The city shall not remove solid waste from any customer-furnished container larger than 32 gallons. 
(3)  The city will provide containers for customers in areas where automated collection service is provided. The number and size of containers provided will be according to the service level requested by the customer; however, it is the duty of each customer to subscribe to the number and size of containers sufficient for convenient and safe removal by the city. 
(c)  Location of pick up points. It shall be the duty of any person planning to construct any apartment house, multiple dwelling unit, business place or industrial building, prior to obtaining a building permit, to submit for the approval of the sanitation division plans showing location of any garbage containers, commercial containers or pickup points. 
(d)  Nonautomated collection service. In areas where nonautomated collection is provided for yard waste service and customers choose to place waste out for collection in bundles, the bundles must not have any dimension greater than 48 linear inches or weigh more than 50 pounds. 
(e)  Automated collection service. 
(1)  Customers in areas where automated collection service is provided shall use a specified collection container for the collection and removal of household solid waste, such container to be distributed by the city at no cost to the customer. The container shall remain the property of the city and shall not be removed from the property when a customer changes residences as the container is assigned to the property address by an identifying number. 
(2)  If a container is lost by theft, or damaged beyond use by any means other than by the customer's own neglect or misuse, a container shall be replaced by the city at no cost to the customer. If a container is lost by theft, the customer must file a report with the police department before the city will replace the container. If the container is lost or damaged beyond use as a result of the customer's neglect or misuse, a designated fee will be charged by the city for a replacement container. 
(3)  The customer shall promptly notify the city sanitation division in the event of the need for repair to or replacement of a container. 
(4)  On scheduled collection days, automated collection containers shall be placed within three feet of the street curb or edge of the road, or in a location designated by the sanitation division. All containers must be placed so as to face in the proper direction and so as not to obstruct the collection vehicle. Container lid must be kept closed at all times to prevent any accumulation of water. Bags, boxes or other items shall not be placed on top of the closed container lid. 
(5)  Solid waste placed in the container must be containerized in either plastic or paper bags to prevent the contents from being displaced by the elements when the container is being emptied. 
(6)  It shall be unlawful to overload containers in a manner which is likely to cause damage to the collection vehicle or the container, create a litter condition, or impede collection. 
(7)  The city sanitation division shall not collect solid waste on or around automated containers except as specifically provided in this subsection. If additional refuse is generated on the premises that can not be accommodated by regularly scheduled service in the automated containers provided, the customer may request and use additional automated containers. 
(f)  Use by other customers. It shall be unlawful for any person to place or deposit any solid waste generated elsewhere in or around a refuse container owned or provided for the use of another customer. 
(g)  Spilling or scattering contents. It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with the contents of any container set out for removal by the city or any private collection agency in such a manner that the contents of the container are left spilled out or scattered on public or private property. 
(h)  Damage to or destruction of. It shall be unlawful for any person to damage or destroy any container placed at the curbside for collection. 
(i)  Violation of section; penalties. Any person who violates or fails or refuses to obey or comply with any subsection of this section shall upon conviction be punished, in addition to such other punishment, including a term of community service, as may be provided by the court, by minimum fines and penalties: 
(1)  For a first conviction of $100.00 or by imprisonment for not more than ten days; 
(2)  For conviction of a second offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, by a fine of $200.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment; 
(3)  For conviction of a third or subsequent offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, by a fine of $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than three months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-271), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, §§ 9—11, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 99-88, § 2, 1-28-1999) 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Sec. 22-72. - Commercial and industrial bulk rubbish collection. 
It shall be the duty of every person in possession, charge or control of any commercial or industrial place of business where the volume of combustible rubbish makes the use of curbside collection impracticable to utilize approved receptacles designed for the storage and collection of such rubbish. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-272), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-73. - Bailers and compactors. 
Persons using bailers or compactors and whose waste collections are made by the sanitation division shall not place for collection bundles of waste exceeding 50 pounds in weight or 48 inches in any dimension. No bundles exceeding such weight or size limit shall be collected by the city, and it shall instead be the responsibility of the persons using such bailers or compactors to deliver such waste to a designated receiving facility. Bundles from bailers and compactors meeting these requirements will be collected only on nonautomated routes, and for the purpose of calculating collection fees, each bundle will be counted as one collection unit. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-273), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-74. - Wastes from businesses not placed in city containers. 
It shall be unlawful for any person operating a place of business, or any employee of such person, to place or deposit, in any waste container that is furnished and maintained upon a public street or sidewalk by the city for the convenience of the walking public, garbage, rubbish or other waste material accumulated at such place of business except in such cases where the city provides a container for specific use by a particular business. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-274), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-75. - Leaves and grass clippings. 
Leaves and grass clippings shall be containerized and placed for pickup on the collection day determined by the superintendent of the sanitation division. Leaves shall be placed in tied, closed, or sealed bags, and placed adjacent to that portion of the street right-of-way normally used by vehicles and in a location and manner so as to not obstruct the flow of storm drainage runoff in gutters and ditches. Each bag shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-275), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 10-675, § 1, 9-23-2010; Ord. No. 19-20 , § 1, 1-24-2019)  
Sec. 22-76. - Shrubbery clippings. 
Shrubbery clippings and other small miscellaneous vegetation, including garden vegetation, if tied in bundles, shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight or 48 inches in any dimension, and, if containerized, shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-276), 4-21-1994) 
Cross reference— Vegetation, ch. 27.  
Sec. 22-77. - Cardboard or pasteboard boxes. 
Cardboard or pasteboard boxes or other similar containers may be placed out for noncontainer ized collection if because of their size or quantity they would be impractical to contain. Cardboard or pasteboard boxes or other similar containers shall be prepared in a manner so as not to create a litter problem, stacked in a manner that permits convenient removal, and placed in a location designated by the sanitation division for collection on the day determined by the superintendent of the sanitation division. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-277), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 12, 12-11-1997)  
Sec. 22-78. - Ashes. 
Ashes must be containerized and not contain live coals and must be wetted sufficiently to prevent dust from forming during collection. The sanitation division will not remove ashes from apartment complexes utilizing licensed haulers or from commercial or industrial places of business. Instead the owners of such premises shall remove all such material to an authorized receiving facility. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-278), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-79. - Bulky waste, white goods and loose yard waste. 
(a)  All bulky waste, white goods or loose yard waste to be removed by the sanitation division from private residences shall be placed either between the sidewalk and curb or in an accessible place approved by the sanitation division. Tree limbs shall be cut in lengths not exceeding five feet in length, with protruding branches trimmed. All such waste shall be placed in an orderly, neat manner adjacent to that portion of the street right-of-way normally used by vehicles so as not to obstruct sidewalks or the flow of traffic or water. All bulky waste, white goods and loose yard waste shall be collected weekly. All such waste not removed by the city must be delivered by the owner to an authorized receiving facility. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any tree removal contractor, licensed or otherwise, to leave or deposit tree or limb removal debris at curbside for the city to remove. All contractors doing business in the city shall collect and remove or arrange for the collection and removal of tree or limb removal debris to a facility permitted by ADEM to accept this type of waste, whether such facility is operated by the city or privately. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful to place for removal bulky waste, white goods or loose yard waste between utility poles and utility pole support cables, under trees, under low utility wires; around, adjacent to, or on top of fire hydrants; or adjacent to fences or buildings. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-279), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 13, 12-11-1997;Ord. No. 17-601 , § 1, 8-24-2017)  
Sec. 22-80. - Service not provided by city. 
(a)  The city does not provide service for the removal or collection, from any premises, of: 
(1)  Construction and demolition waste or materials resulting from the construction, demolition or renovation of buildings or structures which is not containerized as provided in section 22-71(1); 
(2)  Materials resulting from commercial-related activities, work performed by a contractor, or work requiring a building permit; 
(3)  Tree limbs and trimmings resulting from land clearing or from tree service contractors or other commercial workers; 
(4)  Loose rubbish; 
(5)  Rocks, mulch, dirt, including topsoil and potting soil, and other debris resulting from a residential or commercial landscaping or construction effort; 
(6)  Hazardous wastes or other wastes that are determined by law or by the sanitation division to be hazardous to the health or safety of collection personnel; or 
(7)  Animal or fowl excrement, dead animals or fowl or their parts; 
(8)  Bulky waste, yard waste or rubbish from apartment complexes, or commercial or industrial places of business that use private hauler collection agencies; and 
(9)  Motor vehicle tires from a business engaged in the manufacture, sale, exchange, repair, replacement or changing of tires or in a related tire business. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the person in possession, charge or control of the premises to provide for the removal of solid waste, and in those instances specified above, and to deliver such waste to an authorized receiving facility. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-280), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 14, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 17-601 , § 2, 8-24-2017)  
Sec. 22-81. - Accidents, collisions, wrecks. 
It shall be the duty of any person engaged in the business of moving wrecked or damaged motor vehicles from the public streets or other public property in the city to: 
(1)  Put out, immediately upon arrival at the scene of such wrecked or damaged vehicle, any necessary or absorbent material to absorb any petroleum product, radiator fluid or any other fluid released onto such street or property as a result of the wreck or damage, and to properly recover and dispose of such material so as to prevent, to the extent possible, such petroleum product, radiator fluid or other pollutant from entering the municipal separate storm sewer system; and 
(2)  Remove from the public street or other public property, at and about the scene of such damaged or wrecked motor vehicle, all glass, metal, debris, oil spills or other hazards that may have been cast upon the public street or other public property as a result of such motor vehicle's being wrecked or damaged. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-281), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-82. - Residential collection practices. 
(a)  Garbage removal from occupied single-family residential units shall be made exclusively by the sanitation division on a once-per-week schedule approved by the mayor. Collection will be either automated or nonautomated. Participation in the city's removal or collection system by single-family residential customers is mandatory for all residents of the city. Single-family residential customers living in automated collection areas may choose their level of service by choosing the size and number of containers they will use. Customers will be allowed to adjust their level of service one time during the year following the service start date. Otherwise, customers will be allowed to change service levels only on or about the anniversary of their service start date. Automated collection within the city is mandatory in those areas designated by the sanitation division. 
(b)  Yard waste collection shall be made by the sanitation division on weekly schedules approved by the mayor. Collection will either be automated or nonautomated. Participation in the city's removal or collection system by single-family residential customers is mandatory for all residents of the city. Yard waste shall be containerized for city collection, if containerization of such waste is possible. Containers and bundles of waste shall not exceed 50 pounds in weight or 48 inches in any dimension. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-282), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 05-659, § 1, 9-29-2005)  
Sec. 22-83. - Commercial collection practice. 
Commercial garbage collection shall be provided by the sanitation division, as requested, for commercial establishments within the city on a once-per-week basis. All such service by the sanitation division shall be by means of approved cans, bags or city provided automated containers. The owners and persons in possession, charge or control of each commercial establishment, and in the case of premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy, the owners and property management company (including their agents) are responsible for removal of all acceptable waste from such premises, and for its delivery to an authorized receiving facility. Private containerized collection shall be provided by licensed haulers in accordance with health and sanitation standards. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-283), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 15, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 99-88, § 3, 1-28-1999; Ord. No. 05-659, § 2, 9-29-2005)  
Sec. 22-84. - Placement location. 
It shall be unlawful to place garbage cans or containers for collection of garbage, refuse or other waste at any place other than immediately adjacent to the curb (or the edge of the roadway on noncurb streets) in front of the premises where such waste was accumulated unless prior approval is, upon a showing of need, obtained from the sanitation division for placement at some other location. Where collections are authorized to be made from private alleys and accessways, approaches shall be maintained in such a manner as not to be a hazard to sanitation division collection personnel or equipment (it being understood that tree limbs, parked cars and holes in such alleys or accessways shall, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, be considered as hazards to such personnel). Failure to comply with these provisions after notification by the sanitation division will cause service to be discontinued until correction has been made. At no time will collection personnel enter houses, buildings or fences for the purpose of the collection of garbage, refuse or other waste; however, the director of public works services of the city shall promulgate rules pertaining to special off-street service for persons with disabilities who are without assistance and cannot place containers at the curb, but no outbuilding or fence shall be entered without permission. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-284), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 16, 12-11-1997)  
Sec. 22-85. - Placement time. 
It shall be unlawful to place or permit the placement of garbage cans or containers immediately adjacent to the curb (or the edge of the roadway on noncurb streets) before sundown on the day preceding the days designated by the sanitation division for collection, or to leave such cans or containers on the placement site after the days designated for collection. Containers must be properly placed for collection prior to the beginning of the scheduled work day for sanitation personnel. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-285), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-86. - Medical supplies and laboratory waste disposal. 
It shall be the duty of any person disposing of needles, glass, vials, plaster casts and laboratory wastes or other medical supplies to package disposed-of items in such a manner as not to be a hazard to collection and disposal personnel. If a hazard is determined to exist by the sanitation division, collection service will be discontinued until correction has been made. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-286), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-87. - Dumpsters and commercial containers. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection (a), except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Adjacent property means public or private property adjacent to the private premises utilizing a dumpster. 
Dumpster means a dumpster or commercial container used for the collection of garbage, trash or other debris. 
Dumpster owner means the owner of the company providing the dumpster or any person working on its behalf. 
Person in charge of the premises means the owner or person in possession, charge or control of any private property utilizing a dumpster. 
Premises means any lot, yard, plot, tract, parcel or other piece of land or property located within the city. 
Public property means any real property which is owned, maintained or controlled by the city or any other county, state, or federal governmental entity, and shall include any street, sidewalk, avenue, road, drive, lane, boulevard, alley, highway, park or other property owned, operated or controlled by the city, or any other public governmental entity for the use, benefit or enjoyment of the general public. 
(b)  City rights-of-way or easements. 
(1)  a.  It shall be unlawful for the dumpster owner and the person in charge of the premises to place or locate a dumpster, except for dumpsters placed by the city or a contractor acting on the city's behalf, on any right-of-way or easement of the city. 
b.  Dumpsters found to be in violation of the foregoing subsection regarding placement on the city right-of-way or easement, shall be relocated from said right-of-way or easement by the dumpster owner. In cases where no other location is available, then the dumpster owner must remove the dumpster permanently and the person in charge of the premises must arrange for another satisfactory means of waste disposal for the location in question. 
(2)  Access ways to dumpsters which cross or intersect any city right-of-way must be paved and constructed so as to withstand the maximum gross vehicle weight of the collection vehicle. Compliance with this provision shall be the responsibility of the person in charge of the premises. 
(c)  Placement; access; and identification. 
(1)  a.  The person in charge of the premises shall provide a concrete or asphalt surface of sufficient dimension for the location and placement of the dumpster. It shall be the responsibility of the dumpster owner to see that the dumpster is placed and maintained on said surface and said dumpster owner shall not place or locate any dumpster on premises that do not provide the required surface. 
b.  In cases of hardship which are not merely financial in nature and which are beyond the control of the person in charge of the premises, the director of public works may, upon the written request of the person in charge, agree to waive or modify the surfacing requirement and may prescribe appropriate conditions or safeguards thereto. 
(2)  The person in charge of the premises shall maintain the surface and access ways thereto in good repair and condition. 
(3)  The dumpster owner shall maintain a log, which the dumpster owner shall make available to the city upon request, identifying: 
a.  The name of the person in charge of the premises and his or her contact information including address (if other than the address where the dumpster is located) and telephone number(s); 
b.  The address where the dumpster is located; and 
c.  The type of dumpster. 
(d)  Condition. 
(1)  a.  Dumpster owners shall provide dumpsters in good repair and condition with tight fitting lids, doors, or covers. 
b.  The dumpster owner shall ensure that upon collection the closures or access points for the dumpster are closed and secured. 
(2)  The person in charge of the premises shall see that the dumpster lids, doors, covers, and access doors remain closed when not in actual use. 
(3)  Dumpster owners shall ensure that drain plugs with respect to dumpsters designed with drains shall be in place at all times except during cleaning. 
(4)  All dumpsters shall be kept in good condition, clean, free of loose debris and litter and disinfected. Any dumpsters producing or causing noxious, foul or offensive odors shall be immediately removed or cleaned to eliminate the odor. Compliance with this provision shall be the responsibility of the dumpster owner and person in charge of the premises. 
(e)  Placement of garbage. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the person in charge of the premises to have or allow the placement of garbage, trash or other solid waste outside the dumpster. 
(2)  Removal of debris shall be accomplished by either placing said debris in the dumpster or transporting it to the solid waste disposal authority. In the event the debris is removed to the solid waste disposal authority, said person in charge of the premises shall provide, upon request of a city agency, proof of disposal at the solid waste disposal authority. 
(3)  In general, for a violation of this subsection (e), the penalty provisions of section 1-7 of this Code shall apply, including, but not limited to, subsection (e) thereof; provided, however, the following penalty shall be imposed for violation of this subsection (e): 
a.  Over a 12-month period, upon first conviction regarding the premises in question or the person in charge of the premises, a fine of not less than $200.00 or more than $500.00, or imprisonment for not more than ten days. 
b.  Upon a second conviction regarding the premises in question or the person in charge of the premises, a fine of not less than $300.00 or more than $500.00, or imprisonment for not more than 30 days, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
c.  Upon a third or subsequent conviction regarding the premises in question or the person in charge of the premises, a fine of not less than $500.00 and imprisonment in jail for a period of not to exceed six months. Such sentence shall include a mandatory sentence of not less than two days in jail, which shall not be subject to suspension or probation. 
(f)  Waste removal. It shall be unlawful for the person in charge of the premises to fail to maintain the premises, including the dumpster, free of solid waste that would tend to: 
(1)  Attract children and endanger their lives and health; 
(2)  Spread disease; 
(3)  Invite plundering; 
(4)  Attract vagrants; or 
(5)  Create fire hazards or other safety or health hazards. 
(g)  Screening. 
(1)  It shall be unlawful for the person in charge of the premises to maintain a dumpster that is not screened so as not to be visible from the ground level of adjacent property. Such screening may be accomplished by any one of the following: 
a.  By locating the dumpster on a portion of the premises where it is not visible from adjacent property; 
b.  By providing a visual screen consisting of (i) a fully enclosed structure; (ii) a solid or otherwise non-transparent vertical wall or fence of a minimum height of at least six inches above the top of the dumpster at any point which is maintained in good condition and repair; (iii) natural objects, plantings, structures or other appropriate means which are at a minimum height of at least six inches above the top of the dumpster at any point which are neat and well maintained; or (iv) any combination of the foregoing; 
c.  In cases of hardship which are not merely financial in nature and which are beyond the control of the person in charge of the premises, the director of public works may, upon the written request of said person in charge, agree to waive or modify the screening requirement provided that he may prescribe appropriate conditions which mitigate the visual impact to adjacent property. 
(2)  The dumpster owner shall not place a dumpster on premises without the proper screening or a waiver thereof, or outside the screened area. 
(h)  Enforcement. The provisions of section 22-87 may be enforced by either a sworn officer of the Huntsville Police Department or by an employee of the Code Enforcement Section of the Community Development Division of the City of Huntsville. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-287), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 17, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 99-88, § 4, 1-28-1999; Ord. No. 02-312, 5-9-2002; Ord. No. 03-506, § 1, 6-26-2003; Ord. No. 03-818, § 1, 10-9-2003; Ord. No. 05-774, § 1, 9-22-2005; Ord. No. 08-651, § 1, 7-31-2009; Ord. No. 10-66, § 1, 2-11-2010; Ord. No. 11-514, §§ 1, 2, 8-11-2011)  
Sec. 22-88. - Change in commercial service. 
Changes to or from city service requested by commercial customers shall be requested in writing and shall be approved by the sanitation division. The sanitation division reserves the right to decline service to any commercial business, including premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 5(20-288), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 99-88, § 5, 1-28-1999)  
Sec. 22-89. - Special collections. 
Waste that has not been containerized, bundled or stored and is authorized for collection in accordance with the provisions of this article may be collected by the sanitation division by making arrangements for a special collection or other means of disposal. Residents disposing of building or construction debris (which is not the result of commercial related activity and which does not result from the work of a general contractor) that is determined by the sanitation division to be impractical to contain may arrange for a special collection. In cases where no arrangements for special collection have been made with respect to waste that has not been containerized, bundled or stored and is authorized for collection in accordance with the provisions of this article, such waste may be collected by the sanitation division and shall be considered a special collection. Fees for these special collections are in addition to the customer's normal monthly rate for containerized service and are determined as provided in section 22-182. Materials resulting from the repair or replacement of driveways or concrete slabs are excluded from special collections. 
(Ord. No. 97-817, § 18, 12-11-1997)  
Secs. 22-90—22-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - LICENSED HAULERS AND RELATED ISSUES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference— Licenses, ch. 15. 
 
Sec. 22-121. - Removal by city collectors and licensed haulers only; exceptions. 
(a)  No person, except duly authorized collectors of the city or private collectors or haulers licensed by the city pursuant to law, shall collect or remove any solid waste generated, occurring or accumulating within the city or use any of the streets, avenues, alleys or public places and ways of the city for the purpose of collecting or transporting solid waste. All licenses granted by the city to private collectors or haulers and all contracts or other forms of authorization of duly authorized private collectors or haulers shall, until such time as all the bonds have been fully paid and retired, require that all acceptable waste collected and transported under authority of such license, contract or authorization be delivered as follows: 
(1)  Until the actual acceptance date, such acceptable waste shall be delivered to the authority at the existing landfill for disposal at the existing landfill; 
(2)  From and after the actual acceptance date, such acceptable waste shall be delivered to the authority at the plant, for disposal and processing there or for subsequent transportation by such private haulers or collectors to the existing landfill and disposal there; 
however, if the authority cannot accept acceptable waste at the existing landfill or the plant (or at another authorized receiving facility to which acceptable waste is at the time required by the provisions of this article to be delivered), such acceptable waste shall be delivered to the authority at such authorized receiving facility as shall have been specified in a notice published in a newspaper having general circulation and published in the city (which such notice shall also specify the location or locations of such authorized receiving facility). Further, no person shall use any of the streets, avenues, alleys or public places or ways of the city for the purpose of collecting or transporting any solid waste generated, occurring or accumulating within the city, or shall be granted a franchise so to use any of the streets, avenues, alleys or public places or ways of the city (irrespective of whether such person is licensed, and irrespective of whether such person is required to be licensed, by the city), unless all acceptable waste so collected and transported by such person shall be delivered to the authority to the same extent as provided in this subsection. 
(b)  All the provisions of subsection (a) of this section are subject, however, to the following exceptions: 
(1)  The owner or person in possession of any household, business, industry or other property in the city may store, haul and dispose of acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulated upon the premises of such person (not including, however, any acceptable waste previously collected by any such person from the premises of others, notwithstanding that title to such waste may have been transferred to such person) on his own land or otherwise, if such storage, haulage or disposal is accomplished pursuant to a certificate of exception obtained under the provisions of Code of Ala. 1975, § 22-27-3(e); 
(2)  Any person owning or being in charge or possession of any private residence, commercial business or industry may remove and transport acceptable waste generated or occurring upon the premises of such person provided such acceptable waste is delivered to the authority for disposal as and to the same extent required and provided in this section with respect to private collectors or haulers collecting and removing acceptable waste under licenses granted by the city; and 
(3)  Any acceptable waste that is appropriately delivered or tendered to the authority as provided in this section and that the authority does not accept, process or otherwise dispose of, may thereafter be delivered and disposed of in any lawful manner deemed desirable by the licensed private collector or hauler or other person collecting or transporting the waste, it being understood and agreed that, for purposes of the preceding portions of this subsection (b)(3), the authority shall be considered not to have accepted, processed or otherwise disposed of any such acceptable waste only if such acceptable waste shall have been duly and appropriately tendered to the authority, in accordance with its rules and regulations, at an authorized receiving facility and the authority shall have rejected or otherwise failed to accept it, or the authority shall have published in a newspaper having general circulation and published in the city a notice to the effect that it cannot accept any acceptable waste and shall not have revoked or otherwise withdrawn (by notice published in like manner) such notice. 
(c)  Any solid waste that is not acceptable waste shall be disposed of, in a manner authorized or permitted by law, by the person responsible for generating the waste. 
(d)  The city council expressly readopts by reference, as a basis for this section (and other ancillary provisions of this chapter), the findings contained in section 22-2, including particularly (but without limitation) those contained in subsections 22-2(3) through (15). 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1(20-291), 5-27-1987)  
Sec. 22-122. - Issuance and revocation of licenses. 
Licenses for private haulers shall be issued by the city clerk-treasurer of the city based upon applications provided for that purpose. Licenses shall be issued on a calendar year basis—i.e., for a period beginning on January 1 of a calendar year and ending on December 31 of the same calendar year; and each license shall be renewable upon application, provided the applicant demonstrates compliance with: 
(1)  This chapter; 
(2)  The laws and regulations of the state; 
(3)  The rules and regulations of the state and county health departments; 
(4)  The pertinent ordinances of the city; and 
(5)  Insofar as authority property and the use of such property are concerned, with the applicable rules and regulations of the authority. 
Licenses may, however, be revoked by the city council after notice and hearing. Prior to issuance of any such license the city clerk-treasurer shall collect the privilege tax required by the privilege license code of the city. Licensees shall at all times collect, transport and dispose of solid waste in accordance with this chapter and, insofar as authority property and its use are concerned, in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations of the authority. 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1(20-292), 5-27-1987)  
Secs. 22-123—22-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DISPOSAL FACILITIES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference— Authority to provide for solid waste disposal, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-135, 22-27-3. 
 
Sec. 22-151. - Authorized areas for disposal of acceptable waste. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of, at any place within the city other than at an authorized receiving facility or authorized disposal facility, any acceptable waste that is generated, occurs or accumulates within the city, subject, however, to the provisions of section 22-121. 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1, 5-27-1987)  
Sec. 22-152. - Limitations on use of authorized receiving and disposal facilities. 
The authority shall not permit any person to dump, deposit or dispose of, at any authorized receiving facility or authorized disposal facility, acceptable waste other than acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulating within the city or within the county; however, the authority may, pursuant to a contract with the authority, permit the dumping, deposit or disposal, at an authorized receiving facility or authorized disposal facility, of acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulating outside the city and outside the county, but if and only to the extent that, after adequately providing for the proper disposal of all acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulating from within the city and from areas outside the city but within the county, the available facilities of the authority are at the time adequate also to provide for the proper disposal of such acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulating outside the city and outside the county. 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1, 5-27-1987)  
Sec. 22-153. - Authority rules, regulations and tipping fees; certain unlawful activities. 
The authority shall, prior to March 1, 1988, establish rules and regulations respecting: 
(1)  The use of any authorized receiving facilities and any authorized disposal facilities at the time owned or operated by the authority; 
(2)  The storage or disposal of acceptable waste at any authorized receiving facilities and any authorized disposal facilities at the time owned or operated by the authority; 
(3)  The conduct of persons engaging in the dumping of acceptable waste and related activities at any authorized receiving facilities and any authorized disposal facilities at the time owned or operated by the authority; 
and may at any time and from time to time thereafter modify, revise, amend, alter or rescind any such rules and regulations so established. The city recognizes that, under the provisions of existing law (including, without limitation, the act), the authority may fix and establish tipping fees and other charges for the disposal of acceptable waste at any authorized receiving facility and any authorized disposal facility and may at any time and from time thereafter modify, amend, alter or rescind any such tipping fees and other charges so established. It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of acceptable waste at any authorized receiving facility and any authorized disposal facility without paying (or providing, in a manner satisfactory to the authority, for the payment of) any then prescribed tipping fees or other applicable charges; and it shall be unlawful for any person who is delinquent in the payment of any charges that are due the authority for the disposal of acceptable waste and who has refused to pay cash, after being requested to do so by the authority, to enter the boundaries of any authorized disposal facility or authorized receiving facility for the purpose of dumping, depositing or disposing of acceptable waste, until all outstanding charges then due to the authority by such person have been paid or otherwise satisfied in full. Further, it shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of, at other than an authorized receiving facility or an authorized disposal facility, any acceptable waste that is required by this article or by the terms of a license issued by the city to be delivered to the authority and to deposit any hazardous waste or unacceptable waste at any authorized receiving facility or authorized disposal facility. 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1(20-303), 5-27-1987; Ord. No. 87-545, § 1, 11-24-1987)  
Sec. 22-154. - Unlawful activities generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit, for collection and transportation by the sanitation division, any acceptable waste generated, occurring or accumulated from a commercial or industrial establishment under the pretense that such waste was generated, occurred or accumulated from a noncommercial or nonindustrial establishment. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or dispose of any acceptable waste at any authorized disposal facility or authorized receiving facility other than during the receiving time unless authorized by the authority; and it shall be unlawful for any person to dump, deposit or dispose of, at any authorized receiving facility or authorized disposal facility, any acceptable waste not generated, occurring or accumulating from within the city or the county, except pursuant to a contract with the authority as and to the extent provided in section 22-152. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for a person not authorized or actively employed and performing assigned duties at an authorized disposal facility or authorized receiving facility, not having acceptable waste to deposit at an authorized disposal facility or an authorized receiving facility, or not a so-called "business invitee," to enter the boundaries of such a facility. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person, while disposing of acceptable waste at an authorized disposal facility or an authorized receiving facility, or at any other time, to scavenge or remove any item from any such facility. If a person dumps or disposes of, at an authorized disposal facility or an authorized receiving facility, any item or items by mistake, then that and only that person will be permitted to remove such item from such facility and then only with the permission of the authority. If any item that is disposed of by mistake has been covered at a landfill by the landfill crew, the permission from the authority must be obtained before the item may be removed from such landfill. In no event shall anyone be allowed to remove items from the pit at the plant. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be upon any authorized disposal facility or authorized receiving facility except during the receiving time unless authorized by the authority. 
(f)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, within the boundaries of an authorized disposal facility or an authorized receiving facility, any vehicle for the purpose of depositing or delivering solid waste without first having presented such vehicle at the weigh-in station for the purpose of having it weighed, or to leave such a facility without first presenting such vehicle such weigh-in station for the purpose of having it inspected and weighed. 
(Ord. No. 87-65, § 1, 5-27-1987)  
Secs. 22-155—22-180. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - RATES AND CHARGES[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference— Fees authorized, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-47-135, 22-27-5. 
 
Sec. 22-181. - Generally. 
There are established, for the collection, hauling and disposal of acceptable waste by the city, the fees and charges prescribed in this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-320), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-182. - Residential. 
(a)  Garbage, yard waste and other acceptable waste. 
(1)  For each occupied single-family dwelling unit, there shall be a mandatory minimum charge in accordance with the following rate schedule: 
a.  For nonautomated service of garbage and yard waste, $16.50 per month. 
b.  Persons receiving automated service shall have the option of subscribing to any combination of 60-gallon and 90-gallon container sizes. The rate schedule for automated containers shall be as follows: 
1.  A 60-gallon container for garbage, per month $16.50. 
2.  A 90-gallon container for garbage, per month $16.50. 
c.  Additional 60-gallon or 90-gallon containers may be requested and will carry an additional charge of $2.00 or $3.00 per container per month, respectively. 
d.  For less than a full month's service, the charge shall be prorated. If there are one or more residential units with kitchen facilities in any commercial premises, there shall be paid (in addition to the applicable charge for commercial establishments), for the second and each additional such residential unit, the residential charge specified in this section. 
(2)  a.  Persons who are eligible to receive food stamps under the Federal Food Stamp Program operated pursuant to the provisions of 7 USC 2011, et seq., are eligible for a special rate for a single-family dwelling unit occupied by such persons. Proof of eligibility, together with a valid driver's license or other identification containing a photograph of the applicant, shall be furnished when a special rate under this subsection is claimed. 
b.  Application for the special rate shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city. The city may designate the manager of community development or any other person to determine eligibility for the special rate. The decision of such person designated by the city shall be final. Any person who qualified for the special rate shall be required to reapply for the special rate on an annual basis. The form for reapplication shall be the same as for initial application. The reapplication period shall be between October 1 and December 1 of each calendar year. 
c.  Persons who, as of January 1, 1999, have qualified for the special rate under the eligibility criteria set forth in prior versions of this article shall continue to be eligible for the special rate, and shall not have to reapply for the special rate on an annual basis. The special rate schedule is as follows: For nonautomated service of garbage and yard waste is $10.00 per month. For automated service: 
1.  A 60-gallon container for garbage, per month $10.00. 
2.  A 90-gallon container for garbage, per month $10.00. 
For less than a full month's service, the charge shall be prorated. 
(b)  Collection of loose yard waste. 
(1)  Any loose yard waste that cannot be containerized, bundled or stored in accordance with the provisions of this chapter shall be collected by the sanitation division. 
(2)  Fees for the collection of loose yard waste shall be set in accordance with the following rate schedule: 
a.  Up to ten cubic yards per collection, no charge. 
b.  Each additional five cubic yards, $45.00 per collection. 
(3)  Fees due for collection of noncontainerized yard waste shall be billed in the same manner as regular service and shall be due and payable under the same conditions as regular service. 
(c)  Special collections. A minimum charge of $45.00 shall be charged for each special collection. The special collection charge for materials, including but not limited to rocks, bricks, cinder blocks, sand, ceramic tile, sheet rock, dirt, sod or any other like material, shall be the greater of the minimum charge or the city's actual disposal cost. The special collection charge for all other materials shall be the greater of the minimum charge or a charge of $45.00 per five cubic yards. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-321), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 19, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 98-956, § 1, 1-14-1999; Ord. No. 10-675, §§ 1, 2, 9-23-2010)  
Sec. 22-183. - Commercial and industrial; garbage and other acceptable waste. 
(a)  Nonautomated service. For nonautomated service, special collection fees shall be billed in the same manner as regular service and shall be due and payable under the same conditions as regular service. Charges for all nonautomated commercial and industrial collection services provided by the city shall be determined by the sanitation division according to the service level requested by the customer and according to the number of containers of refuse collected by the city and establishing a charge according to the average monthly volume, determined (in the case of those establishments utilizing containers of not more than 32 gallons' capacity) in accordance with the following schedule: 
(1)  For each commercial or industrial establishment utilizing not more than three containers of 32 gallons or less capacity per collection, based upon two collections per week, $29.00 per month. 
(2)  For each commercial or industrial establishment utilizing more than three containers of 32 gallons or less capacity per collection, $1.70 per container per collection. 
However, for a commercial complex comprised of multiple commercial establishments where all the refuse and garbage is collected by the city from a central point, the charge shall be made on a volume basis for total volume generated by all such establishments depositing waste at the central point of collection; and the city will bill the owner, manager or agent of such commercial complex for the collection, hauling and disposal of refuse and garbage from such central point. 
(b)  Automated service. For automated service: 
(1)  Fees for one 90-gallon container shall be $29.00 minimum per month. 
(2)  Each commercial or industrial establishment requesting more than one 90-gallon container shall be charged as follows for each additional container: 
a.  A 60-gallon container, per month ..... $14.60 
b.  A 90-gallon container, per month ..... 21.90 
(3)  Any person using city garbage collection service and operating a business at his residence shall pay a garbage charge at the commercial rate provided in this article, but shall not be required to pay any residential charge. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-322), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 97-817, § 20, 12-11-1997; Ord. No. 98-956, § 2, 1-14-1999)  
Sec. 22-184. - Premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy. 
(a)  Premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy, including apartment buildings and complexes, will be charged for service using the residential rates set forth in section 22-182. In all other respects, premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy, including apartment buildings and complexes, will be treated as commercial establishments. 
(b)  Fees for service rendered with respect to premises designed or intended for multiple occupancy, including apartment buildings and complexes, which have master utility accounts, may be charged to the person or entity whose name is listed on the master utility account applicable to such property. 
(Ord. No. 99-961, § 1, 11-23-1999)  
Sec. 22-185. - Errors in charges; discontinuance of service. 
(a)  It shall be the responsibility of the person in charge of a commercial, industrial or residential establishment to report to the sanitation division any error on the garbage charge. No adjustment of any such charge as a result of a determination by the city that an incorrect charge has been made shall be made with respect to any period more than three months prior to the month during which such determination is made. Request for billing correction shall be made in writing to the sanitation division and/or the agent for the sanitation division. 
(b)  It shall be the responsibility of the person in charge of a commercial, industrial or residential establishment to request in writing any desired discontinuance of garbage service. Charges shall continue to accrue until such a written request is received by the sanitation division of the city. 
(c)  Residential customers may request a suspension of garbage services for a minimum period of three months in cases where residents are out of town or rental property is vacant. Requests for suspension of garbage service shall be made in writing to the sanitation division at least five working days prior to the affected period. No requests for suspension of garbage service will be accepted in arrears. In cases of rental property, proof of ownership may be requested. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-323), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-186. - Roominghouses or boardinghouses. 
(a)  Roominghouses or boardinghouses in which no meals are served to roomers or boarders will be treated as residences, governed by applicable parts of this article. 
(b)  Roominghouses or boardinghouses in which meals are served to roomers or boarders will be treated as commercial establishments, governed by applicable parts of this article. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-324), 4-21-1994)  
Sec. 22-187. - Penalty for nonpayment. 
(a)  All the charges and rates set forth or provided for in this article are net. If any bill is not paid on or before the date shown on the bill, there will be added to the bill an amount equal to five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(b)  If the fees, charges or rates for the services furnished by the city or a licensee of the city shall not be paid within 30 days after they become due and payable, the city may, at the expiration of such 30-day period, suspend services or, pursuant to resolution, proceed to recover the amount of any delinquency with interest in a civil action, or both. 
(Ord. No. 94-236, § 8(20-325), 4-21-1994; Ord. No. 98-652, § 1, 8-27-1998; Ord. No. 15-911 , 12-17-2015)  
Chapter 23 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference— Any ordinance providing for local improvements or levying or imposing any special assessment saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(14); any ordinance dedicating, establishing, naming, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, repairing or vacating any street saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(15); any ordinance establishing the grade of any street or sidewalks saved from repeal, § 1-11(a)(16); horses not to stand in streets unless hitched or attended, § 5-109; aviation, ch. 6; buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; cemeteries, ch. 9; environmental management, ch. 12; sleeping in parked vehicles, public places or on private lot of another, § 17-101 et seq.; peddlers and solicitors, ch. 18; peddlers and solicitors in central city area streets, sidewalks and parks, § 18-35; peddlers and solicitors in central city area streets, sidewalks and parks, exceptions, § 18-36; recreation services, ch. 19; depositing solid waste in streets or gutters, § 22-37; traffic and vehicles, ch. 25; unlawful materials on streets, § 25-6; tracking debris onto public streets or other public ways prohibited, § 25-392; riding bicycles on sidewalks, § 25-425; utilities, ch. 26; vegetation, ch. 27; protection of trees on public lands or public rights-of-way, utility easements, or land on which another public interest has been granted, § 27-53; zoning, app. A; subdivision regulations, app. B; requirements for improvements and design of sidewalks in subdivisions, app. B, § 4.6. 
State Law reference— Municipal streets, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-1 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 23-1. - Encumbering streets and sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to encumber a street or sidewalk with goods or merchandise, lumber or fuel or any article or obstruction whatever, except under a building permit from the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-22)  
Sec. 23-2. - Consent for erection or maintenance of obstruction in streets. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or maintain on any of the streets, public alleys or public grounds any obstruction or building without first obtaining the consent of the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 20-23)  
Sec. 23-3. - Obstructing sidewalk or street at night; placing red lights. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to place or leave any material or obstruction of any kind on or to stretch a rope across any street or sidewalk of the city during the night, without placing a sufficient number of red lights to warn all persons before reaching such obstruction that there is danger and that the street or sidewalk is obstructed. 
(Code 1982, § 20-24)  
Sec. 23-4. - Removal of obstructions. 
The chief of police and the director of public works services are authorized to remove all obstructions on city streets, avenues, alleys or sidewalks, regardless of the kind of obstructions, that may be a hazard to pedestrians or traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 20-26)  
Sec. 23-5. - Maintenance and repair of railroad tracks. 
(a)  All persons subject to the requirements of Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-3 shall use, for the maintenance and repair of any street, materials suitable for maintaining the traveled surface of the roadway in a manner conforming to the grade of the street in which the subject railroad tracks are laid, all in a condition safe for use by the public. 
(b)  The materials used for the maintenance and repair of the streets required in this section shall be of an equal or better grade than the material used in surfacing the street over which the tracks pass. The director of public works services or other designated official of the city shall have the authority to prescribe and/or approve the materials to be used for the construction of any new placement or crossing of any such tracks; and it shall be unlawful for any street or other railway company to construct any new tracks at grade within or crossing any public street of the city except upon approval by the council and according to plans approved by the director of public works services or other designated official. 
(Ord. No. 83-359, § 1, 8-30-1983)  
Sec. 23-6. - Removal of abandoned railroad tracks. 
At any time any street or other railroad company abandons any portion of its track within the city and removes the rails and other rail facilities and appurtenances from the right-of-way of the railroad company within the city, it shall be the duty of the street or other railroad company to remove, within a reasonable time after the abandonment, all tracks and other appurtenances in connection with the railway from the streets of the city in accordance with plans approved by the director of public works services, and to restore the street to a condition consistent with the maintenance of the street without the burden of the tracks, and so that the street, without the burden of the tracks, is made safe for public travel. Any such removal with respect to any railway-street crossing shall include not only the rails, ties and other appurtenances, but shall also include the restoration of all approaches to the crossing which are necessary to make the crossing consistent with the grade of the street within the vicinity of such crossing. 
(Ord. No. 83-359, § 2, 8-30-1983)  
Sec. 23-7. - Driveways. 
No driveways shall be constructed to residences or buildings from a street with curbs and gutters unless they are constructed in accordance with Drawing No. 610503, as published by the director of public works services. 
(Code 1982, § 7-142)  
Sec. 23-8. - Municipally maintained dikes. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to build any building nearer than 30 feet to any municipally maintained dike without first obtaining the written approval of the city council. 
(b)  The manager of inspection shall issue no building permits for the erection of any buildings in violation of subsection (a) of this section until it has been presented to the city council and received its approval. 
(Code 1982, § 7-141)  
Sec. 23-9. - Closing of streets; barriers and barricades; precautions. 
When any street or street intersection is in the process of construction or repair, or in the event of any emergency requiring that a street, alley or portion of a street be closed to the public, or when any public work is being done which renders it necessary to fence off any portion of a street, alley or public place within the city, the city engineer or department of public works services shall cause proper barriers or barricades to be constructed or erected, closing such street or such portion of a street, which barriers or barricades shall have placed on or in close proximity a sufficient number of red or yellow lights or flares to warn all persons before reaching such barrier or barricade that there is danger and that the street is obstructed or closed to the public, which red or yellow lights or flares shall be illuminated from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise, and which barriers or barricades shall have displayed suitable markers or signs, so that the public may know that such street or such portion of a street is closed to use by the public. 
(Code 1982, § 20-27)  
Sec. 23-10. - Driving upon streets being repaired. 
When any street or sidewalk in the city is being repaired or built and closed or barred to traffic by the city engineer or department of public works services, or other persons doing or in charge of such work, any person going upon, riding or driving any vehicle, automobile, truck or animal upon such closed street or sidewalk shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 20-28)  
Sec. 23-11. - Removal, relocation of signs; when done by city; cost to be lien. 
(a)  Every person erecting, maintaining or interested in a sign lawfully erected upon or over the streets or sidewalks of the city under the official building code of the city may be required by the manager of inspection to readjust, relocate or remove the streets and sidewalks if, in the opinion of the manager of inspection, the space covered by the sign is necessary for the extension of public utility lines, sewage lines, traffic lights or other improvements necessary for the public convenience. 
(b)  If in the opinion of the manager of inspection it becomes necessary to readjust, relocate or remove such sign, he shall give 30 days' written notice to the person who owns or who is interested in such sign, to remove, readjust or relocate the sign, and upon his failure to do so, may remove the sign. The cost shall be a charge against the property upon which the sign is located, and the cost shall be a lien on the sign and collected the same as taxes are collected. 
(c)  All sign permits shall include a provision to such effect, giving notice to the applicant of the conditions of removal, readjustment or relocation. 
(Code 1982, § 20-32)  
Sec. 23-12. - Playing ball. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in any kind of ball playing on the streets, alleys or sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-33)  
Sec. 23-13. - Cellar doors on sidewalks; permission of city council. 
Steps, stairs, cellar doors or other impediments to free passage that are above the grade of the pavement shall not be permitted upon any sidewalk or pavement without the express permission of the city council recorded upon its minutes. This permission may be rescinded at any time. 
(Code 1982, § 20-36) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to prohibit openings on sidewalks for cellar entrances, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-2.  
Sec. 23-14. - Cellar doors level with sidewalk. 
All cellar doors, trap doors or cellar chutes shall be placed or built upon a level with the grade of the sidewalk at that point. Such cellar or trap doors shall be constructed of iron grating to be approved by the director of public works services or other designated person. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this section or to refuse or fail to comply with its provisions after ten days' notice to do so. 
(Code 1982, § 20-37)  
Sec. 23-15. - Leaving cellar doors on sidewalks open. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to leave a cellar door or grating in the public square or on a street open at night, except when it is in actual use. 
(Code 1982, § 20-38)  
Sec. 23-16. - Keeping cellar doors on sidewalks secure. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to have or keep a cellar door on the public square or any street so insecure as to render the walking upon or over it unsafe or dangerous. 
(Code 1982, § 20-39)  
Sec. 23-17. - Assessment of curb and gutter improvements. 
In addition to all other provisions of pertinent law, there is adopted a policy and procedure for assessment of curb and gutter improvements on public streets within the city having no existing curbs and gutters. Improvements the cost of which is to be assessed, would include all necessary structures to provide proper drainage. The procedure to be followed by interested residents is described in the following text and will be coordinated with the department of public works services. The cost of such improvements are to be assessed against the abutting property served and benefited by the improvement. Special circumstances will affect assessments and are described in detail in subsection (1) of this section. Locations eligible for consideration will be restricted to city limits boundaries. Detailed procedures for curb and gutter improvements are as follows: 
(1)  Technical considerations. 
a.  Project costs shall include all clearing, grubbing, curb and gutter, base, asphalt, inlets, storm drain, and any other appurtenances required due to the installation of the curb and gutter along the street, except such work that may be deemed extra work as defined in subsection (1)b of this section. 
b.  If the curb and gutter plans require extra work, the assessment cost will not include the cost for extra work. Extra work is defined as the extension of sanitary sewer lines, the replacement of dilapidated utility lines, and all off-site work outside of the boundaries defined in subsection (1)c of this section. 
c.  Assessment boundaries will be limited to the lots or tracts of land abutting the streets improved, and which benefit from the improvement. All assessments will be apportioned along the abutting property based upon frontage but no assessment will be more than the increased value of the assessed property due to the improvement. Increased value will be determined prior to project approval, and the project shall not be commenced except upon approval of 51 percent of the owners as to the increased value. 
d.  All projects shall be designed and constructed by the department of public works services or by contract entered into between the city and the lowest bidder. 
(2)  Prioritization procedure. 
a.  In order to be considered for curb and gutter improvements, a written request must be submitted to the department of public works services. This request must contain the limits of desired improvements, statement of intent to waive all objections to assessment costs, and a petition signed by all affected property owners within the improvement limits. 
b.  All projects to be considered shall terminate at street intersections. 
c.  All requests shall be rated by the department of public works services prior to October 1 of each fiscal year in order to be considered for the following fiscal year. 
d.  The city council will determine, after required legal advertising and hearings, whether or not to proceed with the assessment. Funds for improvements may be advanced by the city from municipal funds, or may be provided by long-term borrowing. Assessments shall be payable annually over a period of ten years or less at the legal rate chargeable by the city for public improvement assessments. 
(Ord. No. 90-357, 7-12-1990) 
State Law reference— The Municipal Public Improvement Act, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-48-1 et seq.  
Sec. 23-18. - Unauthorized motor vehicles on public property. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate, tow, push or park any vehicle, piece of equipment or structure of any kind upon any public property not designated for vehicular use without requesting and receiving prior authorization from the city. This section shall not apply to any person or entity while in the performance of a contract with the city or the state for the construction, repair or improvement of any public way or any utility located within the public property specified in such contract. 
(b)  A person convicted of a violation of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 03-751, § 1, 8-28-2003)  
Secs. 23-19—23-50. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - TECHNICAL CODES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference— Buildings and building regulations, ch. 7. 
 
Sec. 23-51. - Construction code adopted. 
The city Standard Specifications for Construction, 1991 edition, as amended through the adoption date of this Code, are adopted. 
(Ord. No. 91-376, § 1, 6-13-1991; Ord. No. 91-435, 9-26-1991; Ord. No. 93-269, 5-13-1993)  
Sec. 23-52. - Engineering standards adopted. 
The city Engineering Standards for Construction of Public Improvements, 1991 edition, as amended through the adoption date of this Code, are adopted. 
(Ord. No. 91-374, § 1, 6-13-1991; Ord. No. 91-431, 9-26-1991; Ord. No. 93-268, 5-13-1993)  
Sec. 23-53. - Scope. 
All newly constructed streets within the corporate boundaries of the city, both those constructed by and on behalf of the city, and those constructed by private developers, to be eligible for acceptance for maintenance as public streets of the city, shall be constructed in accordance with Engineering Standards for Construction of Public Improvements (1991 edition), adopted by Ordinance No. 91-374, as amended, or Standard Specifications for Construction (1991 edition), adopted by Ordinance No. 91-376, as amended, as applicable, which standards are administered by the city engineer. Curbs, gutters and attendant drainage improvements are required with respect to such streets and must be in place prior to such acceptance. 
(Ord. No. 86-779, § 1, 12-23-1986)  
Sec. 23-54. - Accommodating utilities on highways. 
The city council formally adopts the state highway department standards for accommodating utilities on highway rights-of-way as standards (as written and future amendments) for use by the city for accommodating utilities on roads and streets under the jurisdiction of the city on those roads and streets which have or will involve the expenditure of state or federal highway funds. 
(Code 1982, § 20-20) 
Cross reference— Utilities, ch. 26. 
State Law reference— Consent of city as to use of streets for construction or operation of public utility, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-1.  
Secs. 23-55—23-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
 
Sec. 23-81. - Authorization for laying sidewalk. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to lay a sidewalk within city right-of-ways without first having obtained authorization from the city engineer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-81)  
Sec. 23-82. - Notification of construction; grades. 
(a)  When property owners plan to build, alter or repair the sidewalk in front of their property, they shall notify the city engineer for approval; and all sidewalks shall be built to the grade so established. 
(b)  All owners of property abutting on streets that have been paved shall bring their sidewalks to the grade established by the curbing of the street pavement and this shall be done whether or not the sidewalks on the present grade are in good condition. All pavements of the city shall be so constructed as to correspond with the grade of the streets and be free from any abrupt descents, by steps or otherwise and shall incline to the street at the rate of one-quarter inch in each foot of its width. 
(Code 1982, § 20-82)  
Sec. 23-83. - Establishment of grades; supervision of construction; specifications. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to lay a sidewalk in the city until a grade for such walk has been established by the city engineer. Construction shall be under the supervision of the city engineer and shall be in accordance with specifications on file in the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-83)  
Sec. 23-84. - Specifications of director of public works services; acceptance. 
Property owners repairing or building sidewalks shall make them conform to the plans and specifications set forth in the Engineering Standards for Construction of Public Improvements (1991 edition), and such sidewalks when finished shall be approved by the city engineer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-84)  
Sec. 23-85. - Material for sidewalks. 
No sidewalk shall be built of brick or of any material other than that prescribed by the Engineering Standards for Construction of Public Improvements (1991 edition) unless authorized by the city engineer. 
(Code 1982, § 20-85)  
Sec. 23-86. - Maintenance by property owners. 
All property owners abutting on the streets shall put their sidewalks in proper condition and keep them in such condition at all times. 
(Code 1982, § 20-86) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to require owners of abutting property to keep sidewalks in repair, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-2.  
Sec. 23-87. - Erecting steps on sidewalks. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, unless authorized by the city engineer, to erect steps on a sidewalk. 
(Code 1982, § 20-87) 
State Law reference— Authority of city to remove stairways on sidewalks, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-49-2.  
Sec. 23-88. - Poles not in use to be removed. 
It shall be unlawful for any telephone or electric lighting pole or part of such pole that is not actually in use, or any telephone or electric lighting wire not actually in use, to remain in or upon the streets or stretched or hung along or across any of the streets of the city. The resident managers of the various telephone and electric lighting companies shall be charged with the enforcement of the provisions of this section. It shall be unlawful for any such managers to fail or refuse to remove or have removed any such poles or wires within five days after being notified by the city or its officers to do so. 
(Code 1982, § 20-89)  
Secs. 23-89—23-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - EXCAVATIONS 
 
Sec. 23-121. - Compliance. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, except employees of the city, and Huntsville Utilities to make any excavations in or under the streets of the city, without first complying with the terms of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-61)  
Sec. 23-122. - Permits. 
(a)  Any person who shall desire to make any excavation in or under the streets or sidewalks of the city shall be required before commencing such excavation to file a written application and obtain a written permit from the engineering division. 
(b)  Any person performing any land disturbing activity shall request and obtain a permit in coordination with the Stormwater Management Manual, section 2.2.2, grading permits. 
(Code 1982, § 20-62)  
Sec. 23-123. - Responsibility for damage to sewers and streets. 
(a)  Any person who makes any excavation in or under the streets or sidewalks of the city shall be held responsible for any damage he may do to the sewer, street or sidewalk. He shall restore the street and sidewalk to as good condition as it was at the beginning of his work. 
(b)  Should any person fail to make such repairs to the streets and sidewalks as are necessary to restore them to as good condition as they were at the beginning of his work, the street superintendent shall make such repairs; and for such work, there shall be made by the city a reasonable charge against such person. Where such work is on a paved street or sidewalk the minimum charge shall be $3.00 for each square yard or any part of a yard. Nothing in this section shall be construed to release from liability any person who may dig into or out any street or sidewalk and leave it in an unsafe condition. Any person who fails or refuses to pay any such charges made against him by the city within five working days after notice by the director of public works services of such charges against him shall then and there forfeit the license for any occupation which requires excavating in or under the streets and sidewalks of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 20-64)  
Sec. 23-124. - Leaving excavation open. 
If any person making any excavation in or near a street or sidewalk shall leave such excavation open, so as to endanger persons in passing along the street or sidewalk, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 20-65)  
Sec. 23-125. - Fences required around excavations abutting sidewalks or streets.
