(b)  The director of parking and public transit, or his designee, may charge up to an additional $1.00 per space for event parking when the size and scope of the event requires extensive support services such as special revenue collection or transit activities. 
(c)  Effective October 1, 2006, monthly parking rates will increase to $48.00 per month per space. 
(d)  Effective October 1, 2008, monthly parking rates will increase to $52.00 per month per space. 
(e)  Effective October 1, 2010, monthly parking rates will increase to $56.00 per month per space. 
(f)  Any new business that locates in the central business district (as defined in section 25-242), or any existing business that relocates to the central business district will be eligible to enroll in the downtown business incentive program during the period from February 9, 2017 through February 8, 2018. Any business located within the central business district as of February 10, 2017 shall not be eligible for the program. Enrollment in the program shall entitle qualified businesses to receive the following special parking rates at city parking facilities listed in section 25-244: 
Any business that has between five and ten full-time employees shall be eligible to purchase monthly parking at 50 percent of the monthly rate established by this section 25-245 for a period of one year from its enrollment in the downtown business incentive program. 
Any business that has between 11 and 20 full-time employees shall be eligible to purchase monthly parking at 50 percent of the then-existing monthly rate for a period of two years from its enrollment in the downtown business incentive program. 
Any business that has 21 or more full-time employees shall be eligible to purchase monthly parking at 50 percent of the then-existing monthly rate for a period of three years from its enrollment in the downtown business incentive program. 
The authority to determine eligibility for the program shall rest with the director of parking and public transit, whose decision shall be final. The director shall designate which city parking facilities will be utilized for the program and shall be authorized to discontinue the use of certain facilities or to terminate the enrollment period prior to February 9, 2018 if parking demand exceeds availability. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 4, 4-11-1996; Ord. No. 97-291, § 4, 4-10-1997; Ord. No. 05-55, § 2, 2-10-2005; Ord. No. 07-354, § 2, 4-26-2007; Ord. No. 10-739, 10-14-2010; Ord. No. 13-654, 9-26-2013; Ord. No. 17-045 , 2-9-2017)  
Sec. 25-246. - On-street meter rates. 
(a)  Parking meter rates at designated meter space parking facilities shall be established by the director of parking and public transit up to a maximum rate of $0.50 per hour. 
(b)  All on-street parking shall be free to the public after 5:00 p.m. on each day, except for parking at meters located on the west side of Church Street between Clinton Avenue and Williams Avenue, which shall be enforced from 8:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight seven days per week. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 5, 4-11-1996; Ord. No. 97-291, § 5, 4-10-1997)  
Sec. 25-247. - Convention groups; rate modification; city-owned parking facilities. 
Notwithstanding the fees and rates established for city-owned parking facilities, the Huntsville-Madison County Convention and Visitors Bureau and the Von Braun Center shall be authorized to negotiate with the director of parking and public transit or his designee parking discounts with large convention groups. The director of parking and public transit or his designee will also have the authority to negotiate parking agreements with other agencies that want to use city parking facilities for special events; however, these events must not impact parking for VBC events that are already scheduled. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 6, 4-11-1996; Ord. No. 97-291, § 6, 4-10-1997)  
Sec. 25-248. - Buses. 
Bus parking shall be provided as required at on-street and off-street parking facilities as determined by the director of parking and public transit, or his designee, at a charge of $10.00 per bus. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 7, 4-11-1996; Ord. No. 05-55, § 3, 2-10-2005)  
Sec. 25-249. - Control devices in off-street parking facilities; duty of director of parking and public transit. 
The director of parking and public transit shall cause to be installed in each off-street parking facility of the city appropriate control devices, including but not limited to meters, gates, coin or token receptacles and gates actuated by magnetic cards, so that appropriate means will be available at all times whereby members of the public parking in such facilities may pay the established charge for parking in such facility or otherwise verify prior to leaving such facility that the established charge for the parking service has been paid. 
(Code 1982, § 14-184; Ord. No. 96-124, § 8, 4-11-1996)  
Sec. 25-250. - Compliance. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to remove a vehicle parked in any off-street parking facility of the city without first paying the established charge, either by paying the charge to the designated attendant, by depositing the proper amount of money in coin or token receptacles, by displaying upon the vehicle an appropriate permit indicating that the charge has been prepaid or by the use of a magnetic card device for which the charge has been prepaid. In all cases where a permit or magnetic card has been acquired as evidence that the permittee has paid the established charge to the city, it shall be unlawful for any person to park any motor vehicle or exit any city parking facility while the permit has expired or is delinquent according to the established rules of the department of parking and public transit for its issuance. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 9, 4-11-1996)  
Sec. 25-251. - Use of parking facilities restricted. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the operator of a vehicle to park or leave standing a vehicle upon a city-owned parking facility for a period longer than 24 hours without first making arrangements in advance with the department of parking and public transit. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing in any off-street parking facility of the city using gates for revenue control, or within any multilevel parking structure, any vehicle of 80 inches or more in overall width or 78 inches or more in overall height. 
(Ord. No. 96-124, § 10, 4-11-1996)  
Secs. 25-252—25-270. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - PARKING METERS 
 
Sec. 25-271. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Operator means and includes every individual who shall operate a vehicle as the owner, or as the agent, employee or permittee of the owner, or is in actual physical control of a vehicle. 
Park and parking mean the standing of a vehicle, whether occupied or not, upon a street or in an off-street parking facility otherwise than in obedience to traffic regulations, signs or signals or an involuntary stopping of the vehicle by reason of causes beyond the control of the operator of the vehicle. 
Parking meter means and includes any mechanical device or meter not inconsistent with this division placed or erected for the regulation of parking by authority of this division. Each parking meter installed shall indicate by proper legend the legal parking time established by the city and when operated shall at all times indicate the balance of legal parking time, and at the expiration of such period shall indicate illegal or overtime parking. 
Parking meter space means any space within a parking meter zone or adjacent to a parking meter in an off-street parking facility and which is duly designated for the parking of a single vehicle by lines painted or adjacent to or adjoining the parking meters. 
(Code 1982, § 14-201) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-272. - Designation of parking spaces. 
The director of parking and public transit is directed and authorized to mark off individual parking spaces as directed or authorized by ordinance, such parking spaces to be designated by lines painted or by appropriate signs. At each space so marked off, it shall be unlawful to park any vehicle in such a way that such vehicle shall not be entirely within the limits of the space so designated. It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle in a parking space marked and posted for vehicles of certain designated maximum length or width, having an overall length or width in excess of that posted. 
(Code 1982, § 14-202)  
Sec. 25-273. - Bus stops, taxicab stands. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed as prohibiting the director of parking and public transit from providing for bus stops, taxicab stands and other matters of similar nature, including the loading and unloading of trucks, vans or other commercial vehicles. 
(Code 1982, § 14-203)  
Sec. 25-274. - Designation of loading zones. 
The director of parking and public transit is authorized to mark off loading zones in the parking meter areas as directed by city ordinance, such loading zones to be designated by painted lines or by appropriate signs. Each space so marked shall be used only for the purpose of loading and unloading. 
(Code 1982, § 14-204)  
Sec. 25-275. - Installation of meters. 
In parking meter areas, there shall be installed parking meters immediately adjacent to the parking spaces provided for by city ordinance. 
(Code 1982, § 14-205)  
Sec. 25-276. - Arrangement and maintenance of meters. 
The director of parking and public transit shall be responsible for the maintenance of parking meters. Each device or parking meter shall be so set and arranged as to display a signal showing legal parking upon the deposit of the appropriate coins, lawful money of the United States of America, for the period of time prescribed by ordinance. Each device or parking meter shall be so arranged that upon the expiration of the lawful time limit, it will indicate by a proper visible signal that the lawful parking period has expired and in such cases the right of such vehicle to occupy such space shall cease and the operator, owner, possessor or manager shall be subject to the penalties provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1982, § 14-206)  
Sec. 25-277. - Operation of meters. 
(a)  Except in a period of emergency determined by an officer of the fire department or police department, or in compliance with the directions of a police officer or traffic control sign or signal, when any vehicle shall be parked in any parking space alongside or next to which a parking meter is located, the operator of such vehicle shall, upon entering such parking meter space, immediately deposit or cause to be deposited in such meter such proper coin of the United States as is required for such parking meter and as is designated by proper directions on the meter, and as required by the directions on the meter. Failure to deposit such proper coin, when so required, shall constitute a violation of this division. Upon the deposit of such coin, the parking space may be lawfully occupied by such vehicle during the period of time which has been prescribed for the part of the street in which such parking space is located. 
(b)  Any person placing a vehicle in a parking meter space adjacent to a meter which indicates that unused time has been left in the meter by the previous occupant of the space shall not be required to deposit a coin so long as his occupancy of such space does not exceed the indicated unused parking time. If such vehicle shall remain parked in any such parking space beyond the parking time limit set for such parking space, and if the meter shall indicate such illegal parking, such vehicle shall be considered as parking overtime and beyond the period of legal parking time; and such parking shall be deemed a violation of this division. 
(Code 1982, § 14-207)  
Sec. 25-278. - Hours of operation of parking facilities. 
The hours of operation and enforcement of parking facilities shall be as follows: 
(1)  Downtown metered on-street Zone 1—8:00 a.m.—6:00 p.m., except Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. 
(2)  Huntsville Public Library and City Hall Zone—consisting of Lot C and on-street meters along Fountain Circle—8:00 a.m.—9:00 p.m. except Sundays and holidays. 
(3)  Von Braun Center on-street meter zone along Monroe Street, Pollard Street and Gallatin Street—8:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight, seven days a week. 
(4)  Off-street parking facilities—24 hours daily, seven days a week, unless otherwise posted or marked. 
(Code 1982, § 14-208)  
Sec. 25-279. - Vehicles to be parked in marked spaces. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park any vehicle across any line or marking or a parking meter space or in such position that the vehicle shall not be entirely within the area designated by such lines or markings, provided that trucks longer than 22 feet may park parallel adjacent to two or more meters subject to the provisions of section 25-290. 
(Code 1982, § 14-209)  
Sec. 25-280. - Collection and disposition of coins. 
It shall be the duty of the director of parking and public transit to make regular collections of the money deposited in parking meters, and it shall be his duty to remove from the parking meters the coins so deposited in such meters and to deliver such coins to the city clerk-treasurer, who shall deposit such funds as required by law. 
(Code 1982, § 14-210)  
Sec. 25-281. - Overtime parking; deposit of coin to extend time. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, allow, permit or suffer any vehicle registered in the name of or operated by such person to be parked overtime, or beyond the period of legal parking time established as described on the parking meter; or for any person, whether or not he is the owner or operator, to deposit in any parking meter any coin for the purpose of parking beyond the maximum legal parking time for the particular parking meter zone. 
(Code 1982, § 14-211)  
Sec. 25-282. - Parking adjacent to expired meter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any vehicle to remain or be placed in any parking space adjacent to any parking meter while such meter is displaying a signal indicating that the vehicle occupying such parking space has already been parked beyond the period prescribed for such parking space. 
(Code 1982, § 14-212)  
Sec. 25-283. - Occupying vehicle overnight. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to park overnight and occupy a recreational vehicle, motor home, housecar, travel trailer, pickup camper, van or other motor vehicle having sleeping quarters on the streets of the city or in a city municipal parking facility unless specifically permitted and posted. 
(Code 1982, § 14-213)  
Sec. 25-284. - Covering meters. 
It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the director of parking and public transit or his representative, to place or cause to be placed any meter bag or other device with the intent of covering a parking meter or reserving a parking space on the streets of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 14-214)  
Sec. 25-285. - Report of parking violations; general duties. 
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and his assistants and the designated enforcement officers of the department of parking and public transit to check the parking spaces and meters and report the violation of this division as provided in sections 25-286—25-288. 
(Code 1982, § 14-217)  
Sec. 25-286. - Parking violations information reported; notice. 
The officers designated in section 25-285 shall: 
(1)  Keep an account of and report the number of each parking meter which indicates that the vehicle occupying the parking space adjacent to such parking meter is or has been parked in violation of any of the provisions of this division, the date and hour of such violation, the make and the state license number of such vehicle, and any other facts a knowledge of which is necessary to a thorough understanding of the circumstances attending such violation. 
(2)  Attach to such vehicle a notice stating that it has been parked in violation of this division and instructing the owner or operator to report at a certain designated time and place to the municipal court in regard to such violation. Each such owner or operator may, within five days after such notice is attached to such vehicle, pay the sum of $10.00 to the clerk of the municipal court as a penalty for and in full satisfaction of a parking meter violation. 
(Code 1982, § 14-218)  
Sec. 25-287. - Failure to pay fine for violation. 
If a violator does not appear in response to the notice affixed to a motor vehicle within a period of five days, the municipal court shall send to the registered owner of the motor vehicle to which the notice was affixed a letter informing him of the violation and warning him that if such letter is disregarded for a period of five days, a complaint will be filed and warrant of arrest issued. 
(Code 1982, § 14-219)  
Sec. 25-288. - Failure to respond to parking violation notices. 
If a violator does not appear in response to the notice affixed to a motor vehicle or to a letter sent to the owner of the motor vehicle by the municipal court within ten days after such notice was attached to such vehicle or mailed to him respectively, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor regardless of the disposition of the case for parking meter violations. 
(Code 1982, § 14-220)  
Sec. 25-289. - Meter bags for special church events. 
The director of parking and public transit is authorized to install meter bags at no cost to religious institutions for their abutting metered spaces only, to reserve such spaces for weddings, funerals, revivals and other special major events where quantities of parking spaces are required. 
(Code 1982, § 14-221)  
Sec. 25-290. - Meter bags for contractors. 
The director of parking and public transit is authorized to install meter bags permitting contractor vehicles and equipment to park in meter zones 1 and 10 for the construction, renovation or repairs to business or residential establishments. Daily charges for the meter bags shall be the equivalent of eight hours' purchase of meter time. 
(Code 1982, § 14-222)  
Secs. 25-291—25-320. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SCHOOL TRAFFIC 
 
Sec. 25-321. - Traffic study. 
The city engineer is authorized to make or cause to be made within the city studies of traffic problems within the city, as they pertain to both vehicular and pedestrian traffic within the vicinity of public and private schools. Such study shall include the areas within the city within the immediate vicinity of public and private schools and in addition shall include other areas over and along the public streets of the city where children customarily cross public streets on the way to and from school. 
(Code 1982, § 14-327)  
Sec. 25-322. - School crossings; signs; speed limit. 
The city engineer, after having conducted a study of traffic conditions as required in section 25-321, shall cause to be designated and marked off with signs and appropriate markings on the surface of the street certain areas along and upon the public streets of the city which shall be designated and known as school crossings. From and after such time as signs as provided in section 25-323 shall be erected to warn the traveling public, it shall be unlawful to drive a motor vehicle over, along or through a school crossing at a rate of speed greater than 25 miles per hour or such other lesser speed which shall have been determined to be the maximum rate of speed allowable by such a traffic study provided for in section 25-321 after such lesser speed limit as determined by the study shall be approved by the mayor. The city shall designate, by appropriate markings upon the signs, the hours of the day during which the special regulations shall be in effect and the maximum speed limit allowable. 
(Code 1982, § 14-328)  
Sec. 25-323. - Signs. 
In carrying out the authority of sections 25-321 and 25-322, the city engineer or other person designated to erect the signs required under these sections shall designate school crossings with traditional signs and markings in common ordinary use for such purpose, or by use of any other sign or device approved by the Manual of Uniform Traffic Control Devices as published by the United States Bureau of Public Roads. 
(Code 1982, § 14-329)  
Sec. 25-324. - Direction of traffic. 
(a)  Traffic survey; required purpose. The city engineer is authorized, empowered and directed to make or cause to be made surveys pertaining to traffic conditions in the vicinity of schools within the city. These surveys shall particularly pertain to the direction of traffic within the vicinity of schools to the end that traffic over and along public streets in the vicinity of schools shall be required to move in a harmonious and safe manner. 
(b)  Designation of one-way streets. The city engineer is empowered to determine as a result of such surveys of traffic over and along the public streets of the city within the vicinity of schools that vehicular traffic shall be required to proceed one way only over and along certain portions of certain streets. 
(c)  Signs; required, effect of erection. In exercising the power granted in this section, the city engineer may provide that traffic movements over and along portions of designated public streets will be required to move one way only during certain hours; however, the city engineer or other designated person shall place or cause to be placed portable or permanent signs at the entrances to such areas to warn the traveling public of such regulations and restrictions upon the movement of traffic. 
(Code 1982, § 14-330)  
Sec. 25-325. - Parking areas; designation. 
The board of education is authorized and empowered to determine areas on school property to be used for the parking of automobiles and other motor vehicles and to post appropriate signs and markings to warn the public of such regulation. In exercising this authority, the board of education may designate certain areas on school property where only teachers and employees may park their vehicles, certain areas for students and certain areas for visitors, such regulations to be posted by appropriate signs and markings to warn the public. 
(Code 1982, § 14-331)  
Sec. 25-326. - Obedience to parking area signs. 
From and after such time as signs are in place, which signs shall be so designated and worded as to warn the public of parking regulations, it shall be unlawful for any person to park or leave standing an automobile or motor vehicle on school property within the city except in conformity with such regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 14-332)  
Sec. 25-327. - Driving on school grounds. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive any motor vehicle, including motor-driven cycles, upon the grounds of any public school except in the driveways, access roads or other public places set aside by the board of education for such purpose, except at the express direction or permission of appropriate school authorities. 
(Code 1982, § 14-333)  
Sec. 25-328. - Turning movements at exits from school grounds. 
(a)  Regulation. The director of parking and public transit is authorized and empowered to control turning movements of automobiles and motor vehicles at all exits from public school grounds to the public streets of the city. 
(b)  Signs required. The director of parking and public transit shall place or cause to be placed appropriate signs along the public streets at such exits from public schools as he deems necessary and desirable for the safety of the traveling public, which signs shall warn the traveling public of the restrictions upon turning movements. These signs shall read "No Right Turn," "No Left Turn" or "No Turn" as the director of parking and public transit may from time to time determine. 
(Code 1982, § 14-334(a), (b))  
Secs. 25-329—25-360. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - VEHICLE EQUIPMENT AND CONDITION[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference— Vehicle equipment, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-210 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 25-361. - Condition of brakes. 
The chief of police, or any police officer, is authorized to require an inspection of the brakes of any motor-driven vehicle and to disapprove any brakes which he finds are not adequate. All such brakes shall be maintained in good working order. 
(Code 1982, § 14-251(b)) 
State Law reference— Brakes, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-212.  
Sec. 25-362. - Mufflers; prevention of noise. 
Every motor vehicle shall at all times be equipped with a muffler in good working order. 
(Code 1982, § 14-255) 
State Law reference— Mufflers, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-216.  
Secs. 25-363—25-380. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLES SCATTERING LOAD[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference— Vehicles spilling loads, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-76; littering, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 13A-7-29, 32-5A-60; securing vehicle loads, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-75. 
 
Sec. 25-381. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Construction and demolition materials means lumber, roofing and sheathing, scraps, dirt, stone, brick, ceramic, rubble, broken concrete, plaster, conduit, pipe, wire, insulation, carpet or carpet padding, gutters, sheetrock, siding, HVAC, or other similar material. 
Debris means the remains of any material broken down and tracked onto any highway by any vehicle, including but not limited to dirt, gravel, mud, rocks, brush and any other loose material. 
Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable wastes resulting from the handling, storage, preparation, cooking, serving and consumption of food, including wastes from markets, storage facilities, or the handling and sale of produce and other food products. 
Litter means all solid waste that can be or is subject to being blown or carried from place to place by the elements, including but not limited to cigarette butts, rubbish, refuse, waste material, garbage, dead animals or fowl, offal, paper, glass, cans, bottles, trash, scrap metal, debris and any foreign substance of whatever kind and description, and whether or not it is of value. 
Load means any material put in, on or drawn by any vehicle for transport, including but not limited to garbage, litter, trash, rubbish, refuse, loose material, debris, process and fill materials, construction and demolition materials, yard waste, and any foreign substance of whatever kind and description, whether putrescible or nonputrescible, and whether or not it is of value. Loads shall not include people. 
Loose material means any material that is hauled on, in or by any vehicle that could spill, drop, sift, leak, blow or otherwise escape the vehicle, but not limited to garbage, litter, trash, rubbish, refuse, loose material, debris, process and fill materials, construction and demolition materials, yard waste, and any foreign substance of whatever kind and description, whether putrescible or nonputrescible, and whether or not it is of value. 
Process and fill materials means all materials used for fill or that are the result of a specific process. This term includes but is not limited to rock, gravel (any aggregate), sand, dirt, asphalt, pug mix, brick, cinder blocks, cement, concrete, tar, petroleum products, liquid and similar materials. 
Refuse means all solid or semisolid waste resulting from industrial processes and manufacturing operations, such as food processing wastes, boiler and house cinders, wood, plastic, metal scraps and shavings, byproducts accumulated as a result of treatment of liquid waste, etc.; putrescible and nonputrescible animal and vegetable waste from the handling, storage and sale of produce and meats; street sweepings, dirt, leaves, catchbasin dirt and contents of litter receptacles. This term includes but is not limited to garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead animals or fowl, offal, abandoned motor vehicles, and solid market or industrial wastes. 
Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, including but not limited to paper, cardboard, rags, cartons, wood, boxes, excelsior, cloth, furniture, bedding, leather, rubber, plastics, yard trimmings, leaves, glass, crockery, metals, metal cans, metal foils, metal furniture, mineral refuse and similar materials. 
Special vehicle means any vehicle specially manufactured to transport or draw a particular type of load which is used solely in strict accordance with the purpose for which the special vehicle was manufactured, and, in order to accomplish this purpose, is designed without solid sides or a tailgate, or so that the load will extend above a point four inches below the top of the sides of the special vehicle, or so that a tarpaulin or confinement system cannot be rigged or the load covered, secured or sealed while still allowing the special vehicle to accomplish its purpose. Exceptions in this article related to special vehicles shall be narrowly construed so that a vehicle qualifying as a special vehicle shall be exempt only from those requirements of this article which are inherent in the design and purpose of the special vehicle, as manufactured, but not from any other requirements of this article which are not inherent in the design and purpose of the special vehicle, as manufactured. 
Tarpaulin or confinement system means a solid or semisolid cover or system placed and secured over open-topped vehicles to secure loads and of sufficient and appropriate size, structure and strength to prevent the dispersal of loads and loose material from the vehicle. A tarpaulin or confinement system may be constructed from any suitable material, including but not limited to canvas, polyethylene, rubberized cloth, netting, ropes, straps, chains, cables, and racks with a restraining or enclosing system. 
Trash means any nonputrescible solid wastes, including but not limited to yard clippings, leaves, wood, compost, tree limbs, tree trunks, furniture, bedding, appliances, paper, cardboard, plastics, wrappings, cans, tires and similar materials. 
Vehicle means any device in, upon or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon the highway, except devices moved by human power or used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. This term includes but is not limited to trucks, trailers and automobiles. This term includes special vehicles unless specifically denoted otherwise. 
Yard waste means grass, leaves, yard trimmings, shrubbery clippings, trees, branches, palm fronds and all other miscellaneous vegetation. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 2, 2-27-1997) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-382. - Penalties. 
Any person who violates or fails or refuses to obey or comply with any provision of this article shall upon conviction be punished, in addition to such other punishment as may be provided by the court, by minimum fines and penalties, for a first conviction of $100.00 or by imprisonment for not more than ten days; for conviction of a second offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, by a fine of $200.00 or by imprisonment for not more than 30 days or by both such fine and imprisonment; for conviction of a third or subsequent offense committed within one year after the date of the first offense, by a fine of $500.00 or by imprisonment for not more than three months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 12, 2-27-1997) 
State Law reference— Penalties for ordinance violations, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-45-9.  
Sec. 25-383. - Intent. 
The spilling of vehicle loads upon the public streets and other public ways of the city is a dangerous and blighting factor which damages, deteriorates and depreciates these public streets and other public ways, as well as adjacent and surrounding property. The city council finds that the spilling of vehicle loads is a public nuisance and recognizes that appropriate measures must be taken to keep public streets, other public ways and adjacent and surrounding property free from debris and other materials spilling from vehicles. Debris and other materials spilling from vehicles pose a danger of physical injury and property damage to motorists, pedestrians and other inhabitants of the city and cause the proliferation of trash, garbage, litter, and other dangerous or unsanitary debris within the city. The prevention of the spilling of vehicle loads and the removal of spillage from streets is necessary to prevent proliferation of this problem. This article is enacted to protect, promote and preserve the safety and welfare of the citizens of the city through the reduction, control and prevention of vehicle spillage within the city. The council does not intend for this article to conflict with any existing state law. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 1, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-384. - Presumption. 
If an article of litter or loose material bearing a person's name is discovered on any public property not designated for the throwing, dumping or depositing of solid waste, including public streets, sidewalks, gutters, alleys, bodies of water, drainage ditches, storm sewers, sanitary sewers or other property over or with respect to which the city has an easement, or on private property of another without such person's permission, then a rebuttable, prima facie presumption shall arise that the person whose name appears on the article threw, spilled, scattered, dumped, placed, deposited or otherwise caused the article to be thrown, spilled, scattered, blown, dumped, placed or deposited at the place where it was found; however, this presumption, if unrebutted at trial, shall not serve as a basis for a conviction for violation of any provision of chapter 22 in the absence of other evidence of such nature and degree as required by law. 
(Ord. No. 97-814, § 1, 11-13-1997)  
Sec. 25-385. - Exemptions. 
The following activities are exempt from the provisions of sections 25-387, 25-389 and 25-392: 
(1)  The deposit or spreading of sand or other substances, not otherwise expressly prohibited, on the streets of the city for the purpose of street construction, maintenance or repair, or maintenance of utilities or the use of water or other substances in cleaning or maintaining public streets or public ways, when such acts are performed by a city, state or federal governmental entity or a contractor conducting such actions pursuant to a valid contract with a city, state or federal governmental entity. Vehicles carrying loads or loose material covered by this subsection, while in transit to a work site, must satisfy all requirements and prohibitions of this article. 
(2)  The deposit of sand or other substances, not otherwise expressly prohibited, on the streets of the city for the purpose of increasing traction when such acts are performed by a city, state or federal governmental entity or a contractor conducting such actions pursuant to a valid contract with a city, state or federal governmental entity, or by motorists spreading sand from public receptacles. 
(3)  Vehicles hauling loads or loose material that have reached their final destination and are preparing to unload. Vehicles carrying loads or loose material covered by this subsection, while in transit to their final destination, must satisfy all requirements and prohibitions of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 10, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-386. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the police department. Any sworn officer of the police department is empowered to issue citations to appear in municipal court to answer charges for violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 11, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-387. - Spilling vehicle loads prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or permit to be operated any vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways of the city when such vehicle is so constructed, maintained or loaded that the vehicle's load or loose material is permitted to blow, spill, drop, bounce, fall, waste or otherwise escape from such vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways or adjacent or surrounding property. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 3, 2-27-1997) 
State Law reference— Vehicles scattering loads, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-76.  
Sec. 25-388. - Solid sides, tailgate and solid top or tarpaulin or confinement system required with exception for special vehicles. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material unless the vehicle has solid sides and a tailgate, and is further equipped with a solid top or so rigged that a tarpaulin or confinement system can be spread or secured tightly over the top of such vehicle and is further equipped with a tarpaulin or confinement system. Any one or more of the requirements imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. Each vehicle shall have signs painted on both doors or, if the vehicle does not have doors, then on both sides of the vehicle indicating the correct name of the hauler and his telephone number. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 4, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-389. - Covering, securing, or sealing of loads required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material unless the vehicle is covered, secured or sealed to the extent that there will be no loss or spillage during haulage to cause littering of streets or highways or cause a nuisance or hazard to the public health. The requirement imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 5, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-390. - Securing of boat loads required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a boat upon the public streets or other public ways of the city unless all food, coolers, trash, life jackets, vests, skis, ropes, fishing gear, other equipment and loose material are stored and secured to prevent these items from blowing, spilling, dropping, bouncing, falling, wasting or otherwise escaping onto public streets or other public ways or adjacent and surrounding property. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 6, 2-27-1997) 
State Law reference— Securing of loads, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5-75.  
Sec. 25-391. - Maximum load height imposed. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to haul a load or loose material in a vehicle which does not have a solid top unless the load or loose material remains at least four inches below the top of the sides of such vehicle as measured at the front, back and side walls of the vehicle. The use of a tarpaulin or confining system on a vehicle shall not excuse any person from compliance with the provisions of this section. The requirement imposed by this section shall not apply to a special vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 7, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-392. - Tracking debris onto public streets or other public ways prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to drive, operate or permit to be operated any vehicle upon the public streets or other public ways of the city unless the vehicle is free of debris and trash that could be tracked onto the public streets or other public ways of the city in such a manner as to: 
(1)  Cause a safety hazard; 
(2)  Create rough driving conditions; 
(3)  Impede the flow of water in gutters or along streets or that would tend to clog drains, ditches, or sewers; 
(4)  Create a nuisance from dust generated by driving over debris and trash which has been tracked onto the highway; or 
(5)  Create a likelihood of gravel, stone, other debris or trash being thrown into the windshield of other vehicles. 
The requirements of this section shall not apply to the tracking of debris onto public streets and other public ways of the city if the public streets and public ways are part of a construction or maintenance work site. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 8, 2-27-1997)  
Sec. 25-393. - Clearing of streets by persons responsible for spills or tracking. 
Any person operating or permitting to be operated a vehicle or hauling a boat in violation of this article shall immediately cause the public street or other public way or surrounding and adjacent property to be cleared of spilled or tracked material so long as the person does not endanger himself or any other person. If traffic or other conditions are such that it would not be safe to remove the spilled or tracked material, the person responsible for the spilled or tracked material shall immediately notify the police department and request assistance. The person responsible for spilled or tracked material shall bear the costs involved in the containment and removal of the spilled or tracked material. 
(Ord. No. 97-91, § 9, 2-27-1997) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23.  
Secs. 25-394—25-420. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - BICYCLES[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference— Bicycles and play vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-260 et seq. 
 
Sec. 25-421. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Bikeway means any facility that explicitly provides for bicycle travel. There are three classes of bikeways: 
(1)  Bikepath. A bikepath is a completely separated right-of-way designated for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
(2)  Bikelane. A bikelane is a restricted right-of-way designated for the semiexclusive use of bicycles, usually on the street alignment. 
(3)  Bikeroute. A bikeroute is a shared right-of-way designated as a bikeway by signs placed on vertical posts or stencilled on the pavement. Right-of-way may be shared with either or both motor vehicles and pedestrians. 
(Code 1982, § 14-291) 
Cross reference— Definitions generally, § 1-2.  
Sec. 25-422. - Rider responsibility. 
Every person riding a bicycle upon the streets of this city shall be granted all the rights and shall be subject to all the duties applicable to the driver of a motor vehicle by the laws of this state declaring rules of the road applicable to vehicles or by the traffic ordinances of this city applicable to the driver of a vehicle, except as to special regulations in this article and except as to those provisions of law and ordinances which by their very nature can have no application. 
(Code 1982, § 14-300(a)) 
State Law reference— Similar provisions, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-260.  
Sec. 25-423. - Condition. 
The rider of a bicycle shall be responsible for maintaining his bicycle in a safe mechanical condition. 
(Code 1982, § 14-300(b))  
Sec. 25-424. - Towing. 
A bicycle operator shall not tow any vehicle or person except that bicycle trailers properly attached to the bicycle which allow for the firm control and braking may be used. 
(Code 1982, § 14-302) 
State Law reference— Clinging to vehicles, Code of Ala. 1975, § 32-5A-262.  
Sec. 25-425. - Riding on sidewalks. 
Bicycles and tricycles shall not be ridden on the sidewalks of this city unless such sidewalk has been designated as a part of a bikeway. 
(Code 1982, § 14-306) 
Cross reference— Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23.  
Sec. 25-426. - Trick riding. 
A person riding a bicycle shall not weave in and out of traffic or ride in an irregular or reckless manner such as zigzagging, stunting or otherwise ride with disregard for his own safety or the safety of others. It shall be unlawful for any person to ride a bicycle without having at least one hand upon the handlebars. 
(Code 1982, § 14-308)  
Sec. 25-427. - Parking. 
The operator shall not park his bicycle upon a sidewalk in such a manner as to obstruct pedestrian traffic. Bicycles shall not be parked upon the streets in spaces designated for the use of a motor vehicle. 
(Code 1982, § 14-309)  
Sec. 25-428. - Warning for safe operation. 
The operator shall give an audible warning whenever necessary to ensure the safe operation of the bicycle; however, the use of a siren or whistle is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 14-313)  
Sec. 25-429. - Bicycle alterations. 
No bicycle shall be operated upon a street with handlebars so raised that the hands of the operator are above his shoulders while gripping them. Any alteration to extend the fork of a bicycle except by a commercially manufactured fork is prohibited. 
(Code 1982, § 14-314)  
Secs. 25-430—25-460. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IX. - VISUAL OBSTRUCTIONS 
 
Sec. 25-461. - Enforcement. 
The provisions of this article shall be enforced by the city engineer. When the city engineer shall find that any provision of this article is being violated, he shall issue written notification to the person owning, renting or leasing or otherwise in possession of the real property upon which the violation exists, of such violation, indicating the nature of the violation and the necessary action required to correct the violation. If the violation is not removed or abated within 14 days from the written notification, the city engineer may issue a citation to the person responsible for the violation, directing him to appear in the municipal court at a time and on a date stated in the citation to answer to charges of violations of this article, which charges shall be stated in the citation. It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for any person to fail to appear in municipal court at the time and place stated in a citation issued by the city engineer pursuant to this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-46)  
Sec. 25-462. - Street intersections; visibility area delineated. 
(a)  It shall be a misdemeanor for any person owning, renting, leasing or otherwise in possession of real property at intersecting streets to install, set out or maintain or allow the installation, setting out or maintenance of any sign, hedge, fence, shrubbery, natural growth or other obstruction to the view, whether movable or stationary, higher than 30 inches (76.2 centimeters) above the level of the adjacent intersection. 
(b)  The obstruction shall not be placed in that triangular area between the property line and a diagonal line joining points on the property line, 30 feet (9.1 meters) from the point of their intersection. 
(c)  In the case of rounded property corners, that triangular area shall be between the property lines extended and a diagonal line joining points on the property lines, 30 feet (9.1 meters) from the point of their intersection. 
(d)  In both subsections (b) and (c) of this section, such area within the triangle that encroaches within the interior of the setback lines applicable to any lot or parcel of real property by and through the zoning ordinances of this city as fully set forth in this Code shall be exempted from the application of this section and shall not be deemed a part of the visibility area. 
(e)  Subsections (b), (c) and (d) of this section shall also apply to the intersection of a public street right-of-way and a railroad right-of-way. 
(Code 1982, § 20-47)  
Sec. 25-463. - Driveways; visibility area delineated. 
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person owning, renting, leasing or otherwise in possession of real property to install, set out or maintain or allow the installation, setting out or maintenance of any sign, hedge, fence, shrubbery, natural growth or other obstruction to the view, whether movable or stationary, higher than 30 inches (76.2 centimeters) above the level of the adjacent roadway on any lot where a private drive enters a street within the triangular area formed by the street property line, the private drive-edge line and a line connecting them at ten feet (three meters) from their intersection. 
(Code 1982, § 20-48)  
Sec. 25-464. - Outside the triangular area. 
It shall be a misdemeanor for any person owning, renting, leasing or otherwise in possession of real property to install, set out or maintain or to allow the installation, setting out or maintenance of any sign, hedge, fence, shrubbery, natural growth or other obstruction to the view, whether movable or stationary, but outside the triangular area as defined in sections 25-462 and 25-463, if the city engineer shall determine, after notice and hearing, that maintenance of such obstruction is, because of the peculiar topography at or near the intersection, an actual hazard, and is being maintained outside the setback lines applicable to the lot or parcel of real property upon which it is situated under the applicable zoning ordinance or regulations. 
(Code 1982, § 20-49)  
Sec. 25-465. - Exceptions. 
Sections 25-462 and 25-463 shall not apply to small trees that are not more than 12 inches (30.5 centimeters) in diameter (trimmed to the trunk), that are at least 15 feet above the level of the intersection and that are planted so as to leave a clear and unobstructed crossview. Sections 25-462 and 25-463 also shall not apply to fire hydrants; public utility poles; street markers; traffic control devices; existing permanent buildings; and signs mounted 15 feet or more above the ground the supports of which do not constitute an obstruction as defined in sections 25-462 and 25-463. 
(Code 1982, § 20-50)  
Sec. 25-466. - Existing obstructions. 
Except as provided in this article, no obstruction to cross-visibility shall be excepted from the application of this article because of its being in existence at the time of the adoption of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 20-51)  
Chapter 26 - UTILITIES[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference— Administration, ch. 2; electric utility board, § 2-1501 et seq.; gas utility board, § 2-1521 et seq.; waterworks utility board, § 2-1861 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 7; electrical code, § 7-211 et seq.; gas code, § 7-241 et seq.; mechanical code, § 7-261 et seq.; plumbing code, § 7-281 et seq.; businesses, ch. 8; cultural facilities and historical preservation, ch. 10; environmental management, ch. 12; stormwater management, § 12-331 et seq.; water wells, § 12-401 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 14; sewers, sewage disposal and other wastewater disposal, ch. 21; solid waste, ch. 22; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 23; accommodating utilities on highways, § 23-54; maintenance practices of City of Huntsville and of public utilities for weeds and overgrown grass, § 27-95; subdivision regulations, app. B; requirements for improvements and design of utilities in subdivisions, app. B, § 4.10.
