Editor's note— The rates and charges in this division are those in effect at the time of preparation of this Code. They are subject to change without council approval to the extent provided in section 26-453. 
 
Sec. 26-451. - Generally. 
Rates or charges for natural gas to consumers served by the gas distribution system of the city shall be as provided in this division. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-76, 4-13-2000)  
Sec. 26-452. - Allocations, prorations and penalties. 
(a)  Allocations, prorations. Whenever, for any reason, any or all of the suppliers of natural gas to the city curtails, decreases or impairs in any way whatsoever the supply of natural gas which the city secures for the consumers and customers of the city natural gas system or should the supply of natural gas not be available to serve all of the customers and consumers of the city natural gas system, then, in such event, the city shall have the right, for the purposes of allocating the supply to the consumers and customers of the city natural gas system to allocate and prorate the amount of natural gas which any or all of the consumers or customers receive for such periods of time as shall be required by the city. Notice of such allocations shall be given by announcements to media, newspapers and other means of communication. 
(b)  Penalty and curtailment . Should any customer, on any day or for any month, who has been placed on allocation or proration without the city's prior approval take or use a volume of natural gas in excess of the maximum daily or monthly quantity of natural gas which the city has allocated or prorated to any of its customers or consumers, then such volume in excess of such allocation or proration shall constitute unauthorized overrun volume, and for such overrun volume the customer or consumer who incurs such overrun shall pay unto the city any penalty assessed on the city by any pipeline or supplier for the overrun and a penalty of $1.00 for each mcf of natural gas constituting unauthorized overrun volume taken by the customer or consumer up to and including the volume of natural gas which is one percent in excess of the amount which has been allocated or prorated to the customer or consumer, and a penalty of $10.00 for each additional mcf of natural gas in excess of one percent over and above the amount allocated or prorated to the consumer or customer. The penalty shall be paid by the customer or consumer who incurred the unauthorized overrun together with and in addition to the demand and commodity charges payable by the customer or consumer for the month in which said overrun volume was taken. The payment of a penalty for unauthorized overrun shall not under any circumstances be considered giving such customer or consumer the right to take unauthorized overrun nor shall such payment be considered as a substitute for any other remedy available to the city against the offending customer or consumer for failure to respect its obligations to adhere to the provisions of this rate schedule. In addition to the penalties imposed or improvised in this subsection, whenever such unauthorized overrun has or might impair or jeopardize the supply of natural gas which the city has secured for its other customers and consumers, then the city shall have the right to discontinue the natural gas service to such customer or consumer who has incurred such unauthorized overrun. 
(c)  Applicability . The provisions of this section shall be applicable to all customers served by the city natural gas system, including but not being limited to those customers and consumers whose rates and charges are set forth in class 00, class 10, class 11, class 16, class 22, class 35, class 39, class 40 and class 41. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, §§ 17-77—17-79, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 01-970, § 17-92, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-453. - Deposit and rate adjustment. 
(a)  Deposit . A cash deposit or suitable guarantee, as approved, by the city gas utility board, not exceeding twice the highest bill may be required of any customer or person before gas or transportation service is supplied. The city electric utility board, the city gas utility board and the city waterworks utility board may enter into an agreement to establish a combined utility deposit; to establish a minimum deposit for all types of service, and to distribute the proceeds from these deposits. Interest may be accumulated on these deposits from October 1, 1973, at a rate as may from time to time be determined by the board and will be added to the deposit at the time service is terminated. The deposit, plus accumulated interest, may be applied against any unpaid bills of the customer and if any balance remains after such application is made, such balance shall be refunded to the customer. 
(b)  Gas rate adjustment. Recognizing that rates charged for natural gas are governed and determined by the cost of natural gas and other gas which is purchased by the city, the rates which are set forth in the rate schedules for charges for natural gas as set forth in sections 26-454—26-464 are to be increased and decreased daily on the basis of the cost of natural gas or other gas purchased by the city from its supplier. To the cost of gas purchased, the city shall add the cost of transportation, manufacturing gas, operational and distribution costs, and six percent of the total cost as charged to the customer. The adjusted rate shall be effective on the same date as such rate is made effective to the city by its supplier or suppliers of natural gas or such other gas as may or might be injected to the city natural gas system. 
(c)  Transportation rate adjustment. Recognizing that rates charged for transportation services are determined by the cost of agreements and contracts with pipeline suppliers, whereby capacity received by the city is to be paid for whether the contracted capacity is fully utilized and such fixed cost is to be factored into the cost of gas delivered to the customers of the city natural gas distribution system, and that the rates charged for natural gas are to be adjusted as set forth in subsection (b) of this section, all of which has been necessitated by the deregulation of natural gas which will cause the rates or charges for natural gas to fluctuate, it is therefore determined that adjustments to the industrial transportation rates and charges as set forth in sections 26-465—26-469 will be necessary and that all adjustments, changes or amendments from time to time as determined necessary will be made by the city gas utility board to assure that cost of transportation service and other costs charged to customers that utilize industrial transportation rate schedule will compensate the city natural gas system for all costs and expenses that it has and will be incurring in having gas pipeline capacity service being made available to the city natural gas system through which industrial transportation service can be made available to industrial customers as set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-89, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 01-970, § 17-93, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-454. - Commercial and industrial firm gas rate schedule, class 00. 
(a)  Availability . The schedule of rates in this section is available for gas service to all firm commercial or industrial customers contracting and using not less than 15,000 cubic feet and not more than 50,000 cubic feet of maximum daily demand served from the city's gas distribution system. Gas supplied under this rate schedule is for the exclusive use of the customer and will not be resold or shared with others. 
(b)  Applicability . The rate schedule in this section is applicable to firm commercial and industrial customers, including single-metered apartment houses and multiple unit housing projects, with maximum daily gas consumption not less than 15,000 cubic feet. (1,000 cubic feet = 1 mcf.) 
(c)  Rate . 
(1)  Demand charge . $11.64 per month for each 1,000 feet of maximum daily demand of gas delivered to the customer on any day during the 12-month period ending with the current billing month; plus 
(2)  Commodity charge . For all gas consumed each month at $7.53 per 1,000 cubic feet, per month. 
(d)  Availability charge . The availability charge is $12.00 per month. In addition, there will be a charge equal to the highest demand charge established during the 12-month period ending with the current billing month times the demand charge. The availability charge will apply during each month of the calendar year whether or not service is continuously used during such year. If the customer discontinues gas service during a portion of the year, the availability charge will apply each month whether service is active or inactive. In addition to the availability charge, the city may charge the customer for the cost of disconnecting and reconnecting the service. 
(e)  Payment . The rates in this section are net. If any bill is not paid on or before the date shown on the bill, there will be added to the bill an amount equal to five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(f)  Maximum daily demand. The maximum daily demand will be defined as the maximum 24-hour use of gas during the 12-month period ending with the close of the current month. The maximum daily demand will be determined at the option of the city according to one of the following methods: 
(1)  By estimate: 1/20 of the maximum monthly gas consumption during the 12-month period ending with the current month. 
(2)  By actual test. 
(3)  By demand meter. 
(g)  Single point delivery . Rates are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. A separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption, or at different pressures, will be separately metered and billed. 
(h)  Deposit required . The city may require a deposit prior to commencing service under this schedule equal to an amount not exceeding twice the highest bill. 
(i)  Rules and regulations . Service under this section will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(j)  Contract terms . The term of contract under this section will be by agreement of the parties, but in no event, less than one year. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-77, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-455. - Reserved.

Sec. 26-456. - Industrial interruptible rate schedule, class 10.

Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(f)  Maximum daily demand . The maximum daily demand will be defined as the maximum 24-hour use of gas during the 12-month period ending with the close of the current month. The maximum daily demand will be determined at the option of the city according to one of the following methods: 
(1)  By estimate: 1/20 of the maximum monthly gas consumption during the 12-month period ending with the current month. 
(2)  By actual test. 
(3)  By demand meter. 
(g)  Single point delivery . The rates in this section are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. A separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption, or at different pressures, will be separately metered and billed. 
(h)  Deposit required . The city may require a deposit prior to commencing service under this schedule equal to an amount not exceeding twice the highest bill. 
(i)  Rules and regulations . Service under this section will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(j)  Contract terms . The term of contracts under this section will be by agreement of the parties, but in no event less than one year. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-79, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)

Sec. 26-461. - Combination firm and interruptible gas service (Redstone Arsenal), class 15. 
(a)  Availability. The schedule of rates in this section is available for gas service to Redstone Arsenal, Alabama, as served from the city's gas distribution system. Gas supplied under this section is for the exclusive use of the customer. 
(b)  Applicability. This section is applicable to Redstone Arsenal only. 
(c)  Rate. 
(1)  Firm gas: 
a.  Demand charge: $10.80 per month, per mcf of demand; 
b.  Commodity charge: $3.89 per mcf delivered each month. 
The term "firm gas" is defined as being 1,000 mcf delivered, or the maximum quantity of gas delivered to the Army Missile Support Command, Redstone Arsenal, at the points of delivery as shown in the service specifications in any 24-hour period ending at 3:00 p.m. on a date which the city natural gas system has directed a curtailment of interruptible gas service, whichever quantity is the greater amount. 
(2)  Minimum annual charge: The sum of monthly demand charges plus a minimum annual commodity payment equal to 50 percent of the contracted demand multiplied by 365 times the applicable commodity charge per mcf. 
Interruptible gas: $3.32 per mcf delivered each month. 
The term "interruptible gas" is defined as the quantity of gas delivered daily in excess of firm gas. For example, on days of noncurtailment, all gas delivered in excess of 1,000 mcf firm gas will be supplied at the interruptible rate with no limit as to quantity, so long as such quantity is available from the city. 
(d)  Heat content adjustment. The rate in this section is based on natural gas having an average standard heating value of 1,000 BTU per cubic foot. If the average heating value of the gas supplied during any billing month should vary from this standard, the metered quantity of the gas supplied any consumer hereunder may be adjusted upward or downward proportionate to the increase or decrease in such average heating value. For the purpose of determining such average heating value, the city may rely on the accuracy of the reports furnished to it on such heating value by the city's supplier. 
(e)  Minimum monthly bill. The minimum monthly bill will be equal to the highest demand charge established during the 12-month period ending with the last day of the current month. Minimum monthly bills will apply during each month of the calendar year whether or not service is continuously used during such year. If a customer discontinues gas service during a portion of the year, the minimum monthly bill will apply each month whether service is active or inactive. 
(f)  Maximum daily demand. The maximum daily demand will be defined as the maximum 24-hour use of gas during the 12-month period ending with the close of the current month. The maximum daily demand will be determined by demand meters installed by the city at the point of delivery. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-84, 4-13-2000)  
Sec. 26-462. - Industrial firm and interruptible schedule, class 16. 
(a)  Availability . (a)  60 mcf/day at $7.54 per 1,000 cubic feet (mcf) of consumed gas per month. 
(2)  Remainder of daily consumption will be billed at the applicable industrial interruptible rate schedule according to class qualifications. 
(a)  >60 mcf/day at $6.88 per 1,000 cubic feet (mcf) of consumed gas per month (based on IGM-10 class qualifications). 
(b)  >60 mcf/day at $6.72 per 1,000 cubic feet (mcf) of consumed gas per month (based on IGM-11 class qualifications). 
(d)  Availability charge/minimum bill . The firm availability charge is $12.00 per month and the interruptible available charge is $30.00 per month. The availability charge/minimum bill will apply during each month of the calendar year whether or not service is continuously used during such year. (e)  Payment . The rates in this section are net. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(f)  Maximum daily demand . The maximum daily demand will be defined as the maximum 24-hour use of gas during the 12-month period ending with the close of the current month. The maximum daily demand will be determined at the option of the city according to one of the following methods: 
(1)  By estimate: 1/20 of the maximum monthly gas consumption during the 12-month period ending with the current month. 
(2)  By actual test. 
(3)  By demand meter. 
(4)  By agreement with customer according to amount of firm connected load as specified. 
(g)  Single point delivery . The rates in this section are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. A separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption, or at different pressures, will be separately metered and billed. 
(h)  Deposit required . The city may require a deposit prior to commencing service under this schedule equal to an amount not exceeding twice the highest bill. 
(i)  Rules and regulations. Service under this section will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(j)  Contract terms. The term of contracts under this section will be by agreement of the parties, but in no event, less than one year. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-85, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-463. - Residential rate schedule, class 22.

(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-86, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)

(h)  Rules and regulations. Service under this section is subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(i)  Contract terms. The term of contract under this section shall be by agreement of the parties, but in no event, less than one year. 
(Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-87, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Secs. 26-465, 26-466. - Reserved. 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 15-909 , adopted Dec. 17, 2015, repealed §§ 26-465, 26-466, which pertained to industrial transportation rate schedule, classes 37, 38, and derived from Ord. No. 00-315, § 17-89, 4-13-2000.  
Sec. 26-467. - Industrial transportation rate schedule, class 39. 
(a)  Availability . This transportation schedule is available to all industrial customers contracting to transport not less than 300,000 cubic feet and not more than 999,000 cubic feet per day of natural gas delivered to and as metered by the city gas system meter. Transportation service as supplied under this rate schedule is for the exclusive use of the customer, and this transportation service and any gas received through this transportation service will not be resold or shared with any other person or entity. Transportation service under this schedule may be interrupted for any cause as determined by the city. (1,000 cubic feet = 1 mcf.) The city will not be liable for damages resulting from any conditions, which cause transportation service to be interrupted. 
(b)  Applicability . The customer will be responsible for gas supply and transportation on all upstream pipeline for delivery of the customer's natural gas to the city gas system's city gate station, together with all associated cost. 
(c)  Firm transportation rate. A service charge of $530.00 per month, plus: 
Daily Transportation Volume (Mcf) 	Rate (Mcf) 
300—999 	$0.85 
 
(d)  Minimum bill. The minimum bill will be $3,000.00 for each month service is provided. 
(e)  Payment . The above rates are net. If any bill is not paid on or before the date shown on the bill, there will be added to the bill an amount equal to five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(f)  Single point delivery. The above rates are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. Separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption, or at different pressures, will be separately metered and billed. 
(g)  Deposit required. The city may require a deposit prior to commencing service under this schedule equal to an amount not exceeding twice the highest bill. 
(h)  Rules and regulations. Service under this schedule will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(i)  Contract terms. The term of contract under this schedule will be by agreement of the parties, and shall be on a month-to-month contract. 
(Ord. No. 01-970, § 17-90, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-468. - Industrial transportation rate schedule, class 40.

This transportation schedule is available to all industrial customers contracting to transport not less than 100,000 cubic feet and not more than 299,000 cubic feet per day of natural gas delivered to and as metered by the city gas system meter. Transportation service as supplied under this rate schedule is for the exclusive use of the customer, and this transportation service and any gas received through this transportation service will not be resold or shared with any other person or entity. Transportation service under this schedule may be interrupted for any cause as determined by the city. (1,000 cubic feet = 1 mcf.) The city will not be liable for damages resulting from any conditions, which cause transportation service to be interrupted. 
(b)  Applicability . The customer will be responsible for gas supply and transportation on all upstream pipeline for delivery of the customer's natural gas to the city gas system's city gate station, together with all associated cost. 
(c)  Firm transportation rate. A service charge of $530.00 per month, plus: 
Daily Transportation Volume (Mcf) 	Rate (Mcf) 
100—299 	$0.85 
 
(d)  Minimum bill. The minimum bill will be $1,500.00 for each month service is provided. 
(e)  Payment . The above rates are net. If any bill is not paid on or before the date shown on the bill, there will be added to the bill an amount equal to five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00. (f)  Single point delivery. The above rates are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. (h)  Rules and regulations. Service under this schedule will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city natural gas system. 
(i)  Contract terms. The term of contract under this schedule will be by agreement of the parties, and shall be on a month-to-month contract. 
(Ord. No. 01-970, § 17-91, 11-20-2001; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-469. - Fueling station transportation rate schedule, class 41. 
(a)  Availability . This transportation schedule is available to all customers contracting to transport not less than 15,000 cubic feet per day of natural gas as metered by the city's gas system that will be sold by the customer for use in fueling motor vehicles and other equipment and vehicles that utilize natural gas as a fuel. The natural gas under this schedule is to be used as and for a fueling station for motor vehicles and other equipment and vehicles that utilize natural gas as a fuel and shall not be used, resold, or shared with any other person or entity, except as set forth herein. Transportation service under this schedule may be interrupted for any cause as determined by the city. 1,000 cubic feet = 1 Mcf. The city will not be liable for damages resulting from any conditions, which cause transportation service to be interrupted. 
(b)  Applicability . The customer will be responsible for gas supply and transportation on all upstream pipelines for delivery of the customer's natural gas to the city gas system's city gate station, together with all associated costs. 
(c)  Transportation rate. A service charge of $200.00 dollars per month plus: 
Daily Transportation Volume (Mcf) 	Rate (Mcf) 
15 Mcf to 99 Mcf 	$1.80 
 
(d)  Payment . The above rates are net. If any bill is not paid on or before the date shown on the bill, there will be added to the bill an amount equal to five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(e)  Single point delivery. The above rates are based upon the supply of service to the customer's premises through a single delivery and metering point, and at a single pressure. A separate supply for the same customer at other points of consumption, or at different pressures, will be separately metered and billed. 
(f)  Deposit required. The city may require a deposit prior to commencing service under this schedule equal to an amount not exceeding twice the highest bill. 
(g)  Rules and regulations. Service under this schedule will be subject to the rules and regulations of the city's natural gas system. 
(h)  Contract terms. The term of the contract under this schedule will be by agreement of the parties. 
(i)  Transportation rate adjustment. Recognizing that rates charged for transportation services are determined by the cost of agreements and contracts with pipeline suppliers, whereby capacity received by the city is to be paid for whether the contract capacity is fully utilized and such fixed cost is to be factored into the cost of gas delivered to the customers of the city's natural gas distribution system, and that the rates charges for transportation service are to be adjusted which has been necessitated by pipeline contracts being revised which will cause the rates or charges for transportation service to fluctuate, it is therefore determined that adjustments to the transportation rates and charges as set forth in this section will be necessary and that all adjustment, changes, or amendments from time to time deemed necessary will be made by the city gas utility board to assure that cost of transportation services and other costs charged to customers that utilize transportation rate schedule will compensate the city's natural gas system for all costs and expenses that it has and will be incurring in having gas pipeline capacity service being made available to the city's natural gas system which transportation service can be made available to customers as set forth in this division. 
(Ord. No. 13-187, 3-28-2013; Ord. No. 15-909 , 12-17-2015)  
Secs. 26-470—26-500. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - WATER SERVICE[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference— Authority of city to establish, operate and maintain waterworks, Code of Ala. 1975, §§ 11-50-1, 11-50-5; contracts and indebtedness for construction, extension, etc., of waterworks system, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-47-3. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 26-501. - Consent of consumers to provisions of article. 
All persons who are consumers of city water shall be deemed to have consented to the provisions of this article and to all of the rights, powers and authority reserved to the city under the terms of this article. 
(Code 1982, § 23-1)  
Sec. 26-502. - Expenditures for construction or additions. 
No expenditures for any new construction, additions or replacements to the waterworks plant and waterworks system of the city, or equipment used by the plant or the system, shall be made by the waterworks utility board where the total expense will be more than $25,000.00 without the consent and approval of the city council. 
(Code 1982, § 23-49) 
State Law reference— Authority for above section, Code of Ala. 1975, § 11-50-442.  
Secs. 26-503—26-530. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - SERVICE RULES 
 
Sec. 26-531. - Cutting off water in cases of leakage or wastage. 
The city shall have the right, power and authority to cut off the water from any house, building or property when the underground service pipe or service line or any part leading from the water meter to the house, building or property shall become defective or out of repair so as to cause a leakage or wastage of water. 
(Code 1982, § 23-4)  
Sec. 26-532. - Opening and closing valves on pipes or mains. 
No person, except an employee of the waterworks, shall be permitted to open or close the valves upon the pipes or mains. 
(Code 1982, § 23-5)  
Sec. 26-533. - Consent of city for use of water. 
No person having charge or control of any hydrant or water pipe connected with the waterworks of the city shall allow or permit any other person to habitually take, draw or use any water from any such hydrant or water pipe as the other person's primary source of water without first obtaining the permission and consent of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-10)  
Sec. 26-534. - Application for service. 
Each prospective customer desiring water service may be required to sign the city's standard form of application for service or contract before service is supplied by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-11)  
Sec. 26-535. - City to maintain mains and service lines up to water meter. 
It shall not be the duty of the city to keep in repair any underground pipe, service pipe or service line except the main pipe, generally known as the city water main and the service pipe or service line from the city's water main to the water meter on the customer's premises; nor shall it be the duty of the city to furnish water to any customer whose water pipe is not in a fit condition to receive the water and prevent its waste. 
(Code 1982, § 23-12)  
Sec. 26-536. - Customers to maintain water pipes. 
When a customer owns or uses any water pipe and becomes a customer of water from the city, it shall be the duty of such customer, or the owner of the house, building or property, to keep all water pipes from the point where the customer's line is connected with the city's water meter in fit condition to receive water; and if such customer or owner of the house, building or property fails to do so, the city shall not be liable for cutting off the water upon such premises upon such failure of the customer or owner to keep such water pipe or line in fit condition. If the customer owns or uses any water pipe jointly with any other customer who may have separately contracted with the city to furnish water through such common line into the respective branches, the city shall have the right to cut off the water from such common line when the pipe of either or any of the service lines or any branch have been permitted to get out of repair or in condition unfit to receive water; and the city shall not be liable for so cutting off water because of the getting out of repair or unfitness of any common line, pipe, service or branch line. 
(Code 1982, § 23-13)  
Sec. 26-537. - Equipment and maintenance of water systems. 
Persons taking water from the water system must keep their own water pipes and all fixtures connected with the system in good repair and protected from frost. They must provide a stopcock and waste cock properly located, and have the pipes so arranged that the water can be drawn from them when there is danger of freezing. Water will not be furnished any premises not provided with a stopcock and waste cock. 
(Code 1982, § 23-14)  
Sec. 26-538. - Tanks, containers, reservoirs kept in sanitary condition. 
(a)  Any tank, container or reservoir not owned, controlled and operated by the city located within the city which is being used or maintained or which in the future may be used or maintained by any person for the storage of city water obtained from any of the city water pipe lines, from which tank, container or reservoir consumers of city water receive or obtain a supply of city water, shall at all times be kept in a sanitary condition, free from and protected from contamination, subject to the examination and approval of the health officer. 
(b)  Any person who owns or has control of any such tank, container or reservoir and who fails or neglects to maintain it in a sanitary condition free from and protected from contamination shall be guilty of a misdemeanor each day such container, tank or reservoir is permitted to remain in an unsanitary condition, and not free from and protected from contamination. 
(c)  Whenever it may be found that any such tank, container or reservoir is in an unsanitary condition and not free from and protected from contamination, the city shall have the right to cut off all consumers obtaining water from such supply without liability to the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-15)  
Sec. 26-539. - Backflow prevention. 
(a)  Responsibility . The city water system shall be responsible for the protection of the public potable water distribution system from contamination or pollutants due to the backflow or back siphnonage of contaminants or pollutants through the water service connection. The customer has the primary responsibility of preventing pollutants and contaminants from entering their potable water system or the public water system through the elimination or protection of all cross-connections on their premises. The customer's responsibility starts at the service connections to the public potable water system and includes all of their water system. 
(b)  Backflow preventer required . When any customer or consumer of the city water system is engaged in any type of activity or business, the nature of which may or might result in backflow or backsiphonage which could or might result in pollution or contamination of any portion of the city water system, the city water system shall require such customer or consumer to install, at the expense of the customer or consumer, a backflow preventer of such nature and design, as determined by the city water system to be installed in such places and manner as shall be required by the city water system. 
(c)  Inspection and notice . The city water system shall conduct a survey or inspection of the premises of a customer or consumer to determine whether such customer or consumer is engaged in such activity or business as shall require the installation of a backflow preventer and if the city water system determines that such backflow preventer is necessary to prevent possible pollution or contamination of any portion of the city water system, such customer or consumer shall be given written notice by the city water system that such backflow preventer is necessary, together with the type to be installed and the manner and method to install the preventer. Any customer who cannot or will not allow city water system personnel on the premises for an inspection of the customer's water and piping shall be required to install the backflow prevention assembly that will provide the maximum protection to the public potable water supply system. Refusal by a customer to allow an inspection or refusal to install the required backflow prevention assembly shall be a reason to discontinue service for noncompliance. 
(d)  Installation of backflow preventer . The customer or consumer, within a time frame prescribed by the city water system which shall not exceed 90 days, after receipt of the written notice as set forth in subsection (c) of this section, at the expense of the customer or consumer, shall install the backflow preventer as specified by the city water system in the manner and method as set forth by the city water system. 
(e)  Failure to install backflow preventer . If the customer or consumer fails or refuses to install a backflow preventer as specified in the manner and method as set forth by the city water system, or fails or refuses to install the specified backflow preventer in a manner and method as set forth by the city water system, within 90 days from the receipt of the written notice from the city water system to the customer or consumer, which written notice is set forth in subsection (c) of this section, the city water system shall terminate the water supply to such customer or consumer until such time as the specified backflow preventer is installed in the manner and method as required by the city water system. For justifiable cause shown, the city water system may grant written extensions of time to install the specified backflow preventer for such periods of time as shall be reasonable. 
(f)  Discontinuance of service . The city water system may deny or discontinue water service to any customer if a required backflow prevention device is not installed, tested or properly maintained, or if a cross-connection exists on the premises and there is inadequate backflow protection at the service connection. Water service shall not be restored to such premises until the deficiencies have been corrected or eliminated. 
(g)  Unauthorized consumption . Any person or persons who fails to install backflow preventer within the time required by the city water system and takes or causes to be taken any water from the city water system or carries away or causes to be carried away water for any purpose or use whatsoever without first obtaining the consent and permission of the city water system shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, §§ 23-17—23-20; Ord. No. 15-7 , 1-22-2015)  
Sec. 26-540. - Right of entry; refusing entry. 
Where a service line is located on private property and is connected with the city's water system for service, the city shall, at all times, have the right and authority to go upon and enter such premises for the purpose of cutting off the water, reading, repairing, inspecting or testing its water meter or service line or making any repairs the city deems necessary. When any property owner or tenant refuses to allow the city or any of its properly authorized agents, servants, officers or employees to enter the premises for any one of the purposes set out in this section, the city shall have the right and authority to cut off the water from such premises at any other convenient place; and water service shall not be reinstated until the property owner or tenant shall authorize such service line and water meter to be repaired and placed ready for service. The city shall not be liable for cutting off the water on such premises. 
(Code 1982, § 23-21)  
Sec. 26-541. - Cutting off water from mains for repairs or extensions. 
The city expressly reserves the right to cut off the water without notice from any or all of its water mains for the purpose of making repairs or extensions. 
(Code 1982, § 23-22)  
Sec. 26-542. - Discontinuing service to consumers using common line where one branch out of repair. 
If one of several branches from a common line through which water is distributed individually and separately to the several consumers from the common line should get out of condition and leak or waste water, although such branch belongs individually to the consumer or owner of the house, building or property, the city shall have the right to cut the water off to the entire common line as mentioned in section 26-536 and thereby deprive other consumers on such common line of water, though their individual branches are in repair, if such cutting off the water is necessary and without fault of the city, to avoid the creation or maintenance of a nuisance to property owners not connected with or interested in the common line, or to any other person or property. 
(Code 1982, § 23-23)  
Secs. 26-543—26-560. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 26-561. - Made by city employees. 
It shall be unlawful for any person other than the employees of the city waterworks system or its agents to make a connection with or to tap a water main of the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-66)  
Sec. 26-562. - Permit required; applications; deposit. 
All persons desiring to connect with the city water system shall file a written application with the waterworks utility board, which application shall show the point at which the city is requested to furnish water service. At the time the application is filed, the applicant shall pay to the waterworks utility board a sum designated by such board as the reasonable cost to the city of connecting such customer to the city's water system. 
(Code 1982, § 23-67)  
Secs. 26-563—26-580. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - DEPOSITS 
 
Sec. 26-581. - Generally. 
A cash deposit or suitable guarantee, as approved by the waterworks utility board, not exceeding twice the highest bill, may be required of any customer or person before water service is supplied. The waterworks utility board may enter into an agreement with the electric utility board and the gas utility board to establish a combined utility deposit; to establish a minimum deposit for all types of service and to distribute the proceeds from these deposits. Interest may be accumulated on these deposits from October 1, 1973, at a rate as may from time to time be determined by the boards and will be added to the deposit at the time service is terminated. The deposit, plus accumulated interest, may be applied against any unpaid bills of the customer; and if any balance remains after such application is made, such balance shall be refunded to the customer. 
(Code 1982, § 23-81; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-582. - Unlawful to use water until deposit made. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to use water supplied by the city without first having made with the city the deposit required in section 26-581. 
(Code 1982, § 23-82)  
Sec. 26-583. - Water not turned on until deposit made. 
No employee of the city shall turn on the water for service at any place until the deposit required in section 26-581 for such place has been made with the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-83)  
Secs. 26-584—26-600. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - METERS 
 
Sec. 26-601. - Duty of city to supply meters. 
It shall be the duty of the city to install a uniform type of water meter for all consumers of city water, at the expense of the city; and where any consumer has already installed another and different type of meter from that designated by the city, the city shall have the right to replace the meter in use or installed by the consumer by one of the uniform type designated or to be designated by the city; however, in the installation of any meter by the city as provided in this division the expense for the installation of such meter shall only extend to the purchase price of the meter, the retaining box, necessary fixtures to attach the pipe and their installation and shall not extend to the purchase and installation of the necessary pipes required by this article to be furnished by the consumer and installed by the consumer. 
(Code 1982, § 23-96)  
Sec. 26-602. - Responsibility of waterworks utility board. 
The waterworks utility board shall see that water meters of a uniform type are installed throughout the city on the connections of all water consumers for the purpose of regulating and measuring the amount of water that may be used by all consumers from the city waterworks. 
(Code 1982, § 23-97)  
Sec. 26-603. - Approval; stopcocks required between meters and mains. 
All meters shall be of a kind approved by the waterworks utility board and must be placed to the satisfaction of the waterworks utility board. Between each meter and the main a stopcock shall be placed within one foot of the meter. No meter shall be set within four feet of any sink or privy. 
(Code 1982, § 23-98)  
Sec. 26-604. - Use of water by unauthorized person. 
If any person shall permit another, not a guest, employee or boarder in his home or place of business, to use water through his meter, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Code 1982, § 23-99)  
Sec. 26-605. - Meters on private property. 
Where the water meter is located on private property and is connected with the water system for service, the city shall at all times have the right and authority, by and through its agent, servant, officer or employee to go upon and enter such premises for the purpose of reading the water meter, or to cut on or cut off the water, or make any such necessary repairs to the water meter as it deems necessary. Where any property owner or tenant refuses to allow the city or its properly authorized agent, officer or employee to enter such premises for the purpose set out in this section, the city shall have the right and authority to cut off the water from such premises at any other convenient place; and the services shall not be reinstated until the property owner or tenant shall have caused such water meter to be removed and placed ready for service, at whatever place the city shall designate. The city shall not be liable for cutting off the water upon such premises. 
(Code 1982, § 23-100)  
Sec. 26-606. - Record of meters installed, reading of meters. 
The city shall ascertain and keep a record of all water meters and shall read such meters and ascertain or cause such meters to be read and ascertained as soon as practical after the first day of each month the amount of water consumed by each and every customer, during the next preceding 30 days. 
(Code 1982, § 23-101)  
Sec. 26-607. - Fire protection and fire service lines and systems. 
(a)  Establishment. Fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems may be established on private property by its owner at his own cost for pipe, valves, fittings and connections to water mains, etc. The work shall be done under the supervision of the water or fire department and the maintenance of such mains, valves and hydrants shall be at the cost and expense of the owner of the property. The regular, established rate for such connection for such fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems shall be paid and, if not, it shall be disconnected. 
(b)  Connection to water system. Any person establishing fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems shall have the right to have them connected to the city's water system provided the owner pays to the water department, prior to installation and connection, the cost of the meter to be installed and prescribed and specified by the city water department. All work necessary for connection of such system and meters to the city water system shall be performed and done by the water department. No water is to be used from the fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems at any point on the line, except in case of fire; nor are any fixtures whatsoever to be connected with such fire line. 
(c)  Charges. The owner of all fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems installed and connected to the city water system shall pay unto the city a monthly charge based on the current water rate schedule. 
(d)  Restrictions on unmetered systems. The owner of all existing unmetered fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks and fire prevention systems located within the city and without the city, and connected to the city water system, shall keep and maintain such systems in such a manner as not to cause or allow leakage or waste of water; and if the owner of the system allows the fire hydrants, fire sprinkler systems, hose racks or fire prevention systems to consume or use water for any other cause or reason other than fire, the superintendent of the water department shall have the right and authority to disconnect the service and, prior to restoring or reconnecting such service, may cause or require the owner to comply with the provisions of sections 26-607(b) and 26-607(c), and, after restoring or reconnecting the service with a meter, to be subject to the payment of the charges as set forth in section 26-607(c). 
(e)  No guarantee by city. The city guarantees no certain water pressure and shall in no case be in any way liable or responsible to any persons whatsoever in case of fire, for any damage that may result from any alleged insufficiency of such fire protection, either from want of pressure or volume, accessibility or for any other cause. 
(Code 1982, §§ 23-102—23-104, 23-106, 23-107; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015) 
Cross reference— Fire prevention and protection, ch. 13.  
Sec. 26-608. - Tests. 
The city shall, at its own expense, make periodic tests and inspections of its water meters in order to maintain a high standard of accuracy. The city shall make additional tests or inspections of its meter at the request of any customer. If such tests show that the meter is accurate based on industry standards, no adjustment will be made in the customer's bill; and a charge may be established and collected to cover costs incurred. The charge for such services shall be determined by the waterworks utility board of the city. An adjustment shall be made to the customer's bill over a period of not more than 30 days prior to the date of any test demonstrating that the meter was inaccurate based on industry standards; and the cost of making such test shall be borne by the city. 
(Code 1982, § 23-108; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015)  
Secs. 26-609—26-630. - Reserved.

(4)  In business houses or buildings where one or more persons or entities are located therein and each person or entity is engaged in a separate business or different business; or 
(5)  Mobile home parks or facilities where multiple units or spaces each have a water connection, then each separate house, building, or structure, each unit in an apartment house or building, each family in one house, each person or entity engaged in a separate business or different business in one business house or building, each space or unit in a mobile home park or facility shall be subject to the availability charge per month of $6.34 effective January 2013, $7.84 effective October 2013, $9.34 effective October 2014, $10.84 effective October 2015 and $12.34 effective October 2016 in addition to any water consumed. If there is no consumption, the availability charge as set forth in paragraph (b) will apply. 
(d)  Provided further, that for residences, apartments, mobile home parks, and commercial establishments serving six or more families, apartment units, separate or different businesses through a common master meter, the charge shall be $1.64 per 1,000 gallons effective January 2013, $1.66 per 1,000 gallons effective October 2013, $1.68 per 1,000 gallons effective October 2014, $1.69 per 1,000 gallons effective October 2015, and $1.71 per 1,000 gallons effective October 2016. In addition to the above, there will be an availability charge per month of $6.34 effective January 2013, $7.84 effective October 2013, $9.34 effective October 2014, $10.84 effective October 2015, and $12.34 effective October 2016, per unit. 
(e)  The City of Huntsville shall pay a monthly maintenance charge of $7.24 effective January 2013, $7.31 effective October 2013, $7.39 effective October 2014, $7.46 effective October 2015, and $7.53 effective October 2016, for each fire hydrant in the water system.

(Code 1982, § 23-121; Ord. No. 90-617, 11-20-1990; Ord. No. 95-306, 5-11-1995; Ord. No. 99-314, 4-8-1999; Ord. No. 00-313, § 23-121, 4-13-2000; Ord. No. 02-842, § 23-121, 10-10-2002; Ord. No. 05-550, 8-11-2005; Ord. No. 07-1125, 11-20-2007; Ord. No. 12-1019, 12-20-2012)  
Sec. 26-632. - Leaks, waste. 
If any leak or waste is found to have occurred at any water meter box, due to defective plumbing by the city, a water bill or charge for the current month shall be rendered to the consumer equal to the average bill or charge for the past three preceding months. If any leak or waste is found on private property underground where such leak or waste is not plainly visible, a bill or charge for the then current month shall be rendered to the customer at such place or the owner of the property, equal to the average bill for the past three preceding months, and there shall be added to the average bill, based on the past three preceding months' consumption, a charge at the then current residential-inside city limits-first 3,000 gallons rate schedule as set forth in Ordinance No. 12-1019 adopted on December 20, 2012 used over and above the averaged amount for the past three preceding months; provided, further however, that if such leak or waste shall occur in any water fixture or if it shall be otherwise visible or audible or known to the consumer, a bill or charge for the full amount of water used as shown by the meter reading shall be rendered against such customer and no allowance or credit thereon shall be made. The rates and charges as set forth in this amendment shall become effective on date of adoption of this ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 13-249, 4-25-2013) 
Editor's note— Ord. No. 13-249, adopted Apr. 25, 2013, repealed former § 26-632, and enacted a new section as set out herein. The former section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1982, § 23-122; Ord. No. 84-713, 11-20-1984; Ord. No. 95-305, 5-11-1995.  
Sec. 26-633. - When meters fail to register. 
When any water meter fails to register, an average shall be obtained from the readings taken from such meter from the preceding three months during which the meter was known to be operating correctly; and these readings shall be used as a basis of payment for water consumed through such meter for the period in which the meter is out of order and until repaired or replaced. 
(Code 1982, § 23-123)  
Secs. 26-634—26-640. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Billing and Collection Procedures 
 
Sec. 26-641. - When consumers billed. 
The city shall, as soon as practical after the meter is read, cause to be either mailed or electronically delivered to the customer a statement of water consumption furnished by the city or to the owner of the house, building or property where such water service is furnished. Such statement shall show the quantity of water consumed by the consumer for the preceding 30 days and the amount due. In the case of the first billing of new accounts and final billings of all accounts where the period covered involves fractions of a month, the availability charges shall be adjusted to a basis proportionate with the period of time during which service was furnished. Any consumer requiring service for a period not exceeding 30 days shall be required to pay the availability charge for one month, together with the rate for the water consumed. 
(Code 1982, § 23-136; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-642. - Failure to receive bill. 
Failure to receive a statement or water bill shall not entitle any person to the net rates, nor shall it prevent the city from discontinuing service or cutting off the water in accordance with section 26-645. 
(Code 1982, § 23-137)  
Sec. 26-643. - Dishonored checks. 
When any check or order is delivered to the city in payment of any water account or water bill and is accepted and such check, or order, upon due presentation to the bank or trust company upon which it is drawn is not paid, the city shall charge the amount of such check or order back to the water bill or water account of such person. Such water bill or water account shall be considered a delinquent account, and the city shall be authorized to discontinue service in accordance with section 26-645, the same as if the check or order had not been given. 
(Code 1982, § 23-138)  
Sec. 26-644. - Penalties. 
A penalty of five percent on the first $250.00 of the bill plus one percent on any portion of the bill exceeding $250.00 shall be charged on all water bills based upon the rates set out in section 26-631 if such bill is not paid in full on or before the date shown on such bill. Payments that are due on a weekend or holiday will be due the next business day. 
(Code 1982, § 23-139; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-645. - When service discontinued for failure to pay bill; reconnection charge. 
If any consumer or owner of the house, building or property shall refuse or neglect to pay his water bill or charge on or before the penalty date as shown on the statement the water may be turned off and shall not be turned on again until the bill or charge shall be paid in full, plus a reasonable charge for turning on and off the water. 
(Code 1982, § 23-140)  
Sec. 26-646. - Collection of connection and disconnection charges. 
A fee for connection, reconnection and disconnection for water services, and a charge to process returned checks which may or might be dishonored, may be established and collected to cover costs incurred for connecting, reconnecting service or disconnecting service. Such charges for such services shall be those charges which shall be made and determined by the waterworks utility board. 
(Code 1982, § 23-141)  
Sec. 26-647. - Service not restored while delinquent consumer resides on premises. 
No member of the consumer's family or anyone else living in the same house or building or on such property with the consumer where the water is cut off shall have the right to make or offer to make a deposit for water, or to demand that the city turn on the water at such place, so long as a delinquent lives there, and the water bill or charges, plus a reasonable charge as required in section 26-645, is unpaid. Further, delinquent charges owed by any member of the consumer's family living in the same house or delinquent charges of anyone else living in the same house will be charged back to the current active account to the same extent as if those charges were owed by the person who made the application for the account. 
(Code 1982, § 23-142; Ord. No. 85-53, 1-24-1985)  
Secs. 26-648—26-670. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - WATER CONSERVATION PLAN 
 
Sec. 26-671. - Established. 
There is established a city water conservation plan. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 1, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-672. - Declaration of policy. 
It is declared that, because of water conditions prevailing and which may prevail in the city, the general welfare requires that the water resources available to the city be put to the maximum beneficial use to the extent to which they are capable, and that the waste or unreasonable use or unreasonable methods of use of water be prevented, and the conservation of such water is to be extended with a view to the reasonable and beneficial use of water in the interests of the people of the city and for the public health and welfare. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 2, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-673. - Authorization. 
The general manager of the city's utilities, or his designate, is authorized and directed to implement the applicable provisions of this division under his determination that such implementation is necessary to protect the public health and welfare and safety. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 3, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-674. - Application. 
The provisions of this division shall apply to all persons, customers and property utilizing City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities water wherever situated. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 4, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-675. - Water conservation stages. 
(a)  No customer of or person who uses water from the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities shall knowingly make, cause, use or permit the use of water received from the city for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, governmental or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provision of this division, or in an amount in excess of that use permitted by the conservation stage in effect pursuant to action taken by the general manager of Huntsville Utilities, or his designate, in accordance with the provisions of this division. 
(b)  The general manager of Huntsville Utilities, or his designate, shall promulgate guidelines which shall set forth the criteria for determining when a particular conservation stage is to be implemented and terminated. Such guidelines shall be updated when, in the opinion of the general manager of Huntsville Utilities, or his designate, the conditions of the utility system have changed so as to necessitate such update. 
(1)  Stage I, voluntary conservation. Customers of or persons who use the water utility of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities are requested to voluntarily limit the amount of water to the amount absolutely necessary for health, business and outdoor use. 
(2)  Stage II, mandatory compliance, water alert. Upon implementation by the general manager of Huntsville Utilities, or his designate, and publication of notice, the following restrictions shall apply to all customers of or persons who use the water utility of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities: Irrigation utilizing individual sprinklers from hoses, or buried sprinkler systems for the purpose of watering lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs and other plants is prohibited except on designated water use days, which shall be as follows: Odd-numbered street addresses will water on odd days of the month, and even-numbered street addresses will water on even days of the month. This restriction shall not apply to commercial nurseries; however, commercial nurseries should restrict water use to that which is absolutely necessary. There is further exempt from the restriction any hand-held garden hose or small hand-held watering container which may be used on any day to water small areas that might need more frequent watering. 
(3)  Stage III, mandatory compliance, water warning. Upon implementation by the general manager of Huntsville Utilities or his designate and publication of notice, the following restrictions shall apply to all customers of or persons who use the water utility of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities: Irrigation utilizing individual sprinklers from hoses, or buried sprinkler systems for the purpose of watering lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs and other plants is prohibited except on designated water use days, which shall be as follows: Users of water at street addresses containing odd numbers will water on either Saturday or Sunday and Wednesday or Thursday when such date is on an odd calendar month number, and users of water at street addresses containing even numbers will water on either Saturday or Sunday and Wednesday or Thursday when such date is on an even calendar month number, it being the intent to have four designated outdoor watering days per week and to allow each user of water to water two times each week. During Stage III, mandatory compliance, water warning, the following additional restrictions shall apply: 
a.  On the Saturday/Sunday and Wednesday/Thursday watering days, no watering may be done between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. Hand-held garden hoses or small hand-held watering containers may be used on any day except during the hours of 6:00 p.m. to 9:00 p.m. 
b.  Washing of private vehicles is prohibited except on the Saturday/Sunday and Wednesday/Thursday odd/even basis. No private vehicles may be washed between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. Commercial car washes and service stations are exempt from this restriction. 
c.  Swimming pools will be filled only on the Saturday/Sunday and Wednesday/Thursday odd/even basis. There shall be no filling between the hours of 6:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
d.  Washing of sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other paved areas is absolutely prohibited except by the department of public works services and the fire department to alleviate health or fire hazard. 
e.  Placing sprinklers which spray a significant amount of water in the street is prohibited. 
f.  Taking water from a fire hydrant is prohibited unless the person taking the water from the fire hydrant has a permit from the water department for an expressed purpose and date that hydrant may be used, signed by an authorized utility representative. Utility crews, public works services department and fire department are exempt from this condition in order to properly maintain the water system and provide for public health and safety. 
The Saturday/Sunday and Wednesday/Thursday restriction does not apply to commercial nurseries. However, commercial nurseries should restrict water use to what is absolutely necessary. 
(4)  Stage IV, mandatory compliance, water emergency. Upon implementation by the general manager or his designate and publication of notice, the following restriction shall apply to all customers of or persons who use the water utility of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities: During stage IV, mandatory compliance, water emergency, no outside irrigation utilizing individual sprinklers from hoses or buried sprinkler systems for the purpose of watering lawns, gardens, landscaped areas, trees, shrubs and other plants is permitted. Also prohibited are the following: 
a.  The washing of private vehicles is prohibited except at commercial car washes or service stations. 
b.  The use of water from fire hydrants for any reason other than use by utility crews, department of public works, and the fire department to maintain the water system and quality is prohibited. 
c.  Stage IV, water emergency temporarily voids any standing fire hydrant use permits until the emergency has passed. 
d.  Washing of sidewalks, streets, driveways, parking areas, tennis courts, patios or other paved areas is absolutely prohibited except by the public works services department and the fire department to alleviate health or fire hazard. 
e.  The filling of swimming pools is prohibited during the water emergency. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 5, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-676. - Compliance; golf courses and tennis courts. 
(a)  Any golf course, either public or private, that uses City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities water for watering greens and fairways must comply with the watering restrictions imposed by a water alert (stage II) or water warning (stage III). During a water emergency (stage IV), no water from the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities may be used for watering the fairways. 
(b)  Tennis courts (public or private) utilizing rubico surfaces are exempt from the restrictions of stage II and stage III and may be exempt from restrictions during a water emergency if conditions allow. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 6, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-677. - Mandatory conservation stage implementation. 
The water department of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities shall monitor its pumping capacity and demand for water by its customers on a daily basis during periods of hot and dry weather and shall determine the extent of conservation required through the implementation or termination of particular conservation stages in order for the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities Water Department to continue to supply adequate water to its customers. Thereafter, the general manager of Huntsville Utilities or his designate, may order the appropriate stage of water conservation be implemented or terminated in accordance with the applicable provisions of this division. This order shall be made by public announcement on the utility website and/or through social media. The order shall become effective immediately upon such publication and shall continue until such time as all restrictions are removed. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 7, 8-13-1987; Ord. No. 15-912 , 12-17-2015)  
Sec. 26-678. - Area implementation. 
Due to the varied elevations, service areas with varied pumping and storage capacities, certain areas of the city that utilize the city water system may be designated to be in different stages of conservation at various times; and it shall be lawful to designate certain areas of the city to be in a certain stage of conservation. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 8, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-679. - Presumption. 
For the purpose of this division, it shall be presumed that a person in whose name the water utility of the City of Huntsville dba Huntsville Utilities is or was last billed or who is receiving the economic benefit of the water supply has knowingly made, caused, used or permitted the use of water received from the city for residential, commercial, industrial, agricultural, governmental or any other purpose in a manner contrary to any provisions of this division, or in an amount in excess of the use permitted by the conservation stage in effect, if the water has been used in a manner contrary to any provision of this division, or in an amount in excess of the use permitted by the conservation in effect. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 9, 8-13-1987)  
Sec. 26-680. - Penalty. 
Any person violating any provision of this division shall be deemed guilty of an offense and upon conviction shall be punished as and for a violation of a misdemeanor. The violation of each provision and each separate violation shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be punished accordingly. Compliance may be further sought through injunctive relief. 
(Ord. No. 87-326, § 10, 8-13-1987)
